HEADLINE: Campaign English From Senator Dole

 BODY:
Senator Bob Dole's declaration that English should be made "the official language of the United States" was couched in purest patriotism -- to bind the nation together. But, as a contender for the Presidency, he surely knows this issue is divisive. It reeks of xenophobia and is particularly popular among the conservatives he seems too eager to please.
America is and must remain an English-speaking country. The ability of all Americans to communicate without translation is woven into the fabric of our open society. Foreigners who come here know that learning the language is in their own self-interest. Economic opportunity, employment and advancement depend on it -- even following "E.R." on TV. 
 But requiring it by law is a sign that the society is not so open after all, that people who speak foreign languages are not welcome.
Addressing the American Legion convention in Indianapolis last week, Mr. Dole did not indicate how he would proceed, except to say that "alternative language education should stop." Insisting on fluency in English "is a welcoming act of inclusion," he said, "and insist we must." Most of the pending official-English bills in Congress would require that all government business be conducted in English, except where health and safety are involved. Some ban bilingual education and multilingual ballots.
Nebraska started the official-English movement in 1920 with an amendment aimed at German immigrants. More than 20 states have now adopted official English in some form, mostly during the last 15 years and because of concern over the influx of Hispanic and Asian immigrants. President Clinton signed the Arkansas official-English law as Governor in 1987. But George Bush, campaigning for President in 1988, opposed the official-English campaign then under way in Florida.
America is a land of immigrants. The overwhelming majority have proceeded to learn English if they did not already know it. But it offends the nation's freedoms to tell them they must.

HEADLINE: U.S. OPEN '95;
Graf Shakes Seles Awake From a Glorious Dream

BYLINE: By ROBIN FINN 

 BODY:
She rose like a phoenix this summer after spending 28 months in limbo as she recovered from the emotional and physical trauma of being stabbed on the tennis court by a deranged German man who felt the No. 1 ranking should belong to Steffi Graf instead of her.
It took Monica Seles two years to return to the sport she knew she loved and for a time thought she had lost. And when she came back, she did it with such a vengeance that it seemed it was the rest of the competition and not her who had been idling in involuntary exile. 
 But the first chapter of the magnificent and, through 11 matches, invincible comeback by the 21-year-old Seles reached a tearful end yesterday when the United States Open championship was claimed by Graf, the rival to whom she is bound by the strangest and saddest of ties.
In a wildly uneven final-round match that pitted Seles against the very woman on whose behalf she was knifed in the back on April 30, 1993, Graf prevailed, 7-6 (8-6), 0-6, 6-3, and captured her third Grand Slam crown of 1995 and her 18th Grand Slam singles title over all. It marked the first time that a woman finalist was able to win the Open despite losing a set at love.
The two rivals embraced at the net after Graf, an Open champion for the fourth time and undefeated in seven finals this year, proved conclusively that she is the No. 1 player in the world for 1995. The 26-year-old German leads her career rivalry with Seles by 7-4 but had been defeated by the new United States citizen in three of their four previous Slam finals.
"It's been a dream; it seems unreal; I think I've won every Grand Slam now four times, so that's pretty amazing," said Graf, who received a beer shower from her fellow players when she got back to the locker room.
Graf, who has lost only 1 of her 40 matches this year, said she hadn't expected to survive this final. "I didn't think I had the tools for it," she said. "Monica's been playing so well since she came back, which impressed everybody, especially me."
But yesterday it was Graf who impressed Seles.
"I think Steffi played great," said Seles, who admitted her own iron concentration had more than once been frayed by controversial line calls like the one that cost her the first set's tie breaker.
"She was running down balls that very few people even go for, and she played
better on the key points."
Graf, beset by yet another personal trauma not of her own making due to the August arrest and imprisonment of her father, Peter, on charges of tax evasion, called this Slam "the most difficult ordeal" through which she had ever had to persevere. Graf left Germany the day her father was arrested and has been unable to speak to him since then. Peter Graf faces a jail sentence of up to 10 years; Graf, who has not yet been cleared in the investigation, could be liable for tax penalties estimated at $80 million if he's convicted.
"There's been a lot of obstacles to climb over," said Graf, whose health, because of a suddenly sore left foot and a chronically sore bone spur in her back, has been as troublesome as her family melodrama.
Seles also called this Open a personal success story.
"Wow," said Seles, using her favorite word of the moment. "I made the right decision; I'm doing what I love to do, playing tennis, and my life is moving forward again."
The 1-hour-52-minute final ended the 20-match unbeaten streak compiled by Seles at the Open, where she was the champion in 1991 and 1992. It also ended the 11-match comeback streak she compiled until Graf's powerful performance provoked her into more errors, 42, than she could rectify with her 38 winners and 3 breaks of Graf's serve.
In the third set, it was Graf who picked up her serving tempo and, with her aim and her mental toughness just a notch superior to Seles's, secured the pivotal break in the fourth game.
"I knew I had to play great tennis," Seles said. "I think I did play good tennis."
This was Seles's first Slam campaign since she captured her third consecutive Australian Open title at Graf's expense in January 1993.
That Slam was to be her last until this one because of the intervention of Gunther Parche, the unemployed lathe operator who stabbed her in broad daylight, and in mid-match, and then had a suspended sentence twice upheld by the same German court system that incarcerated Peter Graf.
Although she appeared oblivious to the distraction, Seles performed under heavy guard; each time she went to her changeover chair, she sat with her back to a wall, Wild Bill Hickock-style, though in Seles's case, the wall was a broad-backed security man. Aisle-wide guards also stationed themselves on the stairwells leading to the changeover area, a danger zone instead of a resting place for Seles.
"Sitting in the chair is the worst part," she said of her comeback performances, "because I used to feel safe there and now, in the back of my mind, I can't. Not yet, anyway."
The first set was so inconclusive it required a tie breaker that was decided in a controversial manner that ignited Seles to a fever pitch. Assuming she had served an ace down the middle at set point, Seles was already loping to the sideline when she was shooed back to the service line to deliver a second serve. Graf won the point with a forehand return to the corner, then converted the tie breaker after Seles blasted consecutive forehands out of bounds.
Aggravated by the way she surrendered the first set, which had been the one that determined the victor in 9 of their previous 10 matches, Seles took a can't-miss attitude into the next.
"It made me mad," she said.
The second set was a one-sided story: Seles simply poured on the power and outhit Graf by drilling the ball at every white line eligible to receive punishment. Graf later attributed her lapse to a fleeting case of nerves.
But the tables turned yet again in the final set, when Graf somehow conjured up the same courage, and booming serves, she had used to advantage in the first. After saving one match point with a vicious backhand crosscourt return, Seles buried a forehand in the net on Graf's second set point and immediately trotted to the net to congratulate Graf.
In the opening set, Graf's only opportunity to break Seles came in the seventh game, when Seles compromised herself with a series of nervous errors. But pushed five times to the breaking point, Seles steeled herself and saved them all.
As is their nature, neither one of the champions ventured often toward the net: overpowering each other from the baseline has long been the pattern in their rivalry, and it continued to be the case yesterday.
"We both hit the ball hard, and whenever we play in the future, and we will, I'm sure it's always going to be strong tennis," Seles said.
 
 
MATCH POINTS
 The WTA Tour, without a sponsor since an acrimonious and premature dissolution of its five-year contract with Kraft two years ago, has received an IMG-solicited sponsorship offer from Corel Corporation, an Ottawa-based software and graphics marketer. The multiyear, multimillion dollar proposal includes the stipulation that the tour be renamed the Corel WTA Tour; the proposal has not yet been accepted by the WTA Tour.

HEADLINE: MARKET TIMING

 BODY:

Monday
 
The National Association of Manufacturers begins its three-day annual meeting in San Francisco. Robert Parry, the president of the Federal Reserve, is scheduled to speak.
 
Tuesday
 
The producer price index, the first of two inflation indicators out this week, is expected to show inflation still in check. Forecast: up 0.1 percent. The index was unchanged in July and fell 0.1 percent in June.
 
The Rockefeller Group is scheduled to present a reorganization plan for the bankrupt Rockefeller Center at a Federal bankruptcy court hearing in New York.
 
H. J. Heinz is expected to report fiscal first-quarter earnings of 69 cents a share.
 
Wednesday
 
Labor Department releases the consumer price index for August. Forecast: prices up 0.2 percent, the same increase reported for July. The index rose 0.1 percent in June.
 
The Labor Department will also report August real earnings. They rose 0.8 percent in July and 1.2 percent in June.
 
The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development is expected to begin negotiations in Paris over rules to ease foreign investment.
 
The Reader's Digest Association is expected to report fiscal fourth-quarter earnings of 23 cents a share.
 
Thursday
 
The Commerce Department reports retail sales for August. Forecast: up 0.2 percent, following a 0.1 percent decline in July and a 0.8 percent increase in June.
 
The Labor Department releases its initial weekly unemployment report.
 
Friday
 
The Federal Reserve reports industrial production and capacity utilization for August. Forecast: production up 0.4 percent, after a 0.1 percent increase in July. Utilization is expected at 83.5, from 83.4 percent in July.

HEADLINE: Word for Word/William M. Kunstler;
May It Displease the Court: Quotations of a Radical Lawyer

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

 BODY:
WHEN William M. Kunstler died of heart failure last week, it was a bit of a shock to realize that he was 76 years old. He had the energy of a man much younger, and he seems never to have wondered if the times had passed him by.
The radical lawyer was a man of contradictions. This man-child of the '60's could talk like a legal scholar one day and an aging hippie the next. He had elements of both. 
 He was a first-rate intellect who could match knowledge and wits in court with the best litigators -- and, perhaps just as important, a pioneer of the lawyer's sound bite in an age when increasingly the politics of the law was played out through the mass media. Yet he was notorious for neglecting the paperwork, motions and hearings that are the nuts-and-bolts of a law practice.
He was a man who hugged his friends on the sidewalk and a womanizer who by his own admission sometimes gave short shrift to his family. He spoke contemptuously of people who loved creature comforts yet reveled in his own celebrity.
Some of his remarks were courageous and have worn well with time. Others, including some in his 1994 book "My Life as a Radical Lawyer" (Birch Lane Press), seem to have been startlingly ill-considered, even reckless. Herewith some Kunstlerisms, which unless otherwise noted come from the book. DAVID STOUT
 
 
At the Chicago 7 Trial

Your Honor, are we going to stop this medieval torture?
-- to Judge Julius J. Hoffman, who had just ordered a gag and shackles for Bobby Seale, one of the defendants charged with inciting the riots that marred that 1968 Democratic National Convention.
I just feel so utterly ashamed to be an American lawyer at this time.
-- to Judge Hoffman.
Do me too. I don't want to be left out.
-- baiting the judge, who had just cited one defendant for contempt. The judge was happy to oblige.
 
On Race
 Even Abraham Lincoln, "the Great Emancipator," often referred to blacks as "niggers" and attempted to rid America of them.
Every time I have a different case, I want to be the color or race. I want to be Indians. Sikhs I want to be. Blacks I want to be.
-- 1988 interview.
 
On Women
 It demeans and degrades women in a manner as inequitable as it is gross.
-- 1970 Playboy interview, commenting on Playboy.
For someone with my vanity and ego, it was very gratifying. How could I resist?
-- on women throwing themselves at him.
Maybe when I'm 70 I'll get a third wife.
-- reflecting in a 1980 interview with American Lawyer about starting a second family with his young second wife.
 
On Wealth
 Just get enough to live on. Animals that overeat die.
-- in a 1970 talk to students at the University of Cincinnati.
I feel uneasy and guilty. Why should they have boats and I enjoy riding in them while some other man is brushing off rats?
-- reflecting in a 1970 interview on wealthy friends.
 
On Mobsters
 I cannot regard someone like John Gotti as more evil than someone in George Bush's position.
I must confess to a slight romantic attraction to the folk-hero quality I see in them.
Here's to crime!
-- toast at a 1970 party celebrating a civil suit victory by a gangster.
 
On Politicians
 The Kennedys' real immorality has to do with their lack of ethics as political leaders rather than their sexual exploits.
Reagan was a stupid man who was easily led by the nose.
To this day, I believe Rockefeller was a murderer.
-- reflecting in the book on the bloody 1971 Attica, N.Y., prison uprising.
 
On Violence
 Even though I don't like it, I think it is sometimes entirely necessary for the attainment of certain social ends.
-- 1970 interview.
Every person we execute negates our illusory image that we are a compassionate and merciful society.
 
On Defendants
 You'll see how the police treat young third-world people in the depressed communities of our city.
-- opening remarks to the jury in the 1988 trial of Larry Davis, a notorious drug dealer accused of attempted murder in a 1986 shootout with the police and acquitted of the most serious charges.
Mr. Davis is a man who used to help the police sell drugs. When he decided to stop, they decided to kill him.
-- after Mr. Davis's 1989 acquittal in another trial on charges of killing a Harlem drug dealer.
A proud and dedicated revolutionary who believes one must fight with more than empty platitudes the evils in our national and international society.
-- describing his client Thomas W. Manning, convicted in 1986 of killing a New Jersey state trooper.
Members of unpopular groups should not be thrown to the lions; someone has to stand up for them.
I would . . . never represent an individual like Leona Helmsley, who, although she has the same civil rights as anyone, is a rather detestable character.
It would really have been something to be the attorney who defended Oswald.
-- reflecting, in the book, on President John F. Kennedy's assassination.
 
On Patriotism
 I never stand for the Pledge of Allegiance, because it is not true; the United States does not provide "justice for all."
It is not the physical flag but the principles for which it stands that are vital to our survival as a free people.
-- on a 1989 Supreme Court decision upholding flag-burning as form of protest.
 
On His Career
 Over all, I never counted, but my lifetime batting average is probably better than Willie Mays.
-- 1993 interview.
Candidates may rely principally on divisive "wedge" issues, as the Republicans seize on affirmative action and immigration and Democrats make the most of their support for abortion rights and gun control. This will be a departure from past White House races, when, except in wartime, politicians said pocketbook issues mattered most. Bush found that out in '92. But strangely enough, every upturn in the economy these days seems to accompany a downturn in the President's ratings. In '94, the Democrats got no credit for the improved economy. Still, Clinton will try to get his due.
 
JAN. 29
an even earlier start?
The dates for the primary contests are not set in concrete. If the squabbling over the timetable escalates, the Iowa caucuses could end up taking place as early as today, according to an analysis by Paul Wilson, a Republican media consultant. He says that could happen if states continue leapfrogging over one another to stage the earliest contests. As a result, several states could schedule their contests even sooner, further hastening the primary season.
 
Jan. 31
STATE OF THE UNION
By now, Clinton may have had his last, best opportunity to look Presidential this year. As the Republicans savage one another, Clinton could use the White House mantle to set a confident tone to carry through the campaign. This is a good time to bring up a fail-safe accomplishment that's popular with conservatives: Gore's reinventing-Government initiative. The President might also (as he would put it) brag on an improved economy, if the economy is still robust.
Anticipating Republican attacks on his foreign policy failures, Clinton might emphasize his triumphs, however limited, like Northern Ireland, Haiti and the Middle East. Also look for Clinton to present himself as the anti-Clinton. The man whose mantra in 1992 was "Make change our friend" is likely to portray himself as someone who can prevent Republicans from changing too much, particularly tampering with Medicare and, as he might put it, undoing regulations that could make drinking water unsafe for children. This speech also provides a chance for Clinton to challenge Republicans on a favorite issue of Perot voters: campaign-finance reform.
Also take note of Hillary's guest in the gallery. Will the First Family go with a naked plea for independent voters and invite Perot? Hardly. An unknown? Maybe to promote his anti-smoking drive, Clinton will find some towheaded 12-year-old from the battleground state of Florida who ripped down Joe Camel signs.
 
Feb. 12
IOWA CAUCUSES
This is where you can lose by winning. Just ask Bush, who beat Reagan here in 1980 and boasted about the "Big Mo" that would carry him to the nomination. It carried him no farther than Des Moines. Dick Gephardt learned his lesson after winning here in 1988. "You always get a big bounce coming out of the first caucus state," Dole says. "But probably it's not real."
Even so, Dole's been in Iowa so much over the last three decades that he's called the state's third Senator. But because Gramm tied Dole in an Iowa straw poll in August -- and Buchanan placed a respectable third -- no one is about to cede the state to Dole. Alexander, too, has geared his whole campaign on breaking through here and in New Hampshire. Expect a bitter battle over the hearts -- and votes -- of the politically active religious conservatives, who won't be deterred by the snow to participate in the caucuses.
If Dole doesn't come in first, he might as well pack up and head back to Kansas. Even if he does come in first, but staggers across the finish line, his opponents and the press will harp on his weaknesses, and the second-place finisher will get a lift.
 
Feb. 20
NEW HAMPSHIRE PRIMARY
Unlike Bush, Dole doesn't need to drive an 18-wheeler around the parking lot at Cuzzin Ritchie's Truck Stop to demonstrate his empathy for the working class. But Dole should burn his 1988 New Hampshire playbook and use Bush's rebound here as his model. He cannot afford any compromises in this aggressively conservative state. He'll have to sign every pledge to cut taxes, balance the budget -- whatever it takes. Dole need not be reminded that on the eve of this primary in 1988, his pollster, Richard Wirthlin, was whistling "Hail to the Chief." Dole knows better than anyone that he cannot tolerate a second-place finish.
Dole forces are rooting for Buchanan to place second because they think it could knock the others from the race. In a multicandidate field, Buchanan will have a hard time repeating the 37 percent he drew here in 1992. Still, he has worked this state hard and remains popular. If Buchanan places second to Dole in Iowa and then here, the other contenders might consider stopping by the Sheraton Wayfarer Inn, thanking their supporters and bowing out.
Yet Dole wouldn't want Buchanan to do too well, because that would discourage the true believers on the right from helping Dole wrap up a quick victory. With far less money than most of his rivals, Buchanan knows this is his big chance. "I've got to do well early," he says. "If I can, money is not going to save those guys. Money can't buy you love." Buchanan might be overstating his appeal. Few Republicans beyond those in his own entourage think Buchanan could ever get nominated: he's considered too extreme, even with the party lurching further rightward. But the better Buchanan does, the harder it will be for any other candidate to establish an anti-Dole profile.
If an Alexander or a Wilson or a Lugar places first or second in New Hampshire, watch out. It could set off a no-holds-barred tournament for the nomination.
 
Feb. 21
WINNOWING TIME
If Americans don't know by now who Dick Lugar and Arlen Specter are, they never will. Some candidates may drop out. Others may "suspend" campaigns -- essentially hang-ing on only to keep qualifying for Federal matching money. Those who have stashed a lot of cash may stay in, hoping to catch on in other states.
To get a sense of who has the resources to keep going, see which candidates can afford a chartered plane for their campaign staff and the press, and whether the planes are full. Don't be fooled by candidates like Jerry Brown, the former Governor of California, who by the end of the 1992 primary campaign season was traveling in a refurbished prop. Only those with jets are in the game.
 
Feb. 24
DELAWARE PRIMARY
Gramm has high hopes for this state. In a variation on Al Gore's 1988 strategy of practically bypassing Iowa and New Hampshire (when he realized he'd lose them), Gramm has doted on Delaware and a handful of other states, mostly in the South, to make him competitive even if he fares poorly in the first two contests.
It's a strategy that's never worked. (Since 1952, no Republican has won the White House without winning the New Hampshire primary first.) But this may be Gramm's backup plan. He infuriated New Hampshire voters by agreeing to attend a candidates' forum here, as Delaware was scheming to infringe on New Hampshire's tradition of holding the first primary. He was also playing footsie with Arizona and Louisiana, which were likewise trying to horn in on New Hampshire and Iowa and have contests coming up.
 
March 5
YANKEE PRIMARIES
For the first time, five New England states -- Connecticut, Maine, Massachusetts, Rhode Island and Vermont -- are pooling in an effort to wield more clout. This stronghold of moderate Republicanism is Wilson's best shot to find a receptive audience. Wilson is also helped here because his biggest booster is Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts. If Weld can't deliver his state for Wilson, then not only will Wilson be in trouble, but Weld's status as a Presidential power broker will be dashed.
 
March 7
NEW YORK PRIMARY
(A.K.A. D'AMATO PRIMARY)
With the help of Senator Alfonse D'Amato, Dole has the state, with its arcane ballot process, so locked up that it would be a waste of money for others to compete. Expect to hear the other candidates groaning about Dole's having fixed the election. (Dole doesn't dispute the charge, but says, Hey, he got the raw end of the deal in 1988.) Dole will have a few intense days of putting up his armor. But in five days, the campaign will have moved south. And the Senator from Kansas will be 102 delegates richer.
 
March 12
SUPER TUESDAY
For the last six Presidential elections, this has been the biggest single day of voting after New Hampshire. But with all the primaries bunched up this year, it is not so unique that five Southern states -- Florida, Mississippi, Oklahoma, Tennessee and Texas -- are going to the polls today. If Dole or another contender heads into these primaries with the bulk of the delegates, and wins most of these states, he will be hard to stop. But if there's a divided outcome -- say Gramm wins Texas, Wilson wins Florida and Alexander wins Tennessee -- the race will grow more muddled.
 
March 19
BIG-TEN PRIMARIES
Again, if there is a favorite after Super Tuesday, he could seal the nomination by winning the Rust Belt states of Illinois, Michigan, Ohio and Wisconsin.
Time magazine splashes the expected nominee on its cover: Dole, in a serious pose, with the cover line "One More Mission"; Alex Castellanos of the Gramm campaign suggests "Beyond Charisma" for his boss; Terry Holt of the Lugar campaign offers "Is America Serious Enough for Dick Lugar?" and for People magazine, "Boring Is Cool."
 
March 26
THE BIG ONE
While the California primary is the biggest electoral prize, with 163 delegates (winner take all), this state won't matter unless there is such a fractured primary that there is no decisive leader coming in. This is Wilson's best hope. If he loses here, it not only destroys the Governor's prospects, but is also a humiliating home-turf rebuff.
 
April 1
APRIL FOOL'S DAY
If there's no obvious Republican nominee by now, expect the wrangling to continue through May and maybe drag on to San Diego. What happens, for instance, if Dole wins Iowa and New York and Michigan, Wilson wins Massachusetts and California and Ohio, Buchanan wins New Hampshire and South Carolina, Gramm wins Texas and Georgia and Arizona and Alexander wins Tennessee and Florida?
 
April 5
THE BLACK HOLE
The most interesting aspect of the campaign calendar is not the compression of the primary schedule. It's the four-month black hole it creates once the nominee becomes clear. If one candidate has reached the delegate threshold, enduring an obstacle course of bruising primaries, he's probably so broke he can't afford television commercials. And he won't be eligible for public money until the convention.
But unless Clinton had an unexpected challenger, or blew his money on too many polls, he will be awash in cash, maybe up to $8 million. He could use it to strengthen his image or attack his presumptive opponent.
Paul Begala, a strategist for Clinton in 1992, relishes the opportunities for mischief: "That nominee will twist in the wind from April to August, defenseless. How they get around that, I don't know." Mark Helmke, a Lugar adviser, says it could be "a very dangerous period where there are no more primaries, Republicans have spent their money and Clinton is beating up on the Republicans like crazy for being meanspirited."
An advertising blitz could trigger a surge for Clinton -- at least until the Republican convention. To counter the Democrats, some leading Republicans are urging their party to put aside money to wage a generic advertising campaign. Gov. John Engler of Michigan suggests that the prospective party nominee announce his running mate and the top four members of his Cabinet during that period. (Might he be thinking Vice President Engler?)
Don't look for Dole to do that if he's in first place. "I remember when Reagan announced Schweiker," Dole says of Reagan's early choice of Senator Richard Schweiker of Pennsylvania in 1980. "They had two targets out there instead of one. But we've talked about it." The intervening months could give factions time to plan their convention tactics. Lobby groups on both sides of the abortion rights issue would no doubt pressure Republican-platform drafters. Similar battles over the Democratic platform could intensify.
Or both the Republicans and Democrats might be drowned out as the long run-up time spawns the rise of independent candidates. Look for Perot to continue toying with another bid. Republicans may intensify a courtship with Perot to sideline him. As Representative Hyde puts it, "I hope and pray that Ross Perot decides to spend '96 writing his memoirs."
By now, Bradley should be long done with his book. The question might remain: How serious is he about the plunge? The President should be nervous if the thoughtful Bradley takes to the hustings because he sounds off on many Clinton-esque issues, like the shaky position of the middle class.
But even confidants of Bradley question whether he has the gumption (or the tenacity) to endure what must be endured for a Presidential run, particularly as an independent. At the White House, Michael McCurry, the press secretary, will have other worries during the hiatus before the conventions. He is bracing for Republicans to conduct "the world's longest search for a Vice-Presidential running mate."
But Lyn Nofziger, a former Reagan aide, frets that the candidate, whoever he is, "can screw up royally" during this preconvention period, to the point that Republicans won't want him anymore. "But," Nofziger adds, "you're stuck with the guy unless he does something criminal. Or dies."
 
May 13
POLYPOLITICS?
This is the deadline for independents to file petitions to get their names on the Texas ballot -- and the first big sign of whether 1996 is going to be the Year of Polypolitics. That is, whether there are going to be not just two or three, but four, five or six serious candidates in November. Powell, Jackson, Perot, Buchanan, Bradley and Lowell Weicker are among the possible independent contenders. After Texas, several other deadlines follow fast, most before Labor Day.
While expectations are high for independents this season, it's not as easy for them to get on the ballot as Perot's 1992 drive led people to believe. His bid for President was lubricated with $62 million of his own money. Seven states have already passed legislation to discourage competition from independents. A Democratic candidate for President needs about 25,000 signatures to get on the ballot in all 50 states; a Republican needs twice that amount.
And the requirement for a third-party candidate? More than 700,000 signatures.
 
July 15
IT'S NOT WATERGATE, BUT. . . .
Bob Woodward's probe-and-tell book on the Republican race should be out by now. Candidates sweat over whether the Watergate sleuth will uncover something embarrassing just in time for the convention. "Every candidate's scared to death of it," says Murphy of the Alexander campaign.
But Woodward advises the campaigns not to be thin-skinned. If they can't handle his questions, he says, they had "better find other work."
Woodward is focusing his research on Dole, Gramm, Wilson and Alexander, assuming that one will get the nomination. He's also keeping tabs on his old pal Powell. One risk: Book sales plummet if one of the Big Four isn't nominated.
 
July 17
A NEW STUNT?
Four years ago today, the Clintons and the Gores and eight buses roared out of midtown Manhattan and headed for Camden, N.J. -- the first stop on the first of Clinton's popular bus tours. But don't rely on Clinton to try the gimmick again. It was a romantic notion: two youthful candidates and their wives venturing out into America. Yet the magic may be gone. Clinton is President, not an idealistic, would-be President. The Secret Service would probably have to block off a big chunk of the Interstate for security reasons. Besides, it would be mortifying if Clinton didn't draw cheering throngs.
 
July 19
OLYMPICS OPEN IN ATLANTA
This should steal the spotlight from Presidential politics. Maybe Clinton -- and the presumptive G.O.P. nominee -- will show up and wrap themselves in star-spangled good feelings. That is, if the United States does well.
"I predict a major recruiting war between the nominees for the support of Olympic medalists," says Dan Schnur, a Wilson spokesman. "If Shaquille O'Neal can endorse Taco Bell and Pepsi, why can't he endorse Pete Wilson?"
 
July 22
DOLE TURNS 73
It's one birthday he'd just as soon not celebrate.
Expect Clinton to draw a subtle contrast by making a bigger show of his jogging routine.
God help Dole if he catches a cold.
 
Aug. 1
PRESSURE ON POWELL
If there's a clear nominee, the push will be on for Powell to join the G.O.P. ticket; that is, unless he's tarnished himself with an aborted bid for the top job, or if he's already running as an independent. Look for Powell to want a deal. If Dole's the nominee, he'll want a promise that Dole will step down after one term. Also look for him to press for a broad foreign policy portfolio.
If Powell doesn't work out, the short list would include losers from the primary battle, popular Middle West Governors and, of course, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey. But she could fall victim to the right wing, which may threaten to disrupt the convention if there's a pro-choice running mate. Still, a black or female Veep would be a first for the G.O.P.
 
Aug. 10
DELEGATES ARRIVE IN SAN DIEGO
Genuine drama would come from the unlikely, though plausible, scenario of a brokered Republican convention. If that happens, now is Gingrich's last chance to step in.
If the nominee is a certainty, don't count on much interest from the press, particularly since the networks have whined about the lousy camera angles in the San Diego hall. But watch for the party to do something to cook up suspense. The premium for the party this time is to reassert discipline over the gathering and prevent a rerun of Houston 1992, when the hard right took over the show. See if the G.O.P. prevails in moving the last session to Jack Murphy Stadium so the nominee can make his acceptance speech before a huge outdoor crowd, as John Kennedy did at the Los Angeles Coliseum in 1960.
In the off chance that Alexander is nominated, he won't rule out the possibility of delivering an acceptance speech in his familiar work shirt. "I'll just have to see how I feel that night," he says.
 
Aug. 16
THE AFTERMATH
The convention's over; watch the ticket scramble to the center. The talk about knocking the poor off welfare, abolishing affirmative action and slashing taxes -- that was politics. Now it's time for harmony and moderation. The standard-bearer cites examples demonstrating that he was never that conservative. Expect the Christian Coalition and the National Rifle Association to meet privately to plot revenge on the nominee for betraying them.
 
Aug. 19
ANOTHER BIRTHDAY
Clinton turns 50. (Tipper Gore turns 48.)
He'll never be in Dole's generation, but the President is finally an Adult. Maybe the added gray hairs and crow's-feet (not to say more flab) after a term in the hot seat will give him more gravitas.
 
Aug. 26
DEMOCRATIC NATIONAL CONVENTION
For all the talk about Mayor Richie Daley of Chicago trying to live down his dad's fiasco in 1968, the real trouble might be within the Democratic Party. To see how Clinton is faring with his own party, look at the podium at the new United Center. If members of Congress are pushing one another aside to get into the picture with Clinton on stage, that's a good sign. But there is never complete harmony at Democratic conventions, and that's why the party never has to manufacture drama. Be assured that Jesse will be a presence. Maybe he'll want a prime-time speaking slot in exchange for not running as an independent. Jackson, a veteran at building suspense, may stay mum until the last moment. Asked about Democrats who think he's bluffing about making an independent bid, Jackson replies, "Let them live in the suspense of it."
 
Sept. 2
ANOTHER LABOR DAY
Clinton's two most important surrogates, Vice President Gore and Hillary Rodham Clinton, hit the trail in full force.
Don't look for H.R.C. in an apron, but don't expect her in armor, either -- or to be dwelling on health care. Unless she's too stained by Whitewater, Hillary could be the secret weapon in countering the Angry White Male vote. She'll head for big-city audiences where's she's popular and press women to vote.
Gore might take a stab at exciting those who are fuming over Republican efforts to slash environmental regulations. He'll also be Clinton's ambassador to the South, unless the Democrats have totally written off the region. He's Clinton's best, perhaps only, hope to save Tennessee for the Democrats.
 
Oct. 3
NOMINEES' FACE-OFF
The possible date for a postconvention debate. No sweat if it's just the two nominees. But prospects for a multicandidate race may cause great consternation for debate planners, pollsters, the networks and the parties. Janet Brown, director of an independent commission that puts on debates, is already fretting about the logistics. In '92, the commission had to install a bathroom for Perot at the first debate because Bush and Clinton each had one. He never used it. "I'm not in the plumbing business," Brown says. "At least, I don't want to be in the plumbing business."
 
Nov. 3
PRE-ELECTION POLLS
Look for election-eve polls in Sunday papers. A glance at key states could provide a good sense of the electoral college picture. Four years ago, Clinton won 370 electoral votes to Bush's 168, giving Clinton 100 votes to spare. But Clinton, who won 32 states in 1992, has an uphill battle to win back many of these states.
The most important to watch is California; Clinton must have it to win, though that would not guarantee victory. Other key states that Clinton won in 1992, and is trying to recapture, are Ohio, Michigan, Pennsylvania, Illinois and New
Jersey.
Some Democrats even advance a scenario of Clinton getting elected without a single Southern state. It could happen if Jackson, as an independent, siphons Clinton votes in the South and Perot drains away Republican votes in the Middle Western, Rocky Mountain and Western States.
 
Nov. 5
ELECTION DAY
What if there's a multicandidate field and the winner pulls less than 30 percent of the popular vote?
Did I hear someone say run-off?

HEADLINE: New York Has Long Been a Capital of Psychotherapy. How Have the Options Changed?

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO

 BODY:
IT was always a one-way love affair. New York City adored Sigmund Freud. Freud hated New York City.
He was here just once, in 1909, and he took in the usual sights: the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Coney Island, Central Park and Chinatown. But as he left the States, he wrote to his sister: "I am very glad I am away from it, and even more that I don't have to live there." 
 As Freud was busy denouncing all Americans as materialistic, superficial, prudish and uncultivated, New Yorkers couldn't get enough of the father of psychoanalysis. The International Psychoanalytic Society set up shop in Manhattan in 1911, and in the 1920's there were "Freuding" parties in Greenwich Village where guests analyzed one another's dreams. Woody Allen's oeuvre has certainly burnished the image.
"Psychoanalysis might have originated in Vienna, but it was copied and Americanized, then marketed, and marketed on a scale immeasurably greater than Europe could offer, in New York," Ann Douglas wrote in "Terrible Honesty: Mongrel Manhattan in the 1920's" (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, 1995), her sweeping portrait of New York City.
Today Freud is still a strong, some would say towering, presence. No matter how many of his theories or techniques have been rejected or modified, he is still the one who created the "talking cure," the foundation of all psychotherapy.
But with changes transforming the health-care industry and managed-care companies looking for ways to cut costs, Freudian analysis is taking a back seat to cheaper and shorter approaches like cognitive-behavioral therapy and group therapy. The image of a couch-bound patient free-associating four or five days a week for years on end, while a bearded analyst sits silently by, is largely a thing of the past.
"There are still therapists out there who believe in sitting on the sidelines and just letting a patient talk and talk and talk," said Dr. Robert M. Naiman, a Manhattan psychiatrist who has practiced for more than 40 years. "That was O.K. back in the classic orthodox days when patients coming into psychoanalysis expected that, but in this day and age I think people should and do expect activity and interaction."
More typical these days is a patient who sees a therapist once a week and sits up. The talk may indeed explore childhood difficulties and last night's dreams. But it will also focus on current problems, self-defeating tendencies, relationships and career goals. The therapist doesn't give advice per se, but is clearly engaged, asking questions, making connections and helping the patient achieve insights and, ultimately, positive changes.
"People who go into therapy know the process is going to take a long time, but they still want instant feedback," said Doug Garr, a Manhattan author and editor who has seen three therapists since 1982. "You don't want to lose your mind before you regain it."
In general, psychotherapy today tends to fall into two broad categories: a highly focused treatment that tackles a specific symptom by directly modifying thinking and behavior versus a more global, psychoanalytical approach that seeks to affect a major personality change by expanding insight.
The first approach zeros in on a particular problem or unwanted behavior -- a phobia or creative block, say -- and attempts to correct it. It does this not by looking into the psyche for root causes but by taking a pragmatic tack, involving homework assignments and mental exercises, to change thinking and behavior right now. Cognitive, behavioral and short-term therapies all work this way, and because they tend to move quickly -- and cost less -- they have become the darlings of the managed-care industry.
Dr. Russ Newman of the American Psychological Association said the public was warming to the swifter style of therapy, too. "Taking the economics out of it, I suspect that people are more immediate results-oriented, more symptom-focused, more behavior-focused today than probably they were 15 or 20 years ago," said Dr. Newman, the association's executive director for professional practice.
But many believe that for permanent, pervasive changes in both outlook and behavior, a deeper, longer-term plumbing of the mind, emotions and unconscious works best. For that, there are seemingly infinite schools and approaches, from the waning orthodox Freudian perspective (where the daily couch is de rigueur and the Oedipus complex looms large) to mainstream Freudian analysis (with couch optional, once or twice a week, and there's more interaction) to a number of distinct offshoots of Freud that drop many of the sexual theories in favor of others. Then there are Gestalt therapy, existential psychology, the humanistic approach, and many others that don't spring directly from Freud but still seek to boost insight into the causes of behavior by exploring repressed thoughts and memories.
But one trend that may make things somewhat easier for the consumer is the evolution over the years of an "eclectic" point of view, in which therapists shed a rigid theoretical orientation and instead draw on several different approaches, depending on the patient's needs.
"Once you are talking about a theory, you are talking about a very specific lens and certain things will be exaggerated and others will be minimized," said Dr. Beverly M. Rubinstein, a Greenwich Village psychologist whose overarching approach is more analytical than behavioral. "To the extent that the patient is respected, all of the theories have to be secondary to the phenomenon. In geology, the phenomenon is the rock. In therapy, it's the patient."
Nonetheless, choosing a therapist can be a bewildering process. There are not only many kinds of therapies, but also different types of therapists: clinical social workers, psychologists and psychiatrists. (Actually, anyone can hang out a shingle advertising "psychotherapy," but only these three professional categories are recognized by New York State's licensing boards, which uphold standards and mete out punishment.)
 
NEW VIEW ON MEDICATION
 Clinical social workers have completed a two-year post-baccalaureate program. Psychologists have Ph.D.'s., usually earned after four to six years of study. And psychiatrists are full medical doctors. None of the three types are limited to any one approach, but psychiatrists are the only ones who can prescribe medications like Prozac, the antidepressant of the decade. However, social workers and psychologists usually have relationships with psychiatrists who will write a prescription after a consultation.
In the last 10 years it has become more common for patients to take medication for depression or anxiety. The thinking used to be that if moods were lifted "artificially," people would be less inclined to explore the causes of psychological pain, but the opposite view seems to hold sway today.
That is especially true of the selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, or S.S.R.I.'s, like Prozac, Paxil, Zoloft and Luvox, which have fewer side effects than the older generation of tricyclic antidepressants and have proved remarkably effective. For anxiety, Xanax seems to be the drug of choice.
"People take the medication and find they're able to work better in therapy," said Dr. Clark Sugg, a psychiatrist and director of clinical services at the William Alanson White Institute on the Upper West Side. "They begin to have hope and see that things can be different, and it sparks curiosity. It's almost as if you wake up from a dream."
Many health insurance plans do not cover psychotherapy, only psychiatric care in a hospital setting. But those that do usually require some co-payment and authorize a set number of sessions, like 15 or 20. The therapist can request another set of sessions by detailing the patient's inner turmoil; the notes are then reviewed by bureaucrats who often have little or no mental-health training. Therapists commonly warn patients that although those notes are supposed to be confidential, once they leave their offices there is no guarantee they won't come back to haunt the patient.
It is almost impossible to self-diagnose and choose the one therapeutic niche for you. But just about everyone agrees that individuals with phobias respond best to cognitive-behavioral therapy. Individual personality matters, too. Some people are just more comfortable with a pragmatic, focused approach; others may find it absolutely cathartic to speak in great depth.
 
FINDING A GOOD MATCH
 Most therapists suggest the prospective patient get a few names from friends, family members or trusted co-workers and then shop around. Don't hesitate to ask the therapist: What kind of therapy do you do? What does that mean? How does it work? How long will it take? How much will it cost?
The mantra of most therapists, interestingly, is for the prospective patient to find a good personality match. Even if you can't put a finger on it, if the therapist's personality rubs you the wrong way, keep looking. The therapist should seem caring and attentive and should put you at ease. A sense of humor can't hurt. "There are certainly people in my field -- social workers, psychologists and psychiatrists -- who are real zombies socially," one psychiatrist confided.
There are, to be sure, bad therapists out there. One family therapist, Dr. Neil Maron, said he knew of a psychologist who gives her excess patients to her husband, a salesman, for therapy. Group therapy is known among practitioners to attract the occasional aspiring cult leader to its fray. And, yes, there are therapists who fall asleep during sessions, breach confidentiality or become sexually involved with patients.
Even with a competent therapist, the talking cure can be far from a panacea. "Sometimes, when you understand why you're doing things, it makes things worse," said a woman in her 40's who works in the art world and who refused to be identified. "They say that too much knowledge is not necessarily a good thing, and I think that's true of self-knowledge."
Other patients complain of sounding like a broken record, feeling incapable of acting on their insights and growing emotionally dependent on the therapist, afraid to ever end the relationship. Many worry about all the money they're spending, money that could go into savings or into pleasurable -- and possibly even therapeutic -- activities like travel or continuing education.
Even some therapists think the 20th century could take some lessons from earlier eras, when people struggled with painful emotions and awkward personality traits on their own. "I don't think everyone requires therapy in this generation," said Dr. Maron, president of the Center for Marital and Family Therapy in New York City. "In fact, I think people are over-therapized."
When therapy spawns obvious changes, however, it can be exhilarating. Mr. Garr said he had a volatile temper before working on it in therapy. "It hasn't cured it totally, but it has helped," he said. "I can do a lot of self-adjustment in midstream. The smallest thing used to set me off. Now nothing is so bad that I can't cope with it."
 
 
 
How to File A Complaint
 Psychologists and certified social workers in New York State are licensed and disciplined by the state's Department of Education. Psychiatrists are also licensed by the department but are disciplined by the state's Department of Health. In all cases, an investigation begins once an official complaint form is submitted.
A patient may file a complaint against a psychologist or certified social worker by contacting the Education Department's Office of Professional Discipline at (800) 442-8106. Two of the most common complaints are breach of confidentiality and sexual abuse.
Last year the state found substantial evidence of misconduct in 31 cases involving psychologists and 11 cases involving certified social workers. Punishments ranged from a reprimand to revocation of the license.
To file a complaint against a psychiatrist, contact the Health Department's Office of Professional Medical Conduct at (518) 474-8357. Last year the agency took disciplinary action -- usually suspension or revocation of license -- against 30 psychiatrists for violations ranging from sexual abuse to the inappropriate prescription of drugs.

HEADLINE: ATLANTIC CITY;
Missing the Old Neighborhood

BYLINE: By BILL KENT 

 BODY:
TOMMY NARDONE, the crusty owner and cook of the old Brown Derby restaurant, used to dismiss whatever fears customers might have about parking in his dingy corner of the North Inlet. He would assure them that Atlantic City would bloom again, with or without casinos.
For two decades, Mr. Nardone, one of the few city residents to vote against legalized casino gambling, served up big portions of veal and spaghetti. The Brown Derby, one of the more successful of the city's dozen or so mom-and-pop Italian restaurants, had the singular distinction of being on an ocean-front street in Atlantic City's worst neighhorhood. "They used to say, 'If you want to find the Brown Derby, you'd better pack a gun,' " Mr. Nardone said. 
 Today, a new Brown Derby is in a shopping strip in a neighborhood that has bloomed, and then some. Where boarded-up row houses once sagged, rows of bright, powder-blue Victorian-style town houses gleam. Mr. Nardone can even offer his patrons free off-street parking, a rarity.
But business is not what it used to be. Having experienced the best and the worst of the city's rebirth, Mr. Nardone has found that progress has its price.
"I'm paying more for electricity to air-condition this building than I'm paying in rent," said a weary Mr. Nardone, 72, wearing his cook's apron. "On the Friday night of Labor Day weekend, a big holiday weekend without a cloud in the sky, I did $137 worth of business. In the old place, in a bad neighborhood, I did that much on a weekday when it was raining."
A Philadelphia-born contractor, Mr. Nardone opened the Brown Derby in 1973. He cooked while his wife, Tannith, waited on customers.
Oddly, the Brown Derby's dismal location was part of its appeal. The restaurant occupied a narrow row house across Maine Avenue from a wrecked section of the Boardwalk and the ruin of Captain Starn's Pier. At least twice a year, the ocean would flood the area, and patrons who parked on Maine Avenue returned to find their cars swamped. Inside, the Brown Derby was filled with old clocks, photographs and architectural bric-a-brac.
"My customers were millionaires that had yachts in the marina," Mr. Nardone said, "or they were from New York and North Jersey with big summer homes down in Margate and Longport, and even some casino people. They all wanted that home-cooked Italian meal, and they didn't see no bad neighborhood when they came here. They saw the neighborhood they grew up in."
The Casino Reinvestment and Development Authority did not. In 1992, after six years of studies, surveys and political wrangling, the authority broke ground on a $100 million renovation of the entire Inlet.
Mr. Nardone said it "ruined a place that was good enough as it was, that would've come back all by itself if they'd just left us alone." Jim Kennedy, the authority's executive director, disagrees. "Mr. Nardone is living with an idealized version of what the old Inlet was like," he said. "There is no way that neighborhood could have come back on its own."
Most of the casino executives, business people and government officials who admire the new, improved Inlet did not live there in the 1970's. Those who did fought bitterly over the manner and amount of compensation the authority offered. (Mr. Nardone was offered $245,000 for his property, plus $70,000 in moving expenses. He wanted more and is in a legal battle over these and other issues related to the condemnation.)
In June, Mr. Nardone reopened the Brown Derby in a Melrose Avenue shopping strip built by a subsidiary of Harrah's Atlantic City. The casino's employees had frequented the old Brown Derby and wanted it to survive. Michael DeLeva, a spokesman for Harrah's, confirmed that its real estate subsidary wrote a lease favorable to Mr. Nardone.
In June, the casino gave Mr. Nardone a welcome-back party. "I got no complaints against Harrah's," Mr. Nardone said. "They've been good to me." He can't say the same of the new neighborhood; few of its residents eat at his restaurant.
Mr. Kennedy has had lunch there, although he has yet to introduce himself. "I want him to succeed as much as anyone," Mr. Kennedy said. "I like his food."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Tommy Nardone at work inside the new Brown Derby. North Inlet redevelopment forced him to move the restaurant to Melrose Avenue. (Sam D'Amico for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: ENCOUNTERS;
Long After '65, Still Fighting to Overcome

BYLINE: By ERIKA DUNCAN; Erika Duncan is an essayist and novelist who lives in Sag Harbor.

 BODY:
THERE were two Tom Levins on that day, maybe more; I could feel that.
The room was low-ceilinged and old-fashioned. If you opened the door of this house that was built by a sailor two centuries ago, you were barely three yards away from the modern-day traffic of Greenport. 
 On the video screen tiny children with dark faces were clapping; they were singing. Tiny children in very formal coats, buttoned up to their necks, carefully, over the clothing of poverty, were marching on Washington.
The Tom Levin of 1965 merged with the Tom Levin of now, who at 71 looked back on the history of Mississippi's Head Start program he directed. I could see Fanny Lou Hamer of Mississippi's Freedom Democratic Party. I could see Sergeant Shriver, the head of the Office of Economic Opportunity that funded Head Start nationwide. I could see Senator John Stennis, Mississippi's most die-hard segregationist.
"I happen to like Senator Stennis as a man," Tom Levin was saying. "He was a gentleman of a culture that was passing. But I fought him as loud and as dirty as any politician."
Tom Levin, a psychoanalyst and liaison officer for a world organization at the United Nations for the rights of the severely mentally ill, was smiling at his younger and older selves speaking, as his presence wove in and out of the Public Broadcasting Company special he was showing to me.
When President Johnson declared his "War on Poverty," and the Office of Economic Opportunity allocated $96 million for a program for pre-schoolers that had to be up and running in 12 weeks, the response was immediate, nationwide. Only from the state of Mississippi, the poorest of the 50 states, were applications remarkably absent.
On the video screen were the signs, "Colored admitted on Tuesdays only," "No coloreds allowed here"-- a voice: "We are not going to do a program for our darkies. This is Mississippi. The strings attached require us to mix the races at a very early age."
Other voices: "If you find a building, get some children, you can keep and teach your own. That was the answer to a prayer. . .
"When you start telling little 5-year-olds they are equal to little white kids, they grow up believing it."
There were many poor white people in the state of Mississippi as well, their photographs intermingled with the photographs of poor black people on the video screen. Once the program was enacted, very few would send their children, who equally needed the exposure to learning, free lunches and medical care. Those who did would receive threats.
Men and women who earned between $10 and $15 as sharecroppers and domestics would be able to earn between $50 and $75 a week taking care of their own.
The spirituals mix with the country music, the photographs of children with insects on them and parasites inside them, malnutrition, anemia. They are playing with garbage outside shacks. Later, children with a butterfly net, catching butterflies in the Head Start preschools, people building their own schools, an investigation begun by Senator Stennis only eight days into the program about the supposed misuse of funds.
On the walls, old-style oil portraits of Benjamin Disraeli's father and Tom's wife's grandparents intermingle with paintings of ships, as every so often Tom pushes the mute button, coming forward in time to explain it to me.
"Ain't gonna let nobody turn me round, turn me round, turn me round," little children are singing, as the Ku Klux Klan gathers and threats of arson mount.
Little children having medical and dental examinations for the first time in their lives, looking wonderingly up at the doctors.
They are working with crayons, and then suddenly they are "voting," on what color they should use -- red or blue. For always they are given a chance to vote, to teach them not to be afraid to register and vote.
"So that they could teach their parents not to be afraid. I remember each one of those kids," Tom was saying, "and the parents who started to say, 'Better my child die fighting for freedom, than grow up unable to be a man.' "
"Those were the sexist days," Tom adds apologetically.
In Tom's eyes -- and this would eventually cost him his job; he would eventually be forbidden to work below the Mason-Dixon line -- Head Start was never just about the children. Rather it was a way of bringing control over economic resources and dignity and respect to poor and black people.
Though after a mere eight days of the program's being in operation, the State of Mississippi and Senator Stennis were trying to break the back of its link to the civil rights movement. Mississippi now has more black politicians, senators and public officials than any other state, a direct result of the people who were politicized in those days.
In a climate of growing suspicion, why was Tom Levin the one who was chosen to mediate between government agencies and civil rights activists?
Tom Levin started out as a child analyst, because in the early 1950's there were almost no men working psychoanalytically with children. He spent an entire year working with just one autistic child.
He was concerned that competition between "good mother" therapists and "bad" actual mothers was weakening bonds that were already shaky. As a man, he had felt that he would be less likely to go into competition with mothers.
Ultimately he was to reject child analysis entirely, out of a feeling that it violated children's boundaries at a time in their lives when they were too vulnerable to experience a real reciprocity.
But there was also another side to Tom Levin. As a street kid growing up in the Bronx he had seen the Depression break the pride of his father, a hat blocker who could barely read or write. He "saw mothers and fathers losing touch with who they were," he explained, which was why what he encountered in Mississippi would move him so much.
From the time Tom was 6 until he was able to leave home at 15, the family lived in 14 different houses, moving constantly.
"I still cry in a movie if I see a father who is unemployed," Tom says to me.
Tom himself only went through the first three grades of high school, and always on probation. He did bit work from the age of 9, and by the time he was 15 was "a kid union organizer."
He took a job as a "nailer," running a pneumatic nailing machine. "I stood up on a carton. And I told them: 'Stop working! Don't give in!' "
As he tells me how he signed himself onto a ship, I think of his sailboat on a pier only a half block away from the old pillared house with its floor to ceiling historic American flag, its few stars arranged in an arc.
He joined the Navy and when the war broke out he was sent to Japan, a situation he calls "a very important transcultural experience."
"In Okinawa, at the time of the invasion, I heard American marines and sailors bragging about raping grandmothers, taking prisoners and knocking their teeth out for gold." And that too formed his consciousness.
He had wanted to be a doctor, and when he came home he worked for a while as a practical nurse. Eventually he was led into the study of psychoanalysis. But almost from the beginning he was uneasy about ignoring issues of class and culture in the focus on individual "adjustment." He didn't want to help patients adjust to what is unjust in our society.
It was during the march on Birmingham, when he was working for the New York Clinic for Mental Health, doing volunteer group therapy, that he turned on the radio and heard about the hoses and the dogs. He said to himself "This has to stop."
He called up the Southern Christian Leadership headquarters, and quickly became involved in organizing health workers to support the civil rights workers.
This became first the Committee of Conscience and then the Medical Committee for Human Rights, with Tom Levin the founding coordinator.
In the winter of 1963, when the three civil rights workers, James Chaney and Andrew Goodman and Michael Schwerner, were killed, Tom received a call from James Foreman who had organized the Freedom Summer Mississippi Voter Registration Drive, saying: "We need emergency triage. We need doctors."
"It was on June 23, my birthday, I remember," Tom Levin was saying. "We organized 200 medical people to come down.
A letter had come from two leading human rights doctors warning the new recruits that it would be dangerous to try to work in Mississippi.
"I was introduced to Archie Gray, the health director for the State of Mississippi, who said: The only help we need is in sterilizing the 'nigras' and curing their venereal diseases," Tom Levin said.
"Archie Gray turned to the black doctor who had brought me to meet him and said: 'Remember, I'm head of licensing for this state. If you keep this up you know what will happen to you.' "
Tom would show me the clipping from The New Republic which told of an armed attack on his headquarters in which 8 gunshots had been fired, and a globe had exploded inches over his head.
During the summer of 1963 Tom had visited the Freedom Schools and talked to the black high school students, who said: "We were quite happy when we were growing up, playing on the porch, and the family around. We felt loved and cared about. Then, when we got to be 6 years old, we would go to school. And our parents would tell us 'Do what the teacher says,' even though the teachers were treating them very badly and teaching them to be meek."
There was a memory of trust for their parents that the students said was broken by this.
In February 1964, as part of the strategy of the Kennedy/Johnson branch of Democrats to try to break the back of the Southern Dixiecrats within their party, Tom Levin received a telephone call from Polly Greenberg of the Office of Economic Opportunity asking if he would like to write a grant proposal. He finished the proposal that April.
His new organization, CDGM, the Child Development Group of Mississippi, was awarded $1.4 million for a program to start that July.
That was a time when there was a deep suspicion of Government interference among civil rights workers, so Tom said to Polly Greenberg, "The people have to have their own voice. They have to make their own decisions."
"That's what the Office of Economic Opportunity wants," Polly Greenberg replied.
"We decided that no center would be funded unless it was run by a community committee," Tom continues. "By the time the program started in July, already 80 communities had signed up."
Eight days into its operation, Senator Stennis called an investigation into the misuse of funds. "They wanted receipts," the Tom on the screen continues, his voice intermingled with the voice of the real Tom of Greenport and now.
"But the only people whom we could deal with were the small black merchants who wrote their receipts on the back of a paper bag. How can you have 83 centers organized in two weeks, with a million and a third dollars to be spent in eight weeks time without some mix-up?"
As the CDGM staff and the children settled into their new life, seven CDGM project trainees were arrested in a civil rights demonstration. Tom Levin advanced them their bail; he defended the action as a salary advance.
It was unheard of that those who before were afraid to vote or defend their rights, for fear of losing their jobs, would now be able to do whatever they wanted after hours.
Simultaneously the war in Vietnam escalated. Senator Stennis was the head of the Senate Armed Services Appropriation Committee. There was talk both in Congress and in places behind the scenes about the need for the poverty program to take a back seat, to release more funding for Vietnam.
Four weeks into an eight week program, an official decree arrived from the Office of Economic Opportunity that the Child Development Group of Mississippi must move from the church camp at Mount Beulah, seen by the government as the home of the civil rights movement.
CDGM's board, frightened of losing its funding, agreed. The staff, led by Tom Levin, refused. It was Tom Levin's last fight. Both sides asked Tom Levin to resign in order to try to preserve the coalition between the group and the government.
Eventually, another child-development coalition, sanitized and freed from civil rights connections, was formed by Senator Stennis and his associates, as a substitute recipient for the Head Start funds, to try to keep the organization out.
I watch Tom's face. He has not faltered at all in his talking to me. Now I ask him: Have you any regrets?
"I only regret that I did not have more time," he says. "It was not possible for me to continue my work without getting into conflict with the early childhood educational group. I had to have trouble."
When Tom Levin returned from Mississippi he was invited to join the staff of Lincoln Hospital Community Mental Health Center, where he worked on developing career ladders for poor people to enter the health professions.
In the early 70s, he became interested in alternate family styles -- communes, communal families and same gender families. It was during that time that he met his wife Ronny, a family therapist working with the problems of parents of children of artificial insemination.
Then, about 10 years ago, he became involved in the World Association for Psycho-Social Rehabilitation, a group dedicated to the protection of the human, political and health needs of the severely mentally ill, devoted to helping them live in communities and doing away with excessive hospitalization.
Very much an Eriksonian, in terms of his belief in ages and stages, 90 percent of his present day patients are "cases of re-analysis," those with whom others have failed, for to him "it seems right that those who are older among us take on the more difficult cases, drawing on the full range of our experience."
Still as interested as ever in uses and misuses of power in the psychotherapeutic situation, he works to train psychiatrists in transcultural work with groups, so that a therapist coming from Iran, let us say, will be able to understand Hispanics in the Bronx.
"Social change is like Pandora's box," Tom is saying on the screen, as the video nears its conclusion. "You can't control what comes out of it. The government wanted to control Pandora's box and they couldn't. What came out of it was social change beyond what they intended."
As, a little bit later, we stand by his sailboat, labeled, perhaps mischievously, Red, the water buoying us from under the dock all asway, I see from the video still in my mind children singing "Good morning, good morning," even after all their funding is cut.
I see a little girl who hasn't spoken at all in the first three weeks since she came to the center.
She speaks.

SECTION: Section 13; Page 8; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 538 words

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: VILLAGES, EAST AND WEST;
Marijuana Cure: Rx for Arrest

BYLINE: By DAVIDSON GOLDIN 

 BODY:
Once a week for the last two years, Johann Moore would take the subway from his home in Park Slope to lower Manhattan to give away marijuana.
He doesn't anymore. Six months ago he had to start charging for the drug, he said, because of high demand and limited supply. But he insists he's no dealer: His customers pay wholesale. 
 Mr. Moore's customers are the 50 members of the New York Buyers Club, a group he founded for people with serious illnesses, like him, who say smoking marijuana eases their suffering. Mr. Moore generally operates in TriBeCa and on the Lower East Side, where many club members live and where meeting places and drug sources are easy to find.
But marijuana is illegal in New York, even for medical purposes, unless the Federal Government supplies it. So Mr. Moore said he was not surprised when he was arrested three weeks ago on Fifth Street near Avenue B after the police spotted him giving someone marijuana.
Mr. Moore, who is 33 and unemployed, faces a year in prison if convicted on a misdemeanor charge. He said he will plead not guilty when he appears in court on Sept. 28.
Meeting in the basement of a bar near the Holland Tunnel last week, Mr. Moore and club members told how they relied on marijuana.
"I don't get stoned anymore," Mr. Moore said, brushing aside claims that club members use illness as an excuse to get high. He said he used marijuana to ease the discomfort caused by chronic fatigue syndrome.
Most club members, he said, have AIDS or H.I.V. and use marijuana to stimulate the appetite, relieve tension and counter depression. Others say marijuana eases the nausea and pain of chemotherapy, or the pain and spasms of multiple sclerosis.
While critics of marijuana-as-medicine say there is no scientific evidence that it works, anecdotal accounts have been enough to convince a growing number of people like Mr. Moore. He modeled the club on the Cannabis Buyers Club in San Francisco, which he said had more than 4,000 members.
When the New York club began in 1993, Mr. Moore said he would get free marijuana from drug dealers who had lost friends to AIDS. But it soon became too difficult to obtain enough for everyone, so dealers now charge Mr. Moore the wholesale price. Club members -- who must have a doctor's note or other proof of serious illness -- pay $15 for 5 grams, much less than the street price of $50 for 3.5 grams.
One club member, a 40-year-old painter who has had AIDS since 1991, said that marijuana had enabled him to stop losing weight.
"What had been happening before I hooked up with Johann is I'd go to eat, have three or four bites and not be able to finish," he said. "Now I can eat a full meal. That feels good."
David C. Condliffe, who was drug policy director under Mayor David N. Dinkins and now runs the nonprofit Drug Policy Foundation, said that city officials should consider allowing Mr. Moore's club to operate without fear of criminal prosecution.
"You've got a situation where citizens are trying to ameliorate intractable medical conditions," he said, "and on the other hand city officials are responsibly trying to enforce drug laws. But there are ways to reconcile both concerns."
 DAVIDSON GOLDIN

GRAPHIC: Photo: Johann Moore says he only sells marijuana to the seriously ill. (John Penley)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

ORGANIZATION: NEW YORK BUYERS CLUB NEW YORK BUYERS CLUB (64%);
