HEADLINE: Black Film Makers Are Looking Beyond Ghetto Violence

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB 

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 10

 BODY:
Black film makers, who have focused largely in recent years on the bleak and corrosive experiences of ghetto youths, are moving toward more expansive and mainstream themes with far greater appeal to wider audiences.
Like just about everything else in Hollywood, the change is driven mostly by economics. And to some degree, black directors also yearn to explore new themes. Film makers and studio executives say that the novelty of movies about young people killing each other in the slums has been exhausted and that audiences for such productions are dwindling. 
 More significantly, many black film makers and actors have grown uneasy about, are even embarrassed by, films centered on the ghetto, saying that these movies offer only a narrow portrait of African-American life.
"I would assume studios are just accepting of the fact that there's a greater diversity to our lives than kids in the 'hood, than the drug and violence stories," said the actor Samuel L. Jackson Jr., "and we are taking a prominent place in our society and our films are reflecting that."
Among the coming high-profile films that break the pattern:
"Devil in a Blue Dress," based on Walter Mosley's 1990 novel, which opens on Sept. 29. The film, directed by Carl Franklin, depicts black aspirations and life in postwar Los Angeles and stars Denzel Washington as a private eye who becomes involved in a political and racial scandal in 1948.
"White Man's Burden," a dramatic fantasy starring John Travolta and Harry Belafonte, about an America where blacks are the majority and whites are the minority. The film is to open on Dec. 1.
"Waiting to Exhale," based on Terry McMillan's novel about four middle-class black women yearning for happiness, scheduled for release around Christmas.
To a degree, "Dead Presidents" also falls into this category. Produced and directed by Albert and Allen Hughes, fraternal 22-year-old twins who made the highly praised film "Menace II Society" in 1993, "Dead Presidents" is the saga of young men in the South Bronx who enlist in the Marine Corps during the Vietnam War and their grim return to the streets. It is to open Oct. 4.
While "Clockers," Spike Lee's latest movie, deals with drugs and the ghetto, he has gleefully expressed hope that it will be the final movie of its sort for a while. "It was our intention to be the final nail in the coffin," he said, referring to the category of violent, urban black films. Mr. Lee reluctantly took over the direction of "Clockers" after Martin Scorsese dropped out.
"It's dead! It's over! Move on!" he said. "I loved 'Boyz N the Hood' and 'Menace II Society,' but those other films, I don't know. The genre is at its end now. It's up to African-American film makers to open our vision. If you don't expand and grow, you'll die."
Mr. Lee's next films are "Girl 6," a comedy about an actress in Los Angeles earning a living in the phone-sex business, and "The Jackie Robinson Story," about the first black baseball player in the major leagues.
Stacy Snider, president of production at Tri-Star Studios, which made "Devil in a Blue Dress," suggested that "three or four movies by black film makers this fall are the next evolution."
"The challenge for studios when you do commercials and TV spots for these films," she said, "is to grab the white audiences and say, 'Hey this is different, this is a great story, this does not just appeal to a niche audience.' "
Ms. Snider, who is white, added, "I have far more in common with 'Waiting to Exhale' than 'Die Hard.' "
Younger black film makers, while struggling to find financing for their movies, are almost uniformly reaching beyond drugs and death for their subject matter. Melissa Maxwell, the writer and director of "The Fire This Time," a modest film about the Los Angeles riots, is set to make "Tomboys," about an interracial group of young women in Los Angeles struggling to make a living. Darnell Martin, whose 1994 movie, "I Like It Like That" was about a spirited young Bronx woman, is set to make "Listening to the Dead," a psychological horror film about a racially mixed family, also set in the Bronx.
Leslie Harris, whose "Just Another Girl on the IRT," was a hit at the 1993 Sundance Film Festival, is planning "Royalties, Rhythm and Blues," a thriller about a black female executive in the record industry.
"The problem is financing, of course, and many executives you talk to still expect you to do a 'hood movie," Ms. Harris said. "That's the stigma that's put upon us. But look, the typical black story is not from the 'hood anymore. We are very much entrenched in American society, which means we are starting to deal more and more with the politics, money and job pressures, which are what the American dream is all about."
Studios have sought to attract black audiences, especially teen-agers, since the 1970's, when the so-called black exploitation movies drew unexpectedly large numbers of urban viewers. Those films followed a period in which Sidney Poitier had become the nation's first black movie star with crossover appeal. Mr. Poitier, whose persona in films like "Lilies of the Field," "To Sir, With Love" and "Guess Whose Coming to Dinner" embodied middle-class values and accommodation, fell out of fashion in the turbulent 70's.
"When the civil rights movement and the assasinations happened, there was another cycle of black films, the exploitation films like 'Super Fly' and 'Shaft,' in which the despair comes forth," said Thomas Cripps, a professor at Morgan State University in Baltimore and an authority on black films. "It was almost like the return of the ghetto as an ideal."
These "blaxploitation" movies had a strong appeal for budding young black film makers, among them Mr. Lee and John Singleton, and led in turn to more gritty and realistic depictions of black urban life in which there were few heroes and much violence. Mr. Singleton's "Boyz N the Hood" (1991), caught the attention not only of the critics, who praised its somber look at life in South-Central Los Angeles, but also of the studios, which were impressed by its earnings. The film cost $6 million and has grossed more than $56 million, according to the Exhibitor Relations Company, which monitors movie earnings.
There has since been an almost constant stream of variations on that theme, among them "Menace II Society," "Juice," "Jason's Lyric," "Fresh," "Sugar Hill" and "Above the Rim." Because so many of these films were relatively inexpensive to produce, most were profitable. But black film makers have begun turning away from them, and the audiences have waned, too.
"People were trying to imitate the success of 'Boyz N the Hood' without the heart of it," said Mr. Singleton, who made the film when he was only 22. "This was an extremely personal film. It wasn't created and engineered to make a lot of money. It was, like, autobiographical. I wrote and directed it to get a lot of things in my life off my back. My film came out and there were all these imitations. It was like after 'Jaws' came out; there were films like 'The Great White Death,' and 'Piranha.'
Every studio is aware that black teen-agers are the most frequent moviegoers, and it has become obvious that it doesn't take a steady diet of violence to lure them. "Bad Boys," a comedy about a pair of black policemen, has grossed an unexpected $65 million, and "Dangerous Minds," starring Michelle Pfeiffer as an unlikely teacher in a tough high school, has brought in more than $46 million. (The soundtracks are major hits and contributed to each film's success.)
For serious black film makers, though, making forthright, personal movies remains a struggle in the face of demands by studios. "It's all a little tough, and it's always about economics," said Forest Whitaker, the actor and director who finished shooting "Waiting to Exhale" in May. "With black films, everything becomes a test case. If one explores a new genre and it doesn't do well, that's it. But if someone makes a baseball film and it doesn't work, there'll be another baseball film."
But film makers like Mr. Whitaker, Mr. Singleton and Carl Franklin remain hopeful that a new genre of black films, depicting relationships and themes that have not been explored in the past, will take hold among moviegoers, black and white.
"A lot of people, especially a lot of young blacks, thought that you were not really black unless you were from the 'hood, and there was a pressure somehow to identify with that experience," said Mr. Franklin, who also directed the highly praised low-budget thriller "One False Move." "But I look at Berry Gordy of Motown, who took black music and fused it with a lot of elements of classical music, strings and French horns, and created a sound that the world never heard before."
"And that's what we should do," he said. "People should realize that black people are not just urban, not just confined to the urban experience, that we are more international, more cosmopolitan and certainly more unpredictable than that."

HEADLINE: Security Doesn't Justify Arctic Drilling

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Arctic Refuge Drilling Won't Threaten Wildlife" (letters, Sept. 6) were so rife with errors and outdated information, they demand correction. 
 First, the argument that we must drill our last great wilderness for the sake of national security has been soundly rejected. In this age of diversified energy sources, neither the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries nor any other oil supplier can hold the United States hostage. An editorial in Oil and Gas Journal concluded that "imported oil doesn't harm U.S. security." Even the pro-drilling Alaska Congressional delegation and its allies have rejected this argument by supporting repeal of the longtime ban on Alaska North Slope oil exports.
Second, though the specific area under attack constitutes a fraction of the refuge, it is the "biological heart" and "center of wildlife activity" of the entire refuge, according to the Interior Department.
Third, since the late 1980's the General Accounting Office and United States Geological Survey have updated their projections. The survey has cut its expectations of technically recoverable oil in half, and the newer G.A.O. information leads to the conclusion that the odds of finding economically recoverable oil in the refuge are razor-thin.
Fourth, the most recent Interior Department study concludes that drilling the Arctic Refuge will do far more damage to this fragile wilderness than previously thought. And even the Reagan Administration Interior Department projected serious harm to polar bears, musk ox and snow geese, among other residents of the refuge.
As for the caribou, they use the area under debate to bear and nurse their young. When deep snow doesn't allow them to reach this preferred area in time, calf survival is not nearly as high. Oil drilling activities would drive the pregnant cows from this optimal calving area as they have the caribou that used to calve near Prudhoe Bay. This is one reason the Interior Department predicted a 50 percent drop in the population.
 
SUSAN ALEXANDER
Vice President, Environment
Public Media Center
San Francisco, Sept. 7, 1995

HEADLINE: Visit by Pope Sets the Multitudes in Motion

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

 BODY:
It is no ordinary feat, the hosting and hailing of a Pope. There are choirs to be assembled and hymns to be arranged, paths to be charted for motorcades and priests to be enlisted for the serving of communion to jampacked arenas of the faithful.
And then there is the shopping. 
 Where do you find 10,000 gold-and-white mums to encircle the altar at Giants Stadium in New Jersey? Or 60,000 movable chairs for the throngs who will congregate at Aqueduct Race Track in Queens?
The source for the latter turned out to be a party rental business in Great Neck, L.I. Its owner, Bernard Samet, boasted that he "did not flinch" at the order. "But the carpeting," Mr. Samet said, "now that caught me off guard." He must provide 320,000 square feet to transform the dusty track into the pristine flooring of a holy place.
On Oct. 4, Pope John Paul II is scheduled to touch down at Newark International Airport for four whirlwind days of public and private ceremonies in and around New York City, followed by a single day of similar events in Baltimore.
It is the first time the Pope has toured New York City since 1979 and the first time a Pope has ever visited New Jersey. Befitting that milestone, planners expect 88,000 people for his Mass in Giants Stadium. It would be by far the largest the arena has ever accommodated.
For millions of Catholics in New York and New Jersey, the Pope's visit, a rescheduling of a trip that was canceled last year as he recovered from hip replacement surgery, is a rare opportunity to hear the prayers and heed the blessings of the Pope in the states and cities where they live and worship.
For the legions of Catholic officials organizing the visit, it is all that and more. The Pope's frenetic tour through these parts presents a logistical challenge that is staggering in scale and daunting in detail.
Hardly a minute is unplanned; hardly an hour is unrehearsed. Harried organizers of what might well be described as an ecclesiastical blockbuster fret over matters as large as the equitable distribution of free tickets to the Pope's public ceremonies and as small as the height of the chairs he will occupy.
The seat of his custom-made throne in Giants Stadium will be about 23 inches high, rather than the usual 17 to 18, so the Pope won't have to crouch down and rise up so steeply, potentially aggravating his hip, said those involved in its design.
"The Pope doesn't really sit," said Anthony V. Genovese, a liturgical architect supervising the arrangement of the altar area. "He just leans."
What he will lean against took a Fairview, N.J., furniture maker more than a week to carve by hand from birch wood, to upholster in cardinal red, to paint a pearly white and to gild with shimmering shades of gold leaf.
"Everything is larger than life -- the whole affair," said the craftsman, Hans Kraenzlein, who has also built a 64-square-foot altar, the biggest he has ever made.
Mr. Kraenzlein, a Catholic, said there was now only one more exalted boss for whom he could work: God. "I'm hoping I have a little more time before that happens," he said.
Mr. Kraenzlein is not alone in feeling a sense of honor in being able to take some essential part in the Pope's tour.
In northern New Jersey, 2,000 Catholic schoolchildren are readying greetings and carefully chosen wardrobes for their special role in welcoming the Pope at the airport.
And in Brooklyn, 400 Catholic singers from diverse backgrounds have practiced 45 hours for their moment onstage beside the Pope during the Mass at Aqueduct.
Brian Zuar, director of music ministry for the Diocese of Brooklyn, said the choir had learned songs in Korean and other languages so that its program would reflect the diversity of Catholics in New York City.
The preparations for the Pope's Masses at Giants Stadium, Aqueduct and Central Park illuminate a little-known but bustling economy of architects and other artisans who specialize in the sacred. D'Ambrosio Ecclesiastical Art Studios, a company in Mount Kisco, N.Y., will provide the altar at Aqueduct, a wedge of Vermont green and Carrara white marble that weighs three tons.
The preparations also forge a curious alliance between the worlds of religion and rock-and-roll, spirituality and show business.
At most of the Pope's appearances, there will be enormous TV screens and speaker systems to make certain that everyone inside the venues -- and, in some cases, outside -- can see and hear.
For Giants Stadium, Catholic officials have hired concert sound consultants whose previous clients included the Electric Light Orchestra and Linda Ronstadt.
For Central Park, officials have hired production managers whose past gigs include Wigstock, the annual showcase of the city's most flamboyant female impersonators.
And for both those venues and Aqueduct, officials have hired a stage builder whose platforms have previously supported the likes of Madonna and Michael Jackson.
The builder, Jim Evans, who owns a Pennsylvania company, Mountain Productions, said he had never before worked with so many people looking over his shoulder, from Vatican representatives to United States Secret Service agents.
To transport all the staging for the Pope's various appearances, Mr. Evans estimated that he would use 52 tractor-trailers.
By one estimate, there will be more than 1,000 portable toilets in Central Park; more than 1,400 buses transporting people to and from Giants Stadium; more than 250,000 communion wafers available at the three large Masses, and more than 75,000 rosaries distributed at the Aqueduct service.
That's not to mention Mr. Samet's 60,000 chairs. While Giants Stadium has extensive permanent seating and Central Park won't provide many people with perches, Aqueduct needs to erect impromptu pews from scratch.
All of this will cost plenty. The Archdiocese of Newark expects to spend $1.1 million. The Diocese of Brooklyn puts its costs at $1.5 million. The Archdiocese of New York has not released a figure, but a spokesman, Joseph Zwilling, said its expenditures should well exceed those of Newark or Brooklyn.
By church custom, the expenses of a papal visit are borne by the host Catholic dioceses. Each diocese in the New York City area will try to recoup its costs primarily through special calls for contributions at parishes in coming weeks.
Some dioceses also hope to benefit from the sale of memorabilia. The official merchant of souvenirs, Robbi Promotional Advertising of Newark, N.J., is offering about 25 products ranging from T-shirts to video cassettes.
What all of this planning and effort will create is the opportunity for Catholics to get closer to the Pope than many ever anticipated they would. Between Giants Stadium, Aqueduct, Central Park and smaller events at St. Joseph Seminary in Yonkers, Sacred Heart Cathedral in Newark and St. Patrick's Cathedral in Manhattan, there are nearly 300,000 tickets.
None of the tickets, however, is up for grabs; most have been allocated to various dioceses in New York and New Jersey to be distributed randomly to parishes within those dioceses, while a smaller percentage have been set aside for religious orders and special groups -- like organizations of young Catholics -- whom the Pope would like to reach.
 
Seeing the Pope
 These are the major sites the Pope will be visiting in and around New York City.
 
WEDNESDAY, OCT. 4
Sacred Heart Cathedral, Newark: The Pope will hold a 5 P.M. prayer service for about 1,800 people. The public can gather in streets around the cathedral for what will be the only unticketed appearance by the Pope during his entire tour.
 
THURSDAY, OCT. 5
United Nations: The Pope's morning address to the General Assembly not open to the public.
Giants Stadium, the Meadowlands, N.J: The Pope will celebrate a 6 P.M. Mass. Most tickets will be distributed to dioceses in New Jersey.
 
FRIDAY, OCT. 6
Aqueduct Race Track, Queens: The Pope will celebrate a 9:30 A.M. Mass. The Diocese of Brooklyn controls the majority of tickets, but is donating 15,000 tickets to the Diocese of Rockville Center, L.I..
St. Joseph's Seminary, Yonkers: The Pope will address seminarians in a private ceremony. But 20,000 ticketed people will gather on the grounds for a tour by the Pope.
 
SATURDAY, OCT. 7
Central Park: The Pope will celebrate a 9:30 A.M. Mass on the Great Lawn. Tickets will go to Catholic youth youth groups and schoolchildren, with most of the rest distributed in the Archdiocese of New York. People without tickets can gather in a meadow north of the Great Lawn and watch the service on a large screen.
St. Patrick's Cathedral: The Pope will recite the rosary in a 3:30 P.M. prayer service for about 4,000 people with tickets.

HEADLINE: Triumph and Loss As Wolves Return To Yellowstone

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

DATELINE: YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK, Wyo.

 BODY:
THE evening breeze had died and a setting sun was gilding the slopes of the Lamar Valley as Mike Phillips gazed across the steep ravine of Rose Creek and whispered to a visitor, "That area of matted grass to the left of the aspens and the right of the sagebrush -- see it?"
There, perhaps 500 yards away, a young, gray female wolf was taking her ease. Three other young wolves, all black, soon came into view through the binoculars. Now 19 weeks old, a little bigger than coyotes and nearly half grown, the four are part of a litter of eight, the first known reproduction by resident wolves in the Yellowstone ecosystem in seven decades and a signal step toward rescuing the gray wolf from the endangered list. 
 It is a tale of triumph and tragedy with touches of soap opera. The unexpected birth and early survival of the Rose Creek "puppies," as their Federal monitors call them, has helped make the first seven months of the highly controversial effort to restore wolves to Yellowstone more successful than expected. But the father of the pups, a majestic, 122-pound, deep-voiced gray alpha male from Canada simply called Ten, was shot and killed, Federal officials charge, by an unemployed carpenter who took the pelt and head. If convicted, he faces a possible term in Federal prison for killing a member of an endangered species.
The mother of the pups, a black wolf called Nine, abandoned but unwilling to move lest her mate return, gave birth on exposed bare ground, with no protective den, near the town of Red Lodge, Mont., on the outskirts of greater Yellowstone. Federal wildlife biologists recaptured the mother and three-week-old pups and returned them to the fenced enclosure on Rose Creek where Nine and Ten met, mated and lived during their first two months in Yellowstone before being released to the wild.
There, Park Service biologists led by Mr. Phillips, the manager of the Yellowstone wolf recovery effort, have been acting as surrogate fathers, providing the pups with meat. All eight pups escaped in late July when fallen trees broke the fencing of their pen, explaining the presence of the four on the side of the ravine (one of the four has since been recaptured). Their mother has not left the pen, which has been re-secured, so the escapees stay reasonably close.
Ten left a precious legacy: with his many offspring there are now nearly 25 wolves in Yellowstone and the wolf reintroduction project has taken a major leap toward its goal of 100 wolves, or 10 packs, by 2002. When that goal has also been reached in two other areas, in Utah and northwestern Montana, the gray wolf is to be taken off the endangered list in the contiguous 48 states. The species is plentiful and not endangered in Alaska and Canada.
The Yellowstone reintroduction project began last January when three groups of wolves trapped in Canada were put into widely separated acclimation pens in the Lamar Valley. The project has been "extremely successful," said Dr. L. David Mech, an adviser to the project and a leading wolf expert who is with the National Biological Service based at the University of Minnesota in St. Paul.
First, he says, the wolves have bred successfully this year, despite the stress of being moved from their native habitat in Canada and then kept in pens. They had not been expected to reproduce before next year.
Second, they have not migrated back to Alberta since being released from the pens in March, as had been feared. Third, they have killed none of the livestock on the fringes of the park, although it is assumed they will do so eventually. Many ranchers vehemently opposed the reintroduction plan, even though experience in northwestern Montana, where wolves have reappeared naturally in the last decade, has shown that wolf attacks on livestock are rare and that wolves prefer the wild game with which they evolved over the millenniums. Here, as in Montana, ranchers are to be reimbursed for any documented losses to wolves, from a compensation fund maintained by the Defenders of Wildlife, a conservation group in Washington.
All in all, says Dr. Mech, "it is a wonderful start to a monumental conservation effort."
The return of the wolves has struck a chord with the public. Rick McIntyre, a park ranger who leads "wolf hikes" in the Lamar Valley and lectures on wolves, has spoken to almost 40,000 people this summer, confirming the argument that wolves can increase tourism in the region.
But not all opponents have conceded. In July, the Senate Appropriations Committee approved a measure introduced by Conrad Burns, Republican of Montana, to cut funds for the wolf restoration project.
Wildlife biologists say still more animals must be introduced into Yellowstone to assure genetic diversity and hasten the gray wolf's exit from the list of endangered species.
The wolf was the top predator in Yellowstone, and a keystone species of its ecology, until 1926. It was then that the last two animals were killed by park rangers near Soda Butte in the Lamar Valley as part of a formal extermination program. One of three new packs introduced from Canada now bears the name of Soda Butte, after the site of the temporary pen where the wolves were kept to break their homing instinct.
On its release the Soda Butte pack headed north, to a wilderness area in Montana outside the park, then retreated south again. The pack seems to have settled around the park's northern border, radio tracking of the wolves' movements shows.
A second group, called the Crystal Bench pack, has settled farther south, adopting the Lamar River as the northern boundary of its territory.
Once released from their acclimation pen last March, the Crystal Bench wolves romped in the snow, rolled on their backs and looked for all the world as if they were celebrating. In the following weeks they conducted a seminar in wolf behavior and ecology for their discreet human observers. The younger wolves chased and ambushed one another, occasionally tossing up a chunk of meat and leaping to catch it in midair. Once, a young pronghorn antelope teased a yearling wolf, shifting into warp speed and leaving the wolf in the dust when it tried to pursue.
The pack also encountered a grizzly bear and her two cubs. With their weak eyesight, the bears at first ran away but then regrouped as if realizing, in Mr. McIntyre's words, "Hey, we don't have to run from these guys, they're just wolves." After a tense nose-to-nose confrontation between the mother bear and the wolves' alpha female, the two sides engaged in mutual chasing back and forth before declaring a standoff.
On another occasion, as hundreds of people watched, three young wolves teamed up to steal from a grizzly an elk calf it had killed.
One observer captured on videotape the wolves' tactics in killing a calf themselves. They picked one calf out of the herd and gave chase. Unable to outrun the wolves, it dropped down into the grass in an attempt to hide. When the mother elk rushed to protect it, the wolves harassed the mother from several directions. The mother chased one wolf a little too far, upon which the others pounced on the calf. Other elk came to help, but it was too late.
Another videotape shows the pack tentative and uncertain around bison. Wolves historically preyed on bison, but these Canadian transplants have had no previous experience with them. On the tape, the bison took no guff and easily routed the wolves by charging them in a mini-stampede. The wolves may be learning, however. Following elk back from their high-country summer pastures to a cooler and briefly snow-dusted Lamar Valley late last month, they met the bison again. This time the bison fled. The wolves did not make a kill but appeared instead to be testing the big beasts.
What all this adds up to, says Mr. McIntyre, is a restoration of natural ecological processes. The effects of the wolves' predation are expected in time to ripple through the Yellowstone ecosystem, helping reduce swollen elk herds, improving the herds' genetic health by weeding out the weak and sick, taking some pressure off vegetation eaten by overabundant elk, creating carrion for an array of scavengers and affecting natural relationships in thousands of small ways.
But the birth of the family of Nine and Ten has been the big surprise of the project, and has provided its most poignant moments. Nine and Ten, who had never previously laid eyes on each other, were put in the Rose Creek acclimation pen along with Nine's 10-month-old female pup to become the nucleus of a new pack. Immediately, Ten tried to dominate Nine through threatening behavior, but Nine, being an alpha female, did not cower as wolf hierarchy decrees. Soon they were, in wolf terms, a heavy item.
When the trio was released in March, Ten bounded out right away. But a pregnant Nine, apparently afraid of the gate, which she associated with her human captors, refused to leave. The big male stayed around for five days, trying to coax out his mate. The fact that he would do so, knowing feared humans were about, shows how strong the bonding is between wolves, said Mr. McIntyre.
After Nine did finally leave, the pair struck out north-northeast, toward Red Lodge. Nine's daughter separated from the pair and headed into the north-central part of the park, to its Hellroaring area, where she is successfully killing prey as a lone wolf. It was on April 26 that Ten's radio collar sent out the accelerated series of beeps that signals death.
His offspring are almost ideal from the standpoint of the reintroduction project: four females, three black and one gray, designated 16 through 19, and four black males, named 20 through 23. "It's a great litter," says Mr. Phillips.
The pups now weigh perhaps 35 pounds each but are not yet competent hunters. Mr. Phillips says they probably have not yet even advanced to the preliminary "mousing" stage of learning to hunt. Besides, their permanent teeth are not yet fully developed.
Chad McKittrick, the man accused of killing Ten, goes on trial on Oct. 2 in Federal District Court in Billings, Mont. Sherry Scheel Matteucci, the prosecutor, intends to seek the maximum penalty of two years in prison or a $150,000 fine. "I want the message to be clearly sent," she said. "You mess with these animals and you will pay a substantial price."
If all continues to go well, Nine and her pups should be released around the time of the trial or soon afterward. Then will begin another phase of the saga. Nine has been unlucky in love; she was separated from a Canadian mate by civilian trappers who captured her for the reward, and the previous mate may have been killed as well. Will she pick out a new mate from the Crystal Bench pack, as biologists hope, thus promoting some lucky young wolf to alpha status? Will her daughter do the same?
The soap opera continues, and on its outcome depends the future integrity of the Yellowstone ecosystem.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Mitsubishi Plans to Scrap Stake in Rockefeller Center
Mitsubishi Estate plans to walk away from its investment of almost $2 billion in Rockefeller Center and pass ownership to the real estate investment trust that holds the $1.3 billion mortgage on the bankrupt property. 
 Mitsubishi made its proposal in a meeting with the trust's management, according to advisers involved in the negotiations. The plan would also apparently sever the last ties to the Rockefeller family. [Page A1.]
 
Mitsubishi's decision to walk away from Rockefeller Center is likely to symbolize Japanese folly to Americans, just as its purchase came to symbolize a perceived Japanese "threat" in the 1980's. [D6.]
 
Daimler-Benz Reports Loss
Daimler-Benz reported a net loss of $1.06 billion in the first half, as the mark's strength against the dollar caused the German company to take a charge of $816 million. [D4.]
 
Pataki Says Lilco Should Go
Governor George E. Pataki called for the dissolution of the Long Island Lighting Company, indicating that move was central to cutting Long Island's electric rates. [A1.]
 
Dollar Above 100 Yen
Piercing the psychological barrier of 100 yen, the dollar rose to an eight-month high in Asian trading today on expectations that the Bank of Japan would intervene again in the foreign-exchange markets. [D8.]
 
Stocks advanced, with traders focusing on the growth of corporate earnings. [D12.]
 
Hackers Caught in Computer Sting
The United States Secret Service arrested at least six computer hackers after setting up a sting operation by using a computer bulletin board to troll for people illegally trafficking in cellular telephone codes. [B1.]
 
Hughes to Buy Magnavox
Hughes Aircraft has agreed to buy Magnavox Electronic Systems, which makes military systems, from the Carlyle Group for $370 million in cash. [D2.]
 
Merger in Forest Industry
United Paper Mills and the Kymmene Corporation have agreed to merge, creating Europe's largest forestry company. [D4.]
 
Pickens Steps Back From Plan
T. Boone Pickens, chairman of Mesa Inc., said he would exclude himself from a controversial "golden parachute" severance plan. [D2.]
 
G.M. Settles Truck Lawsuits
G.M. has settled four lawsuits resulting from fatal crashes and fires involving pickup trucks with side-mounted gasoline tanks. [A16.]
 
The Struggle of Russian Banks
With little good information to guide them, and not much regulation, Russians face a choice among thousands of banks, but the weaker ones have begun failing. [A1.]
 
Surveys See Soft Landing
The consensus of the National Association of Business Economists and the newsletter Blue Chip Economic Indicators is that the economy has reached a soft landing. [D2.]
 
CBS Puts Muscle Behind Show
CBS is undertaking all types of unorthodox marketing tactics to build buzz for "Central Park West," as the network tries to attract younger audiences. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D10.]
 
Buchwald Settles Movie Claim
Paramount Pictures and Art Buchwald have agreed to settle their seven-year dispute over the film "Coming to America," with Mr. Buchwald and a co-plaintiff, Alain Bernheim, being paid more than $1 million. [D5.]

HEADLINE: In New Economy, Russians Cannot Rely on Their Banks

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 11

 BODY:
The Moskovsky Gorodskoi Bank does not have a cash machine. It does not have a customer service desk or loan officers. It does not have deposit insurance. And at the moment it does not have the $500 that Vladimir A. Shcherbakov entrusted to it.
As he stood outside the bank's main branch, a dilapidated storefront, Mr. Shcherbakov, who needed his money to buy a car, was confronted first by a sign saying no withdrawals could be made for 10 days. Then he was confronted by two men with shiny suits blocking the door, telling him politely but firmly to go away. 
 It seems that the bank's chairman, Anton Dolgov, disappeared late last month, taking with him a large but unspecified amount of the bank's money, according to Russian newspapers. Then the bank, which used the advertising slogan "A Nice Bank Is a Stable Bank," got caught in a nationwide banking crisis that briefly paralyzed the entire Russian financial system at the end of August and pushed Moskovsky Gorodskoi Bank, or Moscow City Bank, to the brink of collapse.
In Russia, banking has developed a reputation as a risky business, especially for bankers, who are gunned down with horrifying frequency by mobsters intent on intimidation and extortion.
But it is no picnic either for ordinary Russians who want someplace to put their money. With little good information to guide them, and not much regulation to rein in unscrupulous or unqualified bankers, Russians face a choice among thousands of institutions of wildly varying strength and probity, most of which have sprung up since the country began its shift to a market economy.
The situation has become particularly dicey in the last few weeks as weaker banks have begun failing and Russia has woken up to just how shaky its financial system is. The stakes are high, and not only for depositors and bankers.
The Government's efforts to stabilize the economy have brought down inflation, but have left most Russians insecure if not disillusioned or angry about their march toward capitalism. With parliamentary elections coming in December and a presidential election scheduled for June, a major financial crisis could have serious political consequences.
Moreover, Russia's ability to stabilize its nascent banking system will be a big factor in determining the speed and success of its entire economic metamorphosis. Companies need well-run, honest banks to provide financing for modernization and expansion -- a role that very few Russian banks are willing or able to play today. And consumers need banks to help modernize a system of handling money that remains primitive by the standards of the United States or Western Europe.
"I've got no idea if I'll get my money back," Mr. Shcherbakov, a 42-year-old civil servant, said as he paced nervously in front of his bank. "I'm resigned to losing it. But if I do get it back, I'll change my rubles into dollars and hold on to it myself."
There are more than 2,500 banks in Russia. They include about 50 big institutions that assert that they will soon rival American and European banks in sophistication if not stability.
The rest are a grab bag, ranging from fronts set up to launder money for organized crime to legitimate institutions that do little traditional banking business but concentrate on currency speculation or a variety of other investment schemes.
Officials at Russia's central bank estimate that 300 small banks are in dire financial straits. They said they are already planning to revoke the licenses of about 80 of them.
Some bankers say that a greater number of banks are at risk, and that the failures will include medium-sized and bigger banks.
"I expect more problems for the banking system," said Boris Sergeyev, a director of Toko Bank, one of the larger and more stable of Russia's banks. "It's a stage in the development of the banking system, and it will result in the failure of many of the less professionally managed banks."
Partly because of the state of the banking system, Russia remains a cash-driven economy. Checks are almost nonexistent. Banks constantly send crateloads of currency around Moscow in armored trucks that speed through the streets like ambulances, lights flashing and sirens wailing.
Workers are usually paid in cash, and many of them so distrust banks that they keep their money under their mattresses -- sometimes literally -- even if it means sacrificing some of the value of their rubles to inflation. The most popular form of money management by far is to exchange rubles, which have declined precipitously in value, for dollars. Most big banks advertise for dollar deposits.
No one, it seems, is immune to the problems of the banks. Mayor Yuri Luzhkov of Moscow complained on Thursday that even the city could not get access to all of its money, with its banks limiting it to about a quarter of the daily withdrawals it wanted to make.
In a survey released on Friday, the Center for International Sociological Studies, a research institute based in Moscow, found that 65 percent of respondents in big cities around the country said they were being hurt by the banking crisis.
The survey, of 4,000 people in six cities, found that while 27.5 percent of respondents would choose to save their money in Sberbank, the state-run savings institution that is regarded as the safest and most conservative option, 53 percent would choose not to put their money in any bank at all.
Last month's crisis, set off when banks stopped lending to one another, fearful that they would not be repaid, was the clearest sign yet of how far Russia's financial development has to go. Because banks rely on short-term loans from one another to keep their operations going, the freezing up of the so-called interbank market brought the whole industry to a halt.
That crisis eased somewhat after several days when the central bank stepped in with emergency loans to get the system operating by encouraging banks to lend to one another. But bankers said the system could grind to a halt again at any time -- a situation that has made depositors that much more nervous and led more people to seek to withdraw their money, making the crisis even more acute.
The crisis is rapidly separating the well-managed banks from those that probably cannot survive. Many others have survived so far only because high inflation and the tumbling value of the ruble have made it easy for anyone with cash to make money.
In its simplest form, the strategy followed by many banks has been to take in deposits in rubles, convert them into dollars, wait for inflation and the declining value of the ruble to erode the Russian currency's value, and then convert the dollars back into a far greater number of rubles than they started with.
The opportunities to make that kind of easy money are rapidly drawing to an end, however. Inflation has fallen from 18 percent a month at the beginning of this year to less than 5 percent a month. The ruble's value has stabilized at around 4,500 to the dollar, roughly half its value of a year ago, and the Government has committed itself to keeping the currency within a range of 4,300 to 4,900 for the rest of the year.
That Russia has a sizable banking system at all is something of an accomplishment. Under the Soviet system, banking was largely limited to a relatively few institutions that funneled state subsidies to industry or handled specialized tasks like financing foreign trade.
Some of the banks that line Moscow's streets today are well on their way to meeting Western standards. The bigger banks issue Visa cards, and a few, like Most Bank, are now issuing their own debit cards, which allow customers to have purchases charged directly to their bank accounts. There are a few cash machines scattered around town, though they remain novelties.
There are 10 big foreign banks operating in Russia, including Citibank and Chase Manhattan from the United States. Restricted in size by Russian regulation and wary of the risks of operating here, they finance trade, make some business loans and trade Government bonds, but are not big forces in Russian banking.
For Russians, it is still easy to pick the wrong bank, as many are now finding out.
At the headquarters of a medium-sized institution called Chasprombank on Friday, two dozen depositors out of several thousand who had placed their savings with the institution were demanding to know why they could not get their money out. The bank had ordered them not to stand at the front door, but instead to wait in back in a muddy courtyard occupied by some aging cars and a mangy dog. No one from the bank was around to give any answers.
Instead, depositors were directed to a bulletin board, where the bank had posted copies of letters it had sent to the central bank seeking a bailout from its financial problems. There was also a list of how depositors would be ranked when it came to getting their money back. First would come war veterans and pensioners, then Heroes of the Soviet Union and Heroes of Socialist Labor, then everyone else.
"I will never trust anybody again!" shrieked an elderly woman, who declined to give her name. She said that she wanted her $250 in savings to help pay for her mother's burial, but that she was No. 353 on a list of depositors seeking to get their money out.
"I wouldn't give anybody a single kopeck ever again," she said.

HEADLINE: Alaska Republicans Push Subsidy for Logging

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: KETCHIKAN, Alaska

 BODY:
The rivers rushing from the steep, misted forests of the Alaska Panhandle are clogged with salmon, as a massive surge of coho moves upstream to spawn and die. In towns like Sitka and Ketchikan, the once-rowdy docks are similarly clogged -- but with tourists, disgorged by the thousands from cruise ships.
All summer long, restaurants have been full. Hotels and lodges have been booked. Seafood processors are rushing to harvest, freeze and ship out some of the prodigious protein that courses through saltwater inlets here. Never before have there been so many jobs in Southeast Alaska. 
 Yet, for all the apparent prosperity, this region of big fish, big trees and big fortunes needs an old-fashioned Government jobs program to keep it from sinking into a harsh recession, according to legislation being pushed by Alaska's all-Republican Congressional delegation.
The state's two Senators, newly installed in two of the most powerful committee positions in Congress, are pushing a bill that would require the Federal Government to provide Southeast Alaska with 2,400 timber jobs -- at a cost to taxpayers of up to $30 million a year, according to Forest Service estimates. The area now has about half that many jobs in timber.
In Alaska, where the politics of pork has long been a much stronger guiding principle than ideology, the fight over timber jobs has put the two major political parties at odds with their national identities. Here, it is the Republicans who are pushing for a deficit-adding jobs bill and the Democrats who are saying that free enterprise should be allowed to work the kind of market magic that is finally taking hold in this state.
Senator Frank H. Murkowski, the chief sponsor of the bill, says timber jobs are the best-paying in the area and provide for long-term stability. He says the Forest Service has reneged on a promise to provide a certain amount of logs to the industry from the vast Tongass National Forest.
But critics say that if the two Alaskan Senators were promoting midnight basketball programs, instead of money-losing timber jobs, their Southeast Alaska Jobs and Communities Protection Act, would be laughed out of the Senate.
Even supporters worry that the bill, co-sponsored by Mr. Murkow ski's fellow Republican, Senator Ted Stevens, might be a tough sell.
Chris Gates, the spokesman for the Alaska Forest Association, whose timber industry members have the most to gain by the bill, said, "If you try to be honest and say it's a jobs bill, it sounds like you're talking about some kind of Communist make-work program."
The push for mandatory timber jobs comes as southeast Alaska has just posted its best employment figures in five years. State officials say the unemployment rate in the Panhandle for July was 5.2 percent, while the national average was 5.9 percent. While timber jobs declined by 40 percent in the last four years, the area added thousands of jobs in seafood processing, tourism and government.
The timber jobs bill and a similar measure that Mr. Stevens has added as a rider to the Interior Department's appropriations bill would make the Tongass the only national forest where jobs were the pre-eminent purpose of managing the land. As chairman of the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee, Mr. Murkowski is in a position to guide the bill through Congress. Mr. Stevens ranks second on the Appropriations Committee.
But nothing in the tortured history of the Tongass has ever been typical. At 17 million acres, it is the largest national forest in America, with the nation's only intact temperate-zone rain forest. Its islands of spruce and hemlock, most of them unpopulated and never logged, are one reason this area is considered the salmon capital of the world. Sportsmen flock here, chasing trophy king salmon of up to 50 pounds. And for those who run commercial boats, the term millionaire fisherman is not an oxymoron.
Because of the distance from markets, the rough terrain and harsh weather -- it rains 150 inches a year in the Panhandle -- large-scale logging has seldom been profitable. It was the Federal Government, in the late 1950's, that created the timber industry, to provide jobs to a sparsely populated area. The Government promised two large companies that if they set up pulp mills here they would be assured a long-term supply of cheap wood from the Tongass. For years, two companies paid less than the price of a cheeseburger for a 500-year-old tree.
But two years ago one of the original mills, run by the Japanese-owned Alaska Pulp Company, closed its plant in Sitka, putting 400 people out of work. It also closed a sawmill in the town of Wrangell, with the loss of nearly 200 jobs.
Now, Southeast Alaska is left with only one big timber concern, the Ketchikan Pulp Company, which provides nearly 1,000 jobs at its mill here. But it, too, is threatening to leave Alaska. The company says the Forest Service is not allowing it to cut enough logs to run a profitable operation.
The Clinton Administration has "created a shortage that is political," said Troy Reinhart, a spokesman for Ketchikan Pulp. Senator Murkowski's bill, he said, would give the company the wood it needs.
Typically, a company bids for timber on Government-owned land. In most national forests, the Government breaks even on these sales or makes some money. But figures show that in the last three years the Government lost $20 million on the timber program in the Tongass National Forest. Industry blames Government inefficiency for the loss, rather than the logistical problems of building roads and other basics that the Government cites.
Critics say the real reason the company may pull up stakes is that it must invest nearly $70 million to clean up the water that has been polluted by waste discharges from its pulp-making operations. Company executives have pleaded guilty to 14 criminal counts of violating Federal pollution laws. The mill grinds logs into pulp, which is then sent overseas and converted into such things as rayon.
Long accustomed to a cozy relationship with managers of the Tongass National Forest, the timber industry has in recent years turned against them, filing lawsuits and castigating the rangers as pawns of environmentalists. "There is absolutely no control over those people running the Tongass," said Mr. Gates, the forest association spokesman. "They're protecting rocks over people. If you just let the industry lay out these timber sales, we could make money for the Government."
Administration officials say they are trying to run the Tongass for wildlife, fishing and tourism, as well as logging. "Our role is not to favor one industry over the other," said Jim Lyons, the Assistant Agriculture Secretary in charge of the United States Forest Service. "We can't manage the national forests by threat from either industry or environmentalists."
In the past, such criticism was dismissed here as typical Washington disregard for the concerns of average Alaskans. But more than ever, timber industry critics come from within the state. Senator Murkowski canceled a series of formal hearings in Alaska and in the capital on his bill after it became clear that many people in his home state opposed it. Instead, Mr. Murkowski held informal workshops to gauge public reaction.
In Sitka, where the mill closed two years ago, the Senator was greeted in August by hostile demonstrators and a crowd that overwhelmingly opposed the bill. It was criticized as "corporate welfare" and labeled by one environmental group as "the Tongass timber baron revival bill."
In Ketchikan, the logging stronghold of the Panhandle, speakers were almost evenly divided, though dozens of demonstrators held up signs supporting the bill.
The most significant opposition, perhaps, came from Gov. Tony Knowles, a Democrat. He had supported other efforts by the Alaska Congressional delegation to open the state to development, notably to oil drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. But on the Tongass, he parted company with the Republicans, saying that more logging was likely to threaten a booming and diversified economy in the southeast.
"This assumes that radical surgery from Washington, D.C., is needed to help our local communities," said the Governor's director of commerce and economic development, Willie Hensley. "Ironically, this notion of a planned or centralized economy is actually counterproductive to the goal of creating a strong, diverse economy."
Tourism jobs have increased 40 percent in four years, state officials say. Ketchikan tour operators like Dale Pihlman, who runs a fleet of boats taking visitors to places like the nearby Misty Fjords National Monument, says the timber bill, with the pollution and logging it would entail, would directly hurt his business.
"The visitor industry is more profitable and has a higher payroll by far than the timber industry," Mr. Pihlman said, "yet I can never get Senator Murkowski to listen to a word of our concerns. People in Southeast Alaska are finally realizing that untouched wilderness is a big resource. But our senators still don't get it."
This month, Senator Murkowski sold his stock in the Louisiana Pacific Corporation, which owns the mill in Ketchikan. He says his interest in mandating timber jobs has less to do with helping the mill and more to do with trying to get the Forest Service to live up to promises it made to keep a certain job base in Alaska.
The problem, critics say, is that keeping a certain number of timber jobs amounts to a direct Federal subsidy at a time when Congress is trying to balance the budget.
In the face of opposition within the state to the timber bill, Mr. Murkowski now says it may be dead until next year. But in place of the bill would be the rider that Senator Stevens attached to the appropriations bill. That clause would require more logging in the Tongass National Forest, over the objections of those who run the forest.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Alaska's members of Congress are seeking to add jobs in the timber industry by allowing more cutting of trees in the Tongass National Forest, which includes Taku Inlet in the southeastern part of the state. (Don Pitcher/Alaska Stock Images)

HEADLINE: Clinton Urges Fight to Keep Student Loans

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: CARBONDALE, Ill., Sept. 11

 BODY:
Seeking to rally public support for student loan programs, President Clinton told a cheering university crowd here today that in the changing global economy "unless we better educate our people, too many of them will be left behind."
The President struck populist tones in attacking bankers and Washington lobbyists, as he fought for a program enacted by Congress in 1993 over the objections of banks to let the Government make direct college loans to students, who have a longer time than under the previous system to repay them. 
 The Republican-run Congress is considering scaling back or limiting the loan program in its effort to balance the Federal budget over seven years, arguing that a Federal bureaucracy is not needed to offer student loans and that loan volume will not be affected by shifting student loans back to the private sector.
But in his campaign-style appearance at Southern Illinois University here, Mr. Clinton attacked the loan system used before the direct Government loans, under which the Government guaranteed loans offered by banks. He said that system was "more cumbersome" and that it would "cost the students more money, which will lead to fewer people taking advantage of the loan program." He added, "But the banks will make their money back."
Mr. Clinton's address before a cheering crowd of thousands was fed by satellite to rallies in Minnesota, Louisiana and California, where he lobbied for education spending just last week at a middle school in the heavily agricultural Central Valley.
With the budget battle with Congress moving into high gear, Administration officials called the appearances part of an effort to put Republicans in Congress on the defensive over their plans to find $36 billion in savings in Federal education and training programs. And Mr. Clinton unabashedly urged his listeners: "Help me. Stand up. Write your members of Congress."
Vice President Al Gore made a similar stop today at the University of Pittsburgh, and 47 other Administration officials are being dispatched to education-related events around the country this week.
Mr. Clinton's own plan to balance the budget over 10 years calls for increased spending on education.
"The unmistakable fault line in America over who makes it and who doesn't today more than ever before is education," the President said. "So as we go back to school and the Congress goes back to work, the question is, Will your country continue to help those who want to help themselves."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Campaigning against Republican plans to change direct Government loans to college students, President Clinton was joined yesterday by Senator Paul Simon at Southern Illinois University in Carbondale. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Charles Hitch, 85, Dies; Led Turbulent U. of California

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
Charles J. Hitch, who served as president of the University of California at a time of campus unrest, budgetary restraints and legislative and administrative intervention, died yesterday in a rest home in San Leandro, Calif. Mr. Hitch, who lived in Berkeley, Calif., was 85.
An economist and Rhodes scholar who compiled an impressive record in academic and administrative posts, Mr. Hitch came to the nation's largest education institution -- then nine campuses with an enrollment approaching 90,000 -- from the Pentagon. As an Assistant Secretary of Defense from 1961 to 1965 in the Administrations of John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson, Mr. Hitch was the controller who revolutionized military budgeting and prepared detailed military spending plans that accounted for roughly 55 cents of every dollar taxpayers paid the Federal Government. 
 In May 1965, he announced that he was leaving his post at the Pentagon to become vice chancellor of the University of California, where he would manage fiscal affairs.
In September 1967, the regents of the university ended a seven-month quest for a new president by unanimously choosing Mr. Hitch, then 57, to succeed Dr. Clark Kerr, whom they had dismissed the previous January, not long after the election of Gov. Ronald Reagan. Mr. Reagan had criticized Dr. Kerr frequently during his campaign and moved to cut higher education appropriations soon after taking office.
When Mr. Hitch became president of the University of California, it was already three years into the era of student activism ushered in by the Free Speech Movement at Berkeley. The pragmatic Mr. Hitch tried to steer a course through the acrimony generated by restive, sometimes riotous students and a punitive Governor and Legislature.
Mr. Hitch's efforts to retain the university's autonomy were not always successful. The university was compelled to abandon its free-tuition policy, to surrender to the regents its authority to appoint and promote tenured faculty and to take orders from the Legislature on disciplining students.
In 1975, when student unrest had given way to increased concern over budget cuts, Mr. Hitch retired. It had been announced the previous October that he had been elected president of Resources for the Future, a research organization in Washington concerned with natural resources. He retired in 1978.
Charles Johnson Hitch was born on Jan. 9, 1910, in Boonville, Mo. His father, Arthur, was a teacher and administrator at the Kemper Military School and College in Boonville, where Mr. Hitch graduated from the junior college in 1929.
Mr. Hitch received a bachelor of arts degree in economics from the University of Arizona in 1931. After a year of graduate work at Harvard, he won a Rhodes scholarship to Oxford University, where he earned a master's in 1935 and taught at Queen's College until 1948, with time out for World War II.
During the war, Mr. Hitch served as a staff economist on W. Averell Harriman's first lend-lease mission in London and with the War Production Board in Washington. In 1943, Mr. Hitch joined the Army and was assigned to the Office of Strategic Services. Two years later, he was discharged as a first lieutenant.
In 1948, Mr. Hitch joined the Rand Corporation, the nonprofit research organization. While there, Mr. Hitch and Ronald N. McKean wrote "The Economics of Defense in the Nuclear Age" (Harvard University Press, 1960). That work prompted Robert S. McNamara, who was to become Secretary of Defense, to invite Mr. Hitch to join President-elect Kennedy's Administration.
At the Pentagon, Mr. Hitch scrapped the system in which each service presented budget claims for programs that often conflicted. Mr. Hitch budgeted functionally, according to missions, and projected costs over five years.
Mr. Hitch's wife, the former Nancy Winslow Squire, whom he married in 1942, died in 1983. He is survived by his daughter, Caroline Hitch Rubio of Hayward, Calif., and two grandchildren.

HEADLINE: U.S. No Longer A Land Steeped In Wanderlust

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
A smaller percentage of Americans are pulling up their roots and moving out of state than at any time since 1950, the Census Bureau said today, suggesting that the great post-war population shifts that reshaped the country's political, social and economic landscape have, for the moment, come to an end.
The Census Bureau's figures show an overall decline in Americans' mobility. It said that about 16.7 percent of the population changed residences during a one-year period ending in March 1994, far below the 20 percent that moved in a typical year during the 1950's and 1960's and the second-lowest level of mobility since 1948 when the Census Bureau began tracking such movement. The percentage of people moving from one state to another dropped to 2.6 percent from 3.6 percent. 
 Demographers, sociologists and economists said the aging of the population, the growth in two-income families, the decline in family size and a continuing sense of financial insecurity all contributed to the trend.
"People are becoming more stable," said Kristin A. Hansen, a demographer with the Census Bureau who produced the study.
While Americans still move with much more frequency that people in Western Europe or Japan, the Census Bureau reported that the proportion of people moving has declined significantly since it hit a post-war high of 20.7 percent in 1964-65. After a brief spurt of wanderlust in 1984-85 when 20.2 percent of the population moved mainly because of improving economic conditions, the sedentary trend resumed and has continued unabated.
And with it, some experts say, the era of the great midcentury migrations -- that of Southern blacks moving to the North and the rise of the Sunbelt -- may have ended. In its place, some political scientists theorize, is a sense that there is no place left to go to seek a better life.
"That could have something to do with the current political mood," said Walter D. Burnham, a professor of government at the University of Texas. "We have always been a country based on optimism and new frontiers. This seems like a different world; one that looks more like a frozen river than a fluid stream."
A demographer with the Census Bureau, Larry Long, said, "In spite of what John Steinbeck wrote, the fact is good times generate lots of migration and bad times cause people to stay where they are and hold on to what they've got."
Some sociologists attribute the decline to the increase in the number of two-earner families. With more married women working and with two incomes increasingly needed to cope financially, pulling up stakes becomes more complicated.
"It's harder to get two jobs elsewhere than one," said Peter A. Rogerson, a professor of geography at the State University of New York at Buffalo. "If you break down the mobility rates you find that the rates for single people have gone up slightly. It's the significant downturn among married people that explains it."
But some experts say the decline in mobility is a natural consequence of the aging of the American population. Moving rates tend to decline with age. Indeed, the report indicates that 35.6 percent of people aged 20 to 24 years old and 30.7 percent of those 25 to 29 years old changed their residence during the period in question -- the highest rates of any age group.
With the elderly -- a rather sedentary group -- making up a higher proportion of the population and with the Baby Boom generation sliding into middle age, the proportion of the people in their more mobile years is relatively low.
"The least mobile group in the society is middle-age people," said Steve Murdock, a sociology professor at Texas A&M University. "If you look at our age structure you find that the Baby Boomers born between 1946 and 1964 make up a third of the U.S. population. They are moving increasingly into ages where there is less mobility."
The report, titled "Geographic Mobility: March 1993 to March 1994," estimates that 6.7 million people moved to a different state, 8.2 million people moved to a different area in the same state and 1.2 million moved to the United States from abroad from March 1993 to March 1994.
According to the report, the biggest drop in mobility was among people who moved within the same county. The proportion fell to 10.4 percent of the population in 1993-94 from the post-World War II high of 13.9 percent in 1950-51.
Some demographers attribute this decline to a high proportion of Baby Boomers having already had children and having "traded up" to larger houses.
The report indicated that people who live in the Northeast are most sedentary, with only 11.7 percent of the population having moved. By contrast, 20.2 percent of the people in the West and 18.1 percent of those living in the South moved.
The Northeast is the only region in the country experiencing net out-migration. More people continue to move to the South, the Midwest and the West than leave those regions.
According to the report, whites have lower overall rates of moving than either blacks or Hispanics. The Census Bureau estimated that 16 percent of whites moved in 1993-94, compared with 19.6 percent of blacks and 22.4 percent of non-white Hispanics.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Staying Put" tracks percentage of people who moved to a different house within the United States each year. Figures also include people who moved from abroad. People who moved to a different state are shown as a portion of all movers. Graph represents figures for 1971, 1976 and the years running from 1981 through 1994. (Source: Census Bureau)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Reaches an 8-Month High Against Yen in Asian Trading

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose to an eight-month high against the Japanese yen in Asian trading today on expectations that the Bank of Japan would intervene again in the foreign-exchange markets to support the American currency.
Lower Japanese interest rates also helped weaken the yen against other leading currencies like the German mark by making yen-denominated deposits less attractive. 
 In Tokyo today, the dollar traded as high as 100.53 yen, its highest level since Jan. 9. By midday, it was quoted at 100.47 yen. In New York yesterday, the dollar ended at 99.96 yen, up from 99.65 yen on Friday.
The dollar has strengthened since the Bank of Japan early on Friday cut its discount rate to a historic low of 0.5 percent from 1 percent and then bought billions of dollars to bolster the American currency. The dollar then rose to more than 100 yen early on Friday for the first time since January before retreating.
"Friday's discount-rate cut and the intervention are gradually showing their effect," said Takuji Ohmi, a trader at Mitsubishi Bank.
The Japanese Government is pursuing policies to weaken the yen and strengthen the dollar to stimulate the country's stagnant economy through increased exports. A weaker yen makes Japanese goods more attractive to foreign buyers.
 Traders said that if the world's big central banks acted to coordinate dollar purchases, the American currency will rise.
Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin released a statement soon after the Bank of Japan cut the discount rate on Friday and said the Group of Seven big industrial democracies s would continue to closely cooperate in the currency markets.
Traders' conviction that central banks want to push the dollar higher was reinforced yesterday when the Bundesbank's president, Hans Tietmeyer, said the currency was "moving in the right direction."
Still, the dollar's rise against the mark is slow after a German Government report showed unexpected economic growth.
In New York late yesterday, the dollar stood at 1.4739 marks, down from 1.4760 on Friday. At midday in Tokyo today, it rose to 1.4755 marks.
The mark also soared to its highest level in more than two years against the yen today and also gained on other major European currencies.

HEADLINE: Manufacturers See Profits Slip

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
Manufacturing companies saw their sales and profits dip moderately in the spring quarter, the Commerce Department said today.
A quarterly survey of 9,200 companies showed that profits slipped in the second quarter to a seasonally adjusted 6 cents for a dollar of sales from a revised 6.2 cents in the first quarter of the year. Previously, the department estimated profits in the first quarter at 6.1 cents for each sales dollar. 
 That was consistent with other broad measures of economic activity that showed a sharp slowdown in the pace of the expansion in the second quarter. The economy is forecast to grow at a stronger, though still modest, rate in the current quarter.

HEADLINE: Recession Seen as Unlikely in '95 or '96

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
The economy has reached the long-discussed "soft landing," with no recession in sight, top analysts believe.
The consensus of the latest surveys by the National Association of Business Economists and the newsletter Blue Chip Economic Indicators is that the economy will grow by 2.9 percent this year and by 2.4 percent in 1996. 
 "Out of 49 respondents, only one anticipates that a recession will begin this year," the business economists said in releasing their survey results today. "Three more expect the next recession to begin sometime in 1996."
None of the 52 forecasters in the Blue Chip survey saw a recession coming in either year.
The term "soft landing" is often used to describe an economy slowing sufficiently to keep inflation in check, but not stalling into a recession.
That was the Federal Reserve's goal when it raised short-term interest rates seven times in 15 months through February 1995. But after the economy slowed almost to a stop last spring, and without any serious inflationary pressures in sight, the central bank lowered rates in July.
The business economists conducted their survey in August. The results were released at the association's annual meeting in San Francisco and made available here. The poll by Blue Chip, which is based in Sedona, Ariz., was taken in September.
The two polls produced identical predictions for inflation: 3 percent this year and 3.2 percent in 1996. The Consumer Price Index rose 2.7 percent in 1994.
They also included similar expectations of unemployment prospects. The business economists' consensus was that the jobless rate would fall to an average of 5.7 percent this year from 6.1 percent in 1994, before edging up to 5.9 percent next year.
The prediction in the Blue Chip survey was for unemployment of 5.7 percent this year and 5.8 percent in 1996.
The business economists' prediction for economic growth this year, 2.9 percent, would be a weaker reading than the 3.2 percent estimate in the association's previous survey, in May. But the latest forecast for 1996 indicated stronger growth than the earlier forecast of 2.2 percent.
Growth slowed from a 5.1 percent annual rate in the final quarter of 1994 to 2.7 percent in the first quarter of 1995 and 1.1 percent in the second.
The growth rate for April through June was the slowest since the economy expanded at a one-tenth of 1 percent rate in the final three months of 1991. The business economists' group predicted it would be the weakest of the year.
Contributing to economic growth this year will be business investment in new plants and equipment, which the business economists predicted would rise by 14.3 percent, and consumer spending, which they saw rising by 2.7 percent.
But the forecasters expected other economic factors, including residential expenditures, government spending and net exports, to decline.
The business economists saw a different growth composition for next year.
The association projected that growth in businesses' fixed investments, at 5.6 percent, would drop into single digits for the first time since 1992. "Growth in consumption will again about match the performance of the overall economy," at 2.3 percent, the group said.
"Modest gains, rather than declines, will be posted by residential investment," at seven-tenths of 1 percent, and by government purchases, at four-tenths of 1 percent, the business economists said, while net exports will rebound strongly, they added.
Finally, the economists predicted that businesses would continue to trim their inventories through much of 1996, paring $9 billion worth of goods.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Lower Ahead of Economic Reports

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Treasury securities ended slightly lower yesterday in light trading, with traders hesitant to take positions ahead of several important economic reports due this week.
"There's a lot of reports out later this week and today is data free," said Lee Youngdahl, vice president at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company. "There just aren't too many reasons to make any decisions today."
The result was a dull session, characterized by lackluster trading and very little price action.
"There's really no justification for a large move in either direction," said Waldo Best, an economist on the trading floor of Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities.
The data due this week include reports on producer and consumer prices, retail sales and capacity utilization and industrial production.
While investors expect little or no increase in inflation for August, some analysts said there was concern that retail sales and industrial production would show accelerating economic growth and could cause the market to sell off. Fixed-income investors fear strong growth could lead to inflation and erode the value of their holdings.
But ahead of the reports, prices started out weak and then barely moved all day.
In early afternoon, Robert Parry, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, suggested that the Fed was unlikely to lower short-term interest rates again this year. The comments weighed on prices, but were not enough to break them out of the narrow range they established early in the session.
"The Parry comments were kind of as expected," said Ted Ake, a senior trader of government securities at Kemper Securities in Chicago.
The Treasury's 30-year Treasury bond closed 2/32 lower at 10325/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 6.58 percent, from 6.57 percent on Friday.
Prices of other maturities were nearly flat. The yield on the five-year note slipped to 6.01 percent from 6.02 percent, while the yield on the 10-year note was unchanged at 6.21 percent.
In the municipal bond market, prices were steady yesterday.
In the primary market, Connecticut is set to price a $325 million special-tax-obligation issue through Merrill Lynch & Company as lead manager today. Yesterday marked the end of a retail order period during which 20-year bonds were marketed to those investors at a top yield of 5.80 percent.
Also, Ohio is scheduled to sell two deals totaling $115 million today, while Wisconsin is expected to sell $105 million of revenue bonds tomorrow.
"I think they'll do well," a trader said. "There's plenty of money and not a lot of issuance."
The corporate bond market was also quiet yesterday. There was little secondary trading even for those issues in the news. Neither the Witco Corporation nor debt traded after the companies said they would merge in a deal that includes an additional $276 million in long-term debt and $486 million in equity.
In new issues, the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation issued $250 million of notes split evenly between 9-year and 30-year notes, said the lead manager, Lehman Brothers. The nine-year notes have a 6.87 percent coupon and are priced at par to yield 64 basis points over comparable Treasury securities. The 30-year notes have a 7.58 percent coupon and are priced at 99.905 to yield 7.588 percent. Both issues are noncallable for life and are rated A3/BBB-plus.
