HEADLINE: Women Less Optimistic About Work, Poll Says

BYLINE: By JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI 

 BODY:
When it comes to the world of work, the mood of America's women appears to have taken a pessimistic turn. They believe overwhelmingly that while women are better off than they used to be, they continue to face restrictions and discrimination, according to a new poll to be made public today.
Of the 3,000 women polled, 84 percent agreed that "regardless of changes that may have occurred, women still face more restrictions in life than men do." A total of 77 percent said that sexual discrimination, although more subtle and less open than it used to be, "remains a serious problem." 
 And 76 percent said that there was a lot or some sexual harassment in the workplace.
Even though those results suggest that women believe there is room for improvement, the poll also shows that women do not have as much hope as they once had. Only 56 percent see the role of women as continuing to change, down from 73 percent in 1990.
Men agreed. Of 1,000 polled, 57 percent believe women's roles will keep changing, down from 76 percent in 1990.
Sheila Wellington, the president of Catalyst, a nonprofit women's research and advocacy group, said she was not entirely surprised by those results. "Women believe, and Catalyst believes, that there is much that remains to be done before the workplace is prepared to take advantage of the talent women have to offer," she said.
But realism seems to have set in. "There was a kind of buoyant optimism 10 years ago and certainly 20 years ago," Ms. Wellington said. "But I don't think this means that women will leave the work force. It does mean that they well be very careful about where they choose to work and how they choose to work."
The poll, which is done every five years, was conducted by Roper Starch Worldwide Inc. for the Virginia Slims brand of Philip Morris USA.
The poll shows that women believe that several factors keep them back, ranging from an old boys' network to the lack of role models.
Those feelings, coupled with the stress of balancing work and family, are taking a toll on how women feel about their jobs. Only 31 percent said that aside from money they got "great personal satisfaction" from their jobs, compared with 37 percent in 1990.
Men, however, are more satisfied with their work life now, with 40 percent getting great satisfaction in 1995, compared with 35 percent in 1990.
To make their jobs more satisfying, 58 percent of the women and 59 percent of the men polled cited incentive or bonus-pay programs to reward higher productivity; 53 percent of the women and 51 percent of the men cited better health benefits as a means to greater job satisfaction. In virtually equal numbers -- about 45 percent in each case -- both sexes also wanted more feedback from their bosses and more rewarding responsibilities.
More women than men -- 38 percent versus 27 percent -- wanted more opportunity to work at home. And 32 percent of the women and 31 percent of the men wanted company-run, on-site day care for their children.
The poll indicates that women work because they must: 73 percent said they worked to support their families or themselves, compared with 55 percent in 1990 and 46 percent in 1980. Only 23 percent said they worked to bring in extra money, down from 32 percent in 1990 and 43 percent in 1980.
The poll, which has a margin of error of plus or minus two percentage points, also asked some questions about women's personal lives.
But the area in which women most desired change was the workplace. When shown a list of items and asked whether major change, some change or no real change was needed, 94 percent of women said that major change or some change was needed in the salaries paid to women; 87 percent believed that women needed more opportunities for leadership positions.
By contrast, 73 percent -- the smallest proportion -- saw the need for major or some change in their role as homemakers.
"Women thought it would take less time to see progress at the top of corporations than it has," said Adele Scheele, a career strategist hired by Philip Morris to interpret the study. "They've been welcomed in, but the rewards, both financial and psychic, are lagging. If corporations want to keep women, they must promise to take them more seriously and make them more visible."

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Blinded by Science? Labor Talks on Move

BYLINE: By Murray Chass 

 BODY:
The so-called labor negotiations have turned into a roadshow: Have law degree, will travel.
For several weeks, small groups of lawyers for the owners and the players have traveled to Pittsburgh, Detroit, New York and Milwaukee (twice) for meetings and have emerged, both sides agree, with better chemistry than negotiators had during the players' eight-month strike. 
 From their undergraduate days, though, these lawyers know that chemistry and economics are different subjects; they might even have avoided taking chemistry. In other words, the better negotiating through chemistry they supposedly have achieved doesn't mean their era of good feeling will translate into an agreement on the economics of the game.
When the owners emerged from their quarterly meetings in Minneapolis in June, they said the most important thing they had to do was get an agreement with the players. They had made the same exact statement coming out of a meeting in May.
The owners are holding their latest quarterly meetings in Detroit this week, and they still haven't achieved their stated No. 1 priority.
All sorts of different and confusing messages are coming from the management side of this ongoing dispute:
*The hard-line owners, led by Jerry Reinsdorf, remain in charge and won't allow an agreement until the players are sufficiently punished for costing the owners hundreds of millions of dollars with their strike, or at least until they have sent Donald Fehr, their leader, into exile.
*While the number of owners who can be classified for public consumption as moderates hasn't grown, enough owners have grown weary of the ongoing dispute that if they were presented with a "realistic plan," enough would vote for it so that the Reinsdorf group wouldn't be able to block it.
*Bud Selig, the acting commissioner of baseball who rules by consensus, can't get a consensus on what the owners want in a deal with the players.
*Owners, one management person said, are lying to each other to create or deepen antagonism for the union, or at least for Fehr, who has been made out to be the bogeyman.
*Owners are fighting among themselves over the economic state of their game and the inability to improve it through an agreement with the players.
Although the owners apparently often have heated exchanges at their meetings, one in particular stood out at the Minneapolis meeting. At least it stood out enough that people have talked about it outside the meeting room.
The antagonists were the ubiquitous Reinsdorf and John Moores, the San Diego Padres' new owner. Moores, according to people who were there, made some comments suggesting that the owners had contributed to their own economic problems by doing dumb things.
Reinsdorf answered him by saying that it seemed like the smartest guy in baseball is the guy who just got in, but after a while, he becomes dumb "like the rest of us."
Immediately after the meeting, Larry Lucchino, who used to be chief executive officer of the Baltimore Orioles but now holds that position with the Padres, rushed over to Reinsdorf and told him he thought what the White Sox owner had issued was a cheap shot.
No ill feeling carried over outside the room, but the White Sox and the Padres clearly are at different ends of the stick that measures militancy and moderation. Reinsdorf's and Selig's protestations to the contrary, people in and out of management believe Reinsdorf holds the whip on the owners' side.
One high-level management person believes Reinsdorf, feeling neither side will inflict a work stoppage next year, prefers the status quo. Clubs will be in such poor financial condition this winter that they won't be able to spend gobs of money on free agents.
With so many players without jobs, they will turn on Fehr for having led them down the unemployment path and banish him to baseball's Elba. Thus satisfied, Reinsdorf will permit a deal to be made.
Reinsdorf scoffed at the suggestion that he doesn't want a deal now. "I want a deal," he said yesterday, "but I want a deal that solves the problems the industry has."
The problem is the sides continue to disagree over the severity of those problems and how to deal with them.
The players' group of lawyers apparently presented an idea at a recent meeting that centered on how players would contribute money annually to a revenue pool, but the owners' lawyers wanted nothing to do with the plan. The owners still want a method -- payroll cap or luxury tax -- that will force clubs to curtail their free-spending ways.
The sides will enter the off season without an agreement. Although the players won't be on strike, people who want to spend money on baseball still will face uncertainty -- fans who want to buy tickets, companies that want to buy commercial time on radio broadcasts and telecasts, networks that want to spend hundreds of millions of dollars for television rights.
It will take a far more polished song-and-dance routine to induce those potential big spenders to take the money out of their pockets than the one the touring troupe of attorneys has been allowed to present.

HEADLINE: Corporate Giants Tighten Their Hold on U.S.

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Companies Merge; Families Break Up" (Op-Ed, Sept. 3), Lester C. Thurow's analysis of the massive income shifts in the American economy neglects a major consequence of this redistribution of wealth: the parallel accretion of political power at all levels of government to the oligopolistic megacorporations now dominating the economy. 
 The resulting de facto suspension of antitrust enforcement, and weakening of regulatory oversight, has worked to remove most restraints on corporate monopolistic practices, thus cementing the economic gains the dominant corporations have achieved at the expense of the general population. The lobbying frenzy now going on in Congress is just one example of this development.
The present period resembles uncomfortably closely the Roaring Twenties, with a stock market driven by speculation and profits achieved at the expense of workers. It is said history never repeats itself, but the continuing maldistribution of the national product bids fair to lead to the massive underconsumption that triggered the Depression.
The prosperity of the past 50 years was founded on the progressive income tax, redistribution downward of the national product and curbing of excessive profits. The problems Mr. Thurow addresses arise from our abandonment of those policies.
 
RICHARD HYSE
Oswego, N.Y., Sept. 5, 1995
The writer is professor emeritus of economics at SUNY.

HEADLINE: Corporate Giants Tighten Their Hold on U.S.;
Homemaker Nostalgia

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Companies Merge; Families Break Up" (Op-Ed, Sept. 3): Lester C. Thurow correctly points out that the decline in men's wages is a major cause of family change. But he implies that the answer to family break-up and child neglect is to shore up male wages and restore the "traditional" family. While better jobs for all is a desirable goal, returning to a system of male breadwinning is an unworkable and, for many families, undesirable solution. 
 The breadwinner-homemaker household is a recent and short-lived arrangement that, even at its height in the 1950's, never met the needs of countless women, men and children. Now that women have genuine alternatives, they are not likely to leave the workplace, no matter how much men are paid. And there is little reason to believe that higher male wages will induce unhappily married couples to stay together.
Yet there are policies to lighten the burden of parents and improve the lives of children. First, give women equal economic opportunities so they can support a family with or without a male breadwinner.
Create family-friendly workplaces that allow fathers as well as mothers to participate in childrearing without penalty. Since employers no longer subsidize an unpaid caretaker at home, they have a new obligation to help employed women and men meet family responsibilities.
 
KATHLEEN GERSON
Professor of Sociology, N.Y.U.
New York, Sept. 3, 1995

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 6; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 261 words

HEADLINE: Corporate Giants Tighten Their Hold on U.S.;
Decay of Family Unit

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Lester C. Thurow (Op-Ed, Sept. 3) identifies wage stagnation in the United States economy as the principal cause of family breakup and paternal abandonment. Numerous elected officials, from President Clinton to Richard Gephardt, the House minority leader, also cite economic anxiety due to wage stagnation as the underlying cause of family fragmentation. Yet little evidence exists to support this thesis. 
 The United States has the highest divorce rate in the world, with more than half of all marriages today likely to end in divorce. Never-married mothers account for more than 30 percent of all childbirths. Tonight, about 40 percent of all American children will go to sleep in homes where their fathers do not live.
Is it reasonable to suppose, as Mr. Thurow and others suggest, that this historically unprecedented collapse of the mother-father child-raising unit can be explained by the fact that the median real wage for male workers has fallen from $34,084 in 1973 to $30,407 in 1993?
Cultural problems almost always require cultural explanations. Yes, economics matters. But as regards decaying family structure, our personal and cultural values -- what we believe about sexuality, procreation and marriage -- matter far more.
When confronted with behavioral trends that are undesirable, liberals often seek to blame the economy. Conservatives often seek to blame big government. Both explanations are partly right, but mostly wrong.
 
DAVID BLANKENHORN
President, Inst. for American Values
New York, Sept. 5, 1995

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
Between Love and Money, A City Chooses Gambling

BYLINE: By Evelyn Nieves 

DATELINE: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y.

 BODY:
YOU won't hear locals call Niagara Falls "the World's Honeymoon Capital" anymore. The ads for heart-shaped tubs on Motel Strip are quaint reminders of the old days, when the "No" in the vacancy signs were always lit. Even the souvenir shops have pulled postcards with wedding themes off the racks.
Not that couples no longer visit. They do; but few stay. And the same is true of families and bus tours. Hotels have already started laying off workers for the winter. There is little chance they will be needed. While more than eight million people poured into town last year, even at the height of the tourist season, the average visit was little more than a day. 
 Hotel and other business owners say that as far as attractions go, the breathtaking spectacle of one of the world's great natural wonders just isn't enough. They have been asking the same thing tourists ask: What more is there? About five minutes from the falls stands the city's downtown, and it is not pretty. There are some offices, several empty stores, one tattoo parlor, little else. "There is really nothing, nothing at all," said Sylvia Virtuoso, who owns an upholstery shop and is the president of a local merchants association.
SMALL wonder then, that Niagara Falls is hoping to open a casino to bring in more tourists and keep them. Bridgeport, Detroit, the Catskills -- you can draw a road map of the most desperate cities and resort areas in the country by tracking plans for casinos, the same way plans for convention centers pinpointed downtrodden downtowns 20 years ago.
No one wants to think about whether there are enough gambling tourists to go around. Business people here point out, rather defensively, that Niagara Falls started talking about the idea of casinos in the late 70's, before a lot of Johnny-come-lately towns. "We went through all the same things we're going through now -- the referendums, the debate," said Ms. Virtuoso, a member of the Niagara Falls Coalition for Casino Gambling. The plan died a slow death, and was resuscitated a few years ago.
But while that idea came and went and returned, the city cannot say the same for a full-scale plan to transform downtown Niagara Falls with trendy boutiques and restaurants. It has never happened. "We missed the boat," Ms. Virtuoso said.
A few years ago, the city did get started on a major tourist attraction, the Falls Street Fair and Station, which was to have boutiques and amusement park-style attractions. The developer went bankrupt and the building stands dormant.
Voters here overwhelmingly approved a casino in a referendum last year. And when a gambling bill passed the State Legislature in June that would legalize gambling in Niagara Falls, the Catskills and several other regions, the idea picked up more momentum. Even though the Legislature must pass the bill again in 1997, then put it up for statewide and local referendums, people are already saying that a casino would recharge Niagara Falls in no time.
"The view here seems to be that people are for it," said Charles Steiner, president of the Niagara Falls Area Chamber of Commerce. "as long as it's done right."
People opposed to gaming tend to be quiet about it. Not so the Mayor, Jacob A. Palillo, a first-term Republican facing a hot primary fight today. Mr. Palillo, a retired firefighter, has been critical of gambling. His challenger, Barbara Ann Geracitano, is all for it and proud to say so.
"We're in a crisis situation here," said Ms. Geracitano, a councilwoman who owns Barbara Ann's Beauty Salon. "You see what we have in downtown Niagara -- absolutely nothing. Tourists come who have no idea that the heart of downtown is a ghost town."
FOR a lot of tourists, the answer is to cross the Rainbow Bridge to Canada. It's standard wisdom among tourists that the Canadian side of Niagara Falls has the best view, not to mention the House of Frankenstein, the Castle of Dracula, Ripley's Believe it or Not and a strip that smells like cotton candy and butter-flavored popcorn.
Niagara Falls, Ontario gets up to 12 million tourists a year, a third more than Niagara Falls, New York. It shows. The streets are packed and parking lots as far as a half mile from the look-out points are full. Many of the handsome bed and breakfast inns on a hill just above the falls are sold out.
Of course, Canada plans a casino for Niagara Falls, too.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 22, 1995, Friday

 CORRECTION:
The Our Towns column on Sept. 12, about interest in opening a casino in Niagara Falls, N.Y., included an erroneous reference to a 1994 referendum on casino gambling. It was held in Niagara Falls, Ontario, not Niagara Falls, N.Y.

HEADLINE: District Battles Home-Rule Erosion

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12

 BODY:
As Congress prepares this week to appropriate its annual Federal payment to the District of Columbia, city officials are campaigning to minimize the number of strings attached.
With the city struggling to emerge from a financial crisis that prompted President Clinton to appoint a financial control board in the spring, Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. and other leaders have been urging lawmakers to approve the payment, of $660 million, without restrictions that would reduce local officials' power under the limited autonomy that Congress granted more than 20 years ago. 
 But Mr. Barry and other municipal leaders acknowledge that some restraints may be unavoidable. "I think we'll have some of them," the Mayor said in a brief interview today.
The payment is an annual subsidy that compensates the District for the property-tax exemption granted Government buildings, foreign embassies and nonprofit organizations. The city has been lobbying to blunt restrictions on that money as a way of preventing further erosion of home rule.
Mr. Barry, for instance, used an appearance today before the Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on the District of Columbia to urge the chairman, James M. Jeffords of Vermont, not to strip the school board's authority to appoint the school superintendent.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1633 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Luxuries They Can't Afford

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Sept. 12

 BODY:
The scene at the sprawling Mercedes-Benz factory in Sindelfingen, where the auto maker assembles its popular E-class model, is bedeviled by sloth and confusion, at odds with the popular image of Teutonic efficiency.
The five-story building, built in 1916, is loud and dimly lit, peppered with numerous half-built cars pushed to one side. Many workers stand idle, either with nothing to do or waiting for a car to reach their station. Activity has ground to a halt in large areas, like the dashboard-assembly section, because too much stock has piled up. Unlike modern plants in Japan or the United States, where cars follow a single line after they leave the paint shop, here they are machine-hoisted back and forth as many as 46 times between lines. 
 Things are better at BMW's 3-series plant in Regensburg in Bavaria, but are still a far cry from the lean and disciplined approach pioneered by the Japanese. Workers pause to knock back beer that they have bought from one of several vending machines on the factory floor. They attach bumpers from a selection of more than 400 styles, install 280 varieties of rear-seat shelves and apply almost any color paint customers can dream up. They also make all the dashboards themselves. The company boasts that all these choices make every model unique, but analysts say the extra costs are a drag on profits.
On top of it all, the workers are among the most pampered in the world, working short hours, earning twice as much as most of their European counterparts and getting 10 weeks of paid holiday every year. Small wonder, then, that the German auto industry is finally saying "Enough."
For a time, Germany's booming economy masked these excesses. But growth has slowed, and now German auto makers are recognizing that they do not know all they should about mass-producing competitively priced cars. As a result, they are taking drastic action to meet the challenge of Japanese and American competition: They are fleeing Germany's high-cost structure and opening new plants abroad, and they are re-engineering existing operations at home to make them more efficient.
Nearly every new car that Mercedes, a unit of Daimler-Benz A.G., is developing will be made outside Germany: its mini "Swatch" line in France, its mini-van in Spain and its four-wheel drive sports vehicle in Alabama. BMW opened a plant in Spartanburg, S.C., last year, Volkswagen A.G. is considering building its new Beetle in Mexico and Adam Opel, the West German unit of the General Motors Corporation, is expanding in Belgium, Britain, Poland and Hungary.
In the last four years, the German auto industry has slashed its work force by 160,000 jobs to the current 630,000. And there is more to come: analysts say Volkswagen needs to eliminate 30,000 workers over the next several years.
"I don't see a new auto plant being built in Germany for the foreseeable future," said Kunibert Schmidt, general secretary of the Association of German Auto Makers, the main industry group.
It isn't just the car industry that is moving production to lower-cost countries. Siemens A.G., the industrial-products giant, is building a semiconductor plant in Britain. Bayer A.G. and Hoechst A.G., the drug makers, are building plants in Texas and China, respectively. Other big German multinational corporations have set up operations in Brazil, China and even Japan.
But because of its vast size, the auto industry represents the direction of Germany's industrial base. As its exodus continues, more Germans are growing alarmed at the loss of jobs, openly calling for change. And they are getting some.
Most significantly, perhaps, cracks are appearing in labor's hard stand against concessions aimed at raising productivity. Just today, Volkswagen won more flexibility from its workers in a labor agreement that traded pay increases and job guarantees for a change in work rules that would lengthen the workweek to as much as 38.8 hours without incurring overtime costs. In the past, VW workers worked as few as 29 hours a week.
Earlier this month, Opel won similar concessions from the union. And at Regensburg, BMW negotiated an agreement with unions that allows the company to run an entire Saturday shift without paying overtime. The agreement also lets it operate its plant for 99 hours a week, with two shifts of workers, far higher than the typical German workweek.
German auto makers are doing more than just wringing concessions from labor. They are also redesigning cars and adopting Japanese-style production techniques to reduce costs.
BMW, for example, uses a certain amount of just-in-time delivery of parts, like seats, carpeting and engines, to hold inventories down. At Sindelfingen, about 100 miles south of Frankfurt, Mercedes has spent almost $200 million on new stamping equipment. It also takes delivery of its seats from suppliers only hours before they go into the cars, and it is reducing the number of parts it makes for its cars.
Opel recently hired a senior production specialist away from the Toyota Motor Corporation. And Volkswagen is reducing the number of chassis that it produces across its four operating companies -- VW, Audi, Skoda in Eastern Europe and SEAT in Spain -- from 16 to four.
In addition, German car companies are shopping more aggressively outside their country for cheaper parts, notably in the weak-currency countries of Italy, Spain and France. The trend started at Volkswagen, where Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua, who had been hired away from General Motors and was later accused of stealing G.M.'s secrets, clamped down on the prices Volkswagen paid suppliers.
In essence, Germany is waking up to a problem that it had ignored for too long, experts say: Its high wages, generous benefits and rigid workplace procedures were pricing its products out of world markets, even as the Japanese and the Americans were racing to increase productivity and hold costs down.
German auto workers are the highest paid in the world, typically costing an auto maker $38.50 an hour, almost twice the cost in France, at $20 an hour, and more than twice the cost in Britain, Italy and Spain. German auto wages are more than 40 percent higher than in the United States, and American factories also tend to be much more efficient.
A recent study by the Economist Intelligence Unit of London found that Volkswagen's main plant in Wolfsburg, Germany, produced an average of 23.6 cars an employee a year, while the Ford Motor Company's Wayne, Mich., plant produced 58.8 Ford Escorts. Toyota's Takaoka plant, which makes Corollas, Tercels and Paseos, produces an astonishing 133.6 cars an employee annually.
The turning point began in the early 1990's, when the German economy went into a deep recession and Japan's new luxury cars, particularly Toyota's Lexus and the Nissan Motor Company's Infiniti, hit world markets.
"Lexus was a profound shock," said Daniel T. Jones, a professor at the Cardiff Business School at the University of Wales. "It was just as good as a Mercedes but much lower priced. Mercedes found they were spending more time fixing their cars after they came off the assembly line than Toyota took in making the Lexus."
At that point, Mr. Jones added, "the German honeymoon of being able to make an ever-more sophisticated car without paying attention to price came to an end. They realized how disastrously inefficient they were and it triggered a real movement to learn from these lean techniques."
It was a painful process for a generation of corporate leaders raised on the concept that success would result from manufacturing a finely designed, finely engineered product in Germany and exporting it around the world. Even today, German business leaders get defensive about moving operations to foreign soil. One official at Siemens, for example, insisted that a plan to build a semiconductor plant in Britain was an "extension" of the company's production plans, not a relocation.
The transformation of the auto industry is even more emotional for German workers, since it involves a steady decrease in their numbers and a realization that the perquisites they long took for granted -- no Saturday work, few night shifts, six weeks of vacation and nearly a month of holidays, high absenteeism, an ever-shrinking workweek -- are coming to an end.
To be sure, Germany still has much going for it. Its work force is highly skilled and its economy remains the powerhouse of Europe. If its unions grant greater concessions, it could sharpen its competitive edge quickly. And it boasts one auto plant that can claim to be a match for the Japanese: the factory Opel built in the former East German town of Eisenach after the fall of Communism.
A so-called green-field plant, Eisenach borrowed many manufacturing techniques practiced by the General Motors joint venture with Toyota in Fremont, Calif. The plant now makes Opel's minicar, the Corsa.
Unlike the BMW and Mercedes plants, Eisenach is remarkably quiet, with no car bodies sitting off to the side. Managers and workers seem busy and wear the same uniform: clean white shirts and dark pants.
Though Eisenach has been rated as the most efficient plant in Europe, with production of 59.3 cars a worker each year, it is likely to be the last auto plant in Germany for a while.
That doesn't mean, of course, that the German auto industry is writing off German workers. Rather, it intends to pursue a two-track production strategy, according to Jens Neumann, a member of VW's management board and the chairman of its North American operations.
"Simple export thinking is not relevant any more," Mr. Neumann said. "It is very tricky keeping the German manufacturing base and at the same time globalizing. You cannot have the one without the other."


GRAPHIC: The BMW 3-series is the company's least expensive line of cars, retailing for between $20,570 and $41,000. By contrast, most other auto makers, including luxury car builders, strive to limit the number of variations to avoid excessive cost and potenital defects.

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Down Last Month

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12

 BODY:
For the third straight month in August, the nation's producers failed to obtain even the slimmest price increase for their finished products, a surprisingly tame Government inflation report showed today.
Particularly impressive, analysts said, were flat or declining prices for goods at earlier stages of production whose surges earlier in the year aroused fears that it was just a matter of time before quickened inflation would ripple all the way through to the consumer. 
 "It's time to file a missing person's report on inflation -- it's nowhere to be found," declared Ron Schreibman, vice president of the National Association of Wholesaler-Distributors, whose members' purchases are captured by Labor Department statisticians.
Today's report contributed to a vigorous bond-market rally that gathered strength in the afternoon and pushed 30-year bond yields down to 6.50 percent, the lowest yield since early July. [Page D19.] The rally was fed by the growing belief that the Federal Reserve could make further cuts in short-term rates this autumn, perhaps as early as Sept. 26, when the policy making Open Market Committee meets.
Stock prices followed bonds higher, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 42.27 points, to a record 4,747.21, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index reaching a record 576.51. [Page D12.]
For finished goods -- those ready for sale to the final individual or business user -- prices edged down one-tenth of 1 percent last month as a sizable decline in energy prices more than offset a small rise for other goods. Food prices, meanwhile, were unexpectedly stable following a sharp July jump caused by unusually hot weather in the Midwest that many analysts thought would have a lingering effect.
Prices for finished goods had been unchanged in July and were down one-tenth of 1 percent in June.
"Who could be anything but pleased?" said Rosanne M. Cahn, an economist at CS First Boston, noting especially how far prices of goods at the intermediate stage of production have subsided in the last several months. "The magnitude of the deceleration is very impressive."
Nondurable items such as chemicals used in manufacturing posted their first decline in 18 months and the price of durable factory materials such as hot-rolled steel sheet and strip also fell. Both declines were one-tenth of 1 percent.
As for raw materials, the Labor Department's index for crude goods dropped 1.4 percent following an eight-tenths of 1 percent skid in July.
Despite such broad reassurance that inflation remains benign, Ms. Cahn and other analysts said further rate cuts in September were not assured. "It's definitely good news for the Fed but by itself it's not enough to push them into easing" monetary policy, said Christopher Low, an economist at HSBC Securities in New York.
These analysts said the Fed would also likely want confirmation that the economy needs additional stimulus and would therefore look for signs of weakness in the monthly reports on retail sales and industrial production, which will be released Thursday and Friday, respectively.
When the erratic food and energy components are excluded, finished goods edged up one-tenth of 1 percent last month, matching February for the best performance so far in 1995.
Over all, today's report also showed that finished goods have now climbed 1.3 percent over the latest 12 months, the narrowest year-to-year rise since November.
The price of gasoline, which had dived 10.1 percent in July, fell another 1.9 percent in August; prices for heating oil and residential natural gas also declined. Electric power for the home, however, rose modestly for the fourth straight month. Fresh and dry vegetables, grown largely in the West, dropped 12.7 percent, offsetting upward pressure from rising prices on pork and grain products produced in the Midwest.
Among intermediate goods, increases for foods and feeds and for construction materials were balanced by the declines for factory materials and energy. In addition to the 1.7 percent decline for hot-rolled steel, prices for copper and brass mill shapes, cold-rolled steel, copper and flat glass turned down after rising in July.
On the other hand, prices of hot-rolled steel bars and aluminum turned up.
Crude goods showing sizable price declines included Irish potatoes, which fell 11.8 percent in August, after a 45.5 percent plunge in July; raw cotton, which was off 11.5 percent, and waste paper, down 12.9 percent. Iron and steel scrap, however, climbed 5.9 percent and aluminum base scrap reversed course to rise 3.1 percent, the report showed.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Producer Prices" tracks index of finished goods prices, seasonally adjusted, from May 1994 through August 1995. (Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics)

HEADLINE: Gore Assails Bill to Revise Telecommunications Laws

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore leveled a blistering attack on legislation to reform the nation's communications laws today, amid signs that the legislation was bogging down in a busy Congress.
Speaking to an audience of telecommunications executives here, Mr. Gore derided the bill passed last month by the House of Representatives as "a contract with 100 companies." 
 "Instead of promoting competition, it promotes mergers and concentration of power," Mr. Gore said. "What individual high rollers and media moguls think of a section of our communications law ought to be less important than what our children think."
The House bill, and a counterpart passed by the Senate in June, would erase six decades of communications regulations and open the telephone and cable television business to free-wheeling competition. But Mr. Gore said the legislation catered to big communications companies at the expense of consumers, who could end up with higher telephone and cable bills.
President Clinton has threatened to veto the legislation, and Mr. Gore reiterated that threat. "The United States ought to be on the leading edge, not the ragged edge, of reform," he said.
White House officials said the Vice President's strong words were calculated to put pressure on Republicans as they prepare to reconcile the House and Senate bills in conference committee.
In particular, these officials said, the Clinton Administration wants Congress to scale back the wholesale deregulation of cable rates in both bills.
But Congressional aides and industry executives said the reconciliation process could be delayed for several weeks as Congress grappled with two other complex and controversial issues: the budget and Medicare.
"The appropriations bill is just really complicated," said Gerald Lowrie, vice president of regulatory affairs at the AT&T Corporation.
Industry executives had hoped that Congress would hammer out a final bill in October and send it to Mr. Clinton soon afterward. But a spokesman for House Speaker Newt Gingrich said the Speaker had not even made plans to appoint members to the conference committee.
A delay in the legislative process does not mean the telecommunications bill is dead, or even in grave jeopardy. White House officials and Republican lawmakers both want to be able to claim during next year's campaigning that they helped to reform the nation's communications laws.
As the election season draws closer, though, the debate between industry giants over issues like cable rates and competition in local phone service is likely to become even more contentious.
Although today's meeting was called the Networked Economy Conference, leaders of the local and long-distance companies seemed anything but linked as they argued about the legislation's merits.
Robert E. Allen, chairman of AT&T, said the bill deserved to be vetoed because it would allow the regional Bell companies into the long-distance business without breaking up their local monopolies. Raymond W. Smith, chairman of the Bell Atlantic Corporation, said the legislation should be signed into law without substantial changes.
For his part, Mr. Gore questioned the commitment of the Republican Congress to genuine telecommunications reform because the Senate recently voted to reduce the budget of the Federal Communications Commission by 20 percent.
Mr. Gore said the Senate's action would strip the F.C.C. of resources at the very time the agency will have to oversee and administer new regulations in every corner of the communications industry.
"This implies that telecommunications reform is either a failure or a fraud," Mr. Gore said.

HEADLINE: A Classmate Is Arrested In a Murder

BYLINE: By RONALD SULLIVAN 

 BODY:
When 25-year-old Christina Jung was found bludgeoned to death in her Fresh Meadows, Queens, apartment, the police at first suspected that the promising young bond trader had been killed by a burglar. After all, they knew of no one who would want to kill her.
But several detectives were not so sure. And yesterday, they announced a surprising twist in the case, saying they had charged one of Ms. Jung's old classmates from the prestigious Stuyvesant High School, Jimmy Ng, in her death. 
 Behind the murder, the police said, was the story of two old classmates who had gone along drastically different paths since leaving high school: Ms. Jung finding success in a fast-moving career at Daiwa Securities, Mr. Ng, 27, apparently floundering to the point where he borrowed $8,000 from her, which he was unable to pay back.
The police said it was a fight over that loan that led Mr. Ng, on the night of April 12, to beat his old classmate to death with a bowling pin. The police said he then tried to make the murder scene look as if a burglary had taken place.
Ms. Jung's body was not discovered until five days after her death, on April 17, when her brother-in-law went to her apartment to look for her; her family and employers had grown concerned because she had not reported to work for several days. Part of the delay in discovering her murder, the police said, was that it occurred the Wednesday before Good Friday, when her office was closed.
The killing plunged into grief a close-knit family whose grandparents came from China a generation ago to find a new life in America. Ms. Jung herself was born in New York City and graduated from Stuyvesant in 1987.
Ms. Jung went on to New York University, where she graduated in 1991 with a degree in finance and then, in 1993, began a career on Wall Street as a trader in government bills for Diawa Securities, the fourth-largest financial corporation in Japan.
At the same time, the police said, Mr. Ng was having much less success in his career pursuits, and ultimately was unemployed.
Some time before Ms. Jung's death, the police said, Mr. Ng approached her with a business proposition, and she agreed to extend him a loan of $8,000. But after months of stalling on repaying the loan, the police said that Mr. Ng, who lived a mile or so away at 67-43 182d Street, went to Ms. Jung's apartment on the night of April 12.
Sgt. Stephen J. Nicastro, the commander of the 107th Precinct detective squad, said that the two began arguing over the debt and that Mr. Ng struck Ms. Jung with a bowling pin she kept in her apartment.
Seeking to find their daughter's killer, Ms. Jung's parents posted a reward of $20,000.
A spring newsletter published by Diawa Securities shortly after her death described the shock it caused at the firm: "In a year of disasters whose scale seemed almost unimaginable, it should probably not be surprising that one small tragedy devastated us with the greatest impact."
Colleagues recalled what they described as "Chris's unforgettable laugh."
Sergeant Nicastro said that detectives pursued several leads after her death, but ultimately uncovered a possible motive -- the $8,000 debt to Ms. Jung. Detectives said that once the investigation made that turn, it ultimately led to Mr. Ng's arrest overnight Monday on the charge of murder.
Sergeant Nicastro declined yesterday to say whether Mr. Ng had provided any statement or whether his fingerprints were found in Ms. Jung's apartment or on the murder weapon.
Nancy Mandell, a spokeswoman for Diawa, said, "Chris was a beautiful, talented and vivacious woman." She said Ms. Jung was widely admired at Diawa as an American of Chinese ancestry who stood out in a Japanese subsidiary that has a relatively conservative reputation.
"Everyone liked her, and her death was a shock to her colleagues here," Ms. Mandell said. "Everyone here is truly relieved they caught her killer. She did not deserve to die for $8,000."
 

CORRECTION-DATE: September 14, 1995

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about the slaying of a bond trader, Christina Jung, misidentified her employer. It is Daiwa Securities America Inc., not its parent, Daiwa Securities.
 The article also misstated the ranking of the parent company. It is Japan's second largest securities company, not its fourth-largest financial corporation.

HEADLINE: U.S. Envoy Highlights Fine Print on Bosnia

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12

 BODY:
Despite last week's agreement among the adversaries in Bosnia and an ongoing NATO bombing campaign, the chief American negotiator said today that the most basic issues of power sharing and territory are unresolved and that there is no guarantee any settlement will hold.
In an hourlong interview before flying to the Balkans for a new round of talks, the envoy, Richard C. Holbrooke, sought to dispel the optimism created by the agreement among the Bosnians, Croats and Serbs to create a Serbian republic within Bosnia and to accept the legal existence of the Bosnian state. 
Mr. Holbrooke seemed to be trying to lower expectations for his new mission. But his comments provided the clearest insight yet into the American strategy at the negotiating table, which is based on bringing pressure on each of the parties to make small compromises in private and locking them in in public.
In the interview, Mr. Holbrooke also praised President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia, laid out the mine fields on the road to peace in Bosnia and dangled the prospect of billions of dollars in economic aid from the West if a peace is achieved. Indeed, President Clinton began consulting leading members of Congress today about an initial $500 million aid package for a postwar Bosnia.
Compared with his mood last week, when Mr. Holbrooke was showing to friends in Europe an article in the French daily Le Figaro touting him as, "Le Kissinger des Balkans," this week he was signaling that at any moment the process could blow up in his face.
"Nothing is agreed upon until everything is agreed upon," Mr. Holbrooke said. "It's the way the parties avoid committing themselves to individual parts of the agreement. They can all at any time renege on anything they've agreed to."
Specifically, he said, negotiators were unable to work out the relationship between the Bosnian state and the Serbian republic to be contained within it.
"We couldn't get it," he said. "The differences were too great. And who controls the presidency? Who controls foreign policy? Is there a single overarching Parliament? How do you adjudicate issues?"
Even harder, Mr. Holbrooke admitted, are the vast divides among the parties over what the future map of Bosnia will look like, particularly the status of the capital of Sarajevo, which the Serbs want a piece of and which the Bosnian Government insists must remain undivided and under its control.
"It's like Jerusalem," Mr. Holbrooke said. "There's a mystical tie to it and it's the toughest single issue. We have almost completely incompatible positions right now."
Perhaps nothing illustrates the illusory nature of negotiating peace in Bosnia than the case of eastern Slavonia, Mr. Holbrooke said.
On the eve of last Friday's announcement, all three sides had agreed to work toward a peaceful resolution of the status of the oil-rich piece of Croatia captured by the Serbs in 1991.
But then the Croats suggested publicly that their country reserved the right to invade. The Serbs wanted to insert a rebuttal into the statement but bar the Croats from doing the same. The Americans said no. In the end, like so many other peace plans and statements that litter the last 41 months of war, the paper was discarded.
Mr. Holbrooke's praise for Mr. Milosevic underscored the extent to which the United States has tried to transform the image of the Serbian leader from that of a potentially indictable war criminal into that of a peacemaker.
"Milosevic appears to have abandoned -- at least for the time being -- the goal of annexing part of Bosnia," Mr. Holbrooke said. "He doesn't want it. He talks openly about needing peace, economic development and international legitimacy for Serbia and of not wanting to be burdened by the Bosnian Serbs."
Mr. Holbrooke described the Serb leader as a "good English speaker" who boasts about his close ties to prominent American bankers on Wall Street. It is a far different portrayal than one offered in a recent article in Foreign Affairs magazine by Warren Zimmermann, a former American Ambassador to Yugoslavia, who called Mr. Milosevic a habitual liar who condoned and organized "unspeakable atrocities."
Mr. Milosevic's success in persuading the Bosnian Serbs to give him the written authority to negotiate on their behalf was "the breakthrough" in the negotiations, Mr. Holbrooke said. When the Serbian leader presented the American negotiating team with the paper empowering him to negotiate, Mr. Holbrooke said: "All of our hearts skipped a beat. He did in fact deliver."
But just in case Mr. Milosevic is lying, as he has done in the past, Mr. Holbrooke did not rule out the possibility that the Serbian President will break his word and seize the part of Bosnia that makes up the entity of the Serb republic.
"I'm a student of Vietnam," said Mr. Holbrooke, who served there as a young Foreign Service officer, "and I don't forget that Henry Kissinger negotiated an agreement for two Vietnams and in the end it collapsed by force of arms and the North Vietnamese used force to annex the country.
"If you ask me my greatest nightmare, it would be just this."
Mr. Holbrooke insisted that he gave Mr. Milosevic no promises to pardon the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, and military commander, Ratko Mladic, who have been indicted by an international tribunal as war criminals. "Au contraire, ma chere," he said. "We have made it absolutely clear to Milosevic that the peace negotiations cannot include the war tribunal."
And Mr. Holbrooke acknowledged that Mr. Milosevic does not control the Bosnian Serbs on the battlefield, as evidenced by their refusal to withdraw their heavy weapons from Sarajevo in the face of intense NATO bombing.
As for the Bosnian Government, Mr. Holbrooke praised President Alija Izetbegovic for his statements published on Monday that signaled his willingness to make compromises for peace.
"We did not sell out the Bosnian Muslims," Mr. Holbrooke insisted. "They wanted this agreement. They knew this was a good deal."

HEADLINE: Dow Surges to Reach a High of 4,747.21

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks rose sharply yesterday, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average to an all-time high.
The Dow jumped 42.27 points to close at 4,747.21, topping its previous record of 4,736.39 on July 17. 
 Some broader market indicators also gained, with the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index setting its sixth straight record, rising 2.60 points, to 576.51.
But the Nasdaq composite index, which is weighed with technology stocks, wilted yesterday on profit taking after setting a record on Monday, dropping 1.56 points, to 1,065.00.
The market's rally came in reaction to a buying spree in the bond market, which surged in response to a Government report that producer prices fell one-tenth of 1 percent last month. This news strengthened the feeling of many stock market investors that inflation remained under control and that the Federal Reserve would reduce short-term interest rates in the fall, possibly at the next meeting of its policy-making committee on Sept. 26.
In addition, the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta reported a slowdown in manufacturing in the Southeast in August. And retail sales were projected by the Johnson Redbook Service to be on track to advance a seasonally adjusted three-tenths of 1 percent in September.
"Yesterday's numbers indicate the best of all circumstances for the investing public: moderate growth and low inflation," said Edward Nickoski, managing director of Piper Jaffray in Minneapolis. "The more you see these kinds of numbers, the more the market will get comfort."
The bond market took off like a shot on the release of the producer prices report, which showed that wholesale prices had either fallen or remained unchanged for the last three months. The Treasury's 30-year bond surged 1 5/32 points, and its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, slipped to 6.50 percent, from 6.58 percent on Monday.
When the New York Stock Exchange opened at 9:30 A.M., the giant large-capitalization companies that make up the Dow Jones industrial index followed the pattern of the credit market. These stocks climbed at the bell and began a steady upward pace that brought the nation's most widely watched index to its highest point at the close.
Advancing issues on the Big Board were far ahead of declining ones, 1,426 to 913. Volume was moderate at 373.6 million shares, compared with 289.9 million shares on Monday.
Financial-services companies were generally strong, with analysts citing a belief that profits of these corporations will be lifted in the current environment. J. P. Morgan rallied 1 5/8, to 74 3/4; the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, 3, to 99; the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, 1 1/8, to 67 1/4, and Merrill Lynch, 1 1/4, to 61 3/8.
Oil and oil-services stocks also posted gains yesterday. Mobil closed at 100 1/8, up 1 5/8; Texaco finished at 66 3/4, up 1/2; Schlumberger closed at 69 1/2, up 1 1/8, and Halliburton ended the day at 45 1/4, up 1 1/4.
Technology issues slumped, however, a decline largely attributable to the announcement of an August drop in the Semiconductor Industry Association's book-to-bill ratio. Coming in the aftermath of last week's run-up, some traders took the opportunity to sell and take profits.
Applied Materials fell 3 1/4, to 109; Texas Instruments declined 2 7/8, to 77 1/8; Micron fell 2 1/4, to 92 1/8, and DSC Communications slipped 2 1/4, to 59 1/8. AST Research, which projected a large loss for the current quarter, declined 1 1/4, to 11 1/2.
Automotive stocks also dropped on anticipation of lower-than-expected third-quarter profits and reduced production. General Motors closed at 47 3/4, off 1 5/8; Ford Motor closed at 30 7/8, down 1 1/8, and Chrysler fell 3/4, to 56 5/8.
Computer Telephone, meanwhile, which agreed to resell Geotek's mobile communication services, soared 2 1/16, to 15. And St. Jude Medical, which formed an alliance with Heartport to develop less invasive techniques for replacing heart valves, gained 3, to 61 7/8.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasuries Soar; Yields Are at 2-Month Low

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities soared yesterday and yields fell to a two-month low, after a Government report showed that producer prices remained surprisingly stable in August.
The Treasury's 30-year bond surged about 15/32 points. Its yield, a sensitive gauge of inflation expectations, dropped to 6.50 percent, its lowest point since July 6, from 6.58 percent on Monday. 
 Bonds rose after the Labor Department said prices paid to factories, farmers and other producers sank one-tenth of 1 percent last month, compared with expectations for an increase of the same amount.
"This economy is generating no inflation right now, and we don't expect that to change," said John Burgess, who helps manage $60 billion of bonds for the Bankers Trust Global Investment Management in New York.
The report on producer prices raised investors' hopes that the Federal Reserve will reduce short-term interest rates in the fall, possibly at the next meeting of its policy-making committee on Sept. 26.
If inflation shows more signs of slowing, the yield on the 30-year bond could drop to 6.25 percent by the end of the year, Mr. Burgess said. Investors will gain more insight into the pace of inflation today, when the Government reports on last month's consumer prices.
The Producer Price Index's core rate, which excludes food and energy costs, rose one-tenth of 1 percent, less than the two-tenths of 1 percent gain that many economists expected.
The report on the Producer Price Index, which marked the third consecutive month with no increase, is "the best possible number people could have looked for," said Steve Ricchiuto, a money market economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities in New York. It also bodes well for today's report on consumer prices, he said.
Yields of bills and notes, which have 10 years and less to maturity, fell less than bond yields.
Investors "need to see a little more proof" the central bank is poised to cut its target for Federal funds, or overnight loans between banks, before driving note yields lower, said Terry Rose, who helps manage $2 billion of bonds at Advisers Capital Management Inc. in New York.
The Fed reduced its Fed funds target a quarter percentage point to 5 3/4 percent on July 6, citing an ebbing threat of inflation.
In a speech to the Belgian Financial Forum Conference in Brussels, William J. McDonough, New York Fed president, said there was little to suggest inflation was poised to pick up speed, even though there were signs the economy was gaining strength.
It appears that "the transition to slower growth is behind us and that the U.S. economy is rebounding to a sustainable growth rate with only limited potential for accelerating inflation," he said.
To be sure, investors "should not ignore the fact that the retail sales report poses a danger for the inflation outlook," said Anthony Chan, chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisors in Columbus, Ohio, which manages $23 billion of bonds.
The Government is scheduled to give its first estimate of August retail sales tomorrow. Some economists expect the report to show sales rose about seven-tenths of 1 percent after sagging one-tenth of 1 percent the prior month.
"If demand comes in stronger, it tells you that although inflation is well behaved at present, it may not remain that way," Mr. Chan said.
So far this month, business at big stores is picking up speed, according to the first of two private-sector studies released yesterday.
The Mitsubishi Bank/Schroder Wertheim index said sales in the week ended Saturday rose five-tenths of 1 percent from the prior week, the strongest increase since the week ended July 8.
And the Johnson Redbook Service said September's retail sales were on track to rise three-tenths of 1 percent from August's levels. That's up from a two-tenths of 1 percent pace recorded a week ago.

HEADLINE: Immigration Panel Proposes Fee For Bringing In Foreign Workers

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12

 BODY:
A bipartisan Federal commission on immigration recommended today that companies pay "substantial fees" -- up to $10,000 -- when they recruit and hire some skilled foreign workers.
The panel, the United States Commission on Immigration Reform, suggested that paying such a fee would be a way for a company to demonstrate its need for a foreign worker, as opposed to an American one. As a trade-off, the commission suggested streamlining the system by which a company certifies that it tried and failed to find an American worker to fill the job, a process that can take up to two years. 
 "We're saying that an employer who wants to hire a foreign worker has to put his money where his mouth is," Susan Martin, the commission's executive director, said at a meeting with reporters. "In our market-driven economy, if you really value something highly, you pay for it."
The suggestion on paying fees for skilled foreign workers is part of a 245-page set of policy recommendations, and justifications for those recommendations, that was issued today by the commission. The nine-member panel, whose chairwoman is Barbara Jordan, the former Democratic Representative from Texas, was established in 1990 to advise Congress in setting immigration policy.
The commission recommended that after a transition period the number of people who could qualify as permanent residents based on their skills or education be lowered to 100,000 a year from the current 140,000. The commission went on to recommend that companies that recruit foreign workers who have college degrees but who are not considered to be at the top of their particular fields, or skilled workers with a minimum of specialized experience, pay a fee -- possibly as high as $10,000 -- for each of those workers.
In the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30, 1994, about 25,000 immigrants fitting those categories gained permanent residence. The commission estimated that the process of certifying that there were no Americans who could do the jobs filled by such workers costs the Department of Labor about $60 million a year.
Representatives of some business groups said companies were wary of the recommendation to impose a fee, doubting that the process of certifying their need for the employees would be streamlined.
"No company is going to bother with the whole immigration process unless they need the person," said Austin Fragomen, chairman of the board of the American Council on International Personnel. "So to have to pay a fee on top of the whole process is just a wrongheaded, ivory tower idea that comes out of things like commissions."
The document issued today presents a more detailed rationale for a set of broad guidelines issued in June that, among other things, called for a substantial reduction in legal immigration. It comes as two bills -- one by Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, and one by Representative Lamar Smith, Republican of Texas -- are being considered in Congress that would impose such restrictions. The Administration has not put forward an immigration bill.
Critics of the commission's proposals have contended that the panel failed to justify reducing the yearly level of legal immigration to 550,000 people from the current figure of about 725,000. Indeed, while the commission's report spells out a number of overarching principles for immigration policy -- including setting goals and priorities, making sponsors financially responsible for immigrants, protecting American workers and infusing immigrants with American mores, including the English language -- the report does not provide a rationale for reducing legal immigration.

HEADLINE: Dollar Is Back Over 100 Yen, As Washington Takes a Bow

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12

 BODY:
After nine months of midnight strategy sessions, emergency meetings with allies and psychological warfare against hotshot currency traders, the Clinton Administration today put to rest, at least for now, one of its lurking foreign policy crises: the dollar was back above 100 Japanese yen for the first time since January.
Even before the markets closed in New York today, Administration officials were celebrating. They gave much of the credit for the dollar's recovery to Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, who in recent months has frequently used skills honed on Wall Street to catch speculators off balance -- often during their summer vacations -- making them increasingly wary of placing billion-dollar wagers that the dollar would resume its decline. 
 "Betting against the U.S. Treasury looks like a riskier proposition than it seemed a few months ago," an American monetary official said today. Some economists agreed. "The execution of this strategy could only be called brilliant," said Allen Sinai, the global economist at Lehman Brothers, "in part because it was done so quietly, in part because the Administration has let actions speak louder than words."
After a fall of roughly 20 percent earlier this year, the dollar has regained its lost ground, closing today in New York at 101.16 yen, up from 99.96 yen on Monday. [The dollar continued its surge in Tokyo on Wednesday, trading above 102 yen for the first time since June 21, 1994.]
There is some risk, of course, that the dollar could reverse direction again. But for now, several senior Administration officials said privately that they were astounded by the speed of the dollar's rebound.
Back in April, when the dollar touched a record low of 79.75 yen, almost no one in the White House or the Treasury believed that the changing alignment of political and economic forces with Japan and Germany, among other nations, would bring the dollar back so strongly. Most doubted it would recover before the 1996 election.
Against major European currencies, the dollar showed little change. The dollar closed in New York at 1.4737 German marks, down slightly from 1.4739 on Monday. The British pound also gained slightly on the dollar, closing at $1.5548, compared with $1.5482 on Monday.
Economic policy is never far from electoral politics these days, and there is a growing hope in the White House that the stronger dollar -- along with the low inflation that a buoyant currency helps sustain -- will make it far easier to keep interest rates from rising as the election approaches.
Mr. Rubin took pains today not to declare victory, saying during a telephone conversation that "markets always make you regret doing that sort of thing." He attributed much of the dollar's rebound to a declaration of the Group of Seven finance ministers and central bankers in Washington on April 25 that stated that "Recent movements have gone beyond the levels justified by underlying economic conditions in the major countries."
At the time, the statement and a vaguely worded expression of resolve to cooperate in reversing the trend were dismissed by many traders and commentators as jawboning.
"People were skeptical and that was wrong," Mr. Rubin said. "What we said would happen is what in fact occurred."
While President Clinton is one of the big winners from the strengthening of the dollar against the yen, the Japanese may have won even more. The soaring yen had only compounded the troubles crippling the Japanese economy -- turning many of the country's key export industries into money-losers -- and it worsened the precarious condition of the country's banks. The stronger dollar also eases some of the pain of Japan's bad investments in the United States: in yen terms, the Mitsubishi Estate Company's nearly $2 billion fiasco over Rockefeller Center would have looked worse in April than it does today.
It took some time, however, and that says much about how political fortunes changed. Japan's banking crisis and its deflation worsened, finally scaring its financial authorities into taking steps to pump more money into the economy. Germany's growth slowed, prompting it to lower interest rates and seek a stronger dollar as well.
And there was good luck: inflation in the United States has stayed low, and the American stock market's rise continued to attract foreign investors. The standoff between the White House and Congress has probably helped as well, convincing investors that a real reduction in the national deficit was on the way.
In part the dollar has come back because the Bank of Japan, after months of vacillation, has regularly stepped in to spend hundreds of millions of dollars a day to prop the dollar up. Combined with Mr. Rubin's surprise interventions, Japan's determination to buoy the dollar has suddenly made it risky for speculators to be caught holding yen.
The end of the bitter trade dispute between Washington and Tokyo over automobiles was probably the final factor, economists and some Government officials say, in helping to reverse the psychology that dominated currency markets until recently. While most outside experts were unimpressed with the details of the agreement, it may have cleared the way for Mr. Rubin to press the Japanese to act more decisively in stimulating their economy and dealing with the banking crisis.
Mr. Rubin communicated frequently with his Japanese counterpart, Masayoshi Takemura, in recent months to nudge Japanese authorities along, but today he declined to give the details of those conversations or speculate about how influential they might have been.
"The important point," Mr. Rubin said, "is that we have seen the Japanese Government taking measures to deal with the realities of their economy -- slow growth, declining prices -- and they have now taken some serious measures."
Tokyo's gradual change in attitude has been matched inby Washington, where the accepted wisdom has been that a weak dollar would bolster American exports to Japan, and bring down the trade deficit. But Mr. Rubin's constant incantation that "a strong dollar is in America's interest" came to signal a revisionist view that the American economy would be helped even more by a revived Japanese economy than by a struggling one.

HEADLINE: Harlem Development Agency Provided Housing, Not Patronage

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"A Welcome Change in Harlem" (editorial, Sept. 7), on the closing of the Harlem Urban Development Corporation, says that the agency has "little to show" for the roughly $4 million a year it received in operating and development funds. 
 Presumably the little does not include the more than 6,000 units of housing the agency developed or helped develop. It must not include the more than 2,600 individual buildings, mostly historic brownstones, that underwent facade restoration.
It cannot include the 3,500 apartments to which the agency provided weatherization services to help improve the living conditions of low- income tenants, the economic viability of small buildings and the conservation of fuel, electricity and water.
It also must not include the homesteading buildings and tenant-owned cooperatives to which the agency provided technical assistance and seed money.
You state that the agency was "controlled largely by local politicians who sat on its board."
The majority of the 11 politicians, less than one-third of the members, were usually represented by nonvoting representatives at board meetings. The board was run by the local ministers, community leaders and businessmen who constituted its majority.
The same 11 politicians, it should be noted, will be on the new board, but the balance of power will rest downtown.
New stores abound on 125th Street, where the agency was responsible not only for the Apollo restoration but also for the Loew's Victoria, the Alhambra renovation and the construction of the 125th Street Mart. Caldor wants a site; Pathmark wants another. It is hard to get into Sylvia's for all the tour buses.
If you want to see change, take a walk up Frederick Douglass Boulevard starting at 145th Street, and look at the renewal of the Bradhurst neighborhood, until three years ago Harlem's most dangerous streets.
You refer to the agency as a "patronage mill." This never applied in any way to the Harlem Urban Development Corporation, where most staff members are professionals with 10 or more years with the agency who live in and care for the community they serve.
 
RUDY DUPUY
DIXIE HARDY MOON, MIKE RODELL
New York, Sept. 7, 1995
 
The writers served with Harlem Urban Development Corp. as, respectively, chief architect, executive assistant and housing development director.

HEADLINE: What U.S. Business Wants From Immigration

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Liberals Duck Immigration Debate" (Op-Ed, Sept. 7) by Michael Lind: American manufacturing no longer has an interest in maintaining a mass influx of unskilled, low-wage immigrants. While a large number of unskilled laborers helped fuel the Industrial Revolution, the technology-driven plants and offices of today's competitive global economy require the expertise of skilled workers. 
 Unskilled foreigners may be displacing some American workers in low-pay service jobs, but these immigrants enter the country through family-reunification immigration and illegal means -- not through business-sponsored immigration.
The National Association of Manufacturers is interested in the immigration issue, but only to maintain the employment-based immigration that provides American companies with the essential technical expertise in short supply in the United States. The shortage of available expert workers is a growing concern of American business.
A survey by Arthur Anderson's Enterprise Group found that a quarter of small businesses surveyed fear that the lack of qualified workers will hamper their growth. Indeed, in Ohio, the shortage of qualified workers is already a reality. The State Bureau of Employment Services was unable to find a single candidate in the state to fill one manufacturer's tool-and-die opening.
It is important that American industry continue to have access to a limited number of skilled foreign workers who are in short supply. Only 140,000 highly skilled immigrants -- less than 1 percent of the American work force -- are allowed into the United States under law.
They help educate and train native workers, give United States companies a leg up in the development of cutting-edge technology and expand overseas markets for American-made products, thereby creating jobs for American citizens. Waves of unskilled immigrants may be dragging down the pay levels of similarly un- skilled Americans, but not at industry's behest.
 
JERRY J. JASINOWSKI
President
National Assn. of Manufacturers
Washington, Sept. 11, 1995

HEADLINE: States Have a Place On the Data Highway

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "The Information 'Have Nots' " (editorial, Sept. 5): 
 Serving on a library board in a small community in rural north central Pennsylvania, I concur it is important for libraries to be connected to the "information highway." However, I think you miss the larger picture, as there are many other important organizations and institutions in our communities that need to be connected that cannot afford it -- schools, medical clinics and nonprofit human service providers.
The answer is not having us taxpayers subsidize the cost but to have the government, particularly state government, provide telecommunication "backbones" (networks) for access. We are already paying as taxpayers for the state network. Why do we have to pay again?
There are excellent examples where more progressive states provide their networks for libraries, schools and nonprofits -- North Carolina and Iowa are two.
More important, telecommunications policies under consideration or being implemented are based on a market-driven model. While this model serves a substantial number of people, it will not serve the information have-nots.
These groups are more than just libraries, and they do not have the economic means to access and be served by the telecommunications providers. Consistent with this is the need for cooperation among those about whom you are concerned, to cost-share and coordinate their computer and telecommunication services.
 
GERALD E. DEPO
Bloomsburg, Pa., Sept. 7, 1995

HEADLINE: Mayor Is Victor In the Primary In Baltimore

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: BALTIMORE, Sept. 12

 BODY:
Mayor Kurt L. Schmoke, the first black to be elected Mayor of Baltimore, won the Democratic mayoral primary tonight, a victory that virtually insures his re-election for a third term in November.
Surviving a strong challenge from Mary Pat Clarke, the City Council president, who is white, Mr. Schmoke won the right to oppose Victor Clark, a car salesman who defeated two other candidates in the Republican primary. 
 But in Baltimore, the nation's 14th largest city, where 85 percent of the 339,000 are Democrats, Mr. Schmoke is expected to win another four-year term easily.
With 98 percent of the ballots counted, Mr. Schmoke had 81,601 votes, or 59 percent, to 53,076, or 39 percent, for Mrs. Clarke, who conceded at 11 P.M. A third candidate, Kelley Brohawn, a water taxi driver, had 2,786 votes, or 2 percent.
Mr. Clark won the Republican race with 64 percent of the vote.
Appearing before supporters at his election night headquarters, Mr. Schmoke said President Clinton had phoned to congratulate him. He then told his supporters, "Baltimore won, and we have to move forward now in a wonderful, dynamic partnership."
The campaign focused as much on the style of the candidates as the substance of their policies.
As liberal Democrats, they shared similar views on most big issues. But while Mr. Schmoke projected the image of a studious bureaucrat whose decisions generally followed careful consideration, Mrs. Clarke accentuated her pugnacious personality, selling herself as a can-do civil servant with more energy and solutions than Mr. Schmoke.
But they also saw the city through vastly different prisms, as if Baltimore was either a half-full or half-empty glass of water. Mr. Schmoke, who constantly reminded voters of his close ties to Mr. Clinton and Gov. Parris N. Glendening, hammered away at the accomplishments of his administration, including a $100 million Federal grant to encourage investment in the inner city and innovative programs in the schools.
He campaigned hard on the notion that even though Baltimore suffered from the same urban ills besetting other big cities, like job loss and high crime rates, the his successes outweighed his failures.
Along the way, he gained national attention for his policies of urban renewal and decriminalization of illegal drugs.
But Mrs. Clarke, once a supporter of Mr. Schmoke, was unrelenting in her characterization of him as a leader who has outstayed his usefulness. Her campaign slogan was, "If it's broke, fix it," and she cited much that she felt needed fixing.
