HEADLINE: Sex Shops Zoning Plan Eases Rules in Manhattan

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
Yielding to criticism from residents in the boroughs outside Manhattan, the City Planning Commission revised its new zoning proposals for sex-related businesses yesterday by expanding the areas in Manhattan where they could operate.
The latest plan would keep the restrictions that are intended to reduce the number and break up the concentration of X-rated video stores and topless bars in places like Times Square. 
 But compared with the original plan, the new proposal would increase by about 40 percent the areas in Manhattan where sex shops could legally operate, including the diamond district, Herald Square, and slivers around City Hall and the World Trade Center.
The changes represent a modest victory for residents and political leaders in the other boroughs who feared that the original proposals would lead many of Manhattan's sex businesses to migrate en masse to industrial and waterfront areas in Brooklyn and Queens.
"There will still be pressure to squeeze sex shops to the outer boroughs, but this is a better proposal than it was before," said Sal F. Albanese, a Democratic City Councilman from Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. "I still have some concerns. But it's a step in the right direction.
But the changes were not welcomed by the Manhattan Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger, who had opposed the Mayor's original proposals in part because of concerns that the zoning would force the closing of sex-related businesses integral to the city's gay community in Greenwich Village. She complained that not only did the new plan not address that concern, but the new proposals would cause problems in other parts of Manhattan.
"The original proposal was a bad proposal, and this makes it worse," she said. "This doesn't solve any problems."
She said the proposal would undermine the financial prospects of "several business districts that are fragile right now." She called the Planning Commission's revisions "a further assault on midtown Manhattan," and criticized Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani for "singling out such areas as the diamond district that represent critical pieces of the city's economy."
The Planning Commission proposals are likely to be the final set of modifications to a plan first proposed by Mayor Giuliani last year. The 13-member commission is to vote on the matter on Monday. It would then go to the City Council for a vote. Mr. Rose said he expected the commission to approve the new plan.
As originally proposed, the plan would have effectively banned sex businesses from all but manufacturing areas outside of Manhattan.
The proposals had sought to reverse the proliferation of sex-related businesses both in midtown Manhattan and in residential neighborhoods where they had rarely been seen before -- places like Chelsea, the Upper West Side and Forest Hills, Queens. In the last decade, city officials say, the number of adult businesses has risen 35 percent, from 131 in 1984 to 177 in December 1993 -- 107 of them in Manhattan.
But as details of the Mayor's proposals became clear, protests arose in many quarters of the city.
"We were responding to the concerns voiced in public testimony," said Joseph B. Rose, the chairman of the Planning Commission. "There was a sense that it might be desirable to provide more opportunities for these businesses to locate in Manhattan, to allay fears in the outer boroughs that these businesses would be displaced to their areas."
He added that the changes would insure that patrons would continue to have easy access to these businesses by mass transit.
The revised plan would leave intact provisions barring sex establishments within 500 feet of residential areas, schools and places of worship, and within 500 feet of one another. But it would eliminate a requirement for a 500-foot buffer zone between areas where adult businesses would be allowed and certain high-density commercial areas where they would be prohibited.
That elimination would have no impact on areas outside of Manhattan, but it would expand the legal areas in Manhattan.
The commission also added details to the legal definition of an adult business. The term would cover a business with either 40 percent of the floor area or 10,000 square feet devoted to adult material.
There was considerable debate among members of the Planning Commission about the measures. Some at yesterday's meeting complained that the plan placed undue and illegal regulations on businesses whose right to exist freely is protected by the Constitution.

HEADLINE: What U.S. Business Wants From Immigration;
A Policy of Compassion

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Liberals Duck Immigration Debate" (Op-Ed, Sept. 7), Michael Lind dismisses the contention that "sinister racist 'scapegoating' " is a motivation behind the argument that legal immigrants take jobs away from American citizens. Yet he is quick to assert that "the white and black working poor have been fleeing the metropolitan areas of California, where the economic competition with Latin American and Asian newcomers is the most intense." 
 Mr. Lind's anti-immigration sentiment is commonplace, and his choice of words is banal compared with other expressions in the media and in Washington. After all, immigrant-bashing is in style once again.
The history of immigration in the United States is far from wonderful. Bigotry was the direct cause of the closing of America's doors to legal immigrants in the 1920's. As more Italians and Jews entered the United States at the turn of the century, anti-Roman Catholic and anti-Semitic attitudes became more popular and more frequently expressed on Capitol Hill and on Main Street.
Similarly, the Oriental Exclusion Acts of 1882 and 1902 (not repealed until 1943) were racially inspired. Asians, mostly Chinese nationals, first arrived in California in 1848. Over the years, as the number of Asians grew, so did xenophobia. Americans denounced Asians for, among other things, unsanitary and immoral habits.
During the economic depression of the 1870's, anti-Asian sentiment rose to such a level that numerous Asians were victims of mob violence. Instead of protecting hard-working residents who built our national railroads, Congress excluded them.
The eradication of racial and national origin quotas from the laws of immigration did not occur until 1965. Mr. Lind erroneously claims that our immigration policy since then is "tailored to the convenience of the American overclass."
Our immigration policy is tailored to the American family, the American worker, the American employer and people fleeing from persecution.
The overwhelming majority of permanent visas approved by the Government are issued to relatives of United States citizens and lawful permanent residents. That is, family reunification is at the heart of American immigration policy. Visas are also issued to foreign investors who wish to come to the United States and infuse their money and energy to build a mighty enterprise.
Other employment-based visas are issued to foreign-national workers but, save for a few extraordinary cases, only after the Department of Labor certifies that there is no United States citizen who would perform the required task.
With the labor certification process, current law prevents foreign-alien workers from taking away jobs from American workers.
The social, political and economic contribution of immigrants to this country is and always has been tremendous.
 
E. SIMON RAPHAEL
New York, Sept. 9, 1995
 
The writer is an immigration lawyer.

HEADLINE: House Panel Opts to Kill Agency Giving Legal Advice to the Poor

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13

 BODY:
The House Judiciary Committee voted today to abolish the Legal Services Corporation, which provides lawyers for poor people in a wide array of civil cases like landlord-tenant disputes, domestic-violence cases or legal battles affecting the homeless, the mentally handicapped and migrant workers.
By a vote of 18 Republicans to 13 Democrats, the committee voted to eliminate the agency, which this year had a budget of $415 million, and replace it with $250 million in block grants next year to the states. The bill would also impose significant new restrictions on lawyers who are paid from the block grants, barring them from filing class-action lawsuits and challenges to the constitutionality of any laws. 
 The legislation is expected to reach the House floor as early as next week. Similar legislation, sponsored by Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, would provide $210 million in block grants. It is expected to be introduced on the floor of the Senate this week. President Clinton, whose wife was once the chairwoman of Legal Services, has threatened to veto the legislation.
With little notice, Legal Services has been put on the list of Federally supported programs slated for drastic cuts or possible elimination by the Republican Congressional leaders. But unlike the Corporation for Public Broadcasting and the National Endowment for the Arts, which are also targets of cutbacks or cutoffs, Legal Services is being rent by three political forces: fiscal austerity, efforts to overhaul welfare and a powerful new hostility in Washington to lawyers that has inspired conservative lawmakers to promote an agenda aimed at limiting lawsuits brought by the poor and injured.
Conservatives in Congress have long argued that lawyers financed by Legal Services have impeded an overhaul of the welfare system. In a handful of suits, lawyers sponsored by Legal Services have successfully challenged state restrictions imposed on welfare recipients.
The Christian Coalition has also lobbied Congress heavily against the corporation, arguing that it has undermined family values by giving poor people lawyers in divorce cases.
"This is a tremendous step toward reforming the ineffective Federal legal assistance program," said Representative George W. Gekas, Republican of Pennsylvania, the principal sponsor of the Judiciary Committee legislation. "The Legal Services Corporation has clearly outlived its usefulness. It's time to try something new."
But the corporation's supporters say that welfare cases represent only a fraction of the work it has done and that the success of those cases demonstrates that the agency has not undertaken frivolous suits. Moreover, the supporters say that block grants would fail to assist the poor because many states have shown no interest in assisting indigent clients in civil suits.
"What is proposed now would be devastating to tens of millions of economically disadvantaged people, half of whom are children," said Roberta Cooper Ramo, president of the American Bar Association. "Without access to civil justice, the American dream is a cruel joke."
Of the 1.7 million cases handled by Legal Services lawyers last year, 33 percent involved family matters like child support, spouse abuse and divorce. Twenty-two percent involved housing, 16 percent involved welfare and other Government benefits and 11 percent involved consumer issues. The remainder dealt with education, employment, health care and individual rights.

HEADLINE: Agency's Report Provokes a Revolt

SERIES: Special Pleaders -- A periodic look at lobbying.

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13

 BODY:
Representative Henry Bonilla, a San Antonio Congressman in his second term, was home for a visit early this year when he received a small stream of visitors who wanted to complain about a Federal agency. The visitors were local back surgeons and some physical therapists angry over a study by the agency that said most back surgery and much physical therapy used by Americans for back pain was unnecessary.
As a Republican member of the Appropriations Committee's panel that deals with the agency's budget, Mr. Bonilla was a good choice for the surgeons' complaints that the Agency for Health Care Policy and Research was a waste of money. Mr. Bonilla, his aides said, looked into its work, concluded it was inefficient and duplicated the work of other Federal agencies and became a leader in the effort to abolish the agency by eliminating its financing. 
 As far as battles in the current multibillion-dollar budget war go, the fight over the agency is only a tiny skirmish, because its budget of $165 million dollars is a fraction of the $300 billion the Federal Government spends on Medicare and Medicaid. But the fight over the agency is emblematic of how such fiscal combat is being waged.
Back surgeons have been mobilizing, including an Arlington, Va., back specialist who said he had taken his case to members of the House and Senate who are among his patients, as are members of the Supreme Court.
The specialist, Dr. Neil Kahanovitz, has founded a lobbying group to battle the research agency, insisting that he is not trying to protect his income or those of fellow back surgeons. He is, he said, simply trying to eliminate a wasteful institution that is biased in matters like how to treat back pain.
The agency, which is supposed to evaluate the effectiveness of medical treatments, issued a set of guidelines for the public last December that said, in effect, that most of the back surgery performed in the country is unnecessary.
Back pain, which is eventually experienced by 8 of 10 American adults, is an often-puzzling medical phenomenon that will disappear by itself in most cases, the agency reported. Billions of dollars in medical costs could be saved without surgery, the report said.
While the agency's work, including the report on spinal treatment, has been endorsed by large segments of the medical profession, the North American Spine Society, the professional group of back surgeons, whose members receive a substantial share of the dollars for back surgery, criticized the study as biased in its methods. So did Dr. Kahanovitz.
But even without such criticism, the agency was in peril. When Republicans in control of Congress are looking to cut $9 billion on the way to eventually balancing the budget, every dollar, or more precisely, every million dollars, can count, the agency's opponents argued.
Representative Gerald B. H. Solomon, a Republican from upstate New York who is chairman of the House Rules Committee, said the agency was a perfect example of a Federal agency that has little reason to exist.
"With an annual deficit of way over two billion dollars there is no way to justify an agency whose work is is routinely duplicated by at least nine other Federal agencies, not to mention many private groups who do the same work," he said.
"Look, we're cutting back on programs while trying to not cut back on programs for needy people. Do you cut school lunch programs or programs like this?"
Representative Sam Johnson, the Texas Republican who led an effort on the floor to eliminate the agency, said he did not believe the complaints from back surgeons were a factor in the debate. He added that he wanted to eliminate the Agency for Health Care Policy and Research because the Government should not be telling doctors how to conduct their business.
But Representative John Edward Porter, an Illinois Republican who is chairman of the Appropriations Committee's panel on health, said, "The fact of the matter is that a number of members were upset with what AHCPR had done regarding back surgery." He said he believed the agency's work was valuable, producing results that people needed to hear.
The agency's director, Dr. Clifton Gaus, has gone on the offensive, depicting the situation as one in which back surgeons were trying to undercut his agency simply to maintain their substantial incomes.
"We've got the mission of doing research that produces information that will allow the consumers and providers to make decisions to get the best quality care at the best price," he said in an interview. "And in doing this, it's bound to create economic winners and losers."
Dr. Gaus said eye surgeons had similarly complained two years ago when his agency issued guidelines for cataract treatment that inevitably meant fewer operations.
The agency was created by a law signed in 1989 by President George Bush and is supposed to study the effectiveness of medical treatments, both in whether they work and whether they are cost-effective. The House has cut its budget to $60 million on its way to eliminating it later on. A Senate appropriations subcommittee today increased that figure to $127 million and the full committee is expected to take up the issue on Friday.
The agency has also issued guidelines on how to treat cataracts, prostate disease, inner-ear infections in children and pneumonia.
Dr. Gaus said it was simplistic to say the agency's work duplicated that of other Government entities because it had a distinct mission to evaluate the costs of treatments, while other agencies did pure research without regard to economics.
While the spine surgeons group has opposed the agency, the American Academy of Orthopedic Surgeons, a larger group of surgeons who operate not only on backs but also bones, joints and muscles, has supported the agency.
Dr. Robert B. Keller, a former professor of orthopedics at the Harvard Medical School, who participated in the lower back pain study, said that the guidelines were the result of the best science available. Those who have attacked the study, he said, are simply trying to protect their livelihoods.
"They have managed through some fairly skillful political moves to cause a lot of damage to this agency simply because they don't like what this agency produced," Dr. Keller said.

HEADLINE: Man Denies Plotting to Bomb I.R.S. Office

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: TYLER, Tex., Sept 13

 BODY:
An unemployed car salesman pleaded not guilty today to charges that he had asked undercover Federal agents to get plastic explosives and help him blow up an Internal Revenue Service building in Austin.
The man, Charles Ray Polk, 45, was charged on Tuesday with plotting to blow up the I.R.S. regional service center. 
 Appearing before Federal Magistrate Harry McKee today, Mr. Polk, described as a militant tax protester, pleaded not guilty to all six charges. The court appointed a public defender.
"There's no doubt in our minds he had the intent to carry this out," said Mike Bradford, United States Attorney for the Eastern District of Texas.
Mr. Polk asked undercover agents about getting plastic explosives and for help in blowing up the building, Mr. Bradford said.
About 4,200 employees work at the center, which processes tax returns from four states. The agents contend that Mr. Polk planned the bombing between April 4 and July 28, when he was arrested on gun charges.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
India Nationalists Oppose Presence of a U.S. Chain

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Sept. 13

 BODY:
India's first Kentucky Fried Chicken restaurant was closed today by local authorities, then swiftly reopened under a court order, as nationalists pressed efforts to curb the entry of foreign corporations into India under its four-year-old program of economic liberalization.
City authorities in Bangalore ordered the restaurant closed after weeks of protests by a local farmers group allied to a wider campaign across India against foreign investments. The city's order cited what was termed an infringement of Indian health rules, but officials of an Indian subsidiary of Pepsico, the corporate parent of Kentucky Fried Chicken, said the closing was politically motivated. 
 "What is the agenda here?" asked Sandeep Kohli, managing director of Pepsico Restaurants International, which has announced an $80 million, seven-year plan to open 60 fried chicken restaurants in India. "Ours is the cleanest restaurant in the whole of India. We are providing jobs, and raising the quality of food service. We are giving a taste of something that is new to India."
Since opening in June, the Bangalore restaurant had drawn as many as 1,500 customers a day to its location on the city's main commercial avenue. But it had also acted as a lightning rod for Indian groups opposed to what they have characterized as a takeover of India by foreign companies. Last month, these groups scored their biggest success when the state government of Maharashtra "repudiated" a contract for a $2.8 billion power plant that the Enron Development Corporation, a subsidiary of the Enron Corporation of Houston, was building near Bombay. The company had spent nearly $300 million on the project.
Officials who shut the Bangalore restaurant said they acted after tests on chicken samples showed a level of monosodium glutamate, a taste enhancer widely used in cooking, that was nearly three times the permissible limit under Indian law. At a news conference here today after Pepsico had obtained an order in a Bangalore court staying the closing, Mr. Kohli said Pepsico's tests showed the levels of the additive to be "far less" than the 1 percent limit set by India.
He accused Bangalore officials of violating Indian standards for food tests. "KFC is a responsible, internationally renowned corporation, serving meals to seven million people daily in 9,400 outlets in 78 countries," Mr. Kohli said. "We have built this customer franchise on the planks of our commitment to quality, service and cleanliness. It pains us, therefore, to be wrongfully vilified in this way."
Bangalore has been considered one of the most favorable cities in India for foreign companies taking advantage of India's economic reforms. The city is the center of India's computer and aerospace industries and has won contracts from major American computer companies for the development of software. But it has also been a center of activity for groups of leftists and nationalists demanding strict limits on foreign investment.
These groups say foreign companies should be limited to ventures involving high technology, and that they should be excluded from activities where India can provide for itself, including food processing, agriculture and the manufacture of consumer goods. "India does not need foreign investment in junk food manufacturing," said Nanjunda Swamy, leader of the farmers group that has led the Bangalore protests.
The protests prompted the posting of a police guard at the Bangalore restaurant, a step that Pepsico executives said had only a limited effect on patronage. Two years ago, protesters ransacked the Bangalore offices of Cargill Inc., throwing office equipment out the window amid contentions that the company's seed imports would put Indians out of work. Other recent protests have been aimed at the Indian operations of the Coca-Cola Company, McDonald's, the Pizza Hut and Frito-Lay units of Pepsico and the Kellogg Company, among others.
According to surveys by Western embassies here, the cancellation of Enron's power plant project has caused some American, European and Japanese companies to delay the completion of investment deals while Indian politicians argue over whether the Enron project should be revived. But Mr. Kohli, who is an Indian citizen, said Pepsico intended to go ahead with its investment plans.

HEADLINE: Coliseum Reopens After Decade in Limbo

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON 

 BODY:
For more than 10 years it has largely been an empty shell on Columbus Circle, an unattractive, windowless block of a building that was the subject of bitter battles among environmentalists, developers and city officials.
Today, something is finally happening with the New York Coliseum, but not the gargantuan residential and commercial project that Mayor Edward I. Koch and Mortimer B. Zuckerman proposed a decade ago. The Coliseum is reopening as what it was designed to be in 1954, a home for commercial trade shows in Manhattan. 
 With its thick yellow support columns freshly painted and its steep gray marble stairways newly polished, the Coliseum is set to welcome 13 events scheduled between now and the end of the year. The first of those, the International Jeanswear and Sportswear Show, opens today.
In the next three months alone the Coliseum's owner, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, expects to take in $700,000 in rent. At that rate, the M.T.A. could have collected $28 million if the Coliseum had not sat virtually vacant since 1985.
Some of the Coliseum's new shows used to fill the Passenger Ship Terminal on the Hudson River, hotel ballrooms in midtown Manhattan and convention centers in other cities. The sportswear show is moving to the Coliseum from Miami. The nationally televised Billboard Music Awards, which had been held in Los Angeles since 1990, booked the Coliseum for Dec. 6 after discovering that Radio City Music Hall and Carnegie Hall were taken. And the New York Flower Show will leave the ship terminal at 50th Street for the Coliseum next March.
Marshall Lester, who organized the sportswear show, said he can draw bigger crowds in New York, in part because foreign wholesalers are more likely to come here than to go to Miami. He is paying $15,000 a day for one floor of the Coliseum, slightly more expensive than one pier at the terminal. But show promoters see advantages in the Coliseum's location -- closer to midtown hotels and passing cabs, and directly above the Columbus Circle subway station.
At the same time, Columbus Circle itself seems to be in the early stages of a renaissance. The Coliseum plaza, where homeless people once camped in cardboard boxes, has open-air restaurants and crafts vendors. Its neighbor across Columbus Circle, once the Gulf and Western Building, is now billed as "the most important new address in the world" -- and the new owner, Donald J. Trump, has not even finished a top-to-bottom remodeling job that will turn it into hotel rooms and apartments.
The new shows at the Coliseum are a short-term answer to the question: What to do about the Coliseum? Officials said the M.T.A. has made no long-term decisions about the building, which was to have been demolished for an office, retail and residential complex planned by Mr. Zuckerman.
His plans were scaled down after complaints that the giant structure he had proposed would cast a long shadow on Central Park. Then real estate values plunged in the recession, which affected the economics of the deal.
It was the demise of Mr. Zuckerman's deal a year ago that made possible advance bookings for conventions. As long as he was in the picture, M.T.A. officials said, the agency had to write a 30-day cancellation clause into all contracts with exhibitors.
"Clearly, from a standpoint of any of these major trade shows, that was untenable for them," said John Tobin, one of the M.T.A. executives overseeing the Coliseum's new mission. "They'd say, 'To hell with it, we'll go to Atlantic City, where there's a hall with a contractual agreement that's definite.' "
Convention experts agree that New York also needed more space. Earlier in the year, a report by the city's Economic Development Corporation found that New York was losing business to cities like Chicago and Toronto, which can accommodate bigger shows. The same analysis concluded that New York City would end up with $30 million in taxes and 10,000 new jobs from a successful convention center at the Coliseum.
Deputy Mayor John S. Dyson, who holds a seat on the M.T.A. board, has long cautioned against siphoning off business from the Javits Center. But Robert E. Boyle, the president and chief executive of the Javits Center, said yesterday that he is not worried about the Coliseum bookings.
"The Coliseum's not really a competitor of ours," Mr. Boyle said, "and it probably can take some smaller shows that we can't accommodate, at least in the short term."
David Larkin, the largest producer of trade shows at the Javits Center, said that the two convention halls needed to coordinate their schedules. "Often people can't get in the Javits Center on the dates that they want," he said. "For that reason, to my mind, the Coliseum needs to be looked at as an arm of the Javits Center rather than as an independent profit center, which it will never be."
It is not clear how the Coliseum will affect the ship terminal, which is operated by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey under a lease from the city that expires at the end of next year. The Giuliani administration says it expects to seek proposals for other possible uses of the terminal. For promoters of midsize shows, there is now more than one choice.
Mr. Tobin said the M.T.A. will net about $400,000 from the 13 Coliseum events this year and has hired a consultant to study how to reduce operating expenses next year.
To prepare for the return of crowds, the M.T.A. has spruced up the Coliseum, though not much -- the agency has spent roughly $180,000 on repairs. "It's not the million dollars you'd spend to really make it a class facility," Mr. Tobin said.
Yesterday, breezing through the Coliseum lobby, Mr. Lester passed display booths taking shape for today's opening. He checked on a 28-foot-tall photograph being tied to a wall. And beside the escalators, which had just been switched on again, he watched what looked like a barn-raising: five workers were heaving timbers while another hammered nails to hold up a suddenly imposing structure.
"It's pretty chaotic," Mr. Lester said as electric saws whined and drills whirred. "And we're just in the early throes."
It is a scene that will be repeated often in coming months. The New York Race for the Cure, to raise money for a nonprofit organization that sponsors breast cancer research, is using a corner of one floor as a registration area starting today. "We get our name up on that huge marquee, which means a lot to us," said Peg Horan, a spokeswoman for the race.
Beth Goldberg, the race-day coordinator, said she had called hotel after hotel before she tried the Coliseum. "The hotels, even if they did have space, didn't want to dedicate such a large space to a group that wasn't going to be using rooms or catering rooms," she said.
Carol Ross, a producer of the New York Flower Show, said she was eager to make the switch.
"As soon as we heard it was reopening," she said, "we called to check it out. It's kind of a no-brainer. For a public show, the Coliseum is a much better, centrally accessible location. The subways are there, the buses are there, it's easy to get cabs outside."
By contrast, the ship terminal, which the flower show had rented in recent years, seemed too remote, and gardeners chafed at the 12-foot ceiling there. At the Coliseum, the ceiling is about 35 feet from the floor.
"Trees that we bring in will look taller at the Coliseum than at the pier with the ceiling touching it," Ms. Ross said. "You know, that wonderful illusion that comes with open space."

HEADLINE: Star at Conference on Women: Banker Who Lends to the Poor

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Sept. 13

 BODY:
If there is one man who has achieved stardom of sorts at the United Nations Fourth World Conference on Women, it is the soft-spoken economist from Bangladesh who wandered into a desperately poor village 20 years ago and got an idea that is changing the face of banking.
"Capital does not need to be the handmaiden only of the rich," said the economist, Muhammad Yunus, who founded the Grameen Bank to help poor people, especially women, by lending them small amounts of money so they could become self-sufficient entrepreneurs. 
 "Access to credit should be a human right," Mr. Yunus says, "irrespective of economic situation."
He is a pioneer in extending "micro-credit" for "micro-enterprises," a poverty-fighting strategy that is widely supported by delegates to the conference. In its "Platform for Action," the conference is seeking a commitment from governments and financial institutions to expand credit to poor women around the world.
"We need to teach commercial banks how to lend to low-income women," said Nancy Barry, a former official with the World Bank and president of Women's World Banking, which works with governments and financial institutions to stimulate small loans to women and create small-scale lending cooperatives and banks run by women.
Mr. Yunus says the owners of capital can be convinced that the poor represent a large, untapped credit market where survival instincts and local skills make the borrowers a good risk. As proof, the Grameen Bank had a loan volume of nearly $400 million last year and is approaching $500 million this year, making it the largest bank in the world serving the poor.
The bank has made small loans to two million families in 35,000 villages in Bangladesh, where more than 90 percent of the borrowers are women and repayment rates exceed 90 percent. Since Grameen served as the first large-scale demonstration that the poor are creditworthy, the concept has branched out to Latin American, Africa and Asia.
In 1985, micro-credit institutions and small credit cooperatives had about one million customers worldwide. While the figure today is approaching 10 million, it represents only 2 percent of the estimated 500 million women worldwide who have virtually no access to credit. Because the concept remains largely disconnected to the mainstream of international banking, many of the advocates here hope to organize a summit meeting on micro-banking in Washington next year.
"Traditional commercial bankers have not been trained to consider this sector of borrowers," said Kathleen Weber, an investment broker with Smith Barney Harris Upham & Company in Bellevue, Wash. "Lending to the destitute is so totally foreign to their education but it is proving itself to be a viable, sustainable and profitable program that also does a lot of social good."
Mr. Yunus began his experiment in 1976 by lending to poor women in a village near the University of Chittagong, where he was a lecturer. He noticed that while many of the women had the skill and the motivation to prosper, their businesses were drained by money lenders who charged usurious rates. So he lent money without collateral and created cells of five women who each could receive loans and guaranteed the repayment of the others. One might buy a duck to sell eggs; another cloth to sew; another bamboo to make stools.
"Someone had to demonstrate that it really works," he said.

HEADLINE: Stocks Rise, With Indexes Again at Highs

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
The stock market surged again yesterday, with the major indexes all establishing new records, but advancing stocks barely topped decliners on the New York Stock Exchange, the American Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq market.
"The most significant factor was that the market differentiated among stocks, not among groups," said Louis Ehrenkrantz, president of Ehrenkrantz King Nussbaum. 
 Once more, stocks were affected by the release of Government economic statistics. The Consumer Price Index inched up one-tenth of 1 percent last month, which caused bonds to soar early in the day and stocks to follow. Bonds soon gave back the gains, with the 30-year Treasury bond losing 8/32 ; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction of its price, rose to 6.52 percent, from 6.50 percent on Tuesday.
A separate report showed that earnings, adjusted for inflation, slid nine-tenths of 1 percent in August, after two consecutive monthly increases. Furthermore, the Federal Reserve, in its "beige book" report, indicated no significant change in the slowly growing economy of the last few weeks.
Spurred by program trading in the session's last hour, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 18.31 points, to 4,765.52, notching its 48th record in 1995, just a day after its previous record close. The Standard & Poor Corporation's 500-stock index rose 2.26 points, to 578.77, another in a series of record closes. And the Nasdaq composite index increased 2.40 points yesterday to its new closing high of 1,067.40.
Advances on the Big Board exceeded decliners, 1,192 to 1,087. A total of 384.4 million shares changed hands, compared with 373.6 million shares on Tuesday.
Shares of the Hewlett-Packard Company and Motorola Inc. were among the technology stocks that moved higher during the day. Hewlett-Packard increased 1 5/8 to 85 1/4 and Motorola rose 1 1/2 to 79 7/8.
But I.B.M. led other high-tech companies down. The company told analysts yesterday that problems with a line of mainframe systems would move certain revenue into the fourth quarter. Its shares fell 2 7/8, to 94 5/8; those of the Microsoft Corporation, the software giant, dropped 1/8, to 96 1/8.
Financial issues benefited from the perception that low inflation will result in falling interest rates, encouraging corporations and consumers to increase their borrowing. The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, also known as Freddie Mac, rose 5/8 a share, to 67 7/8; Dean Witter, Discover & Company, rose 3/4, to 57 3/4, and American International Group climbed 3/8, to 81 3/8.
Some fertilizer stocks were also among the day's standouts. Shares of the Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan closed at 68 3/8, up 2 1/2, and those of IMC Global Inc. closed at 65 1/8, up 7/8.
But automobile stocks slumped amid concern over third-quarter profits. The General Motors Corporation fell 3/4 a share, to 47, and the Ford Motor Company dropped 5/8, to 30 1/4.
Some steel stocks followed autos downward. Shares of the Rouge Steel Company dropped 5/8, to 25 1/8 and those of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation shed 3/8, to 14 3/8.
Gambling issues were lower; because of scandals, traders noted, Louisiana is considering curbs on its casino industry. Circus Circus Enterprises shares dropped 5/8, to 32, and those of the Hilton Hotels Corporation lost 2, to 64.
Pepsico Inc.'s stock rose 1 1/4 a share, to 48 3/4, after the company said it expected net income to advance by 15 percent next year. But Sports Authority Inc., which said it expects its third-quarter same-store sales to be flat, dropped 3 1/2 a share, to 25 1/4. And shares in Three-Five Systems Inc., which announced late on Monday that it expects lower third-quarter earnings, plunged 5 1/8, to 24 7/8.

HEADLINE: Upper Peninsula Journal;
Yes, They're Yoopers, and Proud of It

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER 

DATELINE: MARQUETTE, Mich.

 BODY:
The last copper mine on the Upper Peninsula of Michigan closed this summer at the town of White Pine, putting a thousand people out of work and ending an era. Back in the 1920's, this region produced 80 percent of the world's copper.
Another, briefer era ended in August, when the Air Force shut down its K. I. Sawyer Base 15 miles south of here. After Marquette, "Sawyer was the U. P.'s second-largest city, with 12,000 people," said David Edwards, managing editor of The Mining Journal here, using the common appellation for the peninsula. "We're heading for difficult times." The only thing booming on the peninsula now, Mr. Edwards added, is casino gambling on the reservations of the Chippewas, the Ojibwas and the Sioux. 
 The departure of copper mining and the Air Force has served to deepen a sense of separateness among Yoopers, as the people of the U. P. are called. Not that it was possible to deepen it by much. The geographical isolation of their region, combined with factors including extremes of climate that range from 30-inch snows in March to 100-degree readings in July, has long given Yoopers a self-identity distinct from that of Lower Michigan and sometimes even the rest of the United States.
About 88 percent of the Upper Peninsula's boundaries -- 1,700 miles -- are defined by the coastlines of Lake Superior, Lake Huron and Lake Michigan. The physical isolation, particularly from Lower Michigan, was especially palpable until 1957, when a suspension bridge across the five miles of the Mackinac Straits opened, connecting Michigan's southern region to its northern, where just 4 percent of the state's people occupy large stretches of land.
With the bridge, one of the world's largest, a new familiarity bred a measure of contempt. "Bomb the bridge!" some Upper Peninsula wags demanded. "Build a trapdoor in the northbound lanes," was another proposal.
Within a few years, there was a revival of a movement, more than a century old, to give the Upper Peninsula statehood, as the State of Superior. In 1962, a U.P. Independence Association was founded. In the early 1970's, Lower Michiganders started calling their northern cousins "Yupes," which quickly became "Yoopers." The response was to brand the southerners "Trolls," because they "live below the bridge."
Then Joe Zimmer erected a billboard proclaiming "Governor's Mansion" next to his mobile home on Highway 28 and proposing Bruce Crossing (population 551) in Ontonagon County as "the capital of the 51st state." A secession bill was submitted to the Legislature, and from 1983 to 1985 about 20,000 signatures were collected for a referendum on separation. That was short of the 36,000 required, but the spirit of independence lives on in the newly opened 51st State Saloon in Sault Ste. Marie.
In Ishpeming, a mining town west of here, Jim DeCaire and Joe Potila think "Yooper" should be "a thing of pride," as Mr. DeCaire put it. Twenty years ago they began composing and performing songs and patter as a duet called Da Yoopers, building a repertory with all the subtlety of a chain saw. Their titles include "I Married a Couch Dat Burps."
Despite the coarseness, Da Yoopers' emphasis on the details of Upper Peninsula life -- combat with mosquito swarms in the summer, blizzards in the long winters, and deer hunting combined with beer drinking -- has won them many fans. Part of their appeal lies in their devotion to the Upper Peninsula's collective dialect, which draws on Cornish and Italian from immigrant miners, the French of Canadian trappers and the Finnish of farmers and loggers.
The Finnish substratum is strong in the idiom some call Yoopanese, said Stewart Kingsbury, a Northern Michigan University professor, both in phrases like "let's go store" for "let's go to the store" and in the substitution of "da" for "the."
Not all inhabitants of the Upper Peninsula choose to subscribe to the crass identity promoted by Da Yoopers. "A lot of my old friends don't like it," said Fred Rydholm, a fourth-generation Yooper who has written a two-volume history of the area. Yet he recently entered into the spirit by donating a patched set of his "historical long underwear" to the musical group's reproduction of a North Woods deer camp at Ishpeming.
Kaye Hiebel, a Marquette artist, said that while outsiders thought of the U.P. as "hunting, fishing and snowmobiles," there were also "fine-craft traditions and creativity here." In April, a Northern Michigan University musical, "Haywire," about a 19th-century logging crew, was a winner in the 27th annual American College Theater Festival at the Kennedy Center in Washington.
Jim Harrison, an internationally acclaimed novelist from Michigan, has set some of his work in the Upper Peninsula, including the novella "Brown Dog," in which the title character says of the boreal forest: "The woods can be a bit strange. It takes a long time to feel you belong there, and then you never again really belong in town."

GRAPHIC: Photo: For a long time, northern Michiganders' sense of geographical isolation was especially palpable. Then, in 1957, this five-mile-long bridge across the Mackinac Straits linked the Upper Peninsula to the rest of the state. (John L. Russell for The New York Times)
 
Map shows the location of the Michigan Upper Peninsula.

HEADLINE: U.S. Reports Economy Up But Not Prices

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13

 BODY:
Economic growth, while still spotty, perked up in the late summer even as inflation stayed firmly in check, two Government reports showed today.
The Labor Department said consumer prices edged up a scant one-tenth of 1 percent in August, leaving the Consumer Price Index up just 2.6 percent over the last 12 months. And price pressures have eased in recent months. The three-month compound annual rate was a mere 1.9 percent. 
 The Federal Reserve, in its periodic roundup of economic conditions across the country in what is known as the beige book, said reports from its 12 regional districts "point to some further expansion in economic activity" during the five weeks through Labor Day. "Industrial activity appears to have stabilized and in some areas may now be strengthening," the Fed found. The report added that construction had picked up in many of the districts. But "soft" sectors, like retailing and agriculture, were hurt by unusually hot and dry summer weather.
New York and Dallas were exceptions to the general pattern, with business conditions in these areas characterized as having "deteriorated" since the previous beige book report was published on Aug. 9.
The Fed surveys its districts as part of the preparation for meetings of its Federal Open Market Committee, which gathers eight times a year to set monetary policy. The next meeting is scheduled for Sept. 26.
Echoing the monthly consumer price survey, the Fed researchers also found "no clear change in underlying price pressure."
But this favorable combination of modestly faster growth and stable prices was accompanied in August by a sizable drop in average weekly earnings. After significant increases the two previous months, the August drop pulled earnings, adjusted for inflation, back below where they were 12 months earlier. One analyst, noting that many experts had referred to the sluggish economy of the early 1990's as the "jobless" recovery, said a more appropriate expression these days might be the "wageless" recovery.
The analyst, Nicholas S. Perna, chief economist for the Shawmut National Corporation in Boston, noted that the decline in real wages, for all the difficulties it had created for many families, offered an unexpected bonus. "Inflation is far less of a problem than even the optimists thought it would be," Mr. Perna said.
On Tuesday, the Labor Department reported that prices received by producers fell slightly in August, the third straight month without an increase.
With the Consumer Price Index, the Labor Department was able to calculate that real average weekly earnings in August slumped nine-tenths of 1 percent on a seasonally adjusted basis. This reflected declines in weekly hours worked and hourly earnings coupled with the loss of purchasing power from slightly higher prices. As of August, real earnings were one-tenth of 1 percent below the level a year ago.
The Fed's beige book survey found "little change in price pressures" since midsummer "and there is little apparent concern about an acceleration" in the near future.
The labor market was tight in some areas, such as for construction workers in the Richmond and San Francisco districts, but for the most part wage pressure was mild, the report found.
As for manufacturing, the slowdown reported five weeks ago seems to have leveled off, the Fed reported, with Philadelphia among the districts where it strengthened a bit. But New York was singled out as the only district where factory output continued to fall.
More than offsetting weakness in New York City-area manufacturing, however, was strength in other kinds of business. Tourism, especially from abroad, was particularly strong during the summer.
"On balance," the report said of the New York district, "growth has slowed in recent weeks," as retail sales weakened significantly and residential construction across much of New York State and northern New Jersey remained slow in July and August.
On the inflation front, a six-tenths of 1 percent decline for transportation, which represents 17 percent of the Consumer Price Index, contributed to the minimal rise in prices. Airline fares, which surged in the first half of the year, tumbled 3.5 percent last month after falling 1.3 percent in July. Gasoline prices fell an additional 2.9 percent. And the price of used cars fell for the fourth straight month. But the plunge followed a sustained period of sharp increases that left used cars 9 percent more costly than in August 1994.
Tomato prices fell 24.8 percent, reversing a June-July jump of that magnitude, to help limit the food and beverage component to a rise of two-tenths of 1 percent. Alcoholic beverages rose seven-tenths of 1 percent, the most in four and a half years.
In the "other goods and services" component, higher fall semester tuition charges at schools and colleges accounted for more than half the five-tenths of 1 percent advance, the biggest since February.
Not counting food and energy, which are subject to large swings, consumer prices climbed two-tenths of 1 percent for the fourth straight month, the Labor Department's report also showed.
For the New York metropolitan area, overall prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent after a rise of four-tenths of 1 percent in July.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Ebb Despite News of Low Inflation

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities ended lower yesterday as concerns that economic growth might be accelerating outweighed favorable data on inflation.
The Treasury's 30-year bond fell 8/32 , to 10422/32 , while its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.52 percent, from 6.50 percent on Tuesday.
 
 Government reports issued this week showed that consumer and wholesale prices were rising at a slower rate than they were earlier in the year and that annual inflation was running at less than 3 percent, a level many economists see as comfortable. Yesterday, the Labor Department said the Consumer Price Index rose only one-tenth of 1 percent in August.
Although the price reports were bullish for the market, traders were concerned that the retail sales report due today would show robust growth.
Holders of fixed-income investments fear strong economic growth because they see it as leading to higher inflation, which erodes the value of their assets.
"The inflation numbers are basically playing second fiddle to anxiety about a strong retail sales number," said Alfred Roth, trading floor manager at the First Chicago Corporation. "The feeling is that retail sales are going to be strong because of strong car sales."
Economists generally expect retail sales to show a gain of seven-tenths of 1 percent for August, but just one-tenth of 1 percent when excluding the automobile sector.
A strong retail sales report, which would indicate that the economy is bouncing back after a sluggish first half of the year, would also make the Federal Reserve less likely to lower interest rates anytime soon, analysts said.
"Over all, the C.P.I. was very market-friendly, but people don't think inflation is a problem right now," said Patrick Dimick, Treasury analyst at CS First Boston.
The price index for August was held down by declines in gasoline and other transportation prices. Excluding the volatile food and energy prices, the index rose two-tenths of 1 percent.
Bond prices rose after the report, but the gains were brief. The two-year note closed down 2/32 , to a price of 10012/32 , while its yield rose to 5.79 percent. The 10-year note fell 6/32 , to 10212/32 , to yield 6.18 percent.
Yesterday, the Fed released its latest survey of national economic conditions, the so-called beige book. The report said that the economy kept expanding in most parts of the country in August and that there was no clear indication of upward price pressures. It also said consumer spending was sluggish in August.
The survey will be used by members of the Fed's policy-setting group, the Federal Open Market Committee, when it meets on Sept. 26 to consider interest rates.
Analysts said the bright picture painted by the beige book and comments yesterday by several Federal Reserve officials showed that the central bank was pleased with the economy's performance. That view, they said, casts doubt on a rate cut anytime soon.
In the municipal market, prices finished flat to 1/4 point lower as institutional investors put $500 million to $600 million of bonds up for sale in the secondary market.
Investment-grade corporate bond prices closed in line with Treasuries as the market again focused on new issues. Reebok International, Avalon Properties and Royal Caribbean Cruises issued a combined $350 million of debt.
Israel priced a $500 million debt issue, guaranteed by a United States Government agency.
Junk-bond prices were up slightly on weak trading as the market awaited $2.5 billion of new issues expected next week, traders said. Another $3.5 billion or more is scheduled to price soon after, traders added.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Without a two-war script, arms spending could really be cut.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
THE fight over military spending is heating up as the House and Senate duel over funds for key weapons and President Clinton threatens to veto any appropriations bill that includes money for arms the Pentagon says it does not want.
Well, that is the standard story, anyway. And it is indeed true that the futures of three gee-whiz weapons systems -- the B-2 Stealth bomber, the Seawolf attack submarine and a pared-down Star Wars missile defense -- are under attack by deficit fighters. "Everyone is rummaging around in the basement now, looking for programs to trash," said William Hartung, a senior research fellow at the New School's World Policy Institute. 
 "But connoisseurs of the politics of denial need not despair," Mr. Hartung added. The few billion dollars that are on the line are petty cash compared with the quarter-trillion budgeted annually to be able to fight two wars simultaneously -- a relic of cold war planning that no elected official is questioning.
It is easy to work up a righteous lather over the current weapons debate, which has all the Alice-in-Wonderland qualities of the earlier theological dispute over whether 10,000 nuclear warheads were sufficient to deter Soviet aggression. With 20 B-2 bombers already on order for $2.2 billion each -- each nearly the price of a nuclear aircraft carrier -- and serious questions being raised about the plane's stealthiness, support for building more is limited to a coalition of weapons contractors and members of Congress who have overdosed on Tom Clancy novels.
Much the same can be said for the third Seawolf submarine, priced at $1.5 billion, which is being rationalized as a means of keeping Connecticut and Virginia boat builders on the technological edge and Bill Clinton in the White House. "Even liberals now see defense spending as the form of pork least likely to be challenged," suggested Mr. Hartung, whose critical commentary on military budgeting appears in the fall issue of the World Policy Journal.
In fact, the whole arms debate is taking place at the margin of reality. What really drives spending, argues Lawrence Korb of the Brookings Institution, is the underlying doctrine that dictates a very large and mobile military capable of fighting two wars the size of the Persian Gulf war at the same time.
This policy was born in the last years of the Bush Administration, when the Soviet empire was collapsing, and the chances that Russia would commit the Red Army to a conventional war with any of America's allies was receding rapidly. Gen. Colin L. Powell, then Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, imagined worst-case developments that conveniently justified outlays and personnel equal to late cold war levels.
To be sure, the $250 billion budget for the two-war plan is far less in inflation-adjusted terms than defense spending in the Reagan years. But $250 billion, Mr. Korb notes, is still more than the combined spending for the world's next 10 largest military establishments. Is it really needed?
Not according to Gen. Merrill McPeak, the recently retired Air Force Chief of Staff, who pointed out that America has fought major conventional wars just three times in the last 45 years -- and never two at a time. Indeed, the closer one looks at the two-war plan, the less realistic it seems. It is difficult to imagine two Iraq-like rogue states risking wars that America felt compelled to enter. On the other hand, it is difficult to imagine that America's next foes would cooperate with the Pentagon by leaving themselves wide open to American power.
What's driving this nondebate over arms strategy, Mr. Korb argues, is the peculiar politics of the moment. "During the Reagan years, Democratic Congresses tried to chop away at spending," he said. But with the White House occupied by a Democrat who is eager to protect himself from charges of being soft on security, and Congressional moderates from both parties unprepared to take further whacks at jobs in the military industry, "the spending bar has been set so high that there is nothing really left to argue about," Mr. Korb said.
The precondition for changing policy, Mr. Korb suggests, is a Republican in the White House who is less vulnerable to ideological attack. If Richard M. Nixon could go to China, he reasons, perhaps Bob Dole could trim the military budget to $200 billion. Mr. Hartung said $160 billion was a realistic target for one big war plus limited police actions.
Another possibility is that military cuts will become the path of least resistance for a Congress caught between a pledge to balance the budget and 40 million older people who think Medicare is the greatest invention since Metamucil. But Mr. Hartung is not betting on it. "Defense contractors have moved quickly to make friends with the new Republican majority," he said.

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
Mr. Rockefeller Regrets

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN 

 BODY:
This has not been an easy year for David Rockefeller. The Chase Manhattan Bank, long associated with his family, has been swallowed up by Chemical Bank, forcing Mr. Rockefeller to expressions of gratitude that its name would be kept. Now Rockefeller Center is in financial ruins, up for grabs in a bidding war. In February, Mr. Rockefeller had the unpleasant experience of flying to Japan to plead with the people to whom he sold the world's most prestigious office complex not to declare bankruptcy. But before the meeting began, he fell on the sidewalk and broke his leg.
In financial terms, however, the Chase deal has strengthened the value of the substantial Rockefeller holdings in that bank, and the Rockefeller Center debacle has left the Rockefeller family with a huge financial return. The bankruptcy flowed, after all, from the fact that the Rockefellers managed to sell Rockefeller Center at an inflated price -- not once, but in effect twice. In 1985, the family mortgaged it for $1.3 billion, pocketing an estimated $300 million for themselves. A few years later it sold 80 percent of the property itself to Mitsubishi Estate in Tokyo for $1.4 billion. As a result, $1.7 billion was reaped from properties that are now said to be worth a fraction of that sum. 
 History will likely judge the collapse of Rockefeller Center as, among other things, a milestone in the transfer of the family fortune from the patriarch's generation to the "cousins," many of them restless to cash in on their patrimony.
The first fateful decision in the saga came in 1985, with the establishment by the Rockefellers of an independent publicly held real estate investment trust, which raised money from the public and then lent $1.3 billion to the Rockefeller family using the center as collateral. Tens of thousands of small investors put their money in the trust, many no doubt assuming that the Rockefeller name was a guarantee that it would be safe and secure.
At the end of the last decade, Mitsubishi -- the wealthiest company in the wealthiest industry in Japan -- bought 80 percent of Rockefeller Center for $1.4 billion. Along with the property, of course, came the obligation to service the earlier $1.3 billion mortgage. Plenty of experts thought the price was too high, but Mitsubishi wanted to assert some sort of manifest destiny. The company already owned virtually all of the Marunouchi district, which is the heart of Tokyo's financial district.
But the laws of gravity asserted themselves in the 1990's. Even the Rockefellers and Mitsubishi were not immune to the collapse of real estate values in New York and the end of the "bubble economy" in Japan, which was built on inflated stock and real estate prices. At Rockefeller Center, leases for many of the most prestigious tenants expired in 1994. Instead of being renewed at the high rents projected years earlier, the leases renewed at discount rents insufficient to pay for operating an aging building and servicing a gargantuan mortgage. As a result, the value of shares in the real estate investment trust plummeted. So did Mr. Rockefeller's standing among the trust investors and the Japanese.
Mr. Rockefeller argues that the world's premier commercial address could have been saved from bankruptcy. But Mitsubishi concluded that it was staring into a bottomless pit, and that it was time to cut its losses at the $2 billion threshold. As with so many star-crossed deals between Americans and Japanese of the 1980's, the Rockefeller Center sale was built on arrogance and the players' inflated view of each other's intentions.
The Rockefellers were surprised that the Japanese would be willing to lose face and cut their losses. The Japanese lost faith in David Rockefeller when he tried to work out a plan to save the property from bankruptcy without putting up more of his own family's money.
With bankruptcy, the real estate investment trust owns Rockefeller Center now. It is anybody's guess which outsiders, if any, will join in that ownership by investing, restructuring the mortgage and taking other steps to make the property viable again. Maybe it will be the group led by Sam Zell of Chicago and the Walt Disney Company. Maybe it will be someone else.
In 1911, John D. Rockefeller's business manager, Frederick T. Gates, famously warned his patron to move fast to diversify his vast fortune. "If you do not," he said, "it will crush you, and your children, and your children's children." As the century closes, this most amazing of America's wealthy families is still ruthlessly heeding the lesson, without much sentiment for the monuments that its wealth once created. STEVEN R. WEISMAN

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Essay;
Stop Computer Slots

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
At last: a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination has come up with a moral issue that the next President and Congress can actually do something about.
The issue is state-sponsored gambling, a $40 billion-a-year cancer ravaging society, corrupting public officials and becoming the fastest growing teen-age addiction. 
 "The spread of gambling," Senator Richard Lugar told the Christian Coalition, "is a measure of the moral erosion taking place in our country. . . . It says that if you play enough, you can hit the jackpot and be freed from the discipline of self-support through a job or the long commitment to ongoing education."
In New York last week, Mario Cuomo's tawdriest legacy -- a form of keno known as "Quick Draw" -- introduced casino-style gambling to teen-agers at candy stores, using computer terminals to lure kids into shooting modern craps.
In Connecticut, the race for a casino in Bridgeport is down to bidding between Mirage Resorts (an apt name for the gambler's goal) and a recently re-formed "tribe" of Indians called the Pequots, whose chiefs are turning aboriginal Americans into a nation of croupiers.
In Mississippi, the money spent on gambling last year exceeded all the taxable retail sales in the state. Across the nation, under the fake cover of "supporting education," gambling interests offer a down-and-dirty fix to weak legislators.
It's about time someone running for President put this national rip-off on the nation's agenda. Lugar rightly slams adult hypocrisy: "We cannot tolerate the 'get rich quick' symbolism of gambling, while pleading with our children to avoid other 'tosses of the dice' that lead to unhealthy living and destructive behavior."
His challenge is suitable for the Christian Coalition: Its members may not be able to legislate morality, but here is where they can campaign to stop legislating immorality. A family-values movement to turn the tide of gambling is an issue whose moral moment has come.
Representative Frank Wolf, the Virginia Republican, has offered a bill to establish a National Commission on the Impact of Gambling. Senators Lugar and Paul Simon have a matching bill in the Senate. The commission would provide unbiased answers to "How does gambling affect suicide and crime rates among juveniles? What effect does a casino have on a city's economy? Who loses the money that makes gambling such a profitable business, and who then has to support the losers' families?"
The gambling lobby does not want those questions asked, much less answered. The American Gaming Association has been launched in Washington D.C., with a lobbying kitty of $2 million for openers, to block the Wolf-Lugar bill. ("Gaming" is what gamblers want us to call their racket because it connotes "play"; but when you lose the milk money, you have gambled, not "gamed," it away.)
Chief lobbyist for the gamblers is Frank Fahrenkopf, the Nevada lawyer who was chairman of the Republican National Committee. Frank got me coveted floor passes to several national conventions, and I wish he could find a less despicable way to make a living, such as representing tobacco interests or lobbying for an end to sanctions on Saddam Hussein.
His shock troops to block the gambling probe will be the Gambling Caucus in the House, led by a freshman from Nevada, John Ensign; the veteran Barbara Vucanovich, also of that gambler's paradise, and New Jersey's Frank LoBiondo.
The hearing on Wolf's bid to lift the lid on state-sponsored immorality will be held before the Judiciary Committee on Sept. 29. Chairman Henry Hyde, hero of the Christian Coalition for his principled stand against abortion, takes a straddle on this issue: "I am not a fan of, nor a zealot against, gambling," he tells me, adding with a sigh, "a little hope springs eternal." As things stand, the bill will die in committee.
Unless moralists -- including most particularly those in the Christian Coalition -- get the lead out of their vestments. Is the Republican Party to be the party of gambling, corrupting the very family values it preaches? Clinton is no help; his amoral approach is to add a Federal gambling tax to state taxes, which only puts the Feds in bed with the gamblers.
Get the government to stop promoting gambling. Listen to Lugar.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Port Authority Won't Soon Abandon Economic Forecast Role

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "New York Is, or Was, a Model for London" (Op-Ed, Sept. 8), Tony Travers chastises the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey for announcing that it will not be raising tolls and fares, claiming this will lead to a diminution in the agency's economic forecasting, one of its functions. 
 Leaving aside the amusing notion that London has a developing economy and has to take its lead from New York, the real contradiction in Mr. Travers's article is that the Port Authority is doing exactly what Mr. Travers finds so enlightening for London, and seems to think that the New York-New Jersey region is abandoning. He writes:
"Paradoxically, at just the time New York and New Jersey officials may be scaling back their valuable research base at the Port Authority, London is trying to create just such a centralized structure for economic analysis. The Port Authority's operation is a model."
Although "consolidating" is a more appropriate word, centralizing research efforts is integral to our reorganization. It is part of our strategy to adapt the agency to changing business demands.
The Port Authority has six departments claiming economic analysis as a major part of their mission. While we are eliminating duplications and redundancy, we are evaluating the importance of the economic analysis function by placing it in the Office of Corporate Policy and Planning reporting directly to the executive director.
Mr. Travers notes, "For many years, New York has had to work hard to keep businesses from fleeing to other areas with lower taxes." Yes, and adding to transportation costs with excessively high user fees doesn't contribute to regional economic growth either.
I'm not exactly sure why Mr. Travers takes such great interest in the affairs of the Port Authority, but perhaps his research group at the London School of Economics should factor the combined burdens of taxation and user fees into their economic forecasts. Maybe New York is a model for London after all.
 
JOHN J. HALEY JR.
First Deputy Executive Director
Port Authority of New York
and New Jersey
New York, Sept. 8, 1995

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Medicare Logic Needs a Closer Look

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Speaker Newt Gingrich (letter, Sept. 10) euphemistically calls the Republican proposal to cut $270 billion out of Medicare "an increase, not a reduction." Mr. Gingrich's reasoning, however, is inconsistent with arguments he has made in the past. 
 For years, Newt Gingrich railed against Democratic proposals to "cut" the defense budget. The budget was growing every year, although not always at the rate of inflation. Using the Speaker's Medicare logic, Democrats weren't cutting defense at all, but merely slowing its rate of growth.
Nevertheless, year afer year Mr. Gingrich screamed that Democrats were crippling America's national defense.
Another example of the Speaker's double-talk is in the area of tax cuts, cuts that he loves to talk about. Under the House Republican "tax cut" proposal, the American people's tax bill will be $450 billion larger in 2002 than it will be next year.
Again, using the Speaker's logic, this "cut" is actually a massive tax increase. Naturally, Mr. Gingrich hails this as a cut.
Newt Gingrich should be consistent. His verbal manipulation does not help the American people understand the changes they will face if Congress cuts Medicare. Simply put, when you spend less, you get less.
The proposed Medicare cuts will mean higher monthly payments, fewer services and closed hospitals.
 
CHARLES E. SCHUMER
Member of Congress, 10th Dist, N.Y.
Washington, Sept. 12, 1995

HEADLINE: On Vietnam, Kennedy White House Flew Blind

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "McNamara's War, and Mine" by Louis G. Sarris (Op-Ed, Sept. 5): 
 (1) On page 32 of "In Retrospect" I wrote: "When the Berlin crisis occurred in 1961, and during the Cuban missile crisis in 1962, President Kennedy was able to turn to senior people like Llewellyn Thompson, Charles Bohlen and George Kennan, who knew the Soviets intimately. There were no senior officials in the Pentagon or State Department with comparable knowledge of Southeast Asia."
Mr. Sarris writes, "This statement is untrue." But it is he who is incorrect.
Mr. Thompson, Mr. Bohlen and Mr. Kennan had studied Soviet history, culture and politics for decades, and had associated socially and professionally with the top Russian leaders, including Nikita S. Khrushchev. We had no counterparts with respect to South Vietnam, North Vietnam or China. As a result, during the period just before and after the overthrow of President Ngo Dinh Diem of South Vietnam, we were flying blind.
The erroneous decisions were ours, and we must accept the responsibility for them, but the absence of experienced senior advisers helps explain the errors.
(2) Mr. Sarris states: "The basic problem was the unwillingness of McNamara and other top policy makers to accept the relevance of information with which they personally disagreed."
I don't believe the record supports that judgment. On the contrary, the President, Dean Rusk, McGeorge Bundy, Bill Bundy, the Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Affairs, and I were all skeptical of much of the information we received, not because we questioned the integrity of the originators of the reports, but because we doubted their ability to penetrate and understand the complex political, economic, social and military environment and actions they were reporting.
(3) Mr. Sarris states that just before the assassination of President Kennedy, "the groundwork was being laid for our tragic escalation of the war."
I believe the record shows that far from planning an escalation, President Kennedy had decided -- and publicly announced on Oct. 2, 1963 -- that the United States would plan to withdraw its military forces by the end of 1965 and would start by withdrawing 1,000 (of our 16,000 men) by the end of 1963.
I state on page 79 that the debate in the National Security Council "reflected a total lack of consensus over where we stood in meeting our objectives." But the President nonetheless authorized the beginning of withdrawal, believing that either our training and logistical support led to the progress claimed or, if it had not, additional training would not change the situation and, in either case, we should plan to withdraw.
(4) With respect to the coup that overthrew President Diem, Mr. Sarris appears to be saying that some Pentagon officials fixed responsibility on the State Department and, in particular, on his analysis. That may have been the view of some Defense officials, but it was not and is not mine. I believe that United States support of the overthrow of President Diem was a mistake, but I hold the senior officials -- the President, Dean Rusk and me -- responsible, not Mr. Sarris.
 
ROBERT S. McNAMARA
Washington, Sept. 12, 1995

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Inflation News Lifts Stocks Into Record Territory
 The stock market surged again, buoyed by several Government reports indicating that inflation remained in check. All the major indexes set records, but winners barely topped losers. 
 The Dow industrials rose 18.31 points, to 4,765,52, and the S.& P. 500-stock index was up 2.26 points, to 578.77. The Nasdaq composite index climbed 2.40 points, to 1,067.40. [Page D8.]
 The dollar climbed to a 15-month high, trading as high as 103.75 yen in Tokyo early today before retreating. [D15.]
 
Justice Department Requests More Data on Disney-ABC Deal
 Walt Disney and Capital Cities/ABC disclosed that the Justice Department had asked for more information on their proposed $19 billion merger. Some analysts were surprised, but Disney said it did not expect the request to derail the deal. [D7.]
 
Judge Rules Against Dow Corning
 Dow Corning's Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing cannot shield its parent companies, the Dow Chemical Company and the Corning Corporation, from thousands of lawsuits totaling billions of dollars on breast implants, a Federal judge ruled in Detroit. [D8.]
 
Compromise in Banking Bill
 The chairmen of the House Banking and Rules committees reached a tentative compromise to eliminate one obstacle to the removal of legislative barriers that separate the banking and securities industries. [D4.]
 
Company Accused in Fraud
 The S.E.C. accused Qualified Pensions of Glendale, Calif., and its president, Jerry G. Allison, of violating Federal securities laws and misappropriating at least $4.5 million from the retirement accounts of more than 14,500 savers across the country. [D2.]
 
Hospitals in Antitrust Lawsuits
 In the first antitrust lawsuits of their kind, the Justice Department charged hospitals and doctors in Danbury, Conn., and St. Joseph, Mo., with illegal price-fixing to keep out lower-cost managed care companies. [B6.]
 
Dependent-Care Project Expanded
 Expanding a program that was started three years ago, 21 of the nation's largest corporations, including AT&T and Citicorp, will contribute to a $100 million project to help employees care for dependents. [D4.]
 
Arrests in Computer Pornography
 The F.B.I. made at least a dozen arrests and searched 120 homes nationwide, ending a two-year investigation into the use of America Online to distribute child pornography and arrange sex with children. [A1.]
 
Battle Over K.F.C. in India
 India's first Kentucky Fried Chicken restaurant was closed by local authorities in Bangalore, then swiftly reopened under a court order, as nationalists pressed efforts to curb the entry of foreign corporations. City authorities cited what was termed as an infringement of Indian health rules after a local farmers' group protested. [D5.]
 
Pledge on a Lilco Plan
 The new chairman of the Long Island Power Authority pledged to meet Gov. George E. Pataki's 12-week deadline to develop a plan to lower electricity rates on Long Island and to dismantle Long Island Lighting. [B4.]
 
New Effort in Sports Ads
 TV viewers who have become used to rotating billboards behind home plate and at basketball scorers' tables may soon see electronically inserted ads that appear to be part of the actual background. Advertising. [D7.]

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
WESTINGHOUSE GETS FINANCING FOR CBS PURCHASE

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation has signed loan agreements with the Chemical Banking Corporation and J. P. Morgan & Co. to pay for Westinghouse's $5.4 billion purchase of CBS Inc. The loan deals beat deadlines set in the buyout pact. Westinghouse, a Pittsburgh-based broadcasting and industrial company must still get approval from the Federal Communications Commission and CBS shareholders, and it expects to do so by year's end. The Justice Department raised no antitrust objections. CBS owns the CBS television network as well as TV and radio stations. Westinghouse owns TV and radio stations. The banks are earning fees of about 2 percent of the loan commitments and interest rates of 1.75 percentage points over certain bank rates.
