HEADLINE: Report to Seek Some Changes In Nasdaq

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
A long-awaited report on the Nasdaq stock market, the nation's fastest-growing equity market, will call for changes in the market's governance and supervisory mechanisms, but will not call for a major supervisory overhaul, according to people familiar with the new study.
The report by former Senator Warren B. Rudman, a New Hampshire Republican, will recommend increased public representation on the boards of that stock market, and its parent, the National Association of Securities Dealers, as well as a significant boost in the market's enforcement capabilities, according to people familiar with the new study. 
 The report, which is due to be presented to the N.A.S.D. board on Monday and be released to the public later in the week, is also expected to discuss the relationship between the N.A.S.D. and the Nasdaq market, which the association both manages and oversees, a potential conflict of interest that galls many of the market's critics. But the Rudman report is expected to shy away from recommending a complete overhaul of that controversial relationship.
N.A.S.D. has come under increasing criticism in the last two years about whether the way securities are traded and priced is fair to investors. This criticism has led to an investigation of the exchange's practices by both the Justice Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission. Senator Rudman's report is part of a N.A.S.D. effort to be seen as addressing its problems before any potential Government intervention.
Hired by the N.A.S.D., Senator Rudman with a team of six other financial and economic experts has for the last 10 months conducted interviews and research to pull the report together. Arthur Levitt Jr., the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, recommended Senator Rudman to the N.A.S.D. board.
"I get a sense that what they're really going to do is talk about the governance of the place," said George J. Benston, a professor of finance, accounting and economics at Emory University, who studies the Nasdaq and has consulted on it. But the new report is expected to avoid some thorny issues that face the fast-growing market. "I think they're avoiding the price-fixing issue," Professor Benston added, alluding to allegations, denied by the market and the N.A.S.D., that Nasdaq dealers collude to fix prices.
There is significant pressure on the Nasdaq market and its self-regulated parent, the N.A.S.D., to be responsive to the Rudman committee report, and it is likely that many of its recommendations will be carried out quickly. The S.E.C. and the Justice Department are currently conducting their own investigations of the Nasdaq market, particularly because of the late-reporting habits of many market participants, and concern about reported price-fixing.
The Rudman report is therefore just the first shoe to drop, and it is likely that the N.A.S.D. and the Nasdaq market will try to act quickly on it, not least to deflect any expected criticisms from the S.E.C. and the Justice Department, particularly in the areas of enforcement and regulation. The Nasdaq has recently moved to strengthen enforcement, hiring as many as a dozen extra people in this area since the beginning of the year, according to one market consultant.
The Nasdaq market, where about 5,000 companies quote their shares, has grown very rapidly in recent years, and during August had an average daily volume of 372.8 million shares, a 26.3 percent increase on its 1994 average daily volume of 295.1 million shares. Its share volume this year has outstripped that of the New York Stock Exchange, which is eager to try to attract many of the larger technology companies that are currently quoted on the Nasdaq. The Intel Corporation, the Microsoft Corporation, the Oracle Systems Corporation, the Cisco Systems Corporation, Tele-Communications Inc. and the MCI Communications Corporation are the most traded stocks on the Nasdaq market. And it is generally the market where many of the country's fastest-growing companies, particularly those in high technology, are listed and traded.
Unlike the New York or American Stock Exchanges, Nasdaq does not have an exchange building or floor. Stock prices are transmitted by a computer system that carries price quotes offered by brokerage firms. Trades are executed via telephone and computer.
One of the Nasdaq market's problems is that it has grown so rapidly that its regulators have had trouble keeping up. The late reporting of trades, in particular, has been a continual problem. The size of the difference between the price offered and the price asked for stocks also has generated controversy. That, in turn, has led to allegations that the large price spreads are evidence of price-fixing by dealers in the market.
A study by William G. Christie, a professor at Vanderbilt University, and Paul Schultz, a professor at Ohio State University, concluded that people who make markets in Nasdaq stocks "implicitly agree" to maintain price spreads that are wider than they otherwise might be. By doing so, the market-makers reportedly collude to fix prices, according to some market critics. Wider spreads would offer market-makers the opportunity to make bigger profits.
The Christie-Schultz study helped to spur a class-action lawsuit against 33 Nasdaq stock market dealers -- including such firms as Goldman, Sachs & Company and Merrill Lynch & Company -- filed on behalf of small investors. All the firms charged have strongly denied that they collude to manipulate prices on the Nasdaq markets. In an agreement reached yesterday, defense attorneys for the Nasdaq dealers agreed to hand over to the small investors' lawyers tapes of dealers discussing the prices of stocks. The plaintiffs contend that the recordings show that dealers tried to keep bid and offer prices artificially far apart, a contention denied by the defense.
The issue of reported price-fixing continues to attract a huge amount of professional and academic interest. In the latest twist in that debate, the Financial Economists Roundtable will release a statement about Nasdaq on Monday that will discuss the issue of reported collusion between dealers, and other market matter, said Hans R. Stoll, a professor of finance at Vanderbilt University.

HEADLINE: Era Ends at Port Authority As 160 Workers Are Laid Off

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
Wanda Rivera was sitting at her desk at the headquarters of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday morning grimly watching her co-workers being summoned one by one into an office to receive the news that they were being laid off. Then her phone rang. The display said the call was coming from extension 4479. That office. Ms. Rivera knew it was her turn.
"I thought: it is finally here, the dreaded moment," said Ms. Rivera, 31, a secretary. "I was nervous and frustrated and angry and all sorts of feelings combined." 
 After weeks of bouncing between despair and hope, Ms. Rivera and more than 160 other people lost their jobs yesterday in the first large-scale layoffs at the Port Authority since the Depression. The reductions ushered in a new era for an agency that had long seemed able to dodge the kind of sharp cuts that government and industry have been subjected to in recent years.
But the authority is now being overseen by Gov. George E. Pataki and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, two Republicans who have vowed to trim its size just as they have scaled back their own states' work forces. Yesterday's layoffs, most of which were at the authority's headquarters at the World Trade Center, were the first phase of reductions that are to total at least 600 positions by early next year, from a staff of about 8,800.
The cuts, intended to avoid an increase in the authority's tolls and commuter railway fare, left a tense scene at the authority's offices in the World Trade Center. In some departments, workers sobbed as they packed up the contents of their desks, saying they were bitter about devoting so many years of their lives to an agency that is now casting them aside.
"I am angry, because when you have been with a company almost nine years, it's almost like it's your second family," said Debra Ashe, 35, a senior office assistant at the office of economic and policy analysis, which is being disbanded, doing away with more than 40 jobs. "It really hurts. You expect to stay here and continue working and retire here one day."
The cuts seemed to sting all the more because the authority was known for nurturing its workers and protecting them from the turmoil that often roils government agencies when new governors or mayors are elected.
"This is the Port Authority," said John Dunham, 31, who was dismissed as a senior economic analyst. "Come on, the Port Authority never laid off anyone."
Mr. Dunham, who arrived at the authority only 15 months ago, added, "It has a reputation and history that is now gone."
The layoffs were such a departure for the authority that it held training sessions for senior officials on Thursday on how to dismiss people. The officials were put through exercises in which they pretended they were telling workers they were being dismissed and then described the benefits the workers were entitled to.
Those being laid off are to remain on the payroll until Oct. 15 and then get a severance package that takes into consideration age and seniority and will average about three months pay per worker, officials said. The authority has also set up a career counseling office that more than 100 workers had visited by last night.
Besides the office of economic and policy analysis, three other areas were hard hit: management and budget; international business, and human resources. George J. Marlin, the authority's executive director, has said that the number of workers in those four areas has grown unwieldy in recent decades.
He has pointed to those areas as examples of what he says is a tendency for middle managers at headquarters to duplicate tasks being done at the authority's many sites, which include the region's three major airports, six bridges and tunnels, the Port Authority Trans Hudson commuter railway, most of the marine terminals at New York Harbor and the World Trade Center itself.
When the authority announced the layoffs last week, it said they were the largest, and virtually the only, such cuts in its 74-year history. But Professor Jameson W. Doig of Princeton University, who has studied the authority, said yesterday that it laid off a similar percentage of its work force in the early 1930's, largely because of the Depression.
Senior authority officials said that by last night they had eliminated about 315 positions in this round of cuts, achieving them from the more than 160 layoffs as well as from voluntary departures and from leaving vacant slots open.
The officials said yesterday that they regretted having to undertake the layoffs, but they also insisted that they had no choice.
"It's always painful even when one person has to lose his job, but we feel that this is a vital and necessary first step in moving the Port Authority in a new direction," said John J. Haley Jr., the deputy executive director of the authority.
But the workers who were dismissed had few nice words for Mr. Pataki, Mrs. Whitman or the authority's senior management. Many of them questioned why the authority made so many cuts in the middle of the work force and left alone high-ranking officials who allowed the middle to grow in the first place.
"They want to be able say, 'We broke the back of the fat, arrogant Port Authority,' " said a worker who was laid off in the office of economic and policy analysis and who spoke on condition of anonymity. "I actually think that there is tremendous fat in this agency. Unfortunately, the real layers of fat are in senior management, but those guys are not going to slit their own throats."
Margie Beck, 28, another employee in the office, agreed, saying that her managers had misled her in recent weeks about how many jobs would be saved. "They didn't have to let all these people go," she said.
Others said their departments had been the focus of so many rumors for so many weeks that they were relieved that it was finally over. Now, they said, they could move on.
"I am not angry, in fact I have come to accept it," said another worker who would speak only on condition of anonymity. "I have come to the realization that it is probably not a good place to be even if you did survive."
Many said they had not yet begun looking for employment because they had thought they might escape the cuts. But now, they said, they would relax for a few days and then plunge into the job market.
"It's over with, I feel much better now," said Ms. Rivera, who had been in the office of economic and policy analysis for 12 years. "Let's see what will happen with the future."

HEADLINE: Study Links Job Stress to Early-Birth Risk

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15

 BODY:
Job stress, noise, long periods of standing and work weeks of more than 40 hours all greatly increase the risk of giving birth to premature babies, a study has found.
Researchers examined the outcomes of pregnancies of 1,470 nurses and found that those who worked around loud machines or stood for hours while caring for patients or who worked unusually long and irregular schedules were 70 percent to 80 percent more likely to deliver premature, underweight babies. 
 For women who had a history of premature births, the risk increased by 10 times, said Dr. Timothy R. B. Johnson, chairman of obstetrics and gynecology at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor, the senior author of the study.
He said women who had a previous premature delivery "should seriously consider whether they want to work at all."
A report on the study was published today in The American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology.
The study compared the pregnancies of nurses whose jobs required them to sit in relatively quiet surroundings with nurses who worked with high levels of standing, lifting, stress and noise.
Dr. Johnson said nurses were used in the study because they had similar education and economic backgrounds and were generally well-nourished. The profession also involves a variety of assignments with different levels of stress and physically demanding work.
Women who stood at their jobs for five to six hours at a time increased the risk of premature delivery by 80 percent, the study found. More than six hours of standing tripled the risk.
Babies born before 37 weeks of pregnancy were considered premature. Among the 1,470 nurses, there were 210 premature babies and 1,260 delivered at term.
Babies born prematurely have a higher death rate than those carried to term, and the survivors can have medical problems for a lifetime.
"This study has changed the kind of recommendations I make to women," Dr. Johnson said. "My recommendations to all working women who are pregnant is that they not stand for prolonged periods of time, that they not work for more than eight-hour days or for more than 40-hour weeks."
Barbara Luke, an associate professor at the University of Michigan and an author of the study, said the decision on when to leave work during pregnancy should be based on a woman's job and medical history.
She said it was very important to avoid these risks during the second half of pregnancy.

HEADLINE: Kohl, the Enduring Everyman, Waits for History

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: COTTBUS, Germany

 BODY:
Helmut Kohl has come to this small town near the Polish border to celebrate the Federal Market Gardeners' Show, a panoply of nurtured blooms and emerald lawns grafted onto the environmental neglect of the former East Germany.
The Chancellor, America's most stolid European ally, is large, self- confident, and there is nothing about him -- his gray-suited blandness, his ineffable suggestion of assurance -- that implies mystery. 
 Yet, somewhere beyond his fireside delivery and his readiness to pre-empt wisecracks about his girth with his own wisecracks about his girth, there is a puzzle.
Almost a year into his fourth term since 1982, Mr. Kohl, 65, is set next year to become Germany's longest-serving postwar Chancellor, supplanting Konrad Adenauer, whose 14 years from 1949 to 1963 anchored the former West Germany firmly in the West and oversaw the economic miracle of postwar revival.
Midway through the 1990's, moreover, Mr. Kohl is the only survivor of a coterie of European leaders who shaped the final decade of the cold war. His longtime ally, President Francois Mitterrand of France, has been replaced by the Gaullist Jacques Chirac; from Britain to Spain and Italy, politics has become the politics of uncertainty.
But Mr. Kohl endures. The question that crops up is this: How did a politician once derided as a provincial clodhopper transcend such narrow visions to become what his image-molders depict as a statesman?
The answer, in the hostile view, is that he did not, that greatness was thrust upon him by the utter surprise of German reunification five years ago; that, rather than force history's pace, Mr. Kohl is bathing in its glow.
"He conveys the impression," said Erwin K. Scheuch, a sociologist in Cologne, "that the only thing that interests him now is how he will look in the history books."
From friendlier perspectives, though, it was Mr. Kohl's intuitive, political gumption in seizing history's moment after the Berlin wall fell in 1989 that pre-empted much potential trauma and thus secured a place in history.
With his journeys abroad -- this year, on the 50th anniversary of the fall of Nazism, he has made symbol-laden visits to Israel, the Netherlands and Poland -- Mr. Kohl increasingly projects himself as the embodiment of his land.
But there is nothing so Promethean in his political image back home, where his German supporters see him as Everyman, a mirror of their own appetites and ordinariness, a Roman Catholic churchgoer, a man who, as he repeats with mantra-like frequency, sees the solution to most things in "the wise middle way."
"He's the cross section of the good German citizen," said Rudolf Grosskopf, an author in Hamburg.
The Federal Market Gardeners' Show is no great political event, just one more speech to the converted. It is, though, a symbol of the East catching up with the West, a display of the qualities the Chancellor most wants to instill in the post-Communist East, and which is the grist of his political message in the West.
"A message of confidence, hope and courage goes out from here," the Chancellor says at the show. The gardeners offer standing ovations before and after the speech. And, as Mr. Kohl improvises his way through his address, departing frequently from his text, the theme recurs.
"We have every reason for optimism," he says, referring later to "realistic optimism."
"Helmut Kohl is through and through a party politician," said Joschka Fischer, the head of the increasingly powerful opposition Green Party. "He's never been anything else."
Indeed, his grip on the governing Christian Democrats is legend: no challenger has ever survived a fight with him; he tends his constituencies and remembers his supporters' birthdays; he works the phones and quickly rebukes errors.
"What is very important for him is that he has never lost his contact with the party," said a longtime confidant who insisted on anonymity. "He keeps an eye on the party base. He always knows its mood. It is what keeps him strong."
Mr. Kohl was 15 when World War II ended 50 years ago. He represents a generation of Germans too young to be directly tainted by Nazism yet old enough to know firsthand their compatriots' brutality.
The experience has shaped his caution in dealing with the Nazi past and his vision of a German future closely entwined with a united Europe and the United States.
Even though he seems to believe that Germans have learned their lessons, he never says so openly for fear of the charge that he is trying to bury the memory of the Holocaust. But he talks of Germany's "liberation" from Nazism in the same breath as he talks of recognizing "German guilt and German responsibility for the crimes of the Nazi era."
Mr. Kohl has agreed to the creation of a vast Holocaust memorial at the very heart of Berlin, the capital of reunited Germany, but does not see the past as a reason to stymie the future in a united Europe with Germany at its heart.
"To maintain peace, there can be no diversion from the path to a united Europe," he said in the Netherlands last May.
Equally, though, many Europeans suspect an ulterior motive. "The fear for some Europeans," a diplomat said, "is Teutonic knights in three-piece suits."
In Cottbus, the big issues are left aside. There are perhaps 500 supporters crammed into a meeting hall at the Federal Market Gardeners' Show for Mr. Kohl. His mood is good.
Last year, before Mr. Kohl narrowly won the October elections, the polls and his opponents were already writing him off -- as they did before unification -- although even his enemies would acknowledge his knack for winning against the odds.
Right now, though, the polls are favorable, if only because the Social Democrats, the main opposition party, are in disarray, a reflection of the broader decline of the European left.
His audience here is friendly, and there are not too many of the television cameras that provoke thoughts of media hostility, particularly in his early years as Chancellor, when many saw him as the singular hindrance to his party's fortunes.
Some Germans have criticized Mr. Kohl, who declined to be interviewed for this article, for being overly cautious, and his moves are often cautious -- plodding on the economy, conservative on issues like liberalized shopping hours.
Ever the party politician and back-room manipulator, Mr. Kohl favors consensus. But much of the time, his critics assert, he does not explain his confidence, preferring instead simply to exude it.
In the former East Germany, said Werner Patzelt, a political scientist at the University of Dresden, Mr. Kohl has lost support among the former Communist left for reunification policies that have cost many people jobs and wrenched away security.
But none of that seems to dim the gardeners' enthusiasm for Mr. Kohl. No, he tells them, the power of the German mark will not be lost in the striving for a common European currency (although he does not explain how). Much applause.
No, outsiders will not take jobs from Germans and foreigners legally registered in Germany. More applause.
No, western German money will not stop flowing eastward. Much more applause.
Then comes the pep talk. "We need a new culture of self-reliance in Germany," he says, avoiding the impression that he is talking only to the east Germans who are used to state supports. "The adventure of doing something new in life is something we have prized too little."
Outside, under a rain-drenched pagoda, Mr. Kohl is presented with a red rose named in his honor. Babette Einstmann, a television personality, offers it to him with a few words of praise that refer coyly to the thorns the Chancellor is also known to display in what his detractors call arrogance and his supporters call brusqueness or impatience.
Mr. Kohl takes the rose and considers it. "Stable and well fed," he concludes. "It has much in common with me."

HEADLINE: Senators Formalize Compromise on Child Care

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15

 BODY:
Senate leaders today formalized a bipartisan welfare compromise on providing $8 billion for child care, clearing the way for passage of the overall welfare bill next week with significant Democratic support.
In the aftermath of the compromise, Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader, announced that he would vote for the bill, although with mixed feelings. 
 "The bill still leaves a lot to be desired, but it is an improvement over what we've got now," he said.
Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, scheduled a vote on the compromise and the overall bill for Tuesday afternoon to insure that all lawmakers are on hand. After 95 hours of debate and 38 votes, along with uncounted hours of back-room negotiation, moderate Republicans and Democrats had won several concessions and Mr. Dole said he would expect "broad bipartisan support."
This would be a striking change from what happened in the House, where a substantially more conservative bill passed with just nine Democratic votes last March. Still, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, remains an angry opponent of the bill, which would abolish the longstanding Federal entitlement to assistance for any eligible poor family.
"I hope the President will veto this bill," Mr. Moynihan told reporters. "It's sure as hell cruel in the lives of American children."
The compromise announced by the leaders today would add $3 billion to the $5 billion already in the bill for child care for poor women. Mr. Daschle said today that Democrats would have liked to have had more -- earlier, they sought a total of $11 billion -- but he added that this compromise "represents the most significant commitment the Senate has made thus far" to the notion that child care is essential to move from welfare to work.
The compromise also creates a $1 billion contingency fund to help states with ailing economies, and it raises the percentage of welfare recipients who can be exempted from the automatic time limits on welfare because of hardship to 20 percent from 15 percent.
Still, the bill retains its basic shape, providing for the dismantling of an array of anti-poverty programs and their replacement with limited lump sum payments to the states, known as block grants. The bill seeks to save $70 billion in welfare spending over seven years, and requires 50 percent of the parents to be working by the year 2000. It also imposes a five-year time limit on drawing welfare benefits.
In the last day of voting on amendments, the Senate rejected a move by Mr. Daschle to allow states to use Federal money to provide vouchers and other forms of noncash assistance to the children in families cut off the welfare rolls. "They didn't ask to be born into these circumstances," Mr. Daschle said. "They can't get their parents out of these circumstances."
The amendment was defeated 48 to 44.
The Senate also rejected, 51 to 47, an amendment pushed by Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, that would prohibit legal aid groups that receive Federal money from bringing suit against this welfare overhaul.
"If they want to advocate, God bless them, but let them advocate with their own money," Mr. Gramm said. Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said, "This is targeted at the most vulnerable population."
The Senate split, 49 to 49, on a motion to table another Gramm amendment that would require deep cuts in the staff of the Health and Human Services Department. As a result, that measure will come to a vote again on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Factory Production Increases

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15

 BODY:
The nation's industrial production rose more rapidly in August than it had since last year, led by a surge in automobile manufacturing and by strong demand for electricity during the summer heat wave.
The Federal Reserve said today that production climbed 1.1 percent last month, the biggest gain in eight months. Factories and utilities were operating closer to capacity than they had since March. 
 Analysts said that the surprising broad-based advance might be temporary, but that it seemed to virtually rule out an interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve later this month.
"This is ammunition for the hawks who feel the economy will do just fine without further cuts in interest rates," said Sung Won Sohn, an economist at the Norwest Corporation, a bank holding company in Minneapolis.
The production figures contrast with recent data showing continued economic sluggishness. Just one day earlier, the Government reported that retail sales -- aside from leasing and purchases of steeply discounted cars -- were weak last month.
Analysts said the advance in industrial production, including a 1 percent rise at factories and a 4.9 percent jump at utilities, was a result of special factors. Output in the coming months will grow more moderately, they predicted.
"The manufacturing sector of the economy is rebounding after the spring inventory correction, but I would be very much surprised if the strength continues very long," Mr. Sohn said.
On Wall Street, the reaction was negative but restrained. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 4.23 points, to 4,797.57, and bond prices eased a bit as well, pushing the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond up to 6.48 percent from 6.46 percent.
Federal Reserve policy makers meet in 10 days to decide whether economic conditions warrant any action on interest rates.
After raising rates seven times to stifle inflation and slow growth, the central bank reversed course in July and cut a key rate slightly. But the Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, and his colleagues have stayed on the sidelines since then.
The August gain in industrial production was the largest since an identical increase in December. The last time there was a bigger jump was nearly eight years ago.
Industries were operating at 84.3 percent of capacity last month, a jump of six-tenths of a percentage point from July and the highest rate since March. The Fed pays close attention to the figure for signs factories are approaching capacity and inflationary worker shortages could develop.
"The issue now is whether demand will be buoyant enough to sustain these production increases," said Gordon Richards, economist at the National Association of Manufacturers. "Consumer demand has been held back by high debt loans and slow income growth."
A separate report released today by the University of Michigan showed a sharp dip in consumer sentiment in September as its index fell to 88.9 from 96.2, according to subcribers who pay for the service. Expectations about the economy's future growth also weakened.
 The Federal Reserve said production gains in August were widespread.
Even excluding autos, the output of consumer goods rose six-tenths of a percent after falling nearly 1.3 percent in the first seven months of the year. Appliances, furniture, consumer chemical products and food were higher.
Business equipment continued to show strength and construction supplies picked up.
The Fed also revised its July figures to show an overall production gain of three-tenths of a percent instead of one-tenth of a percent. In the previous five months, output was flat one month and fell four times.
The 1 percent increase in factory production last month -- after remaining unchanged in July -- put manufacturing close to its recent peak, in January. The 4.9 percent jump in utility output followed a 3.5 percent increase. Mining output fell 1.4 percent after gaining seven-tenths of a percent in July.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Industrial Production" shows index of total industrial production from Marcy 1994 to August 1995. (Source: Commerce Department)

HEADLINE: Tenneco Is Leaving Houston for Greenwich

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: DALLAS, Sept. 15

 BODY:
Going against the outflow of companies from Frost Belt to Sun Belt, Tenneco Inc. today announced a move in the opposite direction. Tenneco, one of the nation's 50 largest industrial companies, plans to shift its headquarters to Greenwich, Conn., from Houston, by the middle of next summer.
Only about 70 employees, 30 moving from Houston and the rest to be hired locally, will work in the new headquarters, once the home of Henry R. Luce, the co-founder of Time magazine, and his wife, Clare Boothe Luce, the writer, former Ambassador to Italy and former United States Representative. The building lies near the New York border and Westchester County Airport. Tenneco Gas will remain in Houston, and the staff for payroll, accounting and other corporate services will move to the Woodlands, a northern suburb. 
 Dana G. Mead, Tenneco's chief executive, said that the company, less involved in oil and natural gas than it was in the 80's, now needed to be near deal makers and international markets for its auto parts, packaging and other businesses.
"We can manage this change -- and this growth -- more effectively by being closer to Western and Central Europe, as well as in closer proximity to the U.S. financial community, institutional investors and financial analysts, to the business and national media and to Federal Government officials and agencies," he said in a statement.
At a Houston news conference, he recalled his experience as an Army officer and West Point professor and said: "One of the things the Army teaches you is that you go to the point of action. For those of us in Tenneco's management center, the point of action has shifted to the Eastern Seaboard."
Mr. Mead, born in Iowa and raised in Illinois, lived in Cos Cob, Conn., for four years as an executive of International Paper before he came to Tenneco in 1992. Other headquarters sites he considered were Fairfax County, Va., near Washington; northern New Jersey, and Westchester County.
While suburban Connecticut is already the home of General Electric and many other corporate giants, most of them moved there from New York. The state's real estate market and military industries have suffered in recent years, so even the arrival of Tenneco's 70 jobs became the occasion for a news conference with Gov. John G. Rowland and Mr. Mead.
Responding to Mr. Mead's apology for not bringing more jobs, Governor Rowland said, "Listen, in our economy you get excited about any jobs coming to the State of Connecticut."
"It's a psychological boost, a morale builder," said John Carson, an economist who is president of the Connecticut Policy Development Council in Hartford.
Tenneco, with 1994 sales of $12.2 billion, markets and transports natural gas, makes auto parts including Monroe shock absorbers, builds and repairs ships, and provides packaging for foods and other goods.
The company, which has sold off several units including most of the Case Corporation, a maker of farming and construction equipment, has chopped its headquarters staff to 275 from 1,000 in four years. Mr. Mead said an additional 50 to 100 jobs would be pared.

HEADLINE: Monitors to Oversee Finances of Indicted Trash Haulers

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON 

 BODY:
A State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan has decided to appoint independent monitors to oversee the financial operations of city garbage haulers indicted in June on racketeering and extortion charges, saying he feared that the carters might try to "hide, dissipate or divert" millions of dollars in assets before they go to trial.
The carters are charged with being part of a Mafia-dominated cartel that used arson and threats of violence to control virtually all of New York City's commercial garbage-hauling industry. 
 The ruling on Thursday, by Justice Walter M. Schackman, gives the monitors the authority to review on a daily basis the financial dealings of the multimillion-dollar garbage operations, requiring the companies to open their books and premises. Prosecutors who asked for the appointment of the monitors said it was the first time a state court had granted such a pre-conviction safeguard. The monitors will be appointed in mid-November.
Seventeen individuals and 26 companies, including V. Ponte & Sons and Barretti Carting, among the best known private haulers in the city, were indicted in June. But with the criminal trial of the carters not scheduled to begin until early 1997, the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, said he would seek to give the monitors the authority to help regulate charges and thus save businesses in the city millions of dollars over the next 18 months.
"We believe they have been overcharging by 50 percent, and so the potential for genuine savings to clients in the city is great," Mr. Morgenthau said. "Without the monitors, it could have been back to business for the carters -- threats, exortion, collusion."
Prosecutors have said that if the carters are convicted, they will move to have the companies forfeit all assets, estimated to be worth roughly $268 million.
Frederick P. Hafetz, the lawyer who is coordinating the defense for the companies that were charged, portrayed the judge's decision yesterday as a defeat for prosecutors. He said Mr. Morgenthau's office had initially sought to take "direct decision-making control" of the companies and essentially allow the monitors to run the businesses.
"The District Attorney may try to put a good face on it, but it is a rejection of what he had sought," Mr. Hafetz said. "It is clear from the ruling that the decision-making process will not be taken away from the owners."
Justice Schackman ordered prosecutors and defense lawyers to work together over the next 60 days to iron out the specific terms of the financial oversight.
It has been an open secret for the last 30 years in New York that trash haulers and the unions representing their workers are linked to organized crime. One official report after another has accused the companies of acting together to obliterate competition and thus artificially drive up prices. But the indictments marked the first time prosecutors had come up with enough evidence to take on an entire industry critical to the city's economy.
The rare companies that have been bold enough to defy the major local carting outfits and make minor inroads into the city's $1.5 billion-a-year private garbage hauling industry have been able to offer office buildings and hospitals price reductions of from 300 to 1,000 percent.
Prosecutors built their five-year investigation in large part on the work of an undercover investigator who, they said, witnessed acts of violence and threats, participated in over 100 illegal payments totaling almost $800,000 and helped make hundreds of hours of incriminating tape recordings. Some of that evidence was presented to Justice Schackman, a civil court judge who was asked by prosecutors to order the monitors under the state's forfeiture law.
In making his ruling, Justice Schackman said that the evidence submitted by prosecutors established "a substantial probability" that convictions will result. And in agreeing to appoint the monitors, the judge concluded that it was "reasonable to infer from all the many details assembled by the plaintiff that the defendants, if left entirely to their own devices, would attempt to hide, dissipate or divert their booty."

HEADLINE: Casinos Threaten Pageant As Symbol of Atlantic City

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER 

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 13

 BODY:
For years the Miss America pageant was the only product -- besides salt water taffy and the Monopoly game -- firmly identified with this city. But that bond may be loosening, in part because of a revival of the casino gambling industry.
Though some of the old electricity still crackles around the pageant, the real star of the hour here is not a beauty contestant but an energetic casino operator, Stephen A. Wynn, fresh from Las Vegas with a long list of ideas on how to pump up the town's excitement level. 
 Mr. Wynn, head of Mirage Resorts Inc., is re-entering the Atlantic City scene after self-imposed exile in Nevada, where he almost single-handedly reshaped the gaming industry. He left Atlantic City in 1987 with much grumbling about overregulation by the state and a lack of cooperation, elements he said stifled people with imagination -- like himself.
In Las Vegas, he built the Mirage and Treasure Island mega-resorts that used spectacles like exploding volcanoes and sinking ships to attract ever-bigger crowds to his casinos.
His success there, and changes in the political climate here, have set the stage for applying the formula in Atlantic City, he says. And it is clear that the city and state -- alarmed by the hot breath of competition -- are listening to what he has to say.
As if on cue, the usually fractious City Council voted 9 to 0 to allow Mirage to develop a 150-acre landfill into a casino-resort unlike any of the 12 casino hotels that now occupy cramped properties along the boardwalk and marina.
"We're going to see more changes in the next 36 months than there's been in the past 10 years," said an exultant Mr. Wynn.
Several developments back up his forecast, including a loss of momentum for gambling in other states, including Pennsylvania and Florida.
In New Jersey, in response to charges that overly close regulation by the state was stifling the gaming industry here, some of the more restrictive regulations were lifted last year, like a requirement for background checks on maids and restaurant workers hired at a casino hotel.
Meanwhile, the easing of a long recession brought back players with more money in their pockets. July and August were the best two months on record in the amount of money the casinos raked in, helping push revenues for the year to $2.52 billion for the first eight months of the year.
Work is pushing ahead on a $225 million convention center and a companion 500-room hotel, scheduled for 1997 openings. Casinos already in operation will add another 2,000 hotel rooms, pushing the total above 15,000 for the first time. That figure is considered a minimum for increased airline and convention business, said James Kennedy, executive director of the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority, a state agency that uses a levy on casinos for urban improvement projects.
Another need, adequate surface transportation in the 47-block-long city, is also being addressed. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman recently created a group to study ways to ease traffic and give visitors more mobility, especially as resorts like Mirage's planned $500 million casino-resort take shape away from the boardwalk.
"Things were bad enough when we had 10,000 casino hotel rooms and modest growth," said the group's chairman, James A. Crawford, director of the South Jersey Transportation Authority. "But in a few years we may have 19,000 to 25,000 casino hotel rooms and a new convention center."
There's also progress on a central corridor project that will link the new convention center with the boardwalk five blocks away, a plan intended to clean up the main gateway to the island city at the eastern end of the Atlantic City Expressway, replacing seedy streets and weedy lots with landscaped roads. But plans for filling the new concourse with boutiques and entertainment outlets are in limbo, city officials said.
Smaller in scale, but a powerful symbol of change for people who live here, is a modest shopping strip on Atlantic Avenue, the construction of which will give the city and its 37,000 residents a supermarket for the first time.
In danger of being pushed aside by all this change is the Miss America pageant, an annual fixture since 1921 (except a four-year suspension during the depths of the Depression). The design of the new convention center will not meet its special needs, and the future of its present home, the old convention hall, is in doubt.
"Every year the pageant officials suggest the city is not providing enough assistance and suggest other cities may be more willing to do so," said Louis Toscano, a senior policy adviser to Mayor James Whelan.
"If they left town tomorrow, we'd be sorry to see them go, but we wouldn't roll over and die," Mr. Toscano said, with words that in the past would have been regarded as heresy. "Twenty years ago, Miss America was the highlight of our year, but now it is one of any number of interesting events that take place here routinely."
For example, he said, the exhibition tennis match here last month between Monica Seles and Martina Navratilova received far more publicity worldwide than the Miss America pageant does. So will a matchup soon between the basketball stars Shaquille O'Neal and Hakeem Olajuwon, he predicted.
Leonard Horn, executive producer of the pageant, said he was shocked by Mr. Toscano's attitude.
"Miss America put Atlantic City on the map and we are the fourth oldest live event on television," said Mr. Horn, adding that despite the city's complacency, he had no intention of relocating.
"The pageant will remain in Atlantic City if the convention hall is not altered in some way that doesn't meet our needs," Mr. Horn said.
If that happens and the pageant is forced out by an uncaring city, then in some future September the contest's famous theme song lyrics may be altered to "There she goes, Miss America."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Blunt-Spoken Economist Is Japan's Mr. Yen

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 15

 BODY:
As the United States and Japan jointly push to strengthen the dollar against the yen, the Clinton Administration finds itself oddly aligned with a blunt-spoken economist here who argues that Japan should avoid American ideas about free-market capitalism.
Japanese Government officials, even more than their American counterparts, have desperately wanted a weaker yen to make Japanese exports cheaper and to shake off the country's enduring economic slump. 
 In fact, when the dollar surged past 104 yen today to its strongest showing in 15 months, Japanese markets reacted as joyously as if they had just seen a cloudburst after a yearlong drought.
The man behind much of the currency shift is Eisuke Sakakibara, who two months ago became head of the Finance Ministry's international bureau and has emerged as the de facto Mr. Yen. Government officials here say Mr. Sakakibara was the point man in discussions with Washington and the primary tactician behind Japan's latest efforts to sell yen and buy dollars.
An exuberant and iconoclastic man who got his doctorate in economics at the University of Michigan and taught briefly at Harvard, Mr. Sakakibara laughs easily and takes a distinctively un-Japanese enjoyment in provoking heated arguments.
But his American education and mannerisms belie a strong nationalist view about Japan's economic identity. He passionately criticizes Japanese advocates of "Americanism" who insist the country needs to untangle the maze of regulations and clubby business practices that make the market so difficult for foreign companies and even Japanese entrepreneurs to penetrate.
"If they believe in the universal value of Americanism," Mr. Sakakibara wrote last year in Hatsugensha, a monthly magazine, "the 'reform' they are attempting is nothing but an act of barbarism against our own national cultural values."
Taking a distinctly personal view, Mr. Sakakibara described his dismay at the crime and declining prosperity he saw in York, Pa., where he was a high-school exchange student in 1958. "This nice little town, to my surprise, was turning into a slum after 30 some years," he wrote. "The high school even had a metal detector at the entrance."
The lesson for Japan, he implied, was clear. In a 1990 book entitled, "Beyond Capitalism," Mr. Sakakibara strenuously argued that Japan's economic system should never be modeled on that of America.
In another recent magazine article, he wrote that those who argued that Japan needed to be more open, and perhaps to give up security blankets like the corporate practice of lifetime employment, were guilty of "hysteria" and "masochism."
"Do consumers and salarymen want destruction of the system?" he wrote. "The answer is clearly, 'No.' " Indeed, he said, there was no reason to believe that opening the Japanese market would reduce the country's trade surplus with the world or weaken the yen. "This theory is doubly wrong," he said.
For now, Japan and the United States are in broad agreement about the need to devalue the yen. Until recently, American policy had been to either support a strong yen -- which makes American products cheaper in Japan -- or to be indifferent.
But that changed after the dollar plunged just below 80 yen last spring, and Japan became more desperately mired as growth stagnated, real estate plunged and problem loans at banks grew to more than $400 billion.
From the American perspective, a Japanese economy that is too crippled to import is potentially more troubling than a strong dollar.
The upshot was a coordinated effort over the last month to begin pushing the dollar up and the yen down. In Japan, currency experts and Finance Ministry officials say Mr. Sakakibara's biggest contribution may have simply been his ability to charm and persuade Treasury officials that the time had come for action. Indeed, Mr. Sakakibara is said to be a close friend of Lawrence H. Summers, the Deputy Treasury Secretary.
Despite his talkative nature, Mr. Sakakibara has tried to lower his visibility in recent days and has turned down all requests for interviews, including for this article. People close to him say Mr. Sakakibara has become worried about upstaging the Finance Minister, Masayoshi Takemura.
But currency experts and bankers say there is little doubt about who is in charge of the yen right now. "On Japan's side, it's been Sakakibara -- everyone knows he has become the strong person," said Mamuro Yamazaki, senior economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company in Japan.
"He is very sharp, and very good at communicating," said Hajime Shinohara, counselor at the Bank of Tokyo and a longtime friend of Mr. Sakakibara. "What strikes me about him are his abilities and his charm. He can be very persuasive."
Ultimately, currency values are set by global capital flows rather than attempts by central bankers. And the yen is getting knocked down by a host of other Government policies: the Bank of Japan slashed its discount rate to five-tenths of a percent last week, one of the lowest rates ever, and the Finance Ministry is planning to disclose another stimulus plan next week that would, if approved by the Parliament, provide more than $100 billion in new spending and tax breaks to stimulate the economy.
For the moment, however, most eyes are on the currency operation. Mr. Takemura, the Finance Minister, said this week that the yen still had further to fall and many traders believe the dollar could soon reach 105 yen. Given the dollar's continued push upward today, that seems very possible.

HEADLINE: G.O.P.'s Plan to Cut Medicare Faces a Veto, Clinton Promises

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15

 BODY:
President Clinton said today that he would veto the Republicans' legislative package for Medicare and Medicaid. He said that their proposals for large savings in the Government health plans for the elderly and the poor would have "Draconian consequences" and would "dismantle Medicare as we know it."
Speaking to elderly people at the White House just 24 hours after House Republicans outlined their proposals, Mr. Clinton said, "If these health care cuts come to my desk, of this size, I would have no choice but to veto it." 
 The Republicans seek to cut $270 billion, or 14 percent, from projected Medicare spending during the next seven years. The magnitude of the savings is dictated by the Republicans' plan to balance the budget in seven years, a blueprint approved by both houses of Congress in June. But Republicans say the main reason for their Medicare proposals is to prevent the program's Hospital Insurance Trust Fund from going bankrupt.
Speaker Newt Gingrich's press secretary, Tony Blankley, said he was not upset by the President's comments. Instead, he said: "I am encouraged by that statement as I understand it. It suggests that the President has not had our proposal correctly explained to him. When the President has a chance to understand the bill, we think there is a very good chance that he will like what he sees and will want to sign it. Congressional Democrats have been irresponsibly misrepresenting our proposal."
Even while threatening a veto, Mr. Clinton urged elderly people to seek bipartisan support for changes in Medicare that would control costs without harming beneficiaries. "We ought to be here to build a bridge," he said.
Congressional Democrats, who have accused the Republicans of hiding crucial details of their plan, had pleaded with the White House to threaten a veto. The Republicans would sharply raise Medicare premiums for affluent elderly people, reduce payments to doctors and hospitals and let beneficiaries switch from Medicare to private health plans. The Democrats hoped that a veto threat would invigorate lobbyists for the elderly and labor unions that have championed Medicare for three decades.
Democrats and some moderate Republicans see a way out of the current impasse over Medicare. If Republicans would reduce their demands for tax cuts, for example, Democrats might negotiate some savings in Medicare. But such a compromise is probably months off. The House majority leader, Dick Armey, brushed aside Mr. Clinton's threat today. "The Democrats have a craven approach to Medicare, which is to let it go bankrupt in the long run for what they perceive to be short-term political gain," said Mr. Armey, a Texas Republican. "What they fail to realize is that public tolerance for demagoguery is at an all-time low."
A spokesman for Mr. Armey, Ed Gillespie, said the President's threat would not alter the course Republicans have set for themselves.
The budget blueprint would cut projected Medicaid spending by $182 billion, or 19 percent, during seven years. Medicare is for the elderly and disabled; Medicaid is for low-income people of all ages, including children and people in nursing homes.
Republicans say that Medicare's Hospital Insurance Trust Fund will go bankrupt in 2002 if the current law is not changed. Democrats contend that the money saved from Medicare will be used to balance the Federal budget and cut taxes for wealthy people.
In his speech today, Mr. Clinton denounced the Republicans' Medicare proposals. "Their plan would increase premiums and other costs for senior citizens," he said. "It would reduce doctor choice. It would force many doctors to stop serving seniors altogether. It threatens to put rural hospitals and urban hospitals out of business. Brick by brick, it would dismantle Medicare as we know it."
In June, Mr. Clinton offered a plan to balance the budget in 10 years. He said his plan would squeeze $124 billion of savings from Medicare and $54 billion from Medicaid during seven years. The Medicare proposals would have curbed payments to doctors and hospitals, but would not have increased premiums or other costs for beneficiaries.
Mr. Clinton acknowledged today that his proposals would save less money than the Republicans'. But he said the impact would be less severe. "You can have a healthy Medicare trust fund, you can have reductions in cost inflation in Medicare and Medicaid without these Draconian consequences," he said, referring to the effects of the Republican proposals.
Republicans contend that there is less difference between the White House and Congressional Republicans than Mr. Clinton suggests. They say Mr. Clinton would have to cut projected Medicare outlays by $192 billion to hit the spending targets he set for himself in June.
Congressional Democrats have spurned Mr. Clinton's proposal for Medicare savings. "I think it's too much," said Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House Democratic leader.
The White House position on Medicare differs noticeably from the President's more nuanced, cautious stance on separate legislation to overhaul the nation's main welfare programs. Mr. Clinton has tried to work with Congressional Republicans to cut a deal on welfare and has resisted appeals from liberals in Congress and the Administration who want him to make an explicit veto threat on that issue.
Representative Bill Archer, a Texas Republican who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, said it would be helpful if President Clinton offered concrete proposals to save Medicare from bankruptcy, rather than threatening to veto the Republican plan.
Republicans on the Senate Finance Committee have drafted their own proposals to cut projected Medicare spending. The proposals are generally similar to those developed by House Republicans.
But initial estimates by the Congressional Budget Office suggest that the Senate proposals fall $30 billion short of the Republicans' goal of saving $270 billion in seven years.

HEADLINE: Golf Replaces Grazing In Vacation-Rich Vail

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: VAIL, Colo., Sept. 10

 BODY:
His lambs and ewes grazed peacefully in a high altitude meadow here, but Randy Campbell shifted uneasily in his saddle, pondering the golf courses marching down the valley floor below.
With eight golf courses in 20 miles of river valley, spring pasture land is rapidly vanishing for this fourth-generation Colorado sheep producer. 
 "All the spring range is being subdivided for golf courses," Mr. Campbell said as a crisp fall breeze rustled through a stand of lodgepole pines in the White River National Forest. "In the 1940's, there were 50,000 sheep in Eagle County. Now there are only 9,000."
Herding his hooved charges to the high range, Mr. Campbell battles obstacles his grandfather never dreamed of. His border collies must goad the nervous animals over a bridge spanning Interstate 70, a highway busy with trucks and tourist traffic.
In Vail, where million-dollar vacation homes are blooming like mountain thistles, homeowners increasingly complain about sheep nibbling on their neo-Alpine landscaping and about sheep littering driveways with their droppings. The path of least resistance dictates moving sheep through town just after dawn on Sunday.
If the tension between the old West and the new West plays out daily across the 1-million-square-mile Rocky Mountain region, the clash becomes almost a caricature in the narrow river valleys surrounding Vail, North America's largest ski mountain.
While the traditional economy limps, the tourist economy leaps.
So many vacation homes have been built here, a census revealed recently, that 72.2 percent of Vail's housing units were second homes -- up from 59.8 percent in 1990.
With newspapers describing Vail as "the emptiest city in Colorado," young working people wonder what kind of mountain community will emerge from Tokyo-style real estate prices.
"Who is going to live here in the future -- only wealthy retirees in second homes?" asked Mick Kelly, who this summer opened the Minturn Inn near Vail.
With real estate prices attaining the high, thin air of Rocky Mountain peaks, a broker advertised in the Vail Daily this Saturday a quarter-acre building lot on Forest Road. The asking price was $1.8 million.
Last week, Allen Black, the Eagle County assessor, announced that the county's assessed value of real estate is $6.5 billion -- up 35.6 percent over last year's level. With 29,000 residents, Eagle County now has real estate valued at the combined gross national products of Bolivia and Nicaragua.
Telescoping the geographic space that usually separates the United States's rich and poor, the magnificent, million-dollar mansions of the Cordillera development stand on mountain promontories directly above a trailer park housing Mexican restaurant and hotel workers.
"These castles are feudal," said Cliff Thompson, publisher of a local weekly, Vail Valley Times. "People are always looking up. It is very stressful."
Even flimsy housing for a mountain winter does not come cheaply. On Saturday, the Vail Daily advertised an "adorable and affordable" mobile home in the trailer park for $35,000.
Hotel and restaurant workers here earn about $15,000 a year. By contrast, the Hyatt Regency Beaver Creek, a Vail valley resort, offers this winter an "extravagant honeymoon package" -- a week-long stay that includes sauna, sleigh ride, dog sled ride and hot air balloon ride for the price of $13,999. In January, Vail plans to open a mountainside dining club, the Game Creek Club, where memberships sell for $75,000.
Denver's Roman Catholic Archbishop, J. Francis Stafford, has chided Vail and other Colorado ski resorts for creating "leisure colonies."
"What we risk creating is a theme-park 'alternative reality' for those who have the money to purchase entrance," the Archbishop said last year in a pastoral letter directed at the ski industry. "The births of infants on Medicaid have risen steeply throughout the region, since service jobs often do not include health insurance."
Towns, he said, must go beyond requiring that mansions include caretakers cottages. Setting an example, the Archdiocese is building low-income housing in the nearby towns of Carbondale, Gypsum and Silverthorne.
But the Archbishop's appeals fell on some deaf ears here. Last week, the Vail Village Merchant Association voted to oppose a sales-tax ballot proposal that would raise $3 million to improve bus service for resort workers forced to live outside the valley because of soaring housing costs.
Last winter, Vail's economic exclusivity proved to be its undoing. During blizzards, highway crews who lived in outlying mountain towns could not get to snowplows garaged at the resort.
"I-70 killed us last year, it closed 35 times -- snow, trucks jackknifing," groaned Paul Witt, a spokesman for Vail Associates, the company that owns the ski area. After investing $14 million this year -- largely in high-speed chairlifts, the resort needs a guaranteed stream of customers when the ski season starts in November.
To partly remedy the situation, Vail is providing housing this winter for six snowplow drivers.
But Colorado's booming tourism has done more this year than force the local telephone company to adopt a new area code for the Rocky Mountain part of the state. It is placing growing strain on Interstate 70, the sole highway link from Denver.
Over the last month, transit officials have clocked record volumes of cars going through the Eisenhower Tunnel, a 22-year-old Interstate tunnel that goes under the Continental Divide.
Further aggravating the ski area access problem, Denver inaugurated this April a new airport that is closer by car to Kansas than to Vail. On a Sunday afternoon, the drive from here to Denver International Airport takes three and a half hours -- the same time as the flight from New York to Denver.
Largely because of the access problem, readers of Ski Magazine bumped Vail from the top spot to the sixth ranking in a resort survey to be published in October.
Moving aggressively, Vail's tourism industry wooed airlines to the Eagle County's airport. Offering twice as many plane seats as two years ago, airlines this season will provide direct flights linking Eagle with 10 American cities.
But as 50 jets a week start landing here this winter, returning visitors may note that the century-old sound of freight train whistles will be fading out in the Eagle River valley. Last week, Union Pacific filed plans with the Interstate Commerce Commission to abandon freight service through the valley.
Left to their own devices will be the region's traditional, old West rail users: the wallboard factory in Gypsum, the limestone quarries of Salida, and the coal-fired electricity generating plant at Canon City.
Trying to look on the bright side, Allan Best, managing editor of the Vail Valley Times, said: "This could be the biggest opportunity in the country for a rail trail."
Stripped of rails, the railroad right of way could become another tourist attraction -- 173 level miles of trail for hikers, riders and trailbikers.

HEADLINE: Monkey Jump Journal;
Will Cyanide-Tainted River Ever Be Seen as Safe?

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: MONKEY JUMP, Guyana

 BODY:
The mighty Essequibo River is once again colored a glistening sable, but Lilmati Goobin cannot shake the fearful vision of what it was like a few weeks ago when the jungle river ran an angry red and the Government warned her to keep her family away from its waters.
Except for what comes from the river, there is very little to eat or drink in this tiny granite-mining settlement of 17 huts on wooden stilts. Still, Mrs. Goobin and most of the 35 people who live here have stopped washing and fishing in the river and drinking the water. 
 They have stopped even though Government officials and independent experts from Canada, the United States and the United Nations now say the 685 million gallons of water tainted with cyanide and red clay that spilled into the Essequibo from a breached dam at a gold mine up river a few weeks ago have been almost completely washed out to sea.
Mrs. Goobin said that a few days after the ban was lifted her 19-year-old son, Inshan, cooked and ate a river mullet without telling her. Within hours, she said, his stomach was in knots.
The son recovered in a day, but most people in this isolated place, named for a treacherous channel over which monkeys are said to leap, believe that the river is still poisoned.
"It's a real horrible thing that happens when you can't go down to the river because you are scared," she said. "I don't believe it's safe yet."
There is no scientific proof that Mrs. Goobin's son or any of the other people along the Essequibo who have complained of stomach pains, skin rashes or dizziness got sick from the cyanide that is used at the mine of Omai Gold Mines Ltd. about 70 miles up river from Monkey Jump.
The mine has been worked for over a century. In the largest open-pit operation in South America, Omai scoops up gold-bearing rock and crushes it. The cyanide is mixed with water and used to help separate the fine particles of gold from the rock. The waste water is held in large ponds and recycled.
It was the rock-and-clay dam at the site that failed, allowing the tainted water to enter Omai Creek and finally the Essequibo. Federal guidelines in the United States consider cyanide levels below 15 parts per million to be safe. The water that spilled from the dam contained up to a lethal 25 parts per million.
Experts from the World Health Organization and other organizations have concluded that all the fish in the Omai Creek where it flows into the Essequibo River were killed when the cyanide-tainted water spilled from the dam.
But they said the steady flow of the Essequibo quickly diluted the cyanide to levels just above guidelines for safe drinking water. Cyanide also breaks down quickly in sunlight, so by the time the cyanide and clay reached Bartica, a town of more than 10,000 people five miles from here, it was harmless to humans.
Although the immediate danger appears to have passed, the fear and uncertainty have not. For Guyana, on the northern coast of South American and one of the poorest countries in the Western Hemisphere, the spill could prove very costly.
The Omai gold mine -- operated by Cambior Inc. of Val d'Or, Quebec, and Golden Star Resources Ltd. of Edmonton, Alberta -- employs about 1,000 local people and accounts for 3 percent of the country's gross domestic product and 10 percent of its foreign exchange.
The mine was shut soon after the spill was first reported, on Aug. 19, and will remain inactive until a parliamentary commission finds out what went wrong.
Fishermen who rely on the river for their livelihood have returned to their boats but cannot sell what they catch. Essequibo fish were not killed off by the cyanide, but no one is sure what the long-term impact will be.
Residents in Bartica and more than a dozen settlements have had to find alternate sources of water.
In a statement, Louis P. Gignac, president of Omai Gold Mines Ltd. said: "We are very distressed and embarrassed over what has occurred. Omai fully accepts responsibility for the accident and any legitimate reparation that is a consequence of it."
But some here doubt the company's sincerity.
The company has been offering fishermen about $1,200 in compensation for lost fishing days if they agree to make no further claims for damages. At last count 59 men, nearly all the members of a fisherman's co-op in Bartica, had accepted.
"I went in the office, they gave me a paper, and I marked it," said a 37-year-old fisherman named Kissoon. "I don't know to read or write. I thought it meant that they would pay now and then pay me again in a while."
Seeta Mohamed, a spokeswoman for Omai, said that no one was forced to sign anything and that the head of the fishermen's co-op explained the agreement to everyone who could not read or write. She said hundreds of additional claims from hunters, farmers and miners along the river were still being received.
Many along the Essequibo remain suspicious. "In the hearts and minds of the people," said the Rev. George A. Seng, an Anglican priest in Bartica, "that river is dead."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Over 104 Yen as Officials Give Fresh Endorsement of Rally

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar extended its gains yesterday to above 104 Japanese yen, bolstered by fresh endorsements of the rally from the world's three largest economic powers.
Three officials, Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers of the United States; Hans Tietmeyer, president of the Bundesbank, and Japan's Minister for International Trade and Industry, Ryutaro Hashimoto, indicated separately that they favored further dollar appreciation. 
 The dollar traded late yesterday at a 15-month high of 104.15 yen, up from 102.40 Thursday. It also rose against the German mark, trading at 1.4885 marks, up slightly from 1.4866 late Thursday.
The officials appeared to be reaffirming their commitment to a declaration by the Group of Seven industrial countries in April that vowed to work for the orderly reversal of the dollar's decline against major world currencies. It was also a clear signal that they saw room for further gains.
Mr. Hashimoto was quoted in an article in Nihon Keisai Shimbun as saying that he favored the dollar's rise to 110 yen. Mr. Summers said in an American television interview that he welcomed the dollar's rise and added, "We're prepared to cooperate in foreign exchange markets with our G-7 partners." Mr. Tietmeyer told reporters after a French-German meeting that he hoped for continued corrections of distortions in currency rates and for a "global calming" of those rates.
Amy Smith, senior currency analyst at consulting firm IDEA Inc., said: "It took people a little by surprise, to come out so strongly simultaneously. It led everyone to think it was a warm-up for intervention."
The central banks did not step in, however, leading some investors to take profits.
The mark once again proved resilient as attempts to push the dollar above 1.50 failed. That only reinforced the view that the rally was more a function of yen weakness than dollar strength. European accounts were said to have been selling dollars for marks.
There were widespread rumors that the Chinese central bank was aggressively selling dollars for marks just below the 1.50 level to protect a large options position.
Analysts expect the dollar to remain well supported against the yen ahead of a Japanese fiscal package to be disclosed next Wednesday and possible intervention by the Bank of Japan and perhaps the Federal Reserve.
In other trading, the dollar fell to 1.2080 Swiss francs, from 1.2125 on Thursday. The British pound firmed to $1.5503, from $1.5484 on Thursday.

HEADLINE: U.S. Bond Prices Slip On Report

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The Treasury market, hurt by a stronger-than-expected economic report yesterday, fought off the temptation of a full retreat but gave up some ground.
Traders said some investors took profits ahead of the weekend and sold securities to protect the gains made during the week. Futures trading, which influences cash market transactions, was soft, also bouncing off its lows after the release of higher-than-expected August production and capacity utilization data. 
 The strong numbers fueled speculation that the Fed will not ease rates at the Sept. 26 Federal Open Market Committee meeting. Traders said market participants who tried to cover short positions ahead of the data were hurt.
The price of the 30-year bond slipped 8/32 of a percentage point, to 105 8/32 ; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 6.48 percent, from 6.46 percent on Thursday.
Industrial production gained 1.1 percent in August, the biggest rise since December of last year. Economists had forecast a rise of four-tenths of 1 percent. The increase in capacity to 84.3 percent exceeded the forecast of 83.6 percent and reinforced those who expect the Fed not to act soon.
Anthony Chan, chief economist for Banc One Investment Advisors in Columbus, Ohio, said that the production report suggested the economy's weakest link should not be written off just yet. Not only were the numbers stronger than the consensus, but the prior month's numbers were also revised upward.
"Also supporting the market," Mr. Chan added, was this week's rally by the dollar.
Peter McTeague, a market analyst with MCM Money Watch in Boston, said bonds had been amazing. "Despite the bullish inflation news, the rally in the dollar and the Japanese buying, I sense they are at the crossroads here, with 6.40 to 6.50 percent yields on the long bond pivotal," he said.
The key uncertainties brewing, he said, were yesterday's production report, which he said took the Fed out of the equation for a credit easing this month, but the bond market has already priced in a rate reduction. "That's where the market appears to be mispriced, and with supply coming to the short end of the market in the next few weeks, a correction is in store," Mr. McTeague said.
Then there is the budget battle in Washington. "Everyone is bullish on the prospects, but there hasn't been any discounting of a possible train wreck," Mr. McTeague said. "If it's business as usual, bonds will spill. I'm looking for 6.75 percent on the long bond yield by the end of October."
Matthew F. Alexy, chief market strategist at CS First Boston, said yesterday that the December bond future contract lost half a percentage point on the release of the production and capacity data, only to rebound three-eighths of a point on a strong confidence number from the University of Michigan. The high was 114 27/32 , with the low at 114 6/32 , before closing at 114 17/32 .
He said the session was subjected to a fair amount of volatility, and he did not see the contract breaking out of the 114 to 115 range for about another 10 days. "It will take some strong numbers to push through this range," Mr. Alexy said.
Looking ahead to next week, Mr. Chan of Banc One Advisors said, "The trade data to be released next Wednesday may remind foreign exchange players that the celebration may be a bit premature and therefore shake up some of the bullish tone of the market, which continues to count on growing foreign interests, as the dollar continues to move higher." A strong dollar makes United States investments like Treasury securities more attractive.

HEADLINE: A Future for Amtrak

 BODY:
To save intercity rail passenger service from ruin, Amtrak has been running trains less often and discontinuing others entirely, hoping to fashion a lean but viable system. Now to safeguard its future and secure a reliable source of funding for capital projects, the railroad seeks a permanent trust fund, similar to those in the highway and airline industries. Congress should support the plan.
The benefits of passenger rail service cannot be measured solely in terms of commercial profit and loss. It provides a form of transportation valued by millions of Americans and produces reduced highway and airport congestion and cleaner air, amply justifying some public expense. 
 The Amtrak trust fund plan calls for dedicating half a cent of the 18-cent Federal gasoline tax to the railroad, which would provide more than $600 million a year for improvements. The idea faces ferocious opposition, especially from entrenched highway interests. They resist sharing any part of Federal gasoline tax revenues with the railroads.
Amtrak, which has an overall budget of $2.4 billion this year, receives a Federal operating subsidy of $392 million. The subsidy is expected to drop to about $200 million in the next fiscal year. Congress has so far not threatened Amtrak with extinction.
The Senate Commerce Committee has approved the trust fund principle but the House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure is balking. Bud Shuster of Pennsylvania, the committee chairman, is opposed to giving Amtrak any share of the gas tax that goes to the highway trust fund. He is willing to discuss letting Amtrak have some of the the gas tax that supports mass transit.
To his credit, Mr. Shuster is pressing for reform of wasteful labor practices that have crippled passenger lines. He insists on allowing Amtrak to contract out construction and other work now done at higher cost by union members and scrapping six-year severance pay for many employees, a stand that offers a chance to free Amtrak from ancient shackles.
Amtrak has been succeeding lately at its task of trimming uneconomical services and building on promising ones. The railroad's latest report indicates that more passengers are fitting into fewer trains, creating greater economies.
To hold old customers and attract new ones, Amtrak needs the kind of dependable capital financial structure that highway industries enjoy through a dedicated trust fund. It is an investment the country should make.
