HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
A Tough Act to Follow, And Democrats Know It

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON; Iver Peterson is the Trenton bureau chief of The New York Times.

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK

 BODY:
When Senator Christopher J. Dodd got into his speech at the annual state Democratic dinner on Tuesday, the waiters and waitresses began filtering out of the kitchen to linger along the walls. The chairman of the Democratic National Committee recalled the glories of the Democratic Party -- student loans, family-leave policies, higher minimum wages, open doors to immigration -- and the lobbyists and lawyers and legislators who paid $500 each to be there applauded. But none of the paying guests were listening as raptly, or clapping as hard at the applause lines, as the workers who had just distributed the carrot cake with cream cheese and shaved chocolate icing.
Mr. Dodd, the Connecticut Democrat, is an old-fashioned podium pounder who can rouse a crowd with the best of them, and he summoned the proud ghosts of Democratic champions: Franklin D. Roosevelt, John F. Kennedy, Sam Rayburn, New Jersey's own Woodrow Wilson. "We need to reconnect with the people of this country," he said, implicitly acknowledging that the party had somehow lost touch. 
 Meanwhile, last night in Edison, the Republicans held their annual dinner and dance, where the dress was tuxedos and gowns, not suits and dresses, and where the price of a seat was $1,500 for those who wanted to sit with Governor Whitman at the tables that ring the dance floor.
The Republican fund-raising event came too late to make this column, but it is a fair bet that nobody talked about raising the minimum wage, except to disparage the idea, or about instructing employers on how much paid leave new mothers should be given. Cutting government and passing the savings on to the voters is what New Jersey Republicans talk about -- not strengthening it, unless it is to get tougher on criminals.
Democrats may still ask the voters, "What do you need?" and the answer from people like the men and women working second jobs in hotel ballrooms is "Plenty." But Republicans ask, "What is your peeve?" and they get answers these days from those whose needs are few but whose gripes are legion: Taxes. Bureaucrats. State regulations. Those immigrants.
Still, New Jersey Democrats are nothing if not optimists, and if they think they are out of touch with the second-richest state in the union, they are not saying so. Few of them even hope the party can reclaim the Assembly in November's elections, but they have a strong sense that better days lie ahead. This faith rests on two unproven ideas: Democratic ideals of a caring government will return to fashion, and Mrs. Whitman will eventually self-destruct.
"All she has is an agenda, not a vision," said Alan Karcher, once a Speaker of the Assembly and more recently pressed into service as chairman of the Democratic organization in Mercer County, where Republicans have been making inroads.
"It's like an actor with a great opening act, but no second act," Mr. Karcher went on. "Her first year she said, 'I promised to cut taxes and I delivered.' Now it's her second year and her message is, 'I promised to cut taxes, I did it, and now we're in this great economic renaissance.' And people are saying, 'Whaaat?' "
Mr. Karcher is a smart old fighter and he may be right. Voters want to know what politicians have done for them lately, and Mrs. Whitman's decision to accomplish her 30 percent cut in income tax cuts in two years instead of three gave her a tremendous national bounce just as the Republicans were taking control of Congress, but it deprived her of a third year of stories about the centerpiece of her governorship.
Still, a year ago at this time it was an article of faith that Mrs. Whitman would be undone, not by ennui and overfamiliarity, but by a reaction against higher property taxes that would result from her freeze in state spending. The Governor bet that any local property tax pressure would be felt by local officials, not her. She has been right about that, so far.

HEADLINE: Now, a Debate Over Trolleys In South Jersey

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

DATELINE: WOODBURY

 BODY:
In the 25 years since Burlington and Gloucester Counties last had commuter rail service, people here have had good reason to suspect that mass transit is mainly for people in North Jersey.
But things may soon change. Next month, New Jersey Transit is expected to unveil its recommendations for a trolley line linking the Gloucester suburbs to Philadelphia via Camden, with a possible extension into Burlington later on. 
 As usual, financing is a big obstacle for a project that could cost more than $1.4 billion at a time when Congress is ill disposed to spend money on mass transit. But that hasn't stopped people from debating the two leading proposals for extending rail service to this Gloucester County city, about 10 miles south of Camden:
* Direct service to Philadelphia (a "one-seat ride," in railway jargon) on a new branch of the existing Patco line, which now serves the Camden County suburbs.
* The New Jersey Transit light-rail system, which would travel through the Camden waterfront and require a transfer to Patco line.
"If this project is done wrong, many people fear it will be the last project in South Jersey," said Donald Nigro, president of Delaware Valley Asssociation of Railroad Passengers, which strongly favors the direct link.
That sense of urgency underscores the demand for public transportation in this fast-growing area. Residents and public officials say rail service would improve air quality, ease congestion on highways like Route 42 and promote economic growth.
John F. Sutton, New Jersey Transit's director for new rail construction in the area, says the agency is likely to choose the proposal. For one thing, he said, it would cost less. It would ease access to the Camden waterfront, with its newly refurbished State Aquarium and the popular new Blockbuster-Sony Music Entertainment Center. And it would leave open the option of building a Burlington County line; Patco can accommodate only one new branch.
Perhaps most important, Mr. Sutton went on, New Jersey Transit's experience with its proposed trolley line on the Hudson River waterfront shows that light-rail lines are more attractive to private companies than trains are. That makes it more likely that some of the investment can come from the private sector.
The first stage of the New Jersey Transit project would be a 10-mile stretch from Camden to Woodbury that would cost $400 million; the second would continue the link to Glassboro. If construction begins in 1997, the line could be operating by 2001.
New Jersey Transit is not the only agency that favors a trolley line with a transfer to Patco. "Light rail is better," said Robert G. Schwab, general manager of the Lindenwold-based Patco, whose initials stand for Port Authority Transit Corporation. By contrast, he said, a new Patco line from Gloucester County would be "like having two lanes merging into one" and "might affect our 99 percent on-time performance."
None of this impresses supporters of a Patco extension. They point out that a 1993 New Jersey Transit study found that a trolley and transfer system would attract only 60 percent as many riders as direct service to Philadelphia.
"Too many people in New Jersey Transit are from North Jersey, and they look at South Jersey as a small-scale version of New York," said George G. Williams, chairman of the South Jersey Transit Advisory Committee to New Jersey Transit. "But it's a totally different environment. Driving to Philadelphia is not an onerous task, parking is less expensive, and essentially most people have a single-seat ride anyway, by car or transit. They're not used to the idea of a transfer here."
There has been less support in Burlington County for a proposed rail line from Camden to Mount Holly. Residents along the route say they are worried about the narrow railroad right-of-ways, safety and noise. There are also fears that crime will spread from Camden along the line -- a fear that Camden officials say is unfounded.
"We have a beautiful waterfront and we feel our city is on the move again," said June Morton, a city administrative analyst who has led the local campaign for a waterfront trolley. "But how are toursts ever going to get here if there aren't additional modes of transportation?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: Transit advocates in Gloucester County say a trolley project (heavy line on map) could ease traffic jams like this one on Route 42 in Deptford. But not all agree on the route. (Laura Pedrick for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: PROFILE;
A Theater's Delicate Balance

BYLINE: By KAREN DeMASTERS 

 BODY:
Lori Ott may have one of the toughest jobs at the innovative Crossroads Theater in New Brunswick. As director of development, she is responsible for raising the $2.3 million a year that allows the theater to put on 150 to 200 performances of plays by black writers and actors, or plays done from a black perspective.
The Crossroads season opens next month with "The Piano Lesson," by August Wilson. Recent highlights include "Flyin' West," Pearl Cleage's play about black women in Kansas in 1898, and last season's of "Two Hah Hahs and a Homeboy," starring Ossie Davis and Ruby Dee. 
 Because of the theater's mission of developing minority talent, Crossroads has some advantages in the daily scramble for money that goes on among nonprofit and charity organizations. But dwindling Federal arts support and tighter economic constraints for corporations, foundations and individual donors make the job a constant challenge. Crossroads has an accumulated deficit of $700,000 from 1993 and before, which it is working to pay off.
"It's complicated, and it's becoming more so," said Ms. Ott, 33, who has been in charge of Crossroads's fund raising since November. "Corporations, foundations and government have, for 5 or 10 years, recognized the work of ethnic-specific organizations with special programs to promote diversity. But money is tighter for everyone."
A talented fund-raiser is invaluable to any nonprofit group or charity. "It may be one of the few safe jobs in theater," said Bonnie J. Monte, the artistic director of the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival. "Not only do most organizations have a full-time fund-raiser; they have a staff. Fund raising is a big deal."
Ms. Ott oversees two full-time employees and one part-timer. Her wide-ranging duties involve spending hours on the telephone with potential money sources, filling out voluminous applications (many due at the same time) and arranging meetings between Crossroads administrators and foundation heads.
"There are yearly cycles in funding, so what I do depends on where we are in the calendar," Ms. Ott said. "Part of my job is to know what is happening at each time of the year. I also stuff envelopes once in a while, but we have a great volunteer staff that usually does that. I just have to make sure everything gets done."
Any fund-raiser has to start with a love of the cause, said Ms. Ott, who previously managed a theater company in Philadelphia. "That love is what is going to come through in your words or writing. 'My ability to successfully raise money is directly related to my ability to articulate the needs of the theater.
"The trick is to look at the threats that face you, the things you need money for, and find a way to connect that to the available corporation, foundation or government sources. I can tell you who the players are, what projects they want to do and how to connect them to the theater. You have to know every detail of the theater."
About half of the Crossroads budget comes from earned income -- for example, ticket sales. The other half comes from government sources (including the New Jersey State Council on the Arts, which has allotted Crossroads $250,000 for fiscal 1996, more than any other theater in the state except the McCarter in Princeton), foundations, corporations and individual contributions, in that order.
Ms. Ott finds her search for money further complicated because she is married to Jeffrey Woodward, the managing director of the McCarter, who is in competition for some of the same pots.
"We just agree not to talk about it," she said with a laugh, "but he's very supportive of the nights and extra hours that a fund-raising job involves."
Ms. Ott plans to leave her job soon to have their second baby but said she would consider returning to fund raising.
"It's challenging," she said, "and I enjoy it because the development effort is so close to all the aspects of the theater. It is a central job."

HEADLINE: Money for Art's Sake

BYLINE: By BARBARA STEWART 

 BODY:
LIKE nearly all nonprofit galleries, Aljira: A Center for Contemporary Art, in Newark, is chronically low on cash. So it was natural that rather than pay someone else, the center would have its own artists design its stationery, brochures and invitations.
The people who received the letters and invitations, including donors and others in business, were struck by the jazzy, colorful look and began asking if the artists would design something equally distinctive for their companies. From that beginning, a cottage industry is emerging, along the lines of Trappist monks selling homemade jelly. Now Aljira has received a $50,000 grant to start a graphic design studio that should bring in a bit of cash to support its exhibitions of contemporary art. 
 At a time when New Jersey's arts groups are regrouping after budget cuts, trying to guarantee they will not simply survive but flourish in lean times, the kind of flexibility and innovativeness shown by Aljira is becoming more common. If most arts groups are not actually joining the profit-making business world, most are stretching way out to meet it.
"New Jersey is under a great deal of financial stress," said Barry Taylor, the president of Art Pride, an advocacy group based in Millville. Arts organizations that floundered in the early 1990's after the State Legislature cut the New Jersey State Council for the Arts' appropriation in half are looking for ways to insure financial stability in the coming years.
"It's the same environment we're all responding to," said Harris Ferris, managing director of the American Repertory Ballet in New Brunswick. "Concerns are mounting about long-term funding for the arts. Increasingly, there's concern about long-term, about making arts groups more cost-effective."
Last week his troupe merged with the smaller Garden State Ballet, which had lost its director and staff and was nearing bankruptcy. The combined forces, Mr. Ferris said, will perform in more counties, employ more full-time and freelance dancers, and probably receive support from the Garden State Ballet's contributors.
"This is lean-belly time," Mr. Ferris said. "Arts groups have to be highly adaptive. Funders don't want duplication."
It would be simple -- but inaccurately simplistic -- for people in government and corporations to regard New Jersey's arts groups as nonessential extras, pleasant but dispensable. It's up to arts administrators to convince donors that music, dance and theater performances and exhibitions of paintings, photographs and dinosaur bones are not just enlightening, civilizing forces, but economically crucial ones as well. Every group from major nonprofit institutions like the Newark Museum, with a $17.6 million budget this year, to rural county arts and heritage commissions, which count their dollars in the tens of thousands, faces the same fundamental mission. They have to make those with the money see that the arts put cash in the pockets of people as various as corporate executives, computer salespeople and falafel sellers.
"When the New Brunswick theaters are filled, the restaurants are filled and the parking lots are filled," said Nina Stack, a spokeswoman for the New Jersey State Council on the Arts. "People walk around town and go shopping. Those places pay taxes, and the revenue comes back."
Today, corporations want to know they're getting something in return for their contributions. "The philanthrophic mood has changed," said Victor Davson, Aljira's executive director. "Cultural institutions are under tremendous pressure to make art justify itself, to show that giving that giving X amount of dollars to the arts will generate X amount of dollars."
Which, the state has determined, it will. The Council on the Arts, which administers state spending, has estimated that 600 nonprofit arts groups and their audiences' spending contributed more than $643 million to the state's economy in 1993. Attendance at New Jersey's museums, concerts, plays and so forth came to nine million that year, including 600,000 children on field trips.
That was the year when, under Gov. Jim Florio, the state drastically cut its arts support . In 1989, the council distributed more than $21 million appropriated by the Legislature to 120 private arts groups and 21 county arts agencies. The counties, in turn, distributed the grants to about 350 regional groups. By 1992, the money had been cut by more than half, to $9.7 million. Last year, the appropriation rose to $10.2 million, where it remains.
"State funding has remained at an even level," said Bonnie J. Monte, director of the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival in Madison, the state's only wholly classical theater, which also produces student plays in schools. "But we all envision bigger cuts down the line. We all envision very hard times down the line."
 
Sinking, Then Rising
In the wake of the big state cut, which coincided with Federal cuts and a recession, some organizations went deep into the red. The budgets of a few like the Newark Museum -- known for one of the country's most extensive scientific collections, galleries of American, Asian and African art, and children's programs attended by more than 100,000 last year -- were not affected. Most, like the American Boychoir School in Princeton and the American Repertory Ballet, floundered but have recovered, more or less.
"We cut back to the bone," said Mr. Ferris of the ballet. "There were layoffs and cancellations of weeks of the season. There was a shakeup of the board. All the pieces were almost falling apart and being put back together." Now, he said, the ballet is financially strong. Last season it gave a record number of performances and pulled in high touring revenues.
The state cuts also shook the American Boychoir School, a boarding school with 82 students, ages 10 to 14, who perform around the country. The early 90's "were very tough years for us," said John Ellis, president of the school. Wages were frozen and tours were reduced. Now, he said, the directors see the need for "substantial permanent endowment funds" to guarantee that future government cuts won't hurt the school again. The Boychoir School's goal is to increase the $400,000 endowment established in 1994 to $5 million by the year 2000.
The school's fund-raisers "are turning more vigorously to individual friends," Mr. Ellis said. "We've involved the board of trustees personally in phone calls, dinners, lunches, visits. We need to look to corporations and foundations -- the people who live here, who don't want to have to go to New York or Philadelphia for the arts."
 
Doing More Homework
To arts administrators, it's ever more crucial that individual and corporate donors hear their message as the Federal Government becomes less and less receptive to it. The Republican leadership in Congress has made clear its intentions to abolish the National Endowment for the Arts, the National Endowment for the Humanities and the Corporation for Public Broadcasting. That would mean no Federal money would go to the visual arts, architecture, opera, dance, literature or broadcasting.
By comparison, the New Jersey Legislature gave more than $5 million last year directly to six major organizations: the New Jersey Symphony, the Newark Museum, the Newark Boys Chorus, the Morris Museum, the Sussex County Arts Council and the Union County Arts Center.
Groups that have seen their government contributions dry up are expanding their fund-raising, seeking ways to be secure regardless of the politicians' views. Their ways of coping may be as major as the ballet merger or as subtle as a shift in attitude. Some have grown a bit more pushy in communicating their cultural, educational and economic virtues.
Steven Klindt, the executive director of the Morris Museum in Morristown, is trying to make people "want to participate in a modest way" by making regular contributions. His museum's collection includes dollhouses, rocks, works by New Jersey artists along with a single Rembrandt, and live flying squirrels in the basement.
Alexandra Christy, a senior program officer at the Geraldine R. Dodge Foundation in Morristown, one of New Jersey's leading private donors to the arts, says the grant proposals it is now receiving are more tightly focused and more detailed.
"People have to be very smart," she said. "They are not deciding what plays to put on from an artistic, creative point of view, in a vacuum. They are actually going to the audiences and asking: 'What do you need? What do you want? What would make you come to the theater more often?'
"There's been a very wide gulf between the people who deliver arts and the ones who receive them," she added.
One attempt to bridge the gulf is the Governor's Conference on the Arts in Trenton next week. Hundreds of business leaders, politicians, arts administrators and community leaders are expected to attend.
Meanwhile, arts groups are forming their own alliances to make themselves smarter about money. One such consortium of 22 New Jersey philanthropies called Arts Challenge gave Aljira in Newark the $50,000 to start its graphic design studio.
Mr. Davson, Aljira's director, is a painter who studied art at Pratt Institute and founded the gallery with a fellow artist in a loft. After the grant came through, he went to Babson College near Boston and Harvard Business School to learn a new art: that of running a profit-making business.
He said he did not expect profits ever to cover the center's annual budget of slightly less than $200,000. "It's not to get wealthy,' he said. "If we can make a profit the first year, that would be brilliant."
Selling graphic design work is one tactic that would spread the gallery's name and impress donors who don't expect such practicality from painters and sculptors. "A lot of the work will be humdrum," he said. "We'll be willing to do the most boring projects: corporate documents, government agency reports." Part of the studio's mission would be to sell distinctive designs to business administrators who've never considered design important.
Ms. Christy of the Dodge Foundation said of Aljira's project: "It's a real effort to bring in earned income. That's the name of the game."
More important than earning income, however, is convincing people that the arts organizations' first and foremost purpose -- producing, showing and teaching the arts -- is worthy of their support. That involves spreading the word about the arts' enriching value and widespread popularity among people of all ages and incomes.
The New Jersey Symphony played free concerts last summer in eight parks throughout the state and brought as many as 10,000 children to special concerts. At a Hoboken community center, an actor from Elders Share the Arts helped older people write their life stories and produce from them a play, a history of Hoboken. The Poetry Center at Passaic County Community College encourages people who never gave poetry a thought to write about their own experiences and emotions.
In Salem County, one of New Jersey's smallest and most rural, the Salem Cultural and Heritage Commission pays for three sopranos to sing at nursing homes, and for the Oakwood Summer Theater, where audiences see popular shows like "Annie Get Your Gun." The Salem cultural commission was among the 20 or so distinguished arts organizations named by the state arts council, sharing honors with groups like the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra and the McCarter Theater in Princeton.
People from organizations large and small go into schools, where, they say, they do some of their most important work. Arts groups are working to see that "more money is put into arts than football jerseys," said Ms. Christy of the Dodge Foundation. "They are making sure the superintendent knows what's being taught when the arts are being taught. It's developing the entire creative realm of kids. It's not just for future artists."
The extraordinarily sophisticated 30,000-year-old cave paintings found recently in the south of France make clear "that the human animal needs to create," Ms. Christy said, and went on: "It's not just a luxury for people with time on their hands. It's obviously a primal need. People were doing it when there was no such thing as rich and poor, and Republican and Democrat, and the N.E.A. and N.E.H. Art is not a sandbox for the rich. It's how we survive."

HEADLINE: To Find New-Issue Players, Use a Scorecard

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
IF the stock market has been a party in 1995, nowhere have the champagne corks popped more loudly than among initial public offerings. So: Here's to Netscape Communications, an Internet venture which rose 167 percent during its first day.. Here's to Redhook Ale, a Seattle microbrewer, up 68 percent since its debut in mid-August. And then there's Premisys Communications, a maker of telecommunications equipment, up an astonishing six-fold since April.
It's not just a few standouts, either. Three of every four new issues over the last 12 months have surpassed this year's soaring stock market, and dozens have doubled in price. "God should be so generous every 12 months," said John Fitzgibbon Jr., editor of the IPO Aftermarket. 
 Nor do these gains come at the expense of common sense, at least by some lights. "The real surprising thing," said John Laporte, the manager of the T. Rowe Price New Horizons Fund, "has been that the quality level has been good and remains good." And given a chugging economy and the public's strong appetite for equities, it may be a long time till last call.
But, for common investors, hoping either to join the festivities or just to watch them, the I.P.O. market can be frustrating and confusing. At their best, I.P.O.'s are often tough to assess, with a short history and no record of stock-price behavior. Mix in the notably high-tech nature of this year's I.P.O.'s -- one-third are technological issues -- and the confusion soars. What is the everyman investor to make of On Technology Corporation, for instance, which "develops, markets and supports groupware applications and workgroup utilities software"?
These puzzlements stymie many investors, and Andrew Santer, a consulting pharmacist in Santa Barbara, Calif., is one. of them. "They don't interest me anymore," he said of I.P.O.'s in general. "You can't get enough information to evaluate them."
For investors and the idly curious, one way to get a handle on this riveting but perplexing market is to watch the underwriters who make it happen. While nearly all of them look downright uncanny these days -- just about everything has taken off -- a close examination of their records will show that some underwriters are quicker to spot promising young companies, or detect emerging industry trends, than others, and some have hit low points, even in this skyhigh market.
"If you don't know the horse," said Mr. Fitzgibbon, "you can bet the jockey."
Robert Natale, editor of Standard & Poor's Emerging and Special Situations newsletter, agrees. "The better the underwriter, the better the deal," he said. "The best deals are going to come out under the aegis of excellent corporate finance and excellent research capability."
More specifically, the ability of a firm's analysts to convince investors to buy an issue is critical to how well the stock will perform in the months ahead. And underwriter support of the stock can play a large role in its fate -- especially after the initial euphoria has faded.
Nearly 200 new issues are slated for debut before the end of 1995. They include such eagerly awaited names as Gucci, the Italian shoemaker; Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, the investment bank; Boston Beer, the maker of Samuel Adams; and ESS Technology, a semiconductor outfit. What does it mean that the lead underwriters for these companies are, respectively, Morgan Stanley; Donaldson; Goldman, Sachs and Morgan Stanley? How should these link-ups affect your view of the future of the new stock? Here is a scorecard to help form answers:
The name of the nation's star underwriter depends a bit on definitions. Some firms have hit lots of home runs over the last 12 months, others seem to have played for consistency, and still others are industry or regional specialists.
The firms with more than their share of recent home runs range from huge Goldman, Sachs, which raised a fifth of the $20 billion in I.P.O.'s done in the last 12 months, to much smaller outfits, like Cowen & Company in New York and Robertson Stephens in San Francisco.
Goldman, Sachs has been able to hit eight of its 28 I.P.O.'s out of the park -- a doubling or more in price -- by virtue of its sheer marketing and research muscle. .
The other home-run hitters have scored by being in the right sector -- technology -- at the right time. Alex. Brown, with only a quarter of Goldman, Sach's share of the market, has seen an equal number of its I.P.O.'s double or more in price, including Epic Design Software and CBT Group, another software developer.
"The wind has been to our back with technology stocks," conceded Sandy Robertson, chairman of Robertson Stephens. Seven of the firm's 22 I.P.O.s, including Discrete Logic and Orbit Semiconductor, have doubled or more in price.
Cowen & Company, which has a strong reputation for expertise in technology, has done not only well, but consistently so with only a handful of I.P.O.'s. The company was the lead manager of four I.P.O.'s over the last year, with an average gain of an astonishing 176 percent. When some people held off bringing semiconductor companies public out of fear of a seasonal slump, Cowen listened to the contrary advice of its researchers and brought Semitool and Brooks Automation public last December. Both have more than doubled in price.
Since picking the home runs ahead of time is difficult, investors should prize the consistency of Cowen or of Robertson, Stephens, all of whose I.P.O.'s over the last year have beaten the overall market. Some of the less well-known firms -- William Blair, J.C. Bradford and Needham, for example -- also had perfect batting averages, but with fewer I.P.O.'s than bigger firms like Alex. Brown or Morgan Stanley.
Consistency is especially prized given that some underwriters have had significant strikeouts: I.P.O.'s that lost money even as the overall stock market gained 25 percent this year. "The best underwriters sometimes bring out clunkers," said Mr. Natale of Standard & Poor's.
Sometimes, the misstep is simply a case of being in the wrong place. With international markets having dismal years, firms that underwrote American depository receipts -- certificates of foreign stocks -- have had frequent strikeouts. Three of the four money-losing I.P.O.'s from Goldman, Sachs, for instance, are A.D.R.'s in such companies as Internacional de Ceramica, a Mexican ceramic tile maker. J.P. Morgan, which only had four I.P.O.'s, fared poorly with two A.D.R.'s -- Banco Industrial Colombiano and Banco Wiese Ltdo.
Sometimes, the bad luck consists only of not being in the right place.Lehman Brothers has had few tech issues over the last 12 months, when such I.P.O.'s have proved the most profitable. The scarcity shows: Lehman's average deal during this period has underperformed the market by 7 percentage points. Last year, Lehman had eight technology I.P.O.'s.
"It's just a timing issue when our clients decide to finance," said Marc Paley, the head of the syndicate desk for Lehman. Mr. Paley also emphasized that Lehman continues to do many secondary offerings for technology companies -- 18 over the last 12 months -- and that its record in the sector should be viewed only in that context.
For other underwriters, including some who have been very successful in the past, the mistakes are more diffuse. Despite Merrill Lynch's good record with such past I.P.O.'s as Boston Chicken, only half of Merrill Lynch's 16 deals beat the market over the last 12 months, for example. Of course, the underwriter's record is just one factor in judging the potential of an I.P.O., noted Linda Killian, a research analyst for Renaissance Capital, a money management firm in Stamford, Conn. "What it really comes down is the particulars of the transaction and the price and whether you can make money."
And, of course, current success is no indicator of future results. Some of 1994's high riders have fallen in 1995, and the same can happen to today's leaders. Beware, too, of Wall Street's version of striking while the iron is hot: using a temporary hot streak to push defective issues onto unsuspecting investors.
 Moreover, though many think the party will go on, some say it may be close to last call. "We are now in the midst of an overheated technology market," wrote Robert Sanborn, portfolio manager of the Oakmark Fund, to his shareholders. Calling the phenomenon IPO Mania Redux, he has decided not to participate in any of these offerings.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2642 words

HEADLINE: Foiling the Best Laid Plans;
Hard Realities Roil the Irvine Company's Tidy California Dream

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: IRVINE, Calif.

 BODY:
IF there are two words that sum up this obsessively planned city of 120,000 in the heart of Orange County, they are symmetry and order.
In Woodbridge Village, the largest subdivision here, there is a central corridor of churches, shopping centers and low-rise office buildings with nearly identical manmade lakes on either side. Spreading out from their banks are similar wood-framed town houses, thickets of oleander and tract housing. Businesses, and homeowners, are strictly regulated so they do not upset the buff-hued color scheme. And in a city dedicated to healthy living, there is no cemetery. 
 This neatly packaged version of the California Dream, 50 miles south of Los Angeles, is the creation of the largest designer and developer of master-planned communities in America -- the deceptively low-key Irvine Company and its secretive owner, Donald L. Bren. The privately held company is a sprawling behemoth that began as the Irvine family ranch in the 1860's. Its properties today sprout everything from the state's biggest producer of avocados to shopping malls, hotels, office towers and affluent towns like Newport Beach. And its influence is just as pervasive.
"Their fingerprints are on everything that happens here," said Louis Masotti, head of the real estate program at the University of California at Irvine's management school.
But the Orange County Government's bizarre bankruptcy last December, and then the voters' angry rejection of a tax increase that was supposed to clear up the mess, has turned this seemingly harmonious landscape into a complex, unruly battleground. And all this comes at a time when the county, once nearly all-white and affluent, is in the midst of deep demographic and economic changes of the sort that many residents came here to escape.
No one has more at stake in the outcome of the bankruptcy battle -- and the social contours of the county's future -- than the Irvine Company, which has the mixed fortune of owning a wonderful stretch of land that is concentrated in just one, troubled place. "Their future depends completely on the county's viability," said Mr. Masotti.
As a result, a company that has been compulsive about controlling its environment is now at the mercy of that environment. And a company that always saw its future in clear, bold strokes is now facing the sort of uncertainty its planners had tried to sweep away.
Drastic county budget cuts and the struggle by local and state officials to hammer out a financial rescue plan are producing big reductions in county services and thus a threat to property values. According to the rescue plan passed by the state Legislature in the last day of its session Friday, the county will have to make steep cuts in bus service and cut hundreds of jobs in order to divert funds to repay creditors.
And no matter how successful the plan, the county's troubles will persist for years. Already, it appears that the weak market and the lingering effects of the recession may have forced the company to defer offering interests in some of its real estate holdings to the public.
Nevertheless, company executives continue to express confidence in their long-term prospects. "Is this going to hurt us in the long term?" asked Raymond L. Watson, who is the company's vice chairman and its original urban planner, as well as the former chairman of the Walt Disney Company. "I don't think so. But getting to the long term from where we are could be difficult."
To some extent, the Irvine Company is Orange County. It owns a sixth of the county's land, about 90 square miles stretching from the hills above the Pacific coast to the Cleveland National Forest, 22 miles to the northeast. Its developments are often praised for their quality and planning, and they are a big reason Orange County has enjoyed a reputation as a pleasant alternative to Los Angeles.
The Irvine Company leaves little to chance in any field of endeavor. The company is also a well-oiled political machine with an outsized influence over the election of everyone from town supervisors to the state's Governor -- and perhaps the next President of the United States.
MR. BREN is one of the national Republican Party's top financial contributors and he is the finance chairman for the presidential campaign of his close friend and former Marine buddy, Gov. Pete Wilson of California. Last year, Mr. Bren, his companies and his employees contributed more than $210,000 to Governor Wilson's re-election campaign. When one of Mr. Bren's executives gets involved in a political battle, no one here doubts that Mr. Bren is calling the shots.
"Nothing happens at the company that he doesn't have his hands on, from the color of a door knob to the types of trees at Fashion Island," said Mr. Watson, referring to the tony shopping mall that the company owns in Newport Beach.
During the lengthy and often acrimonious negotiations over the county's financial crisis, Mr. Bren's top political operative, Gary H. Hunt, has been a constant presence.
"We are vigorous in representing our own interests, wherever we see them," Mr. Watson said, adding, "That is what we are supposed to do. It's part of what we are."
The focus of all this influence, and the unusual challenges, is the reclusive Mr. Bren, 63, a trim, well-tanned executive whose relationship with the Irvine Company began when he was a well-to-do home builder in Orange County in the 1960's and 70's. Mr. Bren, who declined to be interviewed for this article, constructed two developments for the company and then, in 1977, bought an interest in it from the Irvine family by resorting to what many criticized at the time as a political dirty trick.
He had teamed up with some wealthy investors, including the shopping center magnate A. Alfred Taubman, Henry Ford 2d, the late Milton Petrie, founder of Petrie Stores, and Herbert Allen Sr., a New York investment banker. Their group was competing with the Mobil Corporation for what was still known as the Irvine Ranch. The financial heft of Mobil, the giant oil company, gave it a big advantage.
But suddenly ads appeared in major newspapers on May 4, 1977, from a previously unknown group called the Committee for Energy Resources. The ads chastised Mobil for throwing money away on real estate instead of drilling for more oil.
"Is Mobil Turning Its Back on America During Our Energy Crisis?" asked the ads, which encouraged people to complain to Congress.
Mr. Bren soon confirmed reports disclosing that he had secretly helped finance the ads -- through Mr. Hunt. "I think that ad won us the deal," said one of the investors in the group. The group paid $337.4 million for the ranch, just edging out a suddenly hesitant Mobil.
In 1983, when the investors decided to take their profits, Mr. Bren bought them out for $518 million, a deal financed largely with bank debt. That gave Mr. Bren slightly more than 92 percent of the stock. Today, he is reportedly worth at least $2 billion and the company is as politically active as ever.
Mr. Hunt is now an executive vice president at the company. He was a special assistant to Ronald Reagan when Mr. Reagan was Governor of California, was a deputy director of the 1980 Republican National Convention and was a vice chairman of President Reagan's first inauguration committee. The company's spokesman, Larry Thomas, was a press secretary to Pete Wilson when he was mayor of San Diego and for George Bush when he was Vice President.
Mr. Bren, frequently referred to as a shy man, clearly enjoys his wealth. He lives in a $5 million mansion near the ocean and is an avid skier. The son of a Hollywood producer, Mr. Bren is now a bachelor, with three children by two ex-wives and, the company has confirmed, a a child by a longtime companion.
What clearly makes this such a trying time for Mr. Bren is that he has traditionally fought to control everything that goes on in his company and thus, by extension, the county. (The company professes, however, to have had no role in the investing decisions that led to the county's bankruptcy.)
The clearest sign that the company's control is loosening was the angry rejection in June of a half-cent increase in the local sales tax. The Irvine Company and other supporters of the plan -- which Mr. Hunt helped design -- outspent their opponents by a lopsided margin of about $1.5 million to about $85,000, but it did not help. Some of the tax's opponents characterized the overwhelmingly negative vote as a referendum on the power of the Irvine Company and other big developers. In the aftermath of that rejection, the county and the state Legislature worked out an alternative financial plan that is likely to end the banckruptcy early next year, but not without a substantial reduction in services.
Mr. Bren has long been hypersensitive about his image as well as that of his company, fighting aggressively for the right to build, but backing down on some occasions when faced with strong public opposition. For instance, the company agreed several years ago to abandon a proposed development on some canyon lands near Laguna Beach and instead sell them for preservation as a park. In another instance of conciliation, it abandoned its initial refusal to provide low-income housing here.
"The Irvine Company is a funny animal," said James Toledano, head of the Democratic Party here and the lawyer for a group fighting a road project the company backs. "Of all the developers in the county, they are probably the most responsive. I think they have figured out how to use their leverage as subtly as possible. For their own selfish interests they are prepared to be good citizens."
Good citizenship has its frustrations. The company had wanted to obtain 800 acres of prime property on the El Toro Marine Air Station, a military base here that is going to be closed down and turned into a big international airport. But earlier this year it was forced to drop an offer to give the county thousands of acres of less valuable land at its eastern end in exchange for the prime site the company wanted.
And residents of the city of Irvine have fought the airport conversion bitterly because of fears their quiet community would be overwhelmed with noise and traffic. The proposed land swap was perceived by some here as a blatant grab for wealth, and ended up giving the company a black eye.
"The future of El Toro is pivotal to the future of Orange County," said Republican Representative Dana Rohrabacher, one of the county's Congressmen, who fought the swap. "Hundreds of millions of dollars were going to be given to a major corporation in that stupid deal. It would have been an amazing ripoff."
A casualty of the uncertainty caused by the bankruptcy, and the slowness of the real estate market in the long California recession, may be what apparently was Mr. Bren's long-planned exit strategy -- heavy new development and the public offering of a series of real estate investment trusts, or REIT's, that would have created a liquid market for part of his holdings.
One REIT, Irvine Apartment Communities, which holds the company's apartment buildings, went public in December 1993 at $17.50, and the company made a second offering this year at $17.25.
THE first REIT rose initially to $21.75 but then slumped to a low of $14.25 in December of last year, just around the time the county declared bankruptcy. This year, however, with the California real estate market just starting to show signs of recovery, it has risen 12 percent, from $16.625 on Jan. 3 to $18.625 Friday. But none of the other offerings look even close because of the weakness of the REIT market and because of the county's troubles.
"This may cause him to rethink his plan entirely or to take a new look at other options," said James F. Wilson, an analyst who follows REIT's for Montgomery Securities.
Still, the Irvine Company remains in fairly solid shape. Indeed, one of the more puzzling aspects of the county's bankruptcy, caused by the former treasurer's reckless losses of $1.7 billion from a county investment fund, is that it is still far from clear what impact it is having on the area, a bustling region with an economy the size of Greece's.
The biggest problem has just been uncertainty -- whether the decline in county services will cut into the area's high quality of life, whether residents will eventually suffer a big tax bite, whether the schools will be hurt. And that has translated into a big drop in home sales, which have fallen close to 30 percent this year countywide.
Nevertheless, the Irvine Company's high-quality projects have fared slightly better. Its latest residential project, called Newport Coast, which will eventually consist of 2,600 housing units, has already sold nearly 200 custom lots at an average cost of more than $1 million.
But the company has still had to endure some belt-tightening. It cutting staff sharply, from about 1,500 in the late 80's to about 200 today. In addition, while the company does not release financial data, its revenues have reportedly been flat the last three years, at about $800 million.
One of the greatest challenges the company faces is the fact that the county had been going through profound changes even before the bankruptcy. Twenty years ago, the county was largely white and affluent, and many of its towns were still regarded as suburbs of Los Angeles. Today, 38 percent of its 2.6 million residents are ethnic minorities; Santa Ana, the county seat, is 73 percent Hispanic and the cities of Westminster and Garden Grove are home to about 110,000 Vietnamese.
The county has many pockets of great affluence, but its per capita income, $25,022 in 1993, the latest year for which figures are available, was sixth in the state. Assessed property values per capita were 15th in the state in 1993 and the median price of a home has dropped since the bankruptcy, from $220,176 last December to about $190,000 last month.
About 200,000 Orange County residents are now living below the poverty line, a number that has been growing at about twice the rate of the overall population in recent years, according to Mark Baldassare, chairman of the University of California at Irvine's department of urban and regional planning.
"The image is really based on the economic character of just a handful of cities," said Mr. Baldassare.
BUT perhaps the greatest contradictions lie in the county's political character. The area is heavily Republican and thinks of itself as libertarian. In reality, however, the residents have fought for environmental protection. Businesses face an extraordinary level of regulation. And taxes -- in the form of a stream of special assessments to pay for neighborhood amenities and services -- are among the highest in California.
"It's always struck me as remarkable that politically Orange County is seen as so conservative and, lo and behold, you have a master-planned city with high taxes," said Larry Agran, a former mayor of Irvine and himself a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1992. "There is a heavy degree of central planning of everything here, with more regulations on businesses than in most other places. But it is democratically imposed regulation. The people say they want it."
And the Irvine Company has wanted it. From the time it began to build cities on what had been dry, hilly grazing land, the company has looked at its vast holdings as a private preserve on which it would shape the future -- and is still struggling to do so.
"What do you want to be thought of when you die? That's the view Don takes of his work," said Mr. Watson, who was trained in architecture. "He's an outstanding developer who believes in what he owns. This is his canvas. In a way, he's more of an architect than I am."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Radio Frenzy Brings Riches

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
There's a lot of money in radio these days. The value of companies that own radio stations has zoomed this year, amid optimism that companies will be able to make more money by buying up stations in one market.
All this has created a wonderful circle. With their share prices zooming, the companies find it easy to sell more shares, thus raising cash to buy more radio stations. That cash drives up the value of radio stations, which in turn makes the shares more valuable. And so on and so on. 
 How well have radio stations done? We put together a list of five companies that solely or primarily run radio stations. On average, they are up 75 percent this year. Not quite as well as some tech sectors -- one technology mutual fund has doubled in 1995 -- but still very impressive.
There is, perhaps, a pattern to Wall Street fads. First comes the smart money that recognizes a fundamental change. In this case, the change was the 1992 change in Government rules that let companies own more stations -- up to two AM and two FM in each market. That created the potential for additional demand at the same time that it made possible some economies of scale, through housing more stations in the same facilities and through having one sales force sell advertising on several stations.
Eventually, as more and more people recognize the changed circumstances, prices start to soar. That brings in the momentum investors -- those who buy stocks because they are going up. A lot of mutual fund managers operate that way now, which may help to explain why market moves these days can last longer than they once did.
Eventually, however, comes the silly time. That is when so many believe in an area -- or more precisely, believe that prices in that area can only go up -- that buyers can be found for almost anything.
That point may have been reached with Triathlon Broadcasting, which is a triumph as an initial public offering. This summer, friends of the underwriter were invited to purchase shares for 1 cent each. This month, shares were sold to the public, by two hitherto obscure underwriters -- Americorp Securities and Royce Investment Group -- for $5.50 each. The share price has since soared to $13.
The buyers got a start-up company. With the proceeds from the offering, the company bought four radio stations in Wichita, Kan. It has plans to buy two stations in Lincoln, Neb., but that depends on a plan to borrow money. The borrowing will be available only if it can show good results from the Wichita stations.
Triathlon bought the four radio stations for a total of $5.9 million, and will have a few million in cash until it does the Lincoln deal. Yet the market value of the company's stock is now $53 million. To justify that price, you have to assume either that these stations are gold mines whose value went unrecognized by the previous owners or that Triathlon's superior management will turn them into cash machines.
Neither looks likely. As it happens, the owners of the company selling most of the stations to Triathlon are -- surprise -- insiders at Triathlon who paid pennies for their shares. And Norman Feuer, Triathlon's chief executive, also serves as chief operating officer of the selling company. If there is a way to make these stations into highly profitable operations, it so far has eluded Triathlon's management.
Nonetheless, they have found a way to get rich even if the stations can't sell many ads. Mr. Feuer's stake in Triathlon, which cost him $2,449 a few months back, is now worth $3.2 million. Isn't Wall Street wonderful?

HEADLINE: Diary

BYLINE: By HUBERT B. HERRING 

 BODY:

BENETTON
Going Where the Suffering Is
Benetton, often accused of exploiting human suffering, has opened a store in a capital of suffering, Sarajevo -- and has made sure to pile sandbags in front of the windows.
 
TELEVISION
Is the Buzz the Message?
You didn't watch "Central Park West" last week? That took great strength of character, considering the mind-boggling effort that CBS, desperate to lure younger viewers with something glitzy, put into hyping the show. It went way beyond buzz -- the network enlisted every bee in its hive to promote this one: the stars' faces adorning Manhattan buses, "advertorials" (horrible word), board games, even a World Wide Web site. The goal, as one marketing type put it: "entertainment-fashion-media-advertising synergy." Whew! That's a mouthful.
 
HEALTH CARE
Will This Fix Medicare?
House Republicans were determined to slash $270 billion out of seven years' worth of projected Medicare spending, and last week they said they'd found a way. But have they? Yes, premiums would rise -- slightly for most, sharply for the rich -- but the plan is short on incentives to nudge the elderly into H.M.O.'s. Bob Dole and Newt Gingrich insist that a free market in health care choices will make it all better -- even without those incentives. But critics like Representative Henry Waxman said cuts in payments to doctors would "destroy Medicare in a few short years." And many elements of the plan are still vague, prompting Democrats to say crucial details are being hidden.
 
ROCKEFELLER CENTER
It's Hard Being a Trophy
How can this happen? One of the world's prize properties, Rockefeller Center, is caught up in such convoluted financial games that billions are being lost on it. The answer is that no one really "owns" such a place, one merely owns the right to collect rents and pay the bills -- but that right is a dubious trophy indeed when the bills exceed the rents. Last week Mitsubishi Estate decided it wanted no more of such losing math and bailed out -- and expects to pay $1 billion for its lesson in New York real estate economics. At which point more investors -- like Sam Zell and Goldman, Sachs -- rushed in, cash in hand, to make it even more complicated. The venerable buildings didn't even sway.
 
POLITICS
Tobacco Money for the G.O.P.
At a time when it faces various regulatory threats -- Government efforts to label nicotine an addictive drug, for instance, and to reduce sales to teen-agers -- the tobacco industry is pouring money into Republican coffers. In the first half of this year, the industry contributed $1.5 million, five times as much as last year's first six months. Nearly half that sum came from Philip Morris. Representative Henry Waxman said the tobacco industry "has gotten its hooks into the Republican leadership." And the head of Common Cause called the heavy donations "a desperate last effort." But a spokesman for Brown & Williamson -- also a donor -- cited his company's belief in the Republican vision of "less government, less red tape."
 
COMMUNICATIONS
Policing the Internet
Computer networks are indisputably glorious things. No stamps, no paper, no fuss. A generation that thought letter-writing had surely died in a sun-washed 19th-century morning room has suddenly started to communicate. Now, alas, comes the dark side. Some people are using this strange new toy to send out child pornography or even lure children to sex. This gets complicated, for even if you get past the ethical question -- isn't private communication private? -- a huge practical one remains: how can you possibly monitor the zillions of 1's and 0's zooming through cyberspace? You can't always, of course, but last week -- after a four-year F.B.I. investigation -- came dozens of arrests for on-line porn and solicitation.
 
THE WORKPLACE
Women's Progress, Stalled
Are women moving steadily closer to equal status in the workplace? Surely nothing could stop the momentum of recent years. Or could it? In a poll out last week, only 56 percent of women said the role of women was continuing to change -- down from 73 percent five years ago. Do women "face more restrictions" than men? Yes, said 84 percent, with 77 percent saying sexual discrimination "remains a serious problem." And 76 percent said there was sexual harassment in the workplace.
 
STATISTICS
Do-It-Yourself Inflation
Numbers flow mercilessly from the Government -- statistics with little apparent purpose except to keep statisticians busy -- and many are easily ignored. But not the Consumer Price Index. "This is real," said Pat Moynihan. "Everything else is talk." This mighty inflation gauge, after all, dictates cost-of-living increases for Social Security and adjustments in tax brackets, and the tiniest blip translates into billions of dollars. What a gift to budget-cutters, then, if the index was found to be flawed. Sure enough, last week a Congressional panel said the index greatly overstates inflation -- and fixing it could trim $634 billion from the deficit over 10 years. This wouldn't exactly be a gift to retirees, though. Part of the index's flaw, it seems, is that it doesn't pick up shifts in buying patterns in response to higher prices. So if this "flaw" is fixed, Social Security recipients struggling to stretch their budgets would, in a sense, be doing the Government a favor, not themselves.
 
TRANSPORTATION
Tunnel of Lost Cash
Talk about a money pit! The Channel tunnel cost such a staggering sum to build -- $15 billion -- that it now faces interest costs of more than $3 million a day. A day! The tunnel's doing fine, mind you -- Eurostar trains are 75 percent full. But there's no way it can shell out that killer interest, and last week the company that runs it said it would simply not pay much of that interest for perhaps 18 months. Which means, of course, that big changes are coming -- and investors will be out a lot of money. But it will certainly keep running. "You cannot sell a hole in the ground for much," said a Eurotunnel executive, "if you've closed it."
 
THE MARKETS
Stocks Are Up. Period.
The facts: The stock market kept soaring last week -- setting records, topping 4,800 for the first time. The reasons: Oh, please don't ask; no one really has any idea why the market does what it does.

HEADLINE: Why Rates Look Good At the Local Credit Union

BYLINE: By ROBERT BRYCE 

 BODY:
WHEN Carolyn Rickard received a check for several thousand dollars from her mother's estate last month, she decided to shop around for a certificate of deposit. She received quotes from two banks and a savings and loan. Then she went to a credit union.
"The credit union's interest rates were higher," says Ms. Rickard, 50, who works for the Texas State Teachers Association Member Benefit Corporation in Austin. So she ended up with three C.D.'s, with varying dates of maturity, at the Austin Area Teachers Federal Credit Union. 
 Ms. Rickard is one of many happy customers of credit unions. Various factors often enable the unions to offer better rates than banks or savings and loans: the unions are exempt from Federal income tax, their workers are often volunteers and their office space may be subsidized by their sponsoring business or association. In Ms. Rickard's case, her union's 12-month C.D. has an annual effective yield of 5.59 percent -- more than half a percentage point higher than the yield offered by the banks she called. "That's darn good," she says.
National averages tell the same story. On Sept. 13, one-year C.D.'s carried an average yield of 4.92 percent at banks, 5.39 percent at savings and loans and 5.69 percent at credit unions, according to the Bank Rate Monitor, a trade publication. And for money market accounts, credit unions averaged 3.75 percent -- 0.92 of a point more than banks and 0.85 more than savings and loans.
Such differences are not new. But, in part, they are propelling impressive growth in credit unions. From 1980 to June 1995, their holdings of household savings more than quadrupled, from $61.5 billion, to $312.6 billion. More significantly, those gains mean that the credit unions' share of the overall market for household savings has grown from 4.4 percent in 1980 to 8.3 percent.
As those percentages suggest, however, credit unions remain a corner grocery in an industry of financial supermarkets.
When Chase Manhattan and Chemical Banking complete their recently announced merger plan, for instance, the new entity will have $297 billion in assets -- not much less than the combined assets of the country's 12,368 credit unions, as of last June.
But bankers are concerned nonetheless. "Because they have a tax subsidy, that means that all banks, savings and loans and other competing financial institutions will lose funds to credit unions," said James Chessen, chief economist of the American Bankers Association. In both Congress and the courts, in fact, bankers are aggressively trying to limit the unions' expansion.
Gail Liberman, editor of the Bank Rate Monitor, confirmed the bankers' fears. "Credit unions are displacing thrifts," she says. "They are just one more thorn in the side of banks, which are competing with brokerage firms, finance companies and mortgage brokers for dwindling assets."
In the loan business, credit unions also have a leg up on the competition. As of Sept. 13, the average new-car loan at a credit union cost a borrower 8.29 percent in yearly interest, while the average bank charged 9.62 percent and the average savings and loan charged 9.48 percent, according to the Bank Rate Monitor. Interest charges on credit cards showed an even larger disparity: the credit unions' average was 13.13 percent a year, compared with more than 18 percent for banks and savings and loans.
As in the case of savings rates, these differences have helped credit unions garner a larger share of certain loan markets. Their share of the auto-loan market, for instance, rose from 16.6 percent in 1990 to 23.2 percent in June, while the banks' share dropped from 44.1 percent, to 43.6 percent.
Rooted in medieval guilds, credit unions are nonprofit cooperatives that were first formed in the United States in 1909. They offer many of the services banks provide and, like banks, they are federally insured.
Despite their more attractive rates on loans and savings, however, credit unions have several disadvantages. For some loans, like mortgages, they charge higher rates than banks and savings and loans. The unions' relatively small size -- the average credit union has $25 million in assets compared with $402 million for the average bank -- means that they have far fewer branches, too. For the same reason, they often do not offer a full panoply of services, whether home equity loans, credit cards or automated teller machines.
The biggest drawback to credit unions, however, may be the membership requirement. To join a credit union, a person must be affiliated with a religious group, union, business or association which sponsors it, or must be related to a credit-union member. Still, about half of all Americans are eligible to join a credit union, and nearly 70 million Americans do. For eligibility information, call the Credit Union National Association at (800) 358-5710. A recorded message will give you the number of the credit-union league in your state.
Nevertheless, the membership factor means that savers cannot scout around among credit unions for the best C.D. deal or other good rates. While they can comparison-shop from bank to bank, they often have only one credit union, if that.
That does not bother Ms. Rickard. She likes the nonprofit nature of credit unions, and she enjoys the convenience of having her C.D.'s in the same place as other accounts. And she appreciates the relatively high rates her credit union offers.
So when her sister, who also inherited some money and also belongs to the Austin teachers credit union, wondered what to do, Ms. Rickard had a quick answer: "I told her to open an account at the credit union."

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Beyond the Waterfront, and Into the Water

BYLINE: By TOM SAWYER 

 BODY:
MIKE DAVIS knows exactly why he likes rowing.
"The thing is," says Mr. Davis, a 53-year-old archeologist, "you're in a completely different element. You are far from all the hard edges. Out there you're dealing with wind and current and an occasional thunderstorm. Out there you're in nature's realm, and you don't quibble with the rules. You don't get a lawyer to get you out of it." 
 Debates over how to, or whether, to revitalize the city's waterfront have been going on for years; meanwhile, quietly, Mr. Davis and a handful of other New Yorkers are way past the waterfront, heading right into the Hudson, Harlem and East Rivers by canoe, kayak and rowboat. Mr. Davis has spent years in the East, and two years ago helped found a nonprofit boating group, Floating the Apple, which builds long wooden rowboats from a former bank lobby in the McGraw Hill building on West 42d Street. "One of the great pleasures of being in Istanbul is rowing on the Bosporus, between Asia and Europe," he said. "Istanbul was built to be seen from the river. Here nothing was built to be seen from the river, except perhaps lower Manhattan."
Activity on the water is on the rise nationally, boat makers say. Canoes, kayaks and rowboats are built around the country by companies like Perception Inc., based in Easley, S.C. With 600 dealers nationwide, it reports a 20 percent growth for each of the last three years. "That's hearty growth," said Dana Jones, the company's marketing coordinator.
New York City got into the act in 1993, when the Department of Parks and Recreation established launch sites and began issuing permits for canoes and kayaks. A total of 34 permits were issued for this year's season, May 29 to Nov. 26, up from 24 last year. The city's intent is to make sure people using small boats know how to pursue their sport safely. "Barges can't stop, and big ships can't stop," Mr. Davis points out. "So you stay out of the way, the same way you stay out of the way of trucks on the street. They're unforgiving."
To row, Mr. Davis and a crew roll their 300-pound boats on a hand-pulled cart three long blocks from the McGraw Hill building to the river, and load them onto a homemade derrick on Pier 84 to swing them onto the water. "I've gone into my I.R.A.'s," Mr. Davis said. "I've got three credit cards that are a disaster area, but this has been worth doing."
In lower Manhattan, another group, the Downtown Boathouse, has a small cinder-block building on the apron of Pier 26, which juts into the Hudson just north of North Moore Street. Inside are the sleek hulls of 35 light-weight rowing or paddling craft in what amounts to a people-size version of the Kerbs Model Boathouse in Central Park. The 50 or so club members, whose fees are $250 a year, carry their boats to the edge of the pier and, depending on the tide, hand them down the three- to nine-foot drop to the water and board from a floating dock.
"We're still in the beginning stages," says Jim Wetteroff, a heating contractor who is club president. "We are in business and we do have a dock and we are getting people into the water."
Other rowers can be found at the 79th Street Boat Basin, where there are weekend launchings from a floating dock; people come carrying little boats from the stony bowels of their Upper West Side apartment buildings. The attraction of the rivers, however few feel it, is clearly there.
"It's our largest open space," Mr. Davis says succinctly. "It's a shame not to use it better."

LENGTH: 1149 words

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Jaguar XJS Convertible and Honda del Sol;
Rich Tan, Poor Tan

BYLINE: By JAMES G. COBB 

 BODY:
TAKE it from Charles Foster Kane: the simplest toys are the ones worth remembering, whether a Rosebud sled or an old MG roadster.
Consider two adult toys at opposite ends of the price spectrum. Starting at $15,310, the Honda del Sol is America's cheapest open-air car (as opposed to a dwarf sport utility like the Geo Tracker). What does the youthful del Sol have in common, if anything, with an aging, bank-breaking tanning device like the Jaguar XJS 6.0 Liter? What wins out, youth or experience? 
 The Jaguar's design dates to 1975 and its V12 engine was introduced in 1971. Built with relatively few concessions to the complexities of modern car making, it is a rather impractical toy for a Citizen Kane with a generous allowance -- a $90,000 (including various taxes) investment in image. No longer required is a stiff-upper-lip tolerance for the glitches that used to be standard Jaguar equipment -- problems that have largely abated since Ford acquired the British company in 1989.
Demand for the XJS, whose longevity is exceeded only by the Porsche 911, is still strong. Sales of the less expensive six-cylinder convertible, the most popular model, were up 34 percent through August. Even in its ninth life, this cat has legs.
If only the V12 will do, act promptly. The '96 XJS will come only with the six, for $62,150 plus luxury tax. The slower-selling coupe is being canceled. Then, for '97, the XJS is to be replaced with an all-new car intended to evoke the sleek E-types of 1961-74.
Like the monarchy -- heck, like Stonehenge -- the Jag is timeless. But this is no precocious retro design, it's the real, old thing. Inside, peering down the long, deeply sculptured hood, it's akin to being at the wheel of a 60's muscle car. The windshield starts just behind the dash, like a product of the 30's, and the glass seems almost vertical. And look at the two oversized, elegant chrome ash receptacles occupying prime space on the console.
The cabin is like a London gentlemen's club, without the knee room or the sherry decanters. The walnut trim is perfect and the tan leather is so buttery you fear for your cholesterol level.
Gliding through Manhattan on a Friday night, top down and cool jazz on the stereo, the "flamenco red mica" test car made waves. At a stoplight in Greenwich Village, a pedestrian exclaimed to friends, "Look at that -- isn't it a beautiful car?" In Chelsea, a sidewalk diner dropped his salad fork to walk over and peer into the parked Jag, ignoring the Rolls-Royce Corniche nearby.
The Jag does show its age in uncomfortable ways. The wide, old-style console forces your legs into a numbness-inducing tunnel, and the controls are ergonomically incorrect in the 1970's tradition. Put up the top, and a 6-footer must recline the seat to make room for the head. The power windows work the old-fashioned way, without an express-down control, and the console switches fool you every time: push them back, which seems like up, to lower a window.
Though the rear side windows, which have no separate controls, are supposed to move with the top, they get out of sync now and then. Needless to say, patricians do not impress the hoi polloi by repeatedly raising and lowering the top to close the windows.
But why close the top? You'd be a fool to pilot the XJS into bad weather, and its pleasant manner unravels with the roof closed. The cabin goes from cozy to claustrophobic; wind hisses at the windows. The "back seat," barely tolerable for a child with the top down, becomes an unusable shelf.
Despite its bulk, the long, narrow Jag sails comfortably around town. But it excels on winding country lanes, cornering with aplomb on wide 16-inch wheels. The long wheelbase and rear-drive configuration are forgiving if you push it too fast into a turn.
The V12 -- so quiet, so smooth -- propels the 4,306-pound beast to 60 m.p.h. in 7.2 seconds, and it mates seamlessly with the four-speed automatic (from General Motors, no less) for the fast-slow tango of back roads.
Though pleasing in its element, the quirky XJS can be irritating in daily driving. The beautiful interior is not particularly comfortable. The wedged-in engine runs hot, and you feel it. The spoiler not only detracts from the clean lines, it nicks the antenna if you open the trunk with the stereo on. The emergency brake lever retracts while engaged, fooling the driver into taking off with the brakes on.
If the XJS is a time capsule, the Honda del Sol is as up to date as a CD-ROM. As short and stubby as the Jag is lithe, this tiny car has excellent seats and legroom for giants. But the crowning glory is a light, lift-off top. A breeze to handle, it fits neatly into a rack in the trunk, where it serves as a second lid, taking only 2.2 cubic feet of space and lifting for access to cargo stored below. There are no rattles, no squeaks and, with the tight-fitting top in place, no more wind noise than you'd expect of a coupe.
Under the hood, Honda offers three four-cylinder engines for '95. The basic S model has a 1.5-liter, 102-horsepower power plant previously used on the basic Civic, and the Si, a step up, has a 1.6-liter version with 125 horsepower. At the top of the line, the VTEC squeezes an amazing 160 horsepower out of 1.6 liters, thanks to variable valve timing. A high-revving sweetheart -- the red line is 8,100 r.p.m. -- the VTEC pulls the 2,522-pound del Sol from zero to 60 in 7.7 seconds. It feels faster.
The test car -- a well-equipped VTEC with a $20,608 sticker -- never showed a hint of instability, staying glued to the road on every curve. Throw it into a corner and it pulls you through, with scarcely a hint of its origin as a Civic economy car. Relive your youth; the del Sol safely accommodates boneheaded maneuvers that would have put your teen-age jalopy into intensive care.
The typically well-designed Honda interior includes excellent climate controls, a radio hidden behind a sliding door and two lockable bins behind the seats. Storage is otherwise limited to a small glove box and a shallow console tray (which doubles as an uninspired cup holder), but that may be for the best. The owner's manual says the car's maximum load, including occupants and luggage, is just 400 pounds. Two 200-pounders should leave their toothbrushes at home.
Given the del Sol's versatility, why does Honda sell only 1,000 a month? Some 62 percent go to women; the car may be too cute for macho-conscious young men. From behind, the targa roof recalls the Porsche 914, but at some angles the squat design invites comparisons with the A.M.C. Pacer.
But that won't bother you from the driver's seat. And in contrast to the XJS -- which is loveliest on the outside looking in -- in the del Sol that's the best place to be.
INSIDE TRACK: The big-budget XJS proves that time can stand still, but the penny-pinching del Sol rolls back your clock.

HEADLINE: U.S. Consumers Gain From Mexico Trade Pact

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Bob Herbert's "Nafta's Bubble Bursts" (column, Sept. 11) plunges into the pitfall of one-sided storytelling in which he calls politicians (like Bill Clinton) and companies (like Mattel) to task.
It is true that on the one hand, job loss in the United States is a critical issue. Certainly we would not want to hear the horrible "sucking sound" that protectionist rhetoric like Ross Perot's predicted. 
 On that, Mr. Herbert is right to raise concern, though it truly is too early to judge: it is not clear how many of the layoffs related to the North American Free Trade Agreement that he mentions would have been lost to Mexico with or without the trade agreement.
On the other hand, the concerns of United States consumers are often left out. If companies like Mattel choose to manufacture products in Mexico and sell them in the United States, that means United States consumers can purchase the same quality products at a lower price.
This, in econospeak, is called a gain in efficiency, and it raises the standard of living for those United States consumers. It is harder to measure this kind of gain, and the benefits do not have the same kind of resounding ring to them as the (surely inflated) figure Mr. Herbert mentions of one million lost jobs.
But the impact of lower prices on a wide range of products will benefit nearly all 250 million United States consumers. Aren't we better off for being able to choose to buy Japanese or Mexican-made cars? This is not a statement on the relative value of cars or other products manufactured here, or in Mexico or Japan.
It simply means that consumers should be given the opportunity to buy the highest quality products at the lowest possible price, and that the trade agreement should increase their range of choices.
I am neither vehemently anti-Nafta nor pro-Nafta, but I do think the broad interests of United States consumers as a whole deserve at least as much attention as the unfortunate (but fewer) individuals whose employers decide they can manufacture products more efficiently in Mexico.
 
ALEC IAN GERSHBERG
Assistant Professor, Urban Policy
New School for Social Reaserach
New York, Sept. 11, 1995

HEADLINE: Chinese Didn't Derail Women's Meeting

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re your Sept. 13 editorial on the forum of nongovernmental organizations in Huairou, China: 
 We were thrilled by the diversity of faces, colors, clothing, languages, crafts and music of 25,000 activist women from every continent. We were intellectually stimulated by the analyses in workshops and plenary sessions of everything from the global economy to local survival strategies.
We were inspired by stories of struggles that ordinary women are waging to secure their survival, dignity and rights.
We watched group after group demonstrate against abuses suffered by women somewhere -- images that will remind us to carry this spirit of democracy wherever we go.
Nothing the Chinese Government did overshadowed any of this. Thousands of Chinese university and high school volunteers were stationed everywhere to help us find our way.
Young and impressionable, they could not help being affected by the democratic look and feel of the forum; several told me this was the case. They are China's next generation of leaders.
Had the forum been as repressed as you made it out to be, your newspaper and others would have been swamped with protests. Our presence indicates we were never "silenced."
 
GLORIA RUDOLF
Brattleboro, Vt., Sept. 14, 1995
