HEADLINE: For Next Generation, New Kunstlers

BYLINE: By JAN HOFFMAN 

 BODY:
Like many of his classmates, Randolph Scott-McLaughlin (Harvard Law School '78) headed straight to New York after graduation. But instead of following his friends down the centuries-old crimson brick road to Wall Street, he took a detour at Union Square to confront one of the founding lawyers of an unusual law center.
"I went right up to him and said, 'Bill, you're the best trial lawyer in the country, and you owe me the obligation to teach me what you know,' " Mr. Scott-McLaughlin announced to William M. Kunstler. Never one to overlook an accolade, Mr. Kunstler laughed and took him under his wing. 
 And for the next nine years, Mr. Scott-McLaughlin, as a fledgling lawyer for the Center for Constitutional Rights, went on a wild legal ride. He helped Mr. Kunstler win the acquittal of two American Indian Movement supporters who faced the death penalty in a Nebraska murder trial. They represented a former Black Panther charged with murdering a police officer. They sued Bernhard H. Goetz on behalf of one of the men he shot in the subway.
Mr. Kunstler, who died on Labor Day at 76, was the country's best-known and most reviled radical lawyer, but he neither worked in a vacuum nor left one behind. No individual practitioner is expected to play the idiosyncratic, oversized role he inhabited for 35 years. But scores of lawyers have been doing similar, less visible work all along. Scores more are standing in the wings. For both directly and indirectly, Mr. Kunstler inspired generations to take up public interest work and to defend clients whom most other lawyers would shun.
And so it came to pass that Mr. Kunstler begat Ronald L. Kuby, 39, his foremost disciple for the last 13 years, to whom he taught his skills as a trial lawyer and master media manipulator.
And through his association with the Center for Constitutional Rights, which presses Federal and international human rights lawsuits, Mr. Kunstler also begat successors like Mr. Scott-McLaughlin, 42, who became a civil rights law professor at Pace University. There, Mr. Scott-McLaughlin in turn begat the Social Justice Center, where his students, the so-called Randy's Raiders, work on cases involving racial violence and voting rights discrimination.
And so the next generation is being groomed to make headlines in the 21st century. One former Randy's Raider, for example, specializes in pursuing police brutality lawsuits in Federal court. And a former intern of Mr. Kunstler so fervently believes, as he did, in fighting racism through criminal defense work that she has already helped represent rapists and batterers.
But though Mr. Kunstler's offspring and near relatives in the law are numerous, their survival is far more difficult than his.
True, civil rights litigators can more readily make their cases on a vast foundation of law that has evolved in areas like criminal defense, housing, immigration, welfare and sex discrimination, where virtually none existed in the 1950's and 60's, when Mr. Kunstler was beginning to make his way.
But times are economically grim for young lawyers. Burdened with $100,000 law school debts, they cannot afford to set up their own shops, as in Mr. Kunstler's mold. And there are almost no jobs at institutions like Legal Aid and Legal Services, which are trembling on the brink of extinction.
And for lawyers of a liberal to radical left persuasion, the political climate is overcast by hostility from both Congress and the electorate. In the combative days of Mr. Kunstler's forays into the Deep South and at the Chicago Seven trial, he, at least, was borne aloft by thousands of students and civil rights supporters -- scarcely the faintest echo of whom can be heard by lawyers in the 90's.
But a relative handful of lawyers serving poor communities and unpopular clients soldier on. "And they're even more energized now: they think the work is really on their shoulders because there's no more Bill," said Haywood Burns, a professor at the City University of New York Law School, which was established 13 years ago to train lawyers for public interest work.
In contrast to the private lawyers who will pick up one or two "good deed" cases along the way, there are dozens of lawyers in the New York region alone -- many associated with special-interest law centers -- whose practice regularly consists of standing up for despised criminal defendants or pressing civil rights cases. In criminal defense, the more frequently mentioned names include Leonard Weinglass, Lynne Stewart, Michael Warren, Ramsey Clark, Mr. Kuby, and now Kevin Doyle, the new chief of New York's Capital Defender Office, which coordinates the representation of death penalty defendants.
Among the prominent civil rights litigators are Steven Banks, Juan Figueroa, Ellen Yaroshevsky, Michael Ratner, Janet Benshoof, Margaret Fung, Beatrice Dohrn and Mr. Scott-McLaughlin.
Then there is James Michael Lenahan. Who? A White Plains practitioner and one-time Randy's Raider, class of '92, Mr. Lenahan has already addressed Mr. Scott-McLaughlin's students about how it is possible to set up your own law office, work 18 hours a day, make no money and catch catnaps with a smile on your face, knowing you have caught the Government in another compromising position. "I know I'm going to Heaven, but if I have to put a dime in the gate, I'm in trouble," Mr. Lenahan said.
The civil rights cases Mr. Lenahan pursues in state and Federal court have made him an outcast, if not an outright pariah, in his own family. Generations of his relatives have been police officers, and Mr. Lenahan was expected to become a prosecutor. Instead, Mr. Lenahan became a general practitioner who specializes in pressing police brutality lawsuits. He came to law school after a 12-year career as a captain in the Army, where he specialized in integrated weapons systems.
Although he still holds some conservative views, Mr. Lenahan, 40, considers his work with Mr. Scott-McLaughlin to have been an eye-opener. "I ran into a number of police officers who downright lied and it made me furious, because as a commissioned officer, I had sworn the same oath they did to uphold the Constitution. But I meant it then, and I do now."
Ablaze with his not-so-youthful idealism, Mr. Lenahan says he feels that he is uniquely qualified to fight injustice: "I'd been a part of the establishment for so long I know how it works."
The financial barricades to maintaining such an ideal-focused practice are almost insurmountable, particularly as the lawyer develops family responsibilities. Mr. Lenahan says that although he grosses $100,000, his overhead -- secretary, paralegal, partner, rent, library -- annually leaves him with a net of $10,000.
Mr. Kuby, who is continuing the now one-man firm of Kunstler & Kuby, said bluntly: "In this climate, you can't do good and do well at the same time."
David Tykulsker, a highly regarded labor lawyer in Newark, says he tries to support himself by seeking a mixture of cases, including workers' compensation claims and union work. With that foundation, he pursues class action suits on labor and environmental issues without pay, hoping that a favorable decision years down the road will yield him a fee.
To survive, many lawyers may have to let economics drive their political sensibilities, Mr. Tykulsker said. "If you look through civil rights reports, you'll see a preponderance of age discrimination cases," he said. "Does this mean age discrimination is a more serious problem than sex or race discrimination? Of course not. But older managers, who are usually white and male, can afford lawyers."
Nonetheless, in recent years, New York University and Rutgers, among other schools, have established programs in public interest law. Even New York City's corporate launching center has had a change of heart. "Columbia Law School used to be the Darth Vader of law schools," said Franklin Siegel, a civil liberties litigator. "But now it's become so much more humanitarian." All Columbia law students must perform 40 hours of community service legal work.
Still, law students worry about finances. Daniella Korotzer, 27, who expects to be sworn in as a member of the New York bar today, half expects the creditors to start breaking her legs any minute: $2,000 student loan bills are arriving monthly, and she has taken a job paying $31,000 a year with Stephen A. Somerstein, a criminal defense lawyer in the Kunstler mode.
But the way Ms. Korotzer sees things, she was born to this work: the first time she went to jail was as a fetus, when her pregnant mother was arrested during a demonstration against the Vietnam War. She majored in women's studies while working her way through the State University at Albany, where she threw herself into a bevy of issues and, yes, got herself arrested.
Although she can rattle off a list of political causes dear to her heart, she prefers criminal defense work to civil litigation, because of its comparatively faster pace. That decision has already led to some dark nights of the soul, for she, a feminist, has helped defend men accused of rape and domestic violence.
During her last year at Northeastern University School of Law, she was an intern with Kunstler & Kuby. Mr. Kunstler was one of the bravest men she had ever met, she said: "I've seen him go to court, knowing he was facing a contempt citation, with a toothbrush stuck in his suit pocket -- for all the world to see, of course."
He ignited a powerful flame. During her job interview with him, she recalled: "Bill assumed that your legal skills were up to par and he had no interest in looking at my writing sample. He simply asked if I had the heart and courage to take the types of cases he takes. I said yes. And that's all he needed to know."
She paused and started laughing. "And then he yelled out to Ron, 'Do you think she's of high enough moral character to work in this office?' "

HEADLINE: Pataki Traveling to Europe, With 2 Trade Groups Paying

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Sept. 17

 BODY:
On his first trip overseas as the Governor of New York, George E. Pataki will travel to Hungary and Italy in search of business and family ties.
Mr. Pataki plans to tour the Hungarian village of Debrecen, which his paternal grandparents left to come to America. And Mr. Pataki's mother, making her first trip overseas, will accompany him to the Italian town of Reggio Calabria, where her father was born. 
 The Governor will meet with corporate and political leaders and is taking along his economic development director, Charles Gargano, to promote business ties. The trip, which begins on Friday, is being paid for by Hungarian and Italian chambers of commerce.
"It's going to be just a very moving personal experience," Mr. Pataki said, noting that he has never visited either the Hungarian town of his paternal grandparents or the Italian town of his maternal grandfather.
In laying the groundwork for the trip, Mr. Pataki has sought to contact relatives in and around his grandfather's ancestral home in Debrecen.
Mr. Pataki's family, which settled in Peekskill, north of New York City, kept in close contact with Hungarian relatives until the 1956 uprising that was quashed by Soviet tanks, he said.
Mr. Pataki visited Hungary in the early 1970's and said he does not remember the trip fondly.
"It was before the collapse of the Iron Curtain," he recalled. "I loved it on the one hand, but hated it on the other because of the horrible system and the Russian soldiers everywhere. I just wanted to leave as soon as I could."
Hungarian officials hope the trip will promote tourism and business investment, particularly in the telecommunications and energy industries in the poor northeastern section of the country where Mr. Pataki's roots are, Peter Gomori, director of the Hungarian Tourist Board, said.
The Pataki administration asked the Hungarian-American Chamber of Commerce of New York and New Jersey to help set up the trip, and it was happy to oblige, Monika Elling, the chamber's president, said. The chamber's 150 members, businesses in both Hungary and the United States, stand to benefit from a strengthening of economic ties, she said.
Neither she nor Mr. Pataki had an estimate of the trip's cost. Ms. Elling said the chamber's contacts with travel agents will make the trip much cheaper than it would have been if organized by people who dealt with Hungary infrequently.
But the head of New York State Common Cause said the arrangement raised ethical questions.
"A chamber of commerce doesn't spend thousands of dollars for no reason," said Andrew Greenblatt, the group's executive director. "I don't know what that reason is, but I don't want any special interest to have that kind of influence over our Governor."
Mr. Greenblatt said the state should pay if Mr. Pataki can justify the trip as in the state's interests. The Governor should pay for portions that concern family business, he said.
Zenia Mucha, Mr. Pataki's communications director, said that while the trip will benefit the state, the administration did not want taxpayers to foot the bill.
Mr. Pataki's tentative schedule calls for him to be in Hungary until Sept. 27, when he is to leave for Rome. He plans to spend a day in Rome and then travel to Reggio Calabria, in southern Italy.
In addition to his mother, Mr. Pataki will travel with his wife, Libby; Teddy, one of the couple's four children; Mr. Gargano; Tim Carey, a Pataki aide; Ms. Mucha; another press aide, and two security guards.

HEADLINE: Senator D'Amato's Chance

 BODY:
The House leadership proposes to cut the earned-income tax credit -- a Federal rebate to low-paid workers -- by about $20 billion, or 15 percent, over seven years. The cuts would undermine the worthy policy of the Clinton Administration to "make work pay" by using tax policy to assure that minimum-wage workers earn enough to lift their families out of poverty.
The House plan is misguided, but Senate Republicans are considering something far worse. William Roth Jr., the new chairman of the Finance Committee, proposes whacking over $60 billion out of the tax credit. That would devastate the smartest anti-poverty weapon Congress has ever devised. 
 The credit will add up to $3,560 next year to the take-home pay of low-wage workers. The credit will be phased out for families earning more than $11,620. The House G.O.P. proposes to include, for the first time, Social Security income as part of a family's earnings. On its own that may appear to be a reasonable provision. But it really puts the Republicans in the callous position of advocating lower taxes on Social Security income for non-poor elderly and higher taxes for the working poor. The House proposal would end the credit for four million childless workers and phase out the credit faster as a worker's income rises, thereby discouraging workers from going after higher-paying jobs.
What Mr. Roth has in mind is even worse than the House proposal. Under current law, the income threshold at which the credit begins to phase out is adjusted for inflation. Under Mr. Roth's proposal, inflation protection would be stripped away, reducing millions of additional working Americans to poverty-level incomes. He would also reduce the size of the credit. The Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal advocacy group, calculates that a family with two children earning $15,000 would, under the Roth plan, pay about $1,750 more in taxes by the year 2002.
If that same family lives in New York State, however, its predicament would be far worse. Taxes would rise by more than $2,000 in 2002. Here is a chance for Alfonse D'Amato, New York's Republican Senator on the Finance Committee, to defend the state's economic interests by protecting the tax credit from the deep cuts favored by Senator Roth.
Almost one million New York families depend on the credit to stay out of poverty. Every one of these families includes someone who works. The Republicans are supposed to be the party that encourages work. But they have come up with a plan to tax away the incentive to chose employment over welfare.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
THE POWER OF THE MAYORALTY
For months now, Mayor Giuliani has complained that he has no control over New York City's Board of Education -- and the purse strings for a quarter of the city's budget. But in the tumult of events over the last week, he has showed just how much power the mayoralty has. Even as the Mayor has wielded more influence than the law gives him, he has made it equally clear that, for him, that power is not enough. Using his bully pulpit with the usual vigor and his ties to the teachers union with increasing transparency, the Mayor forced the board to back off its threat, which loomed all summer, to lay off teachers to meet the Mayor's budget goals. News analysis. [B3.]
 
SUSPECT IN BROOKLYN RAPES IS ARRESTED
A man who the police believe is responsible for sexually assaulting or attacking several women in brownstone Brooklyn neighborhoods was arrested early Saturday morning as he was about to attack another woman, the police said. The man, Tony Harrison, 26, of 418 St. John's Place, was under surveillance by the police and, they said, was seen following a woman into an apartment building on Union Street in Park Slope shortly before he was arrested. [B3.]
 
HOW NONEDUCATOR COULD BE CHANCELLOR
The State Education Commissioner said that he was open to having a qualified noneducator become schools chancellor in New York City, but he declined to say whether Richard Ravitch, the top contender, fit that bill. The Commissioner, Richard P. Mills, has final say on whether someone without an educational background can become the top administrator of a public school system. [B3.]
 
BLOCK PARTY ENDS IN SPRAY OF BULLETS
The block party in Bushwick, Brooklyn, on Saturday was one last end-of-summer bash for the children of Halsey Street. And then, as the party was winding down about 10:10 P.M., there was the flash of guns, a spray of bullets, blood and panic. When the pandemonium subsided, two men, including a bystander, had been killed and four other people, including an off-duty transit police officer, had been wounded. [B5.]
 
OFFICER SUSPENDED AFTER WOMAN DIES
A city police officer was suspended after an early morning fight at a Washington Heights bar left a woman dead, struck with a bullet from the officer's gun. The authorities have not determined whether the off-duty officer fired the gun or whether it accidentally discharged during the dispute. The woman was a bystander, the police said. [B5.]
 
ARMED ROBBERY AT MIDTOWN RESTAURANT
The crocodiles and skeletons were fake, but at least one gun was real at the Jekyll and Hyde Club in mid-Manhattan when three robbers tied up two employees and dashed away with $25,000 to $30,000 in cash, the police said. No one was hurt in the robbery at the restaurant and bar. [B2.]
 
REGION
 
RISING COST OF PUBLIC SCHOOLS
After state budget battles led the State University of New York to increase tuition for the third time in five years, students who chose public education to save money are finding they have to take out loans, or find jobs, anyway. As the school year began this month, the long lines snaking outside financial aid offices on SUNY campuses like Stony Brook included many students from families that never believed they would need help. [B6.]
 
PATAKI TO SEEK BUSINESS TIES ABROAD
On his first trip overseas as the Governor of New York, George E. Pataki will travel to Hungary and Italy in search of business and family ties. Mr. Pataki plans to tour the Hungarian village of Debrecen, which his paternal grandparents left to come to America. And Mr. Pataki's mother, making her first trip overseas, will accompany him to the Italian town of Reggio Calabria, where her father was born. The Governor will meet with corporate and political leaders and is taking his economic development director to promote business ties. [B6.]
 
RAIN FINALLY FALLS ON A THIRSTY REGION
It slanted down from the lowering sky like showers of silver javelins. It lashed dusty windowpanes, beat tattoos on parched leaves and darkened the bone-dry earth. After months of deepening drought in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, a soaking, drenching, cooling rain fell for 12 hours -- 1 to 2 inches in most areas -- bringing nourishment to wilting vegetation, a trickle of hope for sunken reservoirs and welcome relief from a monotonous skein of sunbaked days. [B4.]

HEADLINE: Fierce Storm Leaves St. Thomas Reeling

BYLINE: By MARIA SACCHETTI 

DATELINE: CHARLOTTE AMALIE, V.I., Sept. 18

 BODY:
Edward Agundez and his family fled to the bathroom when the living room windows in their apartment exploded at 11 P.M. on Friday. They spent the next six hours in darkness, with his wife and two sons huddling in the bathtub while he pressed his body against the bathroom door as Hurricane Marilyn raged through St. Thomas.
When the family emerged at 6:30 A.M., they could see into their neighbor's living room through a downed wall. The storm had torn down their ceiling and ripped a hallway closet door from its hinges and tossed it into a room several feet away. 
 "I really thought were were going to die," Mr. Agundez, an immigration official who lives in the Watergate apartments outside town, said today. "My younger son was crying. I would just tell him that everything was O.K. I was so scared, but telling them would just make matters worse."
The Agundezes' shock and disbelief as they tried to salvage what little they could from their waterfront apartment was repeated hundreds of times on this Caribbean island, where people lack electricity, running water and telephones.
The indiscriminate storm, which many residents initially underestimated, cut a swath of surreal destruction across the island, which has 50,000 people and is located about 50 miles east of Puerto Rico. Suffering less damage were the other two islands in the United States Virgin Island territory, St. Croix and St. John, as well as eastern Puerto Rico.
The hurricane was keeping away from land today as it moved through the Atlantic, well to the east of the United States mainland, The Associated Press reported.
Here in Charlotte Amalie, the capital city of the United States Virgin Islands, and nearby, winds were reported to have reached 130 miles per hour in some areas. About 80 percent of the houses were either lost or damaged.
Dozens of boats, many of them 30 to 50 feet long, had been swept from their moorings onto the streets and against buildings. Several cars and trucks had toppled in parking lots, and street lights had been plucked from wires and poles.
At Cyril E. King International Airport, light airplanes and seaplanes lay in heaps of tangled metal beside the runway. The airport remained open for military traffic, for shuttling emergency workers to St. Croix, for receiving emergency provisions and for a few light planes.
The Virgin Islands Territorial Emergency Management Agency received unconfirmed reports of eight people killed in the storm: three people in St. Thomas and five people in St. John, said the agency's planning director, Roy Ward. More than 185 people were reported injured at St. Thomas Hospital, which remained without water and electricity.
The fifth-floor pediatrics ward was shorn off shortly after nurses evacuated the area around midnight on Friday. Several patients were sleeping on mattresses on hospital floors today.
"The glass was bending in and out, and the ceiling was shaking," said one patient who was evacuated, Vennisha Wilson, 20, of Charlotte Amalie. She was sleeping on a mattress and receiving painkillers while she waited for treatment for a sickle-cell disorder.
"I haven't seen my doctor since the storm," she said.
Other buildings, like the Alex A. Farrelly Federal Building and the Legislature, apparently suffered little damage. But winds smashed the roof and walls of the Nisky Center, which contains stores, and some government offices.
Part of the hillside house of Gov. Roy L. Schneider was destroyed. But in a telephone interview today, the Governor was upbeat.
"I am proud of the U.S. Virgin Islands and its residents," he said. "They are hardy and will work hard together assisting each other."
He said he was grateful for the aid of the Federal Emergency Management Agency. "The President and FEMA's response was immediate," he said. "Before the hurricane hit on Thursday, I had in my hands a promise that the resources of our nation's emergency agency were at our disposal. In fact, teams of FEMA's disatster experts were already on their way."
Like a scythe, the storm turned the lush, green hillsides into brown, leafless slopes. Houses without windows or roofs stared darkly from the hills, surrounded by crumpled aluminum, wooden planks and chunks of concrete.
A sense of helplessness and defeat was expressed by many on the island, which was beginning to bounce back from Hurricane Hugo, which blasted the region on Sept. 17, 1989.
"My businesses are completely gone," said Jose Lavilla, who owns a catering business and has contracts with several hotels. "No tourists are going to come here. I'm homeless and unemployed."
Carole St. George, a dental hygenist, with tears coming quickly to her eyes, said her experience with Hurricane Hugo had led her to fear the recovery to come.
"I promised I wouldn't get upset if I was alive yesterday," she said. "But it's all the months and months without phones and no electricity. You can't take a bath. People stand in line for bags off ice. You see people who have lost everything and then you see people who loot and take advantage."
The police and the National Guard reported "small pockets of youth" looting some areas, local emergency officials said.
The police did little to stop people from calmly picking through the spoils under the crushed red roof of the Grand Union supermarket. People filed gingerly through the debris to take canned goods, pet food or nonprescription medicine. One man left with two cheese graters.
Gary Berne, a developer, returned to his house, high on a hill in Frydenhog, to find his roof smashed and water and dirt in his $600,000 home. But his four dogs were fine, and the portable generator that supplies water and electricity was running.
"Tell my wife I'm fine, I'll get ahold of her and we have no house," he said, his voice catching in his throat. "Tell her Hugo was a joke by comparison."

HEADLINE: CLINTON DEFENDS INCOME TAX CREDIT AGAINST G.O.P. CUT

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: ASHINGTON, Sept. 18

 BODY:
Casting himself as a defender of the working class and the American work ethic, President Clinton today sharply attacked Republican proposals to curb tax breaks for low-income families, warning that he might veto any such plan as "inconsistent with those basic, bedrock values this country should be standing for."
At the same time, Mr. Clinton praised the welfare overhaul efforts of Senate Republicans and said he believed Congress and the Administration would eventually compromise on an overall budget agreement, though probably not before the start of the next fiscal year on Oct. 1. 
 Mr. Clinton's comments, in a brief Oval Office interview with The New York Times suggested by the White House, amounted to the spearhead of an Administration-wide offensive against House and Senate proposals to limit the earned-income tax credit, a Federal rebate intended to help low-income workers keep more of their wages. Mr. Clinton expanded the credit significantly as part of his first budget in 1993.
He made the same point at a $1,000-a-plate fund-raising dinner in Philadelphia tonight. "We believe no one should be taxed into poverty," the President said.
The earned-income tax credit has a far lower political profile than popular behemoths like Medicare, and its fate is almost certain to become entangled in more sweeping budget measures Mr. Clinton already opposes. But Mr. Clinton has long cited the expansion of the credit as a major underappreciated accomplishment of his Administration, and attacking the Republican proposals lets him not only defend the interests of a core Democratic constituency, but also highlight Republican plans to cut taxes for the affluent.
Republicans contend that the tax credit program is subject to significant waste and abuse and that families earning well above the supposed limit -- in 1996, about $28,500 for a family with two or more children -- manage to benefit from the credit, in part because Social Security and pension benefits are not included in the limits. The House measure would count such income, and thus reduce eligibility for the credit.
"It's basically an income redistribution scheme that this Administration has greatly expanded, in my opinion, without really looking at its costs," said Senator Don Nickles, an Oklahoma Republican and co-sponsor of the principal Senate proposal.
The President said he, too, was committed to weeding out abuses, but the White House said the Senate Republican proposal for curtailing the benefit would increase taxes for 18 million taxpayers in 2002, by an average of $655. Mr. Clinton said that ran counter to the Republicans' professed desire to lower taxes.
"If there are problems in the administration of the program, let's fix those," Mr. Clinton said. "But let's don't raise taxes on working people while we're lowering taxes on everybody else in the country. It just does not make sense, and it is inconsistent with rewarding work and responsibility and strengthening families. It's inconsistent with those basic bedrock values this country should be standing for now."
About 45 million people benefit from the program, the Administration estimates, including about 15 million families and about 4.5 million people without children to whom the benefit was extended for the first time under the Clinton plan. The Republicans would eliminate the benefit for individuals and reduce it, to varying degrees, for families. Under current law, the income threshold at which the credit is phased out is adjusted for inflation, and the Senate proposal would also eliminate that provision, which the Administration contends would punish millions of workers.
In all, about 35 percent of American families benefit from the credit, and last year, 24,000 families with incomes above $50,000 a year got some benefit. That figure is expected to rise to 36,000 by next year, according to Congressional estimates. Before the 1993 expansion, the program was expected to cost about $20 billion next year; without changes, it is now expected to cost about $25 billion in 1996.
The program began in 1975 under the Ford Administration and was expanded by both George Bush and Ronald Reagan, a bipartisan legacy that Mr. Clinton took pains to point out today.
"You know, President Reagan said it was the best anti-poverty program ever devised," Mr. Clinton said.
Mr. Clinton spoke out today because the proposed changes in the tax credit are part of a much larger tax bill that the House Ways and Means Committee began considering tonight. The measure includes dozens of changes in the taxation of businesses, but it would not appreciably change the taxes owed by most individuals. The vote on the changes in the tax credit will probably be on Tuesday or Wednesday.
Mr. Clinton said cutting the tax credit was particularly inconsistent with bipartisan efforts to encourage work and reduce the welfare rolls.
"I think it will substantially undermine our ability to move people from welfare to work," Mr. Clinton said. "And more importantly, it will make a statement that we're backing off of this value that we want people to succeed as workers and as parents. And if -- that if they're willing to work, no matter how meager their incomes, we want to lift them above poverty, if they work full time."
The White House contends that counting Social Security benefits as part of the income limits could have harsh effects on older poor people, who often care for grandchildren born to single mothers.
Representative E. Clay Shaw Jr., Republican of Florida, a sponsor of the House measure to reduce the credit, said he had no quarrel with making it available to those with incomes below about $11,600 a year. But he said he wanted to reverse the growth that Mr. Clinton undertook and to count Social Security and interest income toward the eligibility limits.
"We're trying to take what basically was originally a Republican program and smooth it out a little bit and just bring it down a little bit," he said. "I think this should include all your resources. If you have $2,000 a year from a C.D. account, that should certainly be included."

He met with a senior adviser, George Stephanopoulos, background, and others in the Oval Office. (David Scull/The New York Times)

 HISTORY -- Enacted in 1975 to give adults with children incentives to work instead of relying on welfare. For those who qualify, it provides a tax credit of 7 to 40 cents on each dollar earned. The criteria for who qualifies were expanded in 1986, 1990 and again in 1993.
 WHO IS ELIGIBLE -- On average, 35 percent of all families with children take advantage of the credit in any given year. Here are the broad criteria for receiving the credit.

HEADLINE: An Island Paradise Lost As Storm Leaves Ruins

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: ST. THOMAS, V.I., Sept. 18

 BODY:
Bjorn Anderson, a hotel tennis director, spent today maneuvering his mini-van through roads partly blocked by fallen utility poles and tilted 40-foot yachts to take groups of tourists to the airport and away from the ruins Hurricane Marilyn left on St. Thomas.
On a hillside once covered with thick foliage, he found new ocean views between bare trees. He pointed out mounds of debris where $300,000 homes used to be. 
 "Oh, this is just sick," said Mr. Anderson, who works at the Grand Palazzo Hotel, as disabled power cables hit his windshield. "Nothing, nothing left."
At least eight people died in the storm and several hundred were injured. There are no official damage estimates yet, but it is obvious to Federal officials that among the three United States Virgin Islands, St. Thomas fared the worst. St. Thomas is smaller than St. Croix but is the territory's tourism and shopping center and its capital. The economic impact is expected to be huge on this American territory that depends on tourism, a $1-billion-a-year industry, for two-thirds of its economy. Many hotels have been severely damaged and cruise ships, which deliver 1.2 million tourists a year, have suspended operations.
Recently, tourism ads for the mainland pointedly noted how Hurricane Luis left the United States Virgin Islands, which also include St. John, unscathed a few weeks ago, but seriously damaged St. Maartin and other islands.
"We were looking forward to a great season because of the misfortune of the other islands," said Mac Groetzinger, owner of Mackenzies Harborview in Red Hook, on the eastern side of St. Thomas.
In a telephone conversation via satellite today, the Federal Emergency Management Agency director, James Lee Witt, told President Clinton, "Sir, we have a mess down here."
More than half the structures here, mostly built of wood, concrete and corrugated steel, were destroyed and 30 percent were seriously damaged. There is no power or telephone and no one is guessing how soon either will be restored.
Penny Feuerzeig, executive editor of the Virgin Islands Daily News, said the storm would be "devastating to tourism and in terms of insurance rates. After Hugo it was either unavailable or unaffordable."
The editor, whose paper did not publish on Saturday, the day after the hurricane hit, was comparing this storm with Hurricane Hugo, which devasted St. Croix six years ago, leaving 22,500 homeless and damaging 90 percent of buildings. Then, the island's winter tourist season was lost, electrical and telephone service were not fully restored until the following year and full recovery was years away. A quarter of the residents left, many of them because they did not want their children to miss out on school.
David Edgell, Commissioner of Travel and Tourism, called the damage from Hurricane Marilyn a temporary setback and said he expected the airport to be functioning normally within six weeks and hotels to be back in business by the start of the winter tourist season in December.
But today, the last of about 2,000 tourists were being evacuated from hotels and it is anybody's guess when any will be back.
Sue and Pete Menghini, tourists from Phoenix, said they arrived on Thursday, after Hurricane Luis scared them away from St. John, their original destination. This afternoon they hitched a ride to the airport to wait for any plane to take them, saying that both tempers and food were short at their hotel. They never got to see St. Thomas, or celebrate their 25th anniversary.
"Pete said, 'What are we going to do for our 50th,' " Mrs. Menghini said. "I said, 'Stay home.' "
While tourists fled, the residents were left to deal with its surrealistic aftermath. Hundreds of people stood in queue after queue for ice, canned goods and basic necessities. Very few businesses were open and schools were closed. A curfew from 6 P.M. to 6 A.M. has been imposed.
Mildred Stridiron, in a car crowded with three daughters and three granddaughters, was among those beginning to worry about money. She was down to her last $50 and had no clue when banks would open.
Lines of up to 80 cars formed near gas stations while convoys of relief workers poured in from the airport. Gov. Roy L. Schneider, whose own two-story home lost its roof and most of its walls, said 26 Federal agencies have responded. National Guard troops directed traffic.
The airport is still closed to commercial carriers but was busier than normal with military and charter flight deliveries of water, construction materials, medical supplies and communication gear. These planes were carrying the tourists out. Shelters were open but most people chose to stay with luckier relatives and friends, or to tough it out in damaged quarters. Items almost as vital as food and water were the plastic sheets and wood strips to build makeshift roofs and walls.
"That's what everybody wants," said Kirk Grybowski, director of the Virgin Islands Emergency Management Agency, who himself was having problems finding a building that still had a roof to store the roofing material.
Looting continued to be reported by business owners but did not appear to be widespread. Governor Schneider said 150 Federal marshals and National Guard troops from Puerto Rico were on their way.
Virgin Islands officials said that despite the enormous emergency need, they and their Federal helpers had learned the lessons taught by Hurricane Hugo. Roads were passable and St. Thomas Hospital reopened today. Officials planned to start taking applications for housing grants and loans by early next week.
Mr. Grybowski said as bad as it looked, in two days St. Thomas had achieved what it took St. Croix a week and a half.
But many angrily said they had trusted weather forecasts that had warned them of a weak hurricane only to be pounded by one twice as powerful. Some did not bother to even tape their windows.
Stephen Knapik, 48, who said he lost two friends when they were swept from their houseboats, said, "If they had known it was a direct hit they wouldn't have been on their boats."
The lack of communication only increased the sense of isolation. There were rumors of another hurricane forming and heading their way.
But during the day, radio stations played, "Don't Worry, Be Happy." and "Here Comes the Sun" in between public service announcement and hurricane talk.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Fall on Data Of Inventory

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of long-term Treasury securities fell yesterday after new inventory data suggested the economy had not slowed as much as expected, dimming the market's hopes for another cut in interest rates.
A recent increase of new corporate debt issuance and a rise in commodity prices also hurt prices, analysts said. The price of the 30-year bond fell 24/32 , to 10416/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 6.53 percent, from 6.48 percent on Friday. 
 The Commerce Department reported yesterday that July business inventories rose three-tenths of 1 percent, slightly less than the increase of a half-percent that economists had expected. Retail inventories fell seven-tenths of 1 percent, indicating that retailers were having success clearing store shelves and suggesting that the economic growth was continuing to be resilient.
But Marilyn Schaja, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities, said the "weaker-than-anticipated increase in inventories, however, is masking somewhat the buildup in inventories that is taking place."
Trading is expected to be subdued until Friday, when Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, presents his semiannual assessment of the economy before the Senate Banking Committee. Mr. Greenspan's testimony comes five days before the Fed's policy-making committee meets.
"When Mr. Greenspan talks before the Senate Banking Committee, all ears are going to be cocked, trying to pick up a clue on Fed sentiment ahead of the meeting next week," said Thomas F. Carpenter, chief economist and manging director ASB Capital Management, a Washington firm that manages more than $6 billion in bonds. He said that much of the trading and positioning of portfolios this week would be done with a view on whether the Fed would take any action on short-term interest rates.
The market view on whether the Fed will cut rates is split, he said, noting that when the case is not clear, the Fed usually takes no action. In July, he said, "everyone knew the Fed would lower rates; at the August meeting everyone knew nothing was going to happen."
Mr. Carpenter does not believe the Fed will ease, citing in part the Fed's recent role in strengthening the dollar and signs of economic growth.
"We have every reason to believe that the third quarter will grow from 2.5 percent to 3 percent, which shows a meaningful acceleration of the 1.1 percent growth of the second quarter," he said.
And Mr. Carpenter noted that the drop in interest rates this year had fueled rallies on the stock and bond markets, "which of themselves provide current and future growth stumulus."
"So in that sense there is no need to lower short rates," he added.
With investors uncertain about the direction of rates, the shorter maturities have become attractive. At yesterday's regular weekly Treasury bill auction, the average discount rates fell to their lowest levels in about a year.
The rate for a three-month bill was 5.25 percent, down 9 basis points from the previous auction and the lowest since Oct. 31, 1994, when it was 5.07 percent. For the six-month maturity, the rate was 5.22 percent, down 11 basis points from last week and the lowest since 5.05 percent on Sept. 19, 1994. A basis point is one- hundredth of a percentage point.

HEADLINE: U.S. Agency Warns About Japan Banks

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18

 BODY:
In the first warning by a Government agency on the dangers posed by the troubles of Japan's financial institutions, Federal regulators today instructed certain federally backed banks to limit their loans to them.
The warning to the nation's 12 Federal Home Loan Banks, which have combined assets roughly equal to those of Citicorp, represents the first move by American financial regulators to insulate the United States from the potential effects of a further meltdown of the Japanese financial system. 
 But the move by the Federal Housing Finance Board, an independent agency, was taken with little consultation with other agencies and did not represent a broad recommendation by the Federal Government for American banks to avoid transactions with Japanese financial institutions.
Treasury officials declined to comment today. Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said in July that more needed to be done to strengthen the Japanese financial system, but he has avoided any suggestion that American banks do anything in response.
Japanese banks are struggling with bad debts several times the size of those that sank much of the American savings and loan industry in the late 1980's. Two Japanese credit unions and a regional Japanese bank have collapsed in the last seven weeks. Depositors raced to pull their money out of the failing institutions in Japan before their collapse, with long lines forming outside branches.
Japanese regulators have said that they do not expect other institutions to fail. But the troubles in Japan have prompted a series of urgent reviews by the Treasury Department and several Federal regulatory agencies.
The practical effect of today's directive will be limited -- primarily leading the 12 home loan banks to lend less spare cash to Japanese institutions in overnight transactions. The home loan banks lend money at low rates to savings institutions and some banks for use in home loans.
Today's warning may prompt more banks to pay closer attention to their loans to Japan, but it appears unlikely to lead to broader repercussions for Japanese banks because the Federal Housing Finance Board is little known and has limited influence. A senior official there today said that the board had not analyzed Japanese balance sheets before issuing today's official advisory to home loan banks.
While American regulators have said little publicly, they have been torn between conflicting pressures. They want to make sure that American financial institutions do not suffer large losses if Japanese banks fail. But they also do not want to risk starting a panic by sounding too urgent a warning on Japanese banks.
While regulators ponder the problem, big commercial banks around the world have been quietly reducing their loans to Japanese banks and making sure that they are not overly exposed to the collapse of any one institution. That has reduced the risk that a Japanese financial crisis could spread around the world -- but may also have worsened the problem within Japan, as banks there begin to find it harder to borrow money to cover brief imbalances between their payments and receipts.
Until recently, some Federal Home Loan Banks were increasing their loans to Japanese institutions, though others had been reducing them, according to the Federal Housing Finance Board, which regulates the banks.
Set up by Congress in the Depression, each of the nation's 12 Federal Home Loan Banks is owned by savings institutions and banks in its region. The home loan banks sell notes and bonds at interest rates barely above those on Treasuries because of their Federal backing. The home loan banks then relend the money at low rates to their owners, which use the funds for housing loans.
As of Friday, the 12 home loan banks had combined short-term loans of $2.9 billion to Japanese financial institutions, said James D. Roy, the president of the Federal Home Loan Bank of Pittsburgh. That was down sharply from $5.6 billion on July 31 as many loans matured and were not renewed. The home loan banks together had $246.7 billion in assets this summer and $13.8 billion in capital, their cushion against losses.
Japanese institutions have seemed like attractive borrowers in the past, but, Mr. Roy said, "this exposure is being worked down across the board."
Bruce A. Morrison, the chairman of the Federal Housing Finance Board, said that he was less interested in the reasons for the lending than in forcing home loan banks to reassess their positions now. "It was a matter sufficient for me to be concerned" and order the agency a few weeks ago to begin reviewing the issue, he said.
Some evidence suggests that the exposure of American banks in general to losses in Japan may be limited. A Federal Reserve survey last March of 138 large American commercial banks found that they had lent a total of $9 billion to Japanese banks, a small fraction of their $238 billion in international loans over all.
When the home loan banks raise money from bond issues, they invest it until they need to relend the money to member institutions. They also invest money deposited with them by local savings institutions and banks.
Much of these investments consist of overnight loans to other banks and purchases of short-term notes issued by other banks. Citing last week's move by a bank-rating agency to issue a lower credit rating to two Japanese banks, the Federal Housing Finance Board strongly warned the Federal Home Loan Banks today to limit these loans and note purchases with respect to all Japanese financial institutions.
Specifically, the board's office of examination and regulatory oversight told the banks to lend less to their Japanese counterparts than the board's standard regulations on creditworthiness would permit. The memorandum, which carries nearly the force of regulation and is the first advisory memorandum issued by the board this year, does not say how much the lending should be reduced but does say that the 12 banks should "manage their unsecured credit exposures more rigorously than required" by the board's financial management rules.
A senior board official said this evening that a home loan bank adhering to the memorandum might limit its lending to a Japanese financial institution to a level consistent with a credit rating for the Japanese institution one notch lower than its current rating.

HEADLINE: Lester Lum Colbert, 90, Chief At Chrysler During the 1950's

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Lester Lum Colbert, a retired president and chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, died Friday at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 90.
Mr. Colbert, whose nickname was Tex, succeeded K. T. Keller as president of Chrysler in 1950. He later added the title of chairman of the auto maker. He resigned as head of the parent company in 1961, after which he was chairman of a subsidiary, the Chrysler Corporation of Canada Ltd., until 1965, when he retired. 
 As a fledgling lawyer in the New York firm of Larkin, Rathbone & Perry, Mr. Colbert impressed a client, Walter P. Chrysler, who was the head of the automobile company. Mr. Chrysler sent Mr. Colbert to Detroit in 1933, where he joined Mr. Keller's executive staff and worked on labor issues for 10 years, including negotiations with Walter Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers union.
Early in World War II, Mr. Keller asked Mr. Colbert to attend night classes and study manufacturing fundamentals, including machine operations and reading blueprints. In 1943, Mr. Colbert was appointed general manager of Chrysler's big Dodge division factory in Chicago, which was making engines for B-29 bombers. After the war, he was promoted to head of the Dodge division.
Mr. Colbert, who had been commended by General H. H. Arnold for his wartime production achievements, headed Chrysler in prosperous times in the first postwar years. When he resigned in 1961, the company had encountered difficulties that included losses during a recession, strikes at suppliers, stockholder lawsuits and abrupt changes in senior management. He was succeeded by Lynn A. Townsend.
Dissident stockholders accused a number of Chrysler executives of profiting improperly from holdings in companies that made automobile parts for Chrysler. William C. Newberg, who was a partner in a supplier company, was forced out as president of Chrysler and required to pay $455,000 to the company. Mr. Newberg later filed a $5 million lawsuit against Mr. Colbert, the company and other Chrysler officers, contending that he had been unfairly removed. The company paid Mr. Newberg $85,000 in a settlement in 1970.
Mr. Colbert confirmed in 1961 that his wife at the time, Daisy Gorman Colbert, had formerly owned several hundred shares in a Chrysler supplier, but he noted that he had been cleared of improper behavior by a New York law firm that investigated the shareholders' complaints.
Born in Oakwood, Tex., a small farming town, in 1905, Mr. Colbert helped his father buy and sell cotton, starting as a teen-ager. He attended the University of Texas and Harvard Law School, from which he received a J.D. degree in 1929.
After his wife died in 1970, he moved to Naples and invested in oil and gas ventures, his son Nicholas said. He was an ardent fund-raiser for the University of Texas for 30 years, including a term as head of the school's development board.
In addition to his son Nicholas, of Houston, his survivors include his wife, Robert Ellen Hoke Colbert of Naples, whom he married in 1972; another son, Lester L. Colbert Jr. of New York, and a daughter, Sarah Colbert Noble of Battle Creek, Mich.

HEADLINE: Oil and Gas Finds by Texaco Give It Hope in Gulf of Mexico

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
In a sign that the Gulf of Mexico continues to hold promise, Texaco Inc. announced yesterday that it had found oil and natural gas in three wildcat wells it drilled off Louisiana, in areas that most major oil companies had considered played out.
While Texaco has yet to decide whether to bring the wells into production and while it remained unclear how big the finds could be, they could help Texaco catch up with rivals such as Shell and Amoco. Those companies have taken the lead in finding oil and gas in very deep water and below salt layers in the seabed. 
 Some analysts were encouraged by Texaco's announcement, because the company had been falling behind in adding to its reserves. They cautioned, however, that it was still unclear whether the wells could be brought into production economically.
"It's nice that they have had successful discoveries," said Holly Gustafson, an oil analyst with Natwest Securities. "There are still many unknowns on these wells."
The shares of Texaco, which is based in White Plains, fell 62.5 cents yesterday, to $66.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.
The Gulf of Mexico has become an important proving ground for the use of computers to read huge amounts of data to help pinpoint where to drill and to demonstrate that oil from very deep waters can be produced economically.
There is a growing conviction that the gulf may contain reserves greater than those of Prudhoe Bay in Alaska, the last giant field discovered in the United States, with reserves totaling 12 billion barrels.
Texaco has tested only one of the new discoveries, in an area 130 miles southeast of New Orleans in 1,754 feet of water. Its partner in the project is Marathon Oil, a subsidiary of the USX Corporation.
Clarence P. Cazalot, the president of Texaco's domestic exploration arm, said yesterday that another well would be drilled in October to determine the size of the reservoir and that commercial production could start in about three years. He added that because the success rate for wildcat wells was about one in five, Texaco's three-for-three record in the gulf this year was encouraging.
Mr. Cazalot said Texaco had accelerated its exploration program in the gulf in a drive to add about 80,000 barrels of production a day over the next five years to its daily domestic output of 665,000 barrels.
Texaco said that it had also drilled a successful exploratory well in deep water about 150 miles southwest of New Orleans. That well, which was drilled with the Shell Offshore unit of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, has been temporarily plugged.
The third well is a subsalt project under 3,393 feet of water 90 miles southeast of New Orleans. The project, in which the Chevron Corporation is a partner, has caused interest in the industry because there could be huge deposits below the salt layers under developed fields. It would be relatively inexpensive to produce oil and gas in such areas, because many platforms and pipelines are already in place.

HEADLINE: Trying to Avoid Being Caught In the Middle;
Mutual Funds Seek Mergers To Grow And Capitalize On 401(k) Retirement Plans

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
The Contractors Supply Company of Kansas City, Mo., knows about building for the long term. It sells everything from hammers to backhoes in Kansas, Missouri and Arkansas.
But until recently, Contractors Supply lacked a basic building block in the retirement plan it offered its 160 employees: bond mutual funds. With Twentieth Century Investors handling their 401(k) and profit-sharing plans, employees had few investment choices beyond the high-growth stock funds for which that fund company is best known. Last month they got that choice, though, a few months after Twentieth Century took over the Benham Group of mutual funds, a bond specialist. 
 Twentieth Century is not alone in its push to expand. Mutual fund companies that have grown steadily by carving out their own niches are now, increasingly, turning to mergers and acquisitions for growth, particularly to capitalize on the rise of 401(k) programs.
"A 401(k) program is often an investor's first brush with mutual funds," said W. Gordon Snyder, executive vice president of Twentieth Century. By offering a full array of funds in a retirement program, he said, a fund company stands a better chance of being selected for an individual's other investments.
In addition, customers are demanding a higher level of service from fund companies, like instant access to account balances and phone transfers between funds. By broadening its array of offerings, a fund company can lower expenses by spreading the cost.
And as investors continue to pour money into funds at a record pace, the gap is growing between full-service behemoths, like the FMR Corporation's Fidelity Investments and the Vanguard Group, and small, niche providers. Fund companies, increasingly aware that the broad middle of that range might be the worst place to be, are being forced to decide whether to be huge or tiny.
But those fund companies choosing to grow by acquisitions or mergers are encountering a paradox. Fidelity and Vanguard did not grow by buying rival funds; their businesses are home-grown. And some fund families, like the Crabbe Huson Group of Portland, Ore., have started down the road to merger only to find that the frustrations of trying to become part of a large, ponderous brokerage firm outweighed the advantages of having a bigger sales force.
Still, at least a dozen mutual fund companies, with more than $250 billion in assets, have changed hands this year. The Oppenheimer Management Corporation, a unit of Massachusetts Mutual Life, increased its portfolio of offerings by 25 percent with the purchase of 12 Quest for Value funds with $1.6 billion in assets from Oppenheimer Capital, an unrelated company; Kemper Financial Service bought Dreman Value Management, which oversees funds with $1.5 billion in assets; New England Investment Companies bought Harris Associates, parent of the $3.2 billion Oakmark mutual funds, and Stein Roe & Farnham bought the American Asset Management Company, a small Cleveland-based fund company.
In addition to fund companies merging with each other, the industry continues to hold attraction for banks and insurance companies, which have been expanding their presence in the fund business in recent years.
The pace shows no signs of abating. "In the long run, I believe the mutual fund industry will be consolidating further," said Stephen B. Timbers, chairman and chief executive of Kemper Financial Services, the mutual fund unit of Kemper Corporation. "The cost of doing business is going up. Companies need to have a broad product line. Distribution is costing more, and a lot of firms are finding they are not of sufficient size to compete."
Size has been a hotly debated topic since May 1994, when Goldman, Sachs & Company issued a report titled "The Changing Economics of the Mutual Fund Industry." One of its conclusions was that "It will be extremely difficult for mutual fund companies to survive" unless they have $10 billion to $20 billion in assets under management. Otherwise, the structural costs of the business will outweigh the fees generated by managing funds.
Not all parties buy this argument -- which, dissidents point out, is being supported by the companies that earn fees on mergers. Geoff Bobroff, a Rhode Island-based consultant, cites numerous forces driving the merger trend: changes in Federal pension laws, the aging of a generation of entrepreneurial fund executives, a change in the industry's cost structure because of the greater popularity of no-load funds, and the increasing cost of hiring good fund managers. "It's not so simple to just say that size is the determining factor," Mr. Bobroff said.
In some instances, mergers have resulted from a fund company's desire to fill a hole in its product line quickly. "Our business mix was too oriented to fixed-income," Mr. Timbers said, so Kemper acquired Dreman, whose funds specialize in stocks that have been beaten down to below-average valuations. "We could have built those funds ourselves," he said, "but it would have taken several years to establish a track record from scratch."
In a way, the shift is similar to what is happening with banks. Technology allows fund companies to provide more service, which leads consumers to ask for even more service. "When a customer calls up, we can now find in five seconds the information it used to take five hours to get," said Jon Fossel, chairman of Oppenheimer Management. "When customers learn you can do that, they call up more often. So our cost of computation per transaction has gone down, but our overall spending has gone up." Spreading those costs over a wider asset base, achieved through acquisitions, eases their impact.
That has been the experience of New England Investment, which operates several mutual fund companies, including Loomis Sayles & Company, New England Funds and Reich & Tang. "There are some economies of scale in the custody and back office activities," said Peter S. Voss, chairman and chief executive. But for his company, the real benefit comes from access to wider distribution -- offering several different families of funds through one sales channel.
As technology improves, fund families become more important than the individual products, says Michael J. Turillo, a partner at KPMG Peat Marwick. As it becomes easier for individuals to move money between funds and to act on different investment strategies, the fund company with the most diversity is most likely to retain customers.
Only recently has competition begun to eat significantly into the industry's high gross margins, which historically have exceeded 50 percent. But the combination of all those factors is likely to cause the consolidation to continue, Mr. Fossel said.
"There are 10 to 12 really big guys, and there is a large handful of boutiques," he said. But with spending growing for new computer systems and hot-shot fund managers, "in the middle, you've got a problem," he said. "The critical mass today is much higher."
Oppenheimer finds itself on the cusp of the big-to-middle group; its $36 billion in assets rank 16th among fund companies. Mr. Fossel aims to expand that to $100 billion by the turn of the century, a feat that will be all but impossible without further big acquisitions.
One area on which he intends to focus: 401(k) business.
Fund companies have been taking a growing share of this expanding business, at the expense of insurance companies, banks and other financial institutions. According to Access Research Inc. of Windsor, Conn., fund companies last year controlled 28 percent of the assets of 401(k) plans, double the level in 1988. Over the same stretch, insurance companies' share fell to 32 percent from 40 percent, and banks' share slipped to 27 percent from 32 percent.
At the same time, companies are offering more investment options to 401(k) participants. A recent survey of 50 large American companies by Watson Wyatt Worldwide, a benefits consulting firm, showed that the number of companies offering 401(k) participants five or more investment options rose to 60 percent this year from 32 percent two years ago.
The fastest-growing part of that business is the market for small-company 401(k) programs, for companies with fewer than 500 employees. While 96 percent of companies with more than 5,000 employees already have 401(k) plans, according to Access Research, only one-third of the companies with fewer than 500 workers now have plans. And only 11 percent of companies with fewer than 50 employees have a 401(k) plan.
"The small-company 401(k) market is untapped and is one of the profitable growth areas," said Mr. Bobroff, the fund consultant. "But you might not make any money on that business for five to seven years."
In addition, said Mr. Timbers of Kemper, which aims for the small end of the market, "To be competitive, you have to have a whole series of portfolios for customers to choose from." But new funds are rarely profitable until they pass at least $60 million in assets. All of which leads companies interested in the that area toward further acquisitions.
Among the bigger fund companies that have attracted attention as a potential takeover target is T. Rowe Price, which manages $44 billion in assets. The company's stock price moved higher this summer on speculation about a possible offer and on enthusiasm for its growing earnings. But T. Rowe Price has said it wants to remain independent.
Not every company that has moved in that direction has enjoyed the trip. In February, the Crabbe Huson Group, an Oregon-based fund family, dropped a planned merger with the Prudential Insurance Company of America.
Cultural differences between the young, upstart Crabbe Huson and the staid Prudential led to the dissolution, said Richard Huson, co-founder of Crabbe Huson. And in the year since the merger talks started, Crabbe Huson's assets more than tripled, to $890 million from $250 million. That growth allowed the company to command better prices for administrative work it farmed out, leaving it in a position to remain independent.
Mr. Huson admits, however, that if the long-running bull market comes to an end, fund companies his size -- now at $1.6 billion -- could face trouble. "If we get into a real bear market, the whole industry will lose assets, and we won't escape that," he said. "So should we go out and try to increase our mass, or is there a market for smallish mutual fund groups that develop a good product? I think there is, but in this industry, a niche might mean billions and billions of dollars."

HEADLINE: Serial Killer Is Sentenced In 2 Deaths

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: RIVERHEAD, L.I., Sept. 18

 BODY:
Joel Rifkin, the confessed serial killer who is already serving at least 27 years in prison, drew 50 additional years to life today for strangling two women and burying them in makeshift graves in a wooded area of Southampton.
Mr. Rifkin, 35, is an unemployed landscaper from East Meadow, L.I., who has told authorities he killed at least 17 women. Last month, he pleaded guilty to the two Suffolk murder charges after unexpectedly abandoning an insanity defense. 
 He showed no emotion today, but accused Judge John J. Jones Jr. of Suffolk County Court of cruel treatment for refusing to delay the proceeding to give him more time to recover from an operation to remove a cyst from his back.
Mr. Rifkin's sentences will run consecutively, meaning he will serve a minimum of 77 years in prison. But the total could go much higher, because he still faces murder charges in other counties, including the Bronx and Queens.
Last year, a Nassau County jury rejected Mr. Rifkin's insanity defense and found him guilty of murdering Tiffany Bresciani, 19, whose body the police discovered in Mr. Rifkin's pickup truck on June 28, 1993. The discovery, made after Mr. Rifkin was stopped for a traffic violation, led to his detailed confession to a string of murders involving prostitutes he said he picked up in lower Manhattan.
The victims Mr. Rifkin buried in Suffolk were Leah Evens, 28, of Brooklyn and Lauren Marquez, 28, of Sunnyside, Queens. Their bodies were found within five miles of the courthouse here.
Michael Ahearn, the assistant Suffolk County district attorney who prosecuted the two Suffolk cases, described Mr. Rifkin today as a remorseless egotist for whom capital punishment would be appropriate. "He views himself as a victim," Mr. Ahearn said. "He cannot feel sorrow."
In a barely audible voice, Sue Evens, the mother of Leah Evens, told Judge Jones, "It is important that this man never be able to harm anyone again."
Mr. Rifkin's lawyer, Kathleen K. Trum, said after the sentencing that rulings by Judge Jones, including one that blocked expert testimony based on hypnosis of Mr. Rifkin, thwarted the planned insanity defense. She said that Mr. Rifkin would appeal.
"I don't understand why so many hurdles have been placed in front of what we are trying to do here," said Ms. Trum, the latest in a series of lawyers representing Mr. Rifkin. "You're going to have more of these people if society doesn't come to grips to learn their psyches. You can't just lock them up and throw away the key."
Ms. Trum said she would try to revive the insanity defense in Queens County, where Mr. Rifkin is charged with the murder of Iris Sanchez, 25, of Manhattan, whose body was found near Kennedy International Airport. A hearing is scheduled for Wednesday.
Before the sentencing, Mr. Rifkin protested Judge Jones's refusal to postpone the hearing.
"My being here today with an open three-and-a-half-inch surgical incision is a flagrant violation of the court's oaths and responsibilities," Mr. Rifkin said.
He argued that there was "no reason in law or logic" why the sentencing could not be postponed.
Mr. Ahearn said the statement typified Mr. Rifkin's obsession with himself. "There is a lack of saying he is sorry or has any remorse," he said outside the courtroom. "Everything is always in terms of himself. He never takes any responsibility for what he has done."
But Ms. Trum said that Mr. Rifkin was filled with remorse.
"Joel's emotion at this point is, 'What is wrong with me?' " she said. "To say that he doesn't show remorse is an insult. Do you think this is the way he wanted his life to go?"

LENGTH: 372 words

HEADLINE: Evaluating American Universities

 BODY:
America's research universities are the envy of the world. Still, they will need to thrive -- and continue to improve -- if the country is to keep its scientific and technological edge. An evaluation of American doctoral programs suggests that the country is making progress but still has work to do.
The study, "Research-Doctorate Programs in the United States," was carried out by the National Research Council, an independent organization chartered by Congress. The researchers rated 274 universities based on the quality of their Ph.D. programs in 36 departments, from art history to economics to genetics. Each department was rated on quality of the faculty and teaching effectiveness. 
 The report brought joy or anguish to many campuses depending on how they placed on "Top 10" lists that appeared in many newspapers. But to focus on rankings is to miss the broader point. In many cases, the difference between the first-ranked and 20th-ranked schools was relatively slight. In biochemistry and molecular biology, the first-ranked school, the University of California at San Francisco, received a faculty rating of 4.84. The University of Texas-Southwestern Medical Center placed 20th with a rating of 4.00. The gist of the report is that America has fine research institutions in virtually every region, though strengths clearly vary by school.
Those who worry about American competitiveness in science and engineering will find grounds for cautious optimism. Since the last ranking in 1982, the growth in the number of science and engineering graduate students has been slow but steady. The students are also more diverse, with a significant increase in women and modest increase in underrepresented minorities.
Data from elsewhere show that much of the net growth is due to an increase in foreign students on temporary visas. Those students made up a fifth of science and engineering graduate students in 1982. In 1992 they made up nearly a third. Most of them will leave here when they graduate, benefiting the economies of their home countries rather than the United States. The country needs to look harder at whether it is producing the right number of home-grown Ph.D.'s in the appropriate specialties.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
A New Field of Dreams or Just a Dream?

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
While George Steinbrenner generates competition between New York City and the state of New Jersey for the honor of building the Yankees a new home, two less-endowed baseball teams face critical stadium developments this week and a third may learn if it's staying put or moving after 109 years.
Voters will go to the polls in Seattle today to decide if they want to approve funding for a $241 million stadium to replace the Kingdome. The prevailing view in the city is if the stadium bid fails, the Mariners will be sold and moved. 
 The Wisconsin State Assembly had been scheduled to vote yesterday on financing for a $250 million stadium for the Milwaukee Brewers, but the bill's supporters don't have the votes and have postponed action until Friday so they can rework the financing plan.
"My committee needs to get work done Monday night," Representative David Prosser Jr., the assembly speaker, said in a weekend interview, alluding to the possible impact of the Seattle vote on the Milwaukee project.
In Pittsburgh, meanwhile, a new stadium could play a pivotal role in the future of the Pirates there, but of more immediate concern is the prospect of the purchase of the team by Kevin McClatchy of Sacramento, Calif., a member of the family that owns the McClatchy newspaper chain.
The Pirates' ownership, which has sought a buyer for more than a year, has given McClatchy, the latest potential buyer, until Friday to come up with a legitimate offer. No other potential buyers who would agree to keep the team in Pittsburgh are in sight.
Besides a buyer, the future of the Pirates in Pittsburgh, like the other teams, is tied to a new stadium. At a time when all franchises are seeking to build attendance and increase revenues, attractive, fan-friendly stadiums such as Camden Yards in Baltimore and Jacobs Field in Cleveland have become the objects of great desire.
Boston, Detroit, Cincinnati, San Francisco and Philadelphia are among the other cities whose teams have talked about new homes, some seeking modern facilities, others baseball-only stadiums.
Furthermore, the Mets have proposed a stadium to replace Shea Stadium, and the Yankees could wind up in a new playground on either side of the Hudson River after their Yankee Stadium lease expires in 2002.
William Collins 3d, a Washington media executive, who unsuccessfully bid for an expansion franchise for northern Virginia, is ready to pounce on any team that may become available. If he were successful in plucking one of the financially troubled franchises, he would move the team to Washington and have it play in Robert F. Kennedy Stadium pending the construction of a new stadium in the rapidly growing area of northern Virginia.
Baseball officials and club owners have been reluctant to allow teams to move; three years ago they blocked the sale of the San Francisco Giants to a Florida group that was prepared to transfer the team to St. Petersburg. But in the face of growing instability in some areas, they would feel compelled to permit certain teams to move.
The Brewers, interestingly, are one of those teams. Their fate holds great interest because their principal owner is Bud Selig, the acting commissioner.
At a recent hearing on the stadium funding bill in Waukesha, Wis., Selig's statement that the team could go elsewhere provoked angry shouts of "go" from spectators. Waukesha and Milwaukee counties are the ones where a one-tenth of a percent increase in the sales tax would generate funds for the proposed new stadium. But resistance from those counties has forced a change in strategy.
"Right now I do not have 50 votes, no way," said Prosser, the co-chairman of the legislative committee that has spearheaded the drive to build a stadium. "We're in the process of reworking Gov. Thompson's bill trying to get to a consensus bill that can pass the assembly."
John Merkt, an aide to the speaker, said yesterday the new financing bill was expected to add two or three counties to the sales-tax plan. He said the Assembly planned to vote Friday so that the State Senate can vote next week. The Brewers' lease at Milwaukee County Stadium expires Oct. 1, he said.
"There is no question that the team cannot survive in Milwaukee without new revenue sources and probably without a new stadium," Prosser said.
According to a legislative audit released last week, the Brewers have lost a net aggregate of $38.9 million the last six years. "Without an increase in revenue, it is highly unlikely that the club will be financially viable in the future," state financial officials stated in a letter accompanying the audit.
As their part of the constructions costs, the Brewers would contribute $90 million, but $50 million of that total would come as a loan from the Wisconsin Housing and Economic Development Authority.
"If there were a serious shortfall of projected revenues," the audit states, "it is possible that the club would have difficulty meeting its obligation to repay the loan."
In King County, Washington, voters are being asked to approve a one-tenth of one percent sales and use tax for up to 20 years. The referendum has not been given much of a chance to pass, and if recent attendance has offered an indication, it won't pass.
The Mariners are in the race for both the American League West championship and the league's wild-card spot in the playoffs, but last week they had four consecutive crowds of less than 19,000.
If the new stadium is defeated and the Mariners' owners sell the team, it's not likely that a local buyer would step forward.
None has emerged in Pittsburgh, where the Pirates face a potential $20 million in losses this year. McClatchy is the latest in a line of potential buyers to try to put together a successful bid.
