HEADLINE: An American In Moscow

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 15

 BODY:
Growing up on Long Island, the grandson of Russian immigrants, Boris Jordan was fascinated by his family's native land and dreamed of returning to it, perhaps as an American diplomat. He never imagined becoming one of Russia's most powerful financiers and one of the most influential players in its economic transformation.
Sent to Moscow three and a half years ago by the CS First Boston Corporation, Mr. Jordan and a small group of colleagues built the securities firm into the dominant investment bank in Russia and played a big role in the development of the country's financial markets. 
 But five months ago, after making its Moscow office one of First Boston's most profitable operations in 1994, he walked out, taking with him the co-head of the office, Stephen Jennings, and a half-dozen other traders and investment bankers.
And now, at the age of 29, Mr. Jordan is using his influence, contacts and fluent Russian in an attempt to build a full-service Russian investment bank of his own, putting his reputation on the line and shaking up the fast-evolving securities business here in the process.
His new venture, Renaissance Capital, will be wholly focused on the former Soviet Union and, Mr. Jordan hopes, will become as powerful a presence in the rapidly growing markets here as, say, Goldman, Sachs is in the United States.
His plan says a lot about Mr. Jordan, who is seen by rivals as cocky, aggressive, self-promoting and genuinely passionate about the opportunities presented by Russia's combination of natural wealth and underdeveloped industry. Nobody seems to hold his age against him, perhaps because he has been there as long as any Western banker who came here looking for profit in the birth of Russian capitalism.
However audacious, Mr. Jordan's plan also suggests just how rapidly the securities industry, and the entire economy, is evolving in a country where investment bankers were considered capitalist evil incarnate just a few years ago -- and in some quarters still are.
"Russia's going to be one of the top five economies in the world 20 years from now, and it started the process with no financial services base of any kind of sophistication," Mr. Jordan said.
"I wanted to build a pan-Russian investment banking business where everyone in the firm was focused on that business, and at First Boston, Russia was always going to be priority No. 5, 6, 7," he said. "I wanted to assemble a group of people who would live and die by this market."
To cement his commitment to the venture, Mr. Jordan said he might even apply for Russian citizenship.
Working temporarily from makeshift offices in a former disco in a Moscow hotel, Mr. Jordan, who will be the firm's chief executive, has added to his team of First Boston defectors other Western or Western-trained bankers, traders, analysts and back-office personnel.
But believing that he needs a strong Russian partner and a Russian identity, he is expected to announce formally in the next month a deal that gives a substantial minority stake to ICFI, a holding company that controls Uneximbank, one of Russia's strongest commercial banks, as well as a large stable of industrial companies.
Mr. Jordan's new firm will be going head to head with First Boston, which insists it has not been harmed by his defection.
Other American and European investment firms are also stepping up efforts to establish themselves here, including Merrill Lynch, Morgan Grenfell, ING Barings and MC Capital, a new venture set up by Hans-Jorg Rudloff, the former head of CS First Boston. Brunswick, a Swedish-owned, Moscow-based brokerage firm, claims to have the leading market share in equity trading.
In the long run, though, Mr. Jordan's most powerful rivals could well be Russian brokerage firms like Troika Dialog and Grant Financial, which are rapidly expanding their equity research and trading, and Russian commercial banks like Menatep and Imperial Bank, which already dominate trading in government debt and are moving into a wide array of investment banking services.
"What Boris Jordan brings to the party is that he hired a team that from day one knows how an international investment bank works," said a competitor who spoke on condition of anonymity. "But you've got the big global banks trying to muscle in and you've got a lot of progress on the Russian side. He's one professional person in a market that consists of many professionals."
If nothing else, Mr. Jordan's timing seems good. The Russian economy is showing signs of stabilizing. There is a functioning, if still relatively illiquid, equity market. Banks and investment firms have gotten the go-ahead from the Government to start mutual funds in Russia, and in the United States the Securities and Exchange Commission decided this month to accept applications from Russian companies to list American depositary receipts of their shares.
The central bank is opening the government-debt market to foreign investors. Russian companies increasingly need investment-banking advice as they seek to raise capital, as do Western companies and strategic investors looking for deals in what most analysts still consider a grossly undervalued, though still hugely risky, market.
When Mr. Jordan arrived here in March 1992, it was far from clear that Russia was a land of opportunity. After three months, Mr. Jordan -- a graduate of New York University's foreign service school who worked for Kidder, Peabody and GPA Group P.L.C., the Irish aircraft-leasing company, before joining First Boston -- was close to concluding that he had made a mistake.
But he stuck it out. By having First Boston serve as an unpaid adviser to the Russian Government's economic reform team, he gained invaluable knowledge of the privatization program and contacts throughout the Government and industry. When Russia's mass privatization program began two years ago, Mr. Jordan moved aggressively. Working on behalf of clients and for the firm's own account, First Boston eventually acquired 17 million of the 144 million vouchers distributed to Russians for use in bidding for shares in the privatized companies.
With better than 10 percent of the privatization program's buying power in his pocket, Mr. Jordan was able to acquire significant stakes in the most attractive Russian companies, making him a market-moving force here and an essential contact for Western fund managers interested in investing in Russia.
As the main conduit between Western capital and Russian industry, First Boston was winning investment-banking assignments from a long list of domestic companies like Lukoil, the giant oil company, and foreign companies like U S West Inc.
The result was that in 1994, a bad year for most global securities firms, First Boston was highly profitable in Russia. Institutional Investor magazine reported that the firm's earnings in Moscow last year were $66 million and that Mr. Jordan got a bonus of $4 million. Neither First Boston nor Mr. Jordan would discuss the figures.
But even with that level of success, Mr. Jordan felt that going it alone was the only way he could take full advantage of Russia's possibilities.
No matter how well Mr. Jordan and his new team do, there is no doubt that he remains influential in Russia's economic development. In the last several months he and Mr. Jennings played a central role in developing a proposal by which the Russian Government would transfer its remaining shares in the country's biggest companies to banks and other investors in a complicated transaction dubbed "loans for shares."
Mr. Jordan, of course, expects to participate profitably in the transaction, though he insists that it's fair for the Government, too.
As Mr. Jordan puts the final pieces for his new venture into place -- he is still negotiating with several American and European investment funds that will become minority partners -- he is also coming to grips with his decision to go native.
For all the excitement of helping to build an economy from scratch and getting a shot at making a fortune, most Americans and Western Europeans working here -- intimidated by the language, the lingering mistrust of foreigners, the crime, the grinding daily difficulties of traveling or even getting the phones to work -- are reluctant to make any long-term commitments to Russia.
Even Mr. Jordan, with his track record of success and Russian heritage, said he and his wife, Elizabeth, had to think hard before deciding to give 10 years to the new venture and a country where prudence requires personal bodyguards.
"We're more and more comfortable here," Mr. Jordan said. "Predominantly, our friends are Russian. We see our future here. Am I going to give up my U.S. citizenship? No. Am I going to take Russian citizenship? I might."
Last winter the Jordans rented a dacha outside Moscow that had been owned by a Soviet propaganda minister. In the attic, Mr. Jordan found a copy of the 1988 central plan for the economy, which presumed in a single document to detail the workings of industry in a world superpower. Looking at it, he said, left him amazed at how far Russia had come.

HEADLINE: Starts of Housing Up Again; Lower Mortgage Rates Cited

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
Housing starts rose slightly in August for the fifth straight month, the Government said today, as low mortgage rates attracted buyers and continued to nourish the economy.
The housing starts rose six-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department said, bringing the annual rate of new construction to 1.398 million new homes -- the highest this year. 
 "These numbers indicate a continuing recovery in housing and probably in the economy as a whole during the second half," Michael Carliner, an economist with the National Association of Home Builders, said.
The pace of new home building has been rising since April. Starts rose a revised 1.2 percent in June, up from the previously estimated nine-tenths of 1 percent, and 7.1 percent in July, up from 6.7 percent, the department said.
"It shows that housing still remains on a good footing and it will help add to third-quarter G.D.P.," James Blumenthal, an economist at MCM Money Watch, said, referring to gross domestic product, a measure of the value of goods and services produced within a country's borders.
The last time building activity was more brisk was last December, when home building ran at an annual rate of 1.545 million units.
Lower mortgage rates have nourished the housing recovery this year. Rates on popular 30-year fixed-rate loans fell to 7.6 percent last week from above 9 percent in January, according to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
Strength in housing helps the economy by creating jobs and increasing demand for everything from construction materials to home furnishings.
"It's just mirroring interest rates and as long as interest rates can stay at relatively low historical levels, then construction can keep moving up," said David Lereah, an economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association.
He said rates were unlikely to go much lower, and that housing starts could begin to ease from August's pace. Analysts said the August rise in building activity was unlikely to be a strong factor when the Federal Reserve's policy makers meet next Tuesday to weigh another cut in interest rates. Many analysts expect the Fed, which cut short-term rates in July, to hold steady next week.
Mr. Lereah forecast housing starts for the year would be about 1.33 million units, less than last year's 1.46 million starts but strong enough to contribute to the economic expansion in the second half of the year.

HEADLINE: Automation Drives a Surge In Currency Trade Volume

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Not only does money make the world go round, it is moving faster, major central banks reported yesterday. The banks reported that currency trading had risen sharply in the last three years, as high-speed electronic trading made more transactions possible.
In the last three years, a period of turmoil in the global currency market, daily turnover is estimated to have grown to the point that it now exceeds $1 trillion, or the value of the gross domestic product of Britain. Three years ago, daily turnover was an estimated $880 billion. 
 The dollar plummeted for most of 1994 and 1995 but recovered recently, while in 1992 and 1993 European currencies were roiled by crises in the exchange-rate mechanism designed to combine Europe's currencies into one.
In April 1995, according to a survey by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York that was released yesterday, daily turnover in the United States foreign-exchange market was $244 billion, up 46 percent from $167 billion in April 1992. The United States market has almost doubled since 1989 and has risen more than tenfold since 1980.
The New York Fed said high-speed automated trading in the United States had grown from almost nothing in 1992 to 13 percent of market volume. Although no precise data exist, electronic trading in overseas markets has probably grown at parallel rates.
Because of the speed and complexity of foreign exchange, an exact figure for global transactions may never be determined. One problem is the double counting of transactions. A sale of a German mark, for example, will be reported twice, once by the seller and once by the buyer.
The problem is magnified in international transactions. While it would be difficult, for example, to identify every American buying an American brand of soup here, it would be even harder to track the transactions if Germans, Belgians and Japanese bought the American product in their countries.
"It becomes still more difficult when an American buys the soup in London, or a German buys the soup in Zurich or Tokyo," said Dino Kos, vice president for foreign exchange at the New York Fed, which conducted the survey of 130 foreign-exchange firms and 17 currency brokers in the United States.
While the mark and the Japanese yen are used in an increasing number of transactions, the report found that the dollar was still used in 86 percent, or $209 billion, of transactions made in the United States. By contrast, the mark was used in 43 percent of transactions in this country and the yen in 23 percent. The sum exceeds 100 percent because foreign-exchange transactions involve at least two currencies.
The New York Fed also surveyed activity in trading of derivatives but will report those figures later this year.
Twenty-five other central banks conduct foreign-exchange surveys every three years in April, following the Fed's lead. The Bank of International Settlements in Switzerland, the central bank of the central banks, combined the data into an overall report.
London, the largest foreign-exchange market, reported the biggest gain in daily volume, 60 percent, to $464 billion, over the last three years. In Germany, the Bundesbank reported a surge of about 40 percent, to between $80 billion and $85 billion. In Tokyo, the Bank of Japan reported a 34 percent increase, to $161.4 billion.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Foreign Exchange Trading" tracks average daily volume of currency trading in United States markets in April of 1977, 1980, 1983, 1986, 1989, 1992, and 1995. (Source: Federal Reserve)

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Moves to Ease Pension-Plan Rule

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
House Republicans moved today to let companies take an estimated total of $40 billion out of pension plans to use for other purposes, an idea that Republican tax writers said would generate $10.5 billion in tax revenue, but that Democrats warned could lead to corporate raids on workers' pensions.
The proposal would do away with penalties Congress imposed in 1990 on what it called excess pension withdrawals that had been used to help finance a wave of takeovers and leveraged buyouts. Under current law, companies can withdraw excess money from pension plans without penalty only if it is used to pay for health benefits for retirees. 
 The provision is part of a pending tax bill that is expected to be approved by the House Ways and Means Committee this week.
Democrats on the tax-writing committee denounced the measure, saying it would undermine an important source of workers' savings. They argued that the proposal would leave pension plans vulnerable to collapse in an economic downturn, potentially requiring a huge taxpayer bailout.
"As soon as these pension funds go belly up and we've started another S.& L.-type crisis around here," warned Representative Sam Gibbons of Florida, the senior Democrat on the panel, "I'm going to arise, wherever I am, dead or alive, and say, 'I told you so.' "
Republicans, who easily defeated Democratic efforts to delete the provision, said they were simply following the outlines of a proposal made earlier by President Clinton. They contended that the measure would free capital for investment while maintaining an adequate cushion to insure that companies could meet their pension obligations.
The debate over the proposal highlighted the intensely partisan atmosphere on Capitol Hill.
Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, expressed bewilderment at the Democratic attacks, saying the Democrats were wrong in contending that the proposal would reduce savings and leave workers vulnerable to losing their pensions.
"There is not one of us that wants to jeopardize the viability of pension funds," Mr. Archer said at a brief news conference. "This will allow companies with excess money in their pension plans to put that money to use, to create new jobs, opening up opportunities to expand the economy."
The Republican proposal would require corporations to leave at least 25 percent more than needed to meet their pension plans' current liabilities. And, instead of reducing savings, Mr. Archer said, relaxing the rules on withdrawals might encourage companies to make bigger pension contributions, because they would know the money would be available for other purposes if it turned out to be more than was needed.
In response, Leslie Samuels, the Assistant Treasury Secretary for tax policy, offered one word: "Ridiculous."
Mr. Samuels acknowledged that the Administration had set a similar threshold of 125 percent of current liability when it supported an extension of the 1990 law last year. But he emphasized that was solely for the benefit of plan participants and was not comparable to Mr. Archer's proposals, which set no limits on how companies could use funds they withdrew.
Mr. Archer's plan is favored by many large companies with well-financed pension plans, said Fred Rumack, director of tax and legal services for Buck Consultants, a benefits advisory company.
More than 60 companies have used a total of $2.1 billion in pension funds to pay for retiree health benefits. The biggest users have been the AT&T Corporation, at $585 million; E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, at $290 million; the Nynex Corporation, at $170 million, and the Ford Motor Company, at $150 million, Labor Department records show.
On Monday night, the committee received charts from the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, a Government agency that protects pensions against default, showing that a pension plan that met the standard of 125 percent of current liability today could face a significant shortfall if the stock market fell 10 percent or interest rates declined by 2 percentage points.

HEADLINE: California Groups Sue Merrill Lynch

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: SANTA ANA, Calif., Sept. 19

 BODY:
A dozen cities and public agencies have filed a $50 million lawsuit against Merrill Lynch & Company, contending that the securities firm defrauded them during Orange County's financial debacle.
The plaintiffs seek return of more than $50 million in taxpayer funds lost through what they contend were "complex and risky investments." 
 A Merrill spokesman told The Orange County Register that the suit, filed Friday in San Francisco Superior Court, had "no legal merit whatsoever."
About $1.7 billion was lost as a result of bets last year by Orange County's former treasurer, Robert L. Citron, on lower interest rates.
